Title: The kinetics of the absorption of hydrogen by LaNi5Hx-n-undecane suspensions
Affiliations: Department of Applied Science, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reilly, J.J., Department of Applied Science, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Johnson, J.R., Department of Applied Science, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: Isothermal kinetics studies of the absorption of hydrogen by LaNi5Hx suspended in n-undecane have been performed. The rate-limiting process is the dissolution of hydrogen in the solvent. The following general rate equation is given: d[H2] dt = 1 2ks(a′'-a′) where ks is the rate constant for the absorption of hydrogen by the solvent and a′'-a′ represents a thermodynamic driving force which is determined by the equilibrium solubility of hydrogen in the solvent and the equilibrium absorption plateau pressure of the solid. The rate constant is defined as ks = As exp(- Es RT) where Es is the activation energy for dissolution of hydrogen in the solvent and is equal to 11.0 ± 1.1 kJ (mol H2)-1. The pre-exponential As is a function of the efficiency of the gas-liquid contact. The rate equation should have general utility and can be used with other hydrides suspended in n-undecane as long as the rate-limiting process is unchanged. A new method for the study of fast reactions involving the dissolution of hydrogen in liquids is discussed. The hydrogen absorption and desorption rates are well within the range required for practical applications. © 1984.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN - Absorption; HYDROGEN INORGANIC COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN STORAGE MATERIALS; LANTHANUM NICKEL HYDRIDE; RECHARGEABLE METAL HYDRIDES; INTERMETALLICS

Title: Elastic energy stores in running vertebrates
Affiliations: Department of Pure and Applied Zoology, University of Leeds, Leeds LS2 9JT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Alexander, R.M., Department of Pure and Applied Zoology, University of Leeds, Leeds LS2 9JT, United Kingdom
Abstract: Large mammals save much of the energy they would otherwise need for running by means of elastic structures in their legs. Kinetic and potential energy, lost at one stage of a stride, is stored temporarily as elastic strain energy and returned later in an elastic recoil. At high speeds, men and kangaroos seem to save in this way more than half the metabolic energy they would otherwise need for locomotion.It is shown by means of a generalized model that muscles and tendons could both be important as elastic energy stores. Analysis of films and force records of kangaroos hopping shows that strain energy stored while the feet are on the ground must be stored mainly distal to the knee. The principal muscles there have short fibres, and most of the storage must be in tendons. Investigation of camels shows that tendons in the feet, distal to the ankle and wrist, are especially important. The scope for elastic storage while the feet are off the groundis also considered.Though the evidence presented in this paper comes mainly from a few species, the conclusions presumably apply to large mammals in general. © 1984 by the American Society of Zoologists.

Authors: Warman J.M., De Haas M.P., Grätzel M., Infelta P.P.
Title: Microwave probing of electronic processes in small particle suspensions
Affiliations: Interuniversity Reactor Institute, Mekelweg 15, 2629 JB Delft, Netherlands; Institut de Chimie Physique, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Warman, J.M., Interuniversity Reactor Institute, Mekelweg 15, 2629 JB Delft, Netherlands; De Haas, M.P., Interuniversity Reactor Institute, Mekelweg 15, 2629 JB Delft, Netherlands; Grätzel, M., Institut de Chimie Physique, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Infelta, P.P., Institut de Chimie Physique, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: The electronic properties of small particles of semiconducting materials have attracted considerable attention because they can mediate the photolytic decomposition of water1-6; a property which may prove useful in solar energy storage devices. Information about the initial electron-hole state formed on photolysis and the subsequent conduction and electron transfer processes occurring at the particle-solvent interface has previously been gained indirectly through steady-state and flash-photolysis studies of colloidal solutions that also contain well known electron donor and/or acceptor molecules. A more direct, 'electrical' method of probing such systems might be expected to lead to a more detailed understanding of the primary photoionization event and the ensuing bulk and surface electronic processes. We demonstrate here the feasibility of such direct probing of microscopic particles of semiconductor materials (TiO2, CdS and Se) suspended in a nonpolar liquid medium. © 1984 Nature Publishing Group.

Title: Regulation of hepatic triacylglycerol synthesis and secretion
Affiliations: Laboratory of Veterinary Biochemistry, State University of Utrecht, Biltstraat 172, Utrecht, 3508 TD, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Haagsman, H.P., Laboratory of Veterinary Biochemistry, State University of Utrecht, Biltstraat 172, Utrecht, 3508 TD, Netherlands; Van Golde, L.M.G., Laboratory of Veterinary Biochemistry, State University of Utrecht, Biltstraat 172, Utrecht, 3508 TD, Netherlands
Abstract: Triacylglycerols are the most concentrated storage form of energy for the mammalian organism. These lipids are synthesized and secreted by the liver and serve as a fuel for other tissues. This paper presents a brief review of the regulation of hepatic triacylglycerol synthesis and secretion. Particular attention will be given to the dissociation of the synthesis of triacylglycerols from that of the metabolically closely related nitrogenous phospholipids. Recent evidence is presented which suggests that triacylglycerol synthesis (and secretion) is regulated, at least partially, at the diacylglycerol branchpoint. © 1984 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V.
Index Keywords: diacylglycerol; fatty acid; phosphatidic acid; triacylglycerol; very low density lipoprotein; animal; article; biosynthesis; liver; metabolism; rodent; Animal; Diglycerides; Fatty Acids; Lipoproteins, VLDL; Liver; Phosphatidic Acids; Rodentia; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Triglycerides

Title: Energy research and development: Changing federal priorities and national needs
Affiliations: Office of the Director, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schriesheim, A., Office of the Director, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Asbury, J., Office of the Director, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Abstract: Since the OPEC Embargo of 1973, the energy R and D priorities of the U. S. government have gone through enormous change. Early policy focused mainly on supply technologies and placed considerable emphasis on moving new technology into the marketplace. Subsequent policy provided much greater support for conservation and renewable technologies while continuing to emphasize fullscale demonstration projects. A host of regulatory and tax measures were enacted to overcome barriers to market entry. In recent years, the federal role has been reformulated. Under present policy, the private sector, with few exceptions, is to be relied upon for all demonstration and commercialization work, while federally-sponsored R and D is limited to: i) basic energy science and base-technology research, ii) energy R and D of a long-term, high-risk character, iii) research on the health, safety, and environmental aspects of energy technologies. In this paper we trace the evolution of federal R and D policy in three technology areas and outline a prescription for federal research support for the future. The three areas are: fossil energy technologies, storage for vehicle applications, and biomass energy technologies.

Authors: Ullrich J., Cocke C.L., Kelbch S., Mann R., Richard P., Schmidt-Bocking H.
Title: A parasite ion source for bare-ion production on a high-energy heavy-ion accelerator [4]
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic and Molecular Physics
Affiliations: Inst. fur Kernphys., Frankfurt Univ., Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ullrich, J., Inst. fur Kernphys., Frankfurt Univ., Germany; Cocke, C.L.; Kelbch, S.; Mann, R.; Richard, P.; Schmidt-Bocking, H., Inst. fur Kernphys., Frankfurt Univ., Germany
Abstract: Cross sections for the production of highly charged recoil ions for 15.5 MeV u-1 U75+ on argon have been measured. Since bare and hydrogen-like argon recoil ions are produced with sigma >10-18 cm2 the feasibility of developing a permanent recoil ion source on a high-energy heavy-ion accelerator or even in a heavy-ion storage ring is discussed.

Authors: Ginley David S., Shelnutt John A.
Title: GROWTH AND RESONANCE RAMAN SPECTRA OF ELECTROCHEMICALLY POLYMERIZED METALLO-PROTOPORPHYRINS.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ginley, David S., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Shelnutt, John A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Acid free metalloprotoporphyrins (Ni, Cu, Zn) have been oxidatively polymerized onto metallic (Ag, Pt, SnO//2) electrodes from alkaline methanol solution. Polymerization was initiated at the potential for ring oxidation. The authors have not been able to electropolymerize Sn(OH)//2 or FeOH protoporphyrin. Polymerization was done in alkaline methanol solution with tetrabutyl ammonium tetrafluroborate as the electrolyte. The films were strongly bonded to the surface, but as a result of deprotonation of the two propionic acid groups, they could be easily removed in aqueous base to obtain free-standing films. The polymeric films are of interest as immobilized catalysts and sensitizers of photochemical reactions for solar energy conversion and storage.
Index Keywords: ELECTRODES, ELECTROCHEMICAL; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; IMMOBILIZED CATALYSTS; OPTICAL QUALITY OF FILM; POLYMERIZATION IN ALKALINE METHANOL SOLUTION; SOLAR ENERGY CONVERSION APPLICATION; METALLORGANIC POLYMERS

Title: Thermodynamic limits to nonlinearity. II. Purely-resistive, dissipative systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL 60680, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, M.S., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL 60680, United States
Abstract: This paper deals with the nonlinearity of a class of idealized thermodynamic systems, such as electrical resistors and semiconductor junction diodes, in which energy is dissipated when the flow of an extensive quantity takes place through them, and the extensive variable is not stored in the system. A thermodynamic model of such a system is constructed by representing it as a weak coupling between two storage systems described by a Master equation. The lowest-order dimensionless measure of nonlinearity, defined as the second derivative of the force variable with respect to the flow, normalized with respect to the flow and the first derivative, is shown to have a lower bound of -2. The proof is based on the assumptions that the force and flow variables are functionally related, and the system is homogeneous, stable, and has a single flow in it.

Authors: Church D.A., Jones K.W., Johnson B.M., Meron M., Sellin I.A.
Title: Production and storage of highly charged ions at room temperature
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic and Molecular Physics
Affiliations: Phys. Dept., Texas a and M Univ., College Station, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Church, D.A., Phys. Dept., Texas a and M Univ., College Station, TX, United States; Jones, K.W.; Johnson, B.M.; Meron, M.; Sellin, I.A.
Abstract: Selective production and storage at thermal energies of highly charged ions (e.g. hydrogen-like argon, Ar17+) are imminently feasible. Multi-step photoionisation by wiggler-enhanced synchrotron radiation of thermal ions stored in a Penning trap is discussed. Potential applications of these ions to electron transfer and photoionisation measurements are pointed out.

Title: THERMAL STORAGE: TOMORROW'S HEAT TODAY.
Source title: Energy Technology: Proceedings of the Energy Technology Conference
Affiliations: American Electric Power Service, Corp, Columbus, OH, USA, American Electric Power Service Corp, Columbus, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Coleman, William R., American Electric Power Service, Corp, Columbus, OH, USA, American Electric Power Service Corp, Columbus, OH, USA
Abstract: Early practical applications of storage heating can be found in Europe's dairy farms during the late 20's and early 30's. However, most consider the birth of electric thermal storage (ETS) as being the second world war when off-peak electricity was used to provide space heating for air raid shelters. Storage space heating has flourished throughout Europe since the 50's. European ETS equipment designs have taken many forms but their most common application has been individual room ERS heaters and to a lesser degree, ETS furnaces. Both ETS heater designs use various types of ceramic, bricklike, storage medias to store sensible heat. In almost all cases, air is the transfer medium; however, air-to-water ETS furnace systems are in limited use.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; ENERGY MANAGEMENT; FURNACES, SPACE HEATING - Design; HEATING - Hot Water Systems; ELECTRIC THERMAL STORAGE; STORED THERMAL ENERGY; THERMAL STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: PROGRESS IN FIRING COAL-WATER MIXTURES IN BOILERS.
Source title: Energy Technology: Proceedings of the Energy Technology Conference
Affiliations: Burns & Roe Inc, Oradell, NJ,, USA, Burns & Roe Inc, Oradell, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Philipp, John, Burns & Roe Inc, Oradell, NJ,, USA, Burns & Roe Inc, Oradell, NJ, USA; Kimel, Egon A., Burns & Roe Inc, Oradell, NJ,, USA, Burns & Roe Inc, Oradell, NJ, USA
Abstract: Coal-water mixture (CWM) fuel is being considered for industrial and utility power boilers originally designed to fire oil. Compared with pulverized coal firing, CWM firing requires lower investments for boiler retrofit and fuel handling. Storage of CWM can be accommodated even on very small sites, whereas storage of coal requires considerable areas which are often not available at oil fired plants. CWM is also considered to be environmentally more acceptable because NO//x emissions are lower, and fuel handling and storages are devoid of noise, fugitive dust, and contaminated rain runoff.

Abstract: A watercooled air-core coil with variable pitch was developed for B equals 0. 46 T, I equals 500 A, with a large inner diameter of 57 mm and DELTA B/B less than 3 multiplied by 10** minus **5 (within 1 cm**3) without any correction coils. Title: ELECTROCHEMICAL PROTECTION OF COAL FROM SPONTANEOUS HEATING AND SPONTANEOUS COMBUSTION.
Affiliations: Moscow Inst of Chemical Technology, Moscow, USSR, Moscow Inst of Chemical Technology, Moscow, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Aleksandrov, I.V., Moscow Inst of Chemical Technology, Moscow, USSR, Moscow Inst of Chemical Technology, Moscow, USSR; Burkov, P.A., Moscow Inst of Chemical Technology, Moscow, USSR, Moscow Inst of Chemical Technology, Moscow, USSR; Kamneva, A.I., Moscow Inst of Chemical Technology, Moscow, USSR, Moscow Inst of Chemical Technology, Moscow, USSR; Khokhlov, Yu.I., Moscow Inst of Chemical Technology, Moscow, USSR, Moscow Inst of Chemical Technology, Moscow, USSR
Abstract: This paper shows how the use of the new method for the electrochemical protection of coal from spontaneous heating and spontaneous combustion by cathodic polarization with an external source of direct current through contact electrodes placed in the material to be protected permits the practically complete suppression of spontaneous heating in a heap of coal with a volume of 450-500 m**3 with an insignificant consumption of energy. This method is considerably more effective than the sacrificial anode protection previously tried under the conditions of the Kharanovskii open-cast mine.

Title: FINITE ELEMENT APPROACH TO LARGE PLASTIC DEFORMATION AT ELEVATED TEMPERATURES.
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Hamburg-Harburg,, Structural Mechanics Div, Hamburg,, West Ger, Technical Univ of Hamburg-Harburg, Structural Mechanics Div, Hamburg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Mahrenholtz, O., Technical Univ of Hamburg-Harburg,, Structural Mechanics Div, Hamburg,, West Ger, Technical Univ of Hamburg-Harburg, Structural Mechanics Div, Hamburg, West Ger; Westerling, C., Technical Univ of Hamburg-Harburg,, Structural Mechanics Div, Hamburg,, West Ger, Technical Univ of Hamburg-Harburg, Structural Mechanics Div, Hamburg, West Ger; Klie, W., Technical Univ of Hamburg-Harburg,, Structural Mechanics Div, Hamburg,, West Ger, Technical Univ of Hamburg-Harburg, Structural Mechanics Div, Hamburg, West Ger; Dung, N.L., Technical Univ of Hamburg-Harburg,, Structural Mechanics Div, Hamburg,, West Ger, Technical Univ of Hamburg-Harburg, Structural Mechanics Div, Hamburg, West Ger
Abstract: In plastic deformation of metal forming, most of the forming energy is transformed into heat. This causes a temperature increase within the workpiece. The yield stress is a function of strain, strain rate and temperature. Hence, the thermomechanical behaviour of the material should be considered in the mathematical solutions. The finite element method (FEM) is hitherto used to achieve a coupled analysis of plastic deformation and heat transfer. In our paper, an alternative method is presented using the FEM for plastic deformation and the finite difference method (FDM) for calculating the heat transfer. This coupled analysis requires less computational efforts and computer core storage in comparison with a coupled analysis using FEM only. Numerical results of drawing and forging demonstrate the method.
Index Keywords: FLOW OF SOLIDS; HEAT TRANSFER; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Element Method; METALS AND ALLOYS - Deformation; THERMOELASTICITY; AXISYMMETRIC WIRE DRAWING; FINITE DIFFERENCE METHOD; HUBER-LEVY-MISES MODEL; THERMOMECHANICAL BEHAVIOR; PLASTICITY

Title: EXPANDING THE USE OF HOST COMPUTERS ON DISTRIBUTED CONTROL SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Daniel Int, Automation Services Div,, Greenville, SC, USA, Daniel Int, Automation Services Div, Greenville, SC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Barnett, W.J., Daniel Int, Automation Services Div,, Greenville, SC, USA, Daniel Int, Automation Services Div, Greenville, SC, USA
Abstract: The host computer on most distributed control systems is largely underutilized. After the configuration is completed and the system is up and running, the typical host computer only provides trending, graphics displays and some data storage. This requires short bursts of CPU support, but the average utilization is small. Advanced control functions, e. g. optimization, are implemented in some systems but except for a few industries, such advanced features typically use a small amount of the available resources. There are numerous functions that such systems can perform and at a little or no additional cost. In fact, the host computer attached to a distributed control system is a powerful tool to help manage the plant. Some of the functions that can be added are production reporting, machine or equipment status reporting, cost accounting, maintenance data collection, and energy monitoring.

Abstract: Lead-acid batteries, because of low specific energy density and life, are marginal for electric vehicle (EV) use. However, with the established lead-acid industry, they may be more economical for limited future EV applications. The NiFe battery provides sufficient energy density and range for many EV applications and can withstand abusive treatment. With its longer life, this system is attractive for commercial EV applications. It is also anticipated that NiZn, NiCd, and ZnCl systems may also show promise for the future.

Title: SOLAR-WATER-STORAGE ELECTRIC POWER STATION: FEATURES, POTENTIAL, AND PROSPECTS FOR PROFITABILITY.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)

Authors with affiliations: Aparisi, R.R., G. M. Krzhizhanovskii, Power-Engineering Inst, G. M. Krzhizhanovskii Power-Engineering Inst; Teplyakov, D.I., G. M. Krzhizhanovskii, Power-Engineering Inst, G. M. Krzhizhanovskii Power-Engineering Inst; Gerasimov, V.N., G. M. Krzhizhanovskii, Power-Engineering Inst, G. M. Krzhizhanovskii Power-Engineering Inst
Abstract: The prospects for combined solar-water-storage electric power stations (SWSES) for hydro units built in the southern USSR are noted. The basic engineering outline of this combination consists of the following elements: a dam, solar steam generator, steam turbine, electrical generator, water-lift pump, and a distributing network of water pipes. One probable setup for a SWSES is shown. In summertime, the solar power station (SES) provides the electrical needs of consumers and facilitates the irrigation (watering) of the agricultural land. At times of seasonal drought (lowering of the water level), the SES makes good the loss of electricity generated from the hydroelectric plant. In addition, on account of the solar radiation, the SES lifts the water that has passed through the hydroelectric power plant and restores the upper water level in the reservoir.

Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 12 papers on magnesium supply and demand; trends in usage in the aluminum and steel industries; automobile applications; pressure die castings; surface modification for corrosion resistance; developments in electrolytic cells for magnesium production; use as an energy storage material; and new corrosion resisting alloys.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOBILE MATERIALS - Light Metals; CORROSION; DIE CASTINGS - Magnesium; ENERGY STORAGE - Materials; MAGNESIUM CASTINGS - Applications; DEMAND; EIREV; FORECASTS; MARKETING; PRODUCTION; REFINING; MAGNESIUM AND ALLOYS

Title: MACROSCOPIC MONTE CARLO METHOD FOR ELECTRON BEAM DOSE CALCULATIONS: A PROPOSAL.
Affiliations: Cross Cancer Inst, Edmonton,, Alberta, Can, Cross Cancer Inst, Edmonton, Alberta, Can
Authors with affiliations: Mackie, T.R., Cross Cancer Inst, Edmonton,, Alberta, Can, Cross Cancer Inst, Edmonton, Alberta, Can; Battista, J.J., Cross Cancer Inst, Edmonton,, Alberta, Can, Cross Cancer Inst, Edmonton, Alberta, Can
Abstract: Traditional Monte Carlo methods can be used to generate numerical arrays containing the probability of the emergence of electrons at various exit positions, directions and energies as a function of incident atomic number, density, energy and direction. The macroscopic Monte Carlo method would follow electrons through voxels in which the dose is to be found. Knowing the incident energy, direction, and position of an electron arriving at a voxel, the transport would proceed by finding the emergent energy, direction, and position based on the atomic number and density of the voxel and prestored probability distribution arrays. These parameters would then be used as the incident parameters for the next voxel. The method reduces calculation times at the expense of the pregeneration and storage of large look-up arrays.
Index Keywords: BIOMEDICAL EQUIPMENT - Radionuclides; DOSIMETRY - Mathematical Models; ELECTRONS - Energy Analyzers; NUCLEAR MEDICINE; ELECTRON PENCIL BEAMS; LOOK-UP ARRAYS; RADIOTHERAPY; VOXEL GEOMETRY; MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF ZINC-BROMINE BATTERIES FOR UTILITY LOAD LEVELING.
Source title: Proceedings of the Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Leo, Anthony, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA; Charkey, Allen, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA
Abstract: The zinc-bromine battery is a promising candidate for stationary energy storage because of its low cost of reactants and potential for long cycle life. Energy Research Corporation is conducting component development and system engineering studies in a program supported by the Electric Power Research Institute. The work discussed in this paper is a continuation of EPRI supported studies at Gould, Inc. The Gould program developed a baseline component and system technology which allowed an effective demonstration of the viability of the zinc-bromine battery.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; UTILITY LOAD LEVELING; VOLTAGE PERFORMANCE; ZINC DEPOSITION; ZINC-BROMINE BATTERIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: OPTIMIZATION IN THE EXPLOITATION AND UTILIZATION OF HYDROPOWER RESOURCES IN CHINA.
Affiliations: Water Resources & Hydropower, Planning & Designing Inst,, Beijing, China, Water Resources & Hydropower Planning & Designing Inst, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Wu Hongzhong, Water Resources & Hydropower, Planning & Designing Inst,, Beijing, China, Water Resources & Hydropower Planning & Designing Inst, Beijing, China
Abstract: Optimization in the exploitation and utilization of hydropower resources in China has been introduced. It consists of (a) dispatching of hydropower stations and reservoirs and (b) selection of hydropower resources exploitation schemes. Several mathematical methods of optimization have been used (including integer programming, linear programming, dynamic programming and SUMT method). After using these methods, more benefits have been obtained, including about 3% increase in energy production and improvement of schemes of a pumped storage station and several other hydropower stations.
Index Keywords: OPTIMIZATION; RESERVOIRS; HYDROPOWER RESOURCES IN CHINA; HYDROPOWER STATIONS; INCREASE IN ENERGY PRODUCTION; OPTIMAL DISPATCH; RESOURCES EXPLOITATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: ELECTRIC ROAD VEHICLES.
Affiliations: Univ of Hong Kong, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong, Univ of Hong Kong, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Chan, C.C., Univ of Hong Kong, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong, Univ of Hong Kong, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong
Abstract: During the last decade, the need to develop electric vehicles has been widely recognised. In a place such as Hong Kong, where the area of the territory is very small and the population density is very high, the use of electric vehicles is an attractive and realistic proposition. This paper presents the importance of electric vehicles in respect to traffic, environment and energy aspects. The recent developments in electric vehicles in several advanced countries are reviewed. The state of the art of electric vehicles is described with the main emphasis on drive/control systems and batteries. A research project on an electric car carried out at the University of Hong Kong is also described.
Index Keywords: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION; PROPULSION - Electric Energy; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES - Research; STREET TRAFFIC CONTROL; DRIVE/CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC AUTOMOBILES; ELECTRIC VEHICLES; HONG KONG RESEARCH; AUTOMOBILES

Title: CALCULATION AND OPTIMIZATION OF PARAMETERS OF LARGE CAPACITIVE STORES WITH IMPULSE DISCHARGE ACROSS RESISTIVE LOAD.
Authors with affiliations: Kubarev, L.P.
Abstract: A method is proposed for calculating and optimizing the parameters of capacitive stores made as Arkad'ev-Marks generators operating in parallel. Diagrams have been constructed that make it possible to analyze clearly the influence of the requirements applying to pulse shape on the energy characteristics of the store, to consider different variants of circuit parameters, and to find the optimal ones.

Title: LOOK AT THE FREE ELECTRON LASER AND ITS POTENTIAL.
Source title: Laser Interaction and Related Plasma Phenomena
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, High Energy Physics, Lab, Stanford, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, High Energy Physics Lab, Stanford, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Smith, Todd Iversen, Stanford Univ, High Energy Physics, Lab, Stanford, CA, USA, Stanford Univ, High Energy Physics Lab, Stanford, CA, USA
Abstract: Optical radiation is amplified in a Free Electron Laser (FEL) at the expense of the kinetic energy of a relativistic electron beam. This article will begin with a discussion of the manner in which this energy exchange takes place. Following this, we will present some scaling laws based on linear accelerator technology which can be used to predict the performance of simple single-pass FEL's. Finally, we shall take a very rudimentary look at some of the advantages to be gained through the use of storage rings instead of linear accelerators to provide the electron beam.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON BEAMS - Theory; MAGNETIC FIELD EFFECTS; FREE ELECTRON LASER; KINETIC ENERGY; RELATIVISTIC ELECTRON BEAM; WIGGLERS; LASERS

Authors: Chabannes Charles R., Case John B., Shukla Devendra K., Ellison Richard D.
Title: THERMOMECHANICAL CONSIDERATIONS IN DESIGNING TESTS AT THE ASSE MINE.
Affiliations: D'Appolonia Consulting Engineers, Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA, D'Appolonia Consulting Engineers Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chabannes, Charles R., D'Appolonia Consulting Engineers, Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA, D'Appolonia Consulting Engineers Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Case, John B., D'Appolonia Consulting Engineers, Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA, D'Appolonia Consulting Engineers Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Shukla, Devendra K., D'Appolonia Consulting Engineers, Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA, D'Appolonia Consulting Engineers Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Ellison, Richard D., D'Appolonia Consulting Engineers, Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA, D'Appolonia Consulting Engineers Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Thermomechanical analyses to support the design of the in situ Brine Migration Tests (BMT) and the Waste-Rock brine interactions Field Tests (WRFT) at the Asse Mine in West Germany have been performed. The tests are being designed and the test hardware manufactured by Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Advanced Energy System Division, Large, Pennsylvania. The tests will be conducted by the Institut fuer Tieflagerung, Braunschweig, FRG. The results of the thermomechanical analyses have had a significant impact on the philosophy of the test designs. The impact of potential fracture development, loading on the test assemblies, axial deformations the test assemblies must undergo, and depth of the test zone below the mine floor are illustrated using the results from the BMT analyses. Overall observations are made on the philosophy of test planning, and fracture development during the cooldown phase of heater tests in salt.
Index Keywords: FLOW OF SOLIDS - Creep; HEAT TRANSFER - Analysis; MATERIALS TESTING - In Situ; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; ASSE MINE; AXISYMMETRIC ANALYSES; BRINE MIGRATION TESTS; ROCK SALT; THERMOMECHANICAL ANALYSES; SALT MINES AND MINING

Authors: Cameron I.L., Hunter K.E., Smith N.K.
Title: The subcellular concentration of ions and elements in thin cryosections of onion root meristem cells. An electron-probe EDS study.
Authors with affiliations: Cameron, I.L.; Hunter, K.E.; Smith, N.K.
Abstract: Quantitative electron-probe energy dispersive X-ray microanalysis has, for the first time, been accomplished at a subcellular level in plant tissue using cryofixed and thin freeze-dried cryosections. The subcellular concentrations of Na+, Cl-, K+, P, S, Mg2+ and Ca2+ were measured in mol/kg dry weight in two types of root meristematic cells of the onion, Allium cepa. The cell wall of the meristematic cells had much higher concentrations of K+ and Ca2+ than was found in the intracellular compartments. Storage granules in the protoderm cells were about 6-12 times lower in P and were about four times higher in S as compared to other intracellular compartments. Comparison between the concentrations of ions and other elements in meristematic plant cells and in mouse cardiac myocytes confirms that major differences in cytoplasmic Na+ and Cl- concentrations do indeed exist between these cell types.
Index Keywords: element; ion; animal; article; cell wall; comparative study; electron probe microanalysis; female; frozen section; heart muscle; mouse; plant; scanning electron microscopy; ultrastructure; Animal; Cell Wall; Comparative Study; Electron Probe Microanalysis; Elements; Female; Frozen Sections; Ions; Mice; Microscopy, Electron, Scanning; Myocardium; Plants, Edible; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Title: SOLID-STATE RECHARGEABLE LITHIUM BATTERIES.
Source title: Proceedings of the Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: AERE, Materials Development Div,, Harwell, Engl, AERE, Materials Development Div, Harwell, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Hooper, A., AERE, Materials Development Div,, Harwell, Engl, AERE, Materials Development Div, Harwell, Engl; North, J.M., AERE, Materials Development Div,, Harwell, Engl, AERE, Materials Development Div, Harwell, Engl; Oliver, M., AERE, Materials Development Div,, Harwell, Engl, AERE, Materials Development Div, Harwell, Engl; Tofield, B.C., AERE, Materials Development Div,, Harwell, Engl, AERE, Materials Development Div, Harwell, Engl
Abstract: The aim of an Anglo-Danish programme to develop a rechargeable, all-solid-state lithium battery, for vehicular traction applications, has resulted in the evolution of a polymer electrolyte-based system. A preliminary design study has predicted high gravimetric and volumetric energy densities (up to 400 Wh/Kg and 500 Wh/litre) for a bipolar configured battery. This potential performance coupled with a fabrication technology which offers both straightforward device manufacture and versatility of battery geometry gives rise to the possibility of applications across the whole battery product range. This report describes the progress which is being made, experimentally, towards the realisation of practical cells and batteries.

Source title: Energy Technology: Proceedings of the Energy Technology Conference
Affiliations: Northwest Natural Gas Co, Portland,, OR, USA, Northwest Natural Gas Co, Portland, OR, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hathaway, Paul L., Northwest Natural Gas Co, Portland,, OR, USA, Northwest Natural Gas Co, Portland, OR, USA
Abstract: We report that the natural-gas-powered on-site fuel cell power plant has a great near-term potential for commercial use. The field test program being conducted by Gas Research Institute, the U. S. Department of Energy, United Technologies Corporation, and the On-Site Fuel Cell Users Group (a consortium of gas distribution utilities) will provide the opportunity to test the on-site power plants in a variety of commercial and industrial applications, and will allow verification of the electrical and thermal efficiencies of the unit, in addition to allowing the manufacturer to determine whether the units can be manufactured at a competitive cost per kilowatt of capacity.

Title: CASE STUDY: THE DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION IMPLICATIONS OF CONVERTING AN OIL/GAS-FIRED INDUSTRIAL BOILER TO WOOD FUEL.
Source title: Energy Technology: Proceedings of the Energy Technology Conference
Affiliations: Ultrasystems Inc, Irvine, CA, USA, Ultrasystems Inc, Irvine, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cooke, R.C., Ultrasystems Inc, Irvine, CA, USA, Ultrasystems Inc, Irvine, CA, USA; Huff, William J., Ultrasystems Inc, Irvine, CA, USA, Ultrasystems Inc, Irvine, CA, USA
Abstract: This paper presents a case study of a design and construction project to modify an oil/gas-fired industrial boiler to fire wood. The boiler is a 100,000 lb/hr Zurn package boiler of the 'O' type. It is located on the East Coast in a metropolitan area where stringent emissions requirements exist. A major evaluation and test program was undertaken to determine the combustion technology and design-concept approach which would assure meeting the air-pollution regulations. In an existing operating boilerhouse, it is also important to carefully analyze the space constraints and to develop a construction approach which will cause the least interference with the ongoing industrial processes and steam generation. When converting to wood fuel in an existing industrial plant setting, it is necessary to provide equipment and adequate storage for receiving, storing, and transferring the fuel, usually in areas already crowded and highly developed.
Index Keywords: BOILER FIRING - Gas; BOILERS - Design; ENERGY RESOURCES; COMBUSTION TECHNOLOGY; DESIGN-CONCEPT APPROACH; FIRE WOOD; OIL/GAS-FIRED INDUSTRIAL BOILER; WOOD FUEL; WOOD

Authors: Todokoro Hideo, Fukuhara Satoru, Komoda Tsutomu
Title: ELECTRON-BEAM LSI TESTER.
Source title: Japan Annual Reviews in Electronics, Computers & Telecommunications
Affiliations: Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab,, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Todokoro, Hideo, Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab,, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab, Tokyo, Jpn; Fukuhara, Satoru, Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab,, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab, Tokyo, Jpn; Komoda, Tsutomu, Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab,, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: An LSI tester that enables analysis of internal voltage waveforms in large-scale integrated circuits (VLSI) using a 1 kev electron probe has been developed. A field emitter is used as the electron source to obtain a fine probe of 0. 1 mu m at 1 kev. The use of low-energy electrons produces negligible charge-up effect and electron damage in the LSIs. The potential and time resolutions in the tester are 100 mv and 1 ns, respectively. A newly developed multi-delay scanning method enables measurement of internal waveforms in passivated LSIs. This tester has been successfully applied to evaluation of internal waveforms in 64 Kbit MOS RAMs and a 64 Kbit bipolar RAM.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Random Access; ELECTRON BEAMS - Applications; INTEGRATED CIRCUIT TESTING - Instruments; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS, VLSI - Testing; 64 KBIT BIPOLAR RAM; ELECTRON-BEAM LSI TESTER; INTERNAL VOLTAGE WAVEFORMS; MOS RAM; MULTI-DELAY SCANNING; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS, LSI

Title: ENERGY SAVINGS BY SUBSURFACE USE.
Source title: Advances in Tunnelling Technology and Subsurface Use
Affiliations: VBB-SWECO, Stockholm, Swed, VBB-SWECO, Stockholm, Swed
Authors with affiliations: Jansson, Birger, VBB-SWECO, Stockholm, Swed, VBB-SWECO, Stockholm, Swed; Winqvist, Torbjorn, VBB-SWECO, Stockholm, Swed, VBB-SWECO, Stockholm, Swed
Abstract: The use of underground space offers advantages both in the possible new technology that utilizes renewable solar energy sources and in the technology for making more effective use of energy systems in built-up areas. Underground structures are considered to be economical and to save energy, and will consequently be included in the national energy conservation programme. Of particular interest is the storage capacity of heat and cold of the underground. Three effects should be considered: the insulating effect of the surrounding mass, which leads to low heat transmission losses, the almost constant power demands for heating or cooling throughout the year and, finally, the capacity to withstand mechanical and thermal stresses.

Title: MAGNESIUM AS AN ENERGY MATERIAL.
Affiliations: Riso Natl Lab, Metallurgy Dep,, Roskilde, Den, Riso Natl Lab, Metallurgy Dep, Roskilde, Den
Authors with affiliations: Vigeholm, B., Riso Natl Lab, Metallurgy Dep,, Roskilde, Den, Riso Natl Lab, Metallurgy Dep, Roskilde, Den
Abstract: Magnesium reacts reversibly with hydrogen to form magnesium hydride which is one of the most dense artificial energy storage materials. With hydrogen as a non-polluting energy source, the storage system has a potential beyond economic competitiveness. A review is given of recent research into the Mg-H//2 system with emphasis on the properties relevant to practical use. Suggested applications are discussed.

Authors: Taoda Kiyomichi, Ito Yoshifumi, Uehara Seibi, Sato Fumiaki, Kumagaya Takeo
Title: UPGRADING OF LOW-GRADE COALS BY HEAT TREATMENT.
Affiliations: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Taoda, Kiyomichi, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn; Ito, Yoshifumi, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn; Uehara, Seibi, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn; Sato, Fumiaki, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn; Kumagaya, Takeo, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd, Jpn
Abstract: Low-grade coals, such as subbituminous coal, are generally high in inherent moisture and even if they have been dehumidified they absorb moisture again and dried coals have property of high spontaneous ignition. They therefore, are not suitable for long distance transportation. Because of this, they have been mostly used for power generation in their native districts. To cope with the recent energy situation there is a growing demand to use these coals as new energy resources by improving their quality. In order to improve their quality, we have been developing a new drying process. Test results have shown that in contrast to raw coal, the coal dried by the process at temperatures of 300-350 degree C has a decreased inherent moisture, an increased calorific value and lower spontaneous combustibility which contribute to marked improvement in its capacity for long distance transport and storage.
Index Keywords: HEAT TREATMENT; COAL DRYING PROCESSES; COAL UPGRADING; HEAT TREATMENT TESTS; LOW-GRADE COALS; COAL

Title: ENERGY CONSERVATION IN THE FERTILIZER INDUSTRY.
Source title: Proceedings, Biennial Conference - Institute for Briquetting and Agglomeration
Affiliations: Maschinenfabrik Koeppern GmbH, Hattingen, West Ger, Maschinenfabrik Koeppern GmbH, Hattingen, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Pietsch, Wolfgang B., Maschinenfabrik Koeppern GmbH, Hattingen, West Ger, Maschinenfabrik Koeppern GmbH, Hattingen, West Ger
Abstract: As a result of the manufacturing processes or after grinding to improve the bulk mixing characteristics, the individual fertilizer components are relatively fine powders. Mixtures of such materials tend to segregation and dusting. Since, additionally, the fertilizer components may react chemically with each other and/or are water soluble, they are also prone to caking. The modern, highly efficient fertilizer transportation, storage, and distribution systems as well as the high speed mechanical spreaders cannot cope with these difficulties. A free flowing, dust-free product with constant composition is required. This led to the development of granulated fertilizer. The agglomeration process originally selected for this application makes use of the natural caking tendency of the fertilizer components by granulating wetted mixtures in pug mills, drums, or pans.
Index Keywords: AGGLOMERATION - Applications; ENERGY CONSERVATION; BINDING MECHANISMS; GRANULATION PROCESS; ROLLER COMPACTION EQUIPMENT; FERTILIZERS

Authors: Hoff G.F., Jensen J.D., Warburton D.L.
Title: SAFETY AND PERFORMANCE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE MULTICELL 150 AH 14. 4 VOLT Li/SOCl//2 RESERVE BATTERY.
Source title: Proceedings of the Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, White, Oak, MD, USA, US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, White Oak, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hoff, G.F., US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, White, Oak, MD, USA, US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, White Oak, MD, USA; Jensen, J.D., US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, White, Oak, MD, USA, US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, White Oak, MD, USA; Warburton, D.L., US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, White, Oak, MD, USA, US Naval Surface Weapons Cent, White Oak, MD, USA
Abstract: Under the Navy's Mine Development Program, Honeywell Power Sources Center (HPSC) and NSWC are developing lithium-oxyhalide reserve batteries for underwater mines. The objective of this work is to determine whether or not the Li/SOCl//2 reserve battery is a suitable power source for ordnance applications: uncontrolled storage for 10 years at temperatures between minus 54 degree C and 71 degree C; high specific energies (550 Wh/Kg) at a one-year discharge rate; voltage regulation of plus or minus 5%; deployment from aircraft, ships and submarines; and safety requirements of NAVSEA Instruction 9310. 1A. In this paper, the thermal, pressure and voltage behavior for the multicell Li/SOCl//2 reserve battery during activation, discharge and voltage reversal are presented and discussed for two instrumented Li/SOCl//2 reserve batteries. Also, the impact on the safety of this multicell battery due to improper activation is discussed.

Abstract: Electrodes employed in electrochemical cells for energy conversion and storage are mostly characterized by a porous structure. Impedance measurements have been used to determine the different components of polarizations.

Title: MAINTENANCE-FREE SEALED LEAD BATTERIES WITH IMMOBILIZED ELECTROLYTE - CONSTRUCTION WITH GRID TYPE PLATES AND/OR TUBULAR POSITIVE PLATES - APPLICATIONS IN INDUSTRY AND NATO.

Abstract: This headline does not comprehend the so-called maintenance-free starter battery for civil motor vehicles which are exclusively designed for starting internal-combustion engines in vehicles. The above headline refers to really maintenance-free batteries with a capacity range between 1Ah and 100Ah in grid type plate construction and with a capacity range between 90Ah and presently 1350Ah in tubular plate construction. The grid type plate construction is widely used for portable appliances where batteries are operated irrespective of orientation and where usually a long cycle life is required, in military design for all kinds of combat vehicles, e. g. tanks, and also for military motorcycles as a vehicle battery and for the energy supply to voluminous electronic equipment and, also, in float operations for stationary and quasi-stationary purposes supplying emergency power to installations and plants with limited capacity.

Abstract: The term 'electrochemistry' implies the use of devices that convert chemical energy into electrical energy and sometimes vice versa. These devices are usually composed of some number of individual cells that are connected together to form a battery. Title: THREE-CRITERION OPTIMIZATION OF PULSE POWER SOURCES.
Authors with affiliations: Gubarev, G.G.; Konotop, V.V.
Abstract: The problem of the optimal selection of parameters and number of parallel-connected high-energy pulse supply sources (PSS) with capacitive energy stores so as to ensure production of a specified current or voltage pulse in the load is formulated as a three-criterion problem in nonlinear programming. A systems technique for solution of rigid systems of differential equations and a modification of the Nelder-Mead deformed-polyhedron method have been used. The formalized optimality criteria ensure the realizability of the values of optimized parameters of the sources, the agreement with prescribed accuracy of calculated and specified load pulse, as well as minimization of the total stored energy of the capacitors in the PSS. Results are reported for optimization of the parallel operation of 2, 3, and 4 pulse sources working into an inductive-resistive load with a two-exponential current pulse being produced.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; CAPACITIVE ENERGY STORES; NELDER-MEAD DEFORMED-POLYHEDRON MODEL; OPTIMALITY CRITERIA; PULSE POWER SOURCES; PULSE GENERATORS

Title: Effect of lipid-coated lysine on digestion and nitrogen metabolism by wethers.
Source title: International Journal for Vitamin and Nutrition Research
Authors with affiliations: Glenn, B.P.; Ely, D.G.
Abstract: Four mature wethers (70 kg) fitted with permanent abomasal cannulas were assigned to a 4 X 4 Latin square design to study the effect of coating supplemental lysine with coconut oil on nutrient digestion, nitrogen retention and recovery of amino acids in the abomasum and plasma. Dietary treatments were: Control (C) = basal diet; Lysine (LYS) = Control + 1% supplemental lysine; Coconut oil-coated lysine (CN-LYS) = Control + 1% supplemental lysine coated with coconut oil; and Coconut oil + diet (CN-DIET) = Control + 1% supplemental lysine + an equal amount of coconut oil added to the entire diet. Lysine supplementation significantly increased total apparent dry matter, ether extract and energy digestibilities. Total nitrogen and protein nitrogen flows to the abomasum were decreased (p less than .1) in lambs consuming CN-LYS and CN-DIET compared with LYS. Urinary nitrogen excretion (p less than .05), ruminal ammonia nitrogen and plasma urea nitrogen (p less than .05) concentrations were higher for LYS, CN-LYS and CN-DIET compared with C and highest for CN-LYS. There were no differences in nitrogen retention among treatments. Recovery of lysine in the diets after coating (CN-LYS) or lipid addition (CN-DIET) was reduced indicating degradation of supplemental lysine to other nitrogenous compounds during the coating process or storage since total dietary nitrogen content was equivalent to LYS. Flow of abomasal lysine (% of lysine intake) was higher (p = .15) for CN-LYS and CN-DIET than LYS. Flow of total essential amino acids (% of total amino acid flow) was greater (p less than .02) when lysine was added to diets. Essential amino with LYS. Plasma amino acid concentrations did not differ among treatments. Coating lysine with coconut oil did not protect the amino acid from ruminal degradation and was ineffective in improving total nitrogen status of mature wethers.
Index Keywords: amino acid; coconut oil; lysine; nitrogen; animal; article; digestion; drug effect; fat intake; male; metabolism; protein intake; ruminant stomach; sheep; Abomasum; Amino Acids; Animal; Dietary Fats; Dietary Proteins; Digestion; Lysine; Male; Nitrogen; Rumen; Sheep

Title: POTENTIAL OF FLYWHEELS FOR SPACECRAFT ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gross, Sidney, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: Energy storage systems for spacecraft in the past have used nickel cadmium and nickel-hydrogen batteries for rechargeable systems, or hydrogen-oxygen fuel cells for relatively short duration missions, such as Apollo or Shuttle. Regenerable fuel cells have also been evaluated and found to have good potential for space stations. Though flywheel systems have been suggested for spacecraft in the past years, only recently have they been given serious consideration for spacecraft.

Title: ADVANCED AND NONTRADITIONAL CONCEPTS WORKING GROUP REPORT.
Affiliations: Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA, Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hertzberg, A., Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA, Univ of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: The purpose of this report is to examine advanced and nontraditional concepts relating to future space power requirements with special emphasis on the requirements for the space station. The group was motivated by the estimated power requirements for a fully operational space station (100-200 kW), a manifold increase over the power requirements which can be conveniently met by current technology. The dominating effect of the power system on the design of the space shuttle both from a mass and volume indicated that new approaches which offered more than incremental changes may prove enabling. Therefore, the group concentrated on high pay-off areas related to heat rejection, energy conversion, and energy storage in particular. In the following sections, we will report on some of the key findings of this working group. (Author abstract. )

Abstract: The West European gas industry has demonstrated that it is able to respond to changes both at the supply and at the demand ends of the market. The international European natural gas transmission system developed by the gas industry for performing its functions is a highly reliable and efficient tool giving the industry access to all major supply regions. The continued expansion of this international pipeline system will enable the European gas industry to master the challenges of the future and to supply natural gas to consumers in line with market requirements.

Title: Effect of lead intoxication on calcium homeostasis and calcium-mediated cell function: A review
Affiliations: Department of Health and Human Services, Food and Drug Administration, National Center or Toxicological Research, Jefferson, AR 72079, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pounds, J.G., Department of Health and Human Services, Food and Drug Administration, National Center or Toxicological Research, Jefferson, AR 72079, United States
Abstract: The interaction between lead and essential metals is a complex, well recognized, but poorly understood phenomenon. Dietary deficiencies or excesses of certain essential metals may alter the absorption, elimination, or dose response of lead. Lead, in turn, may alter the homeostasis and function of essential metals. This review will be limited to the effect of lead on calcium, an essential metal with elaborate systemic and cellular homeostatic mechanisms and innumerable second messenger and coupling-factor functions. Lead may ultimately perturb calcium-regulated or calcium-mediated functions (a) directly by interfering with calcium transport or storage processes, e.g., Ca2+ transport proteins, calcium gates, etc.; (b) indirectly by altering cell functions required for calcium homeostasis, e.g., energy production, plasma membrane permeability, etc.; (c) by substitution of Pb2+ for Ca2+ at functionally important calcium binding sites, e.g., calmodulin. While any individual study may not provide adequate experimental verification of the causal role of perturbations of calcium metabolism and function as the primary toxic lesion of lead intoxication, the collective observations of many studies do strongly support lead-calcium interactions as an important functional lesion in lead intoxicated organelles, cells, tissues, and organ systems.
Index Keywords: calmodulin; lead; calcium homeostasis; human; interaction; intoxication; priority journal; review; Animal; Calcitonin; Calcium; Calcium-Binding Proteins; Cell Membrane Permeability; Child, Preschool; Cholecalciferol; Comparative Study; Coturnix; Energy Metabolism; Homeostasis; Human; Intestinal Absorption; Lead; Mitochondria; Neurotransmitters; Parathyroid Hormones; Synaptosomes

Authors: Commisso R.J., Fernsler R.F., Scherrer V.E., Vitkovitsky I.M.
Title: High-power electron-beam controlled switches
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375
Authors with affiliations: Commisso, R.J., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375; Fernsler, R.F., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375; Scherrer, V.E., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375; Vitkovitsky, I.M., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375
Abstract: The application of an electron-beam controlled diffuse discharge to high-power (>109 W), repetitive opening switches is analytically formulated under a set of assumptions. Basic physics considerations are combined with energy transfer requirements to obtain analytical estimates of the e-beam controlled switch parameters for given circuit requirements. The switch design is optimized by minimizing the switch pressure subject to the constraint of system efficiency. The result of this optimization is that each of the major energy losses - conduction, opening, and electron-beam production - are roughly equal to each other. This formulation is used to relate the switch parameters to the desired operating characteristics for an arbitrary number of pulses. As an example, the formalism is utilized in outlining the design of a single pulse, high-power (≃1010 W) inductive storage system. A judicious choice of gas or gas mixture results in desirable changes in the system design or efficiency.
Index Keywords: electron beam; nonhuman; switch

Abstract: This paper outlines the formation of the Electric Vehicle Development Corporation (EVDC) and delineates its role in influencing the marketing of electric vehicles (EV) for both commercial and personal transportation applications. The marketing introduction approach, beginning with market assessment and ultimately leading to a large-scale demonstration of EVs, is discussed. EV stakeholders and their relationship with the EVDC marketing strategy are identified. Initial large-scale EV demonstrations are scheduled for the 1987-88 timeframe oriented toward commercial fleets.

Title: RESULTS OF FIRING COAL OVERBED AND UNDERBED IN A 20-MW AFBC PILOT PLANT.
Source title: Energy Technology: Proceedings of the Energy Technology Conference
Affiliations: TVA, Chattanooga, TN, USA, TVA, Chattanooga, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bass III, J.W., TVA, Chattanooga, TN, USA, TVA, Chattanooga, TN, USA
Abstract: Process performance was comparable when using either the underbed feed system or the overbed feed system with washed coal. Performance degrades with overbed feeding of unwashed coal. The underbed feed system has problems with plugging and erosion that must be solved in order to achieve reliability goals. The overbed feed system is very reliable; however, washed coal must be used to attain the required process performance. The ability to handle the fines and the rocks in the coal must be demonstrated before overbed feed can be considered a viable option for large utility plants.

Title: ELECTRICAL CONDUCTIVITY OF SINGLE GRAIN AND POLYCRYSTALLINE ZrO//2-Y//2O//3 COMPOSITIONS.
Affiliations: CSIRO, Advanced Materials Lab,, Melbourne, Aust, CSIRO, Advanced Materials Lab, Melbourne, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Badwal, S.P.S., CSIRO, Advanced Materials Lab,, Melbourne, Aust, CSIRO, Advanced Materials Lab, Melbourne, Aust; Rice, R.W., CSIRO, Advanced Materials Lab,, Melbourne, Aust, CSIRO, Advanced Materials Lab, Melbourne, Aust; Swain, M.V., CSIRO, Advanced Materials Lab,, Melbourne, Aust, CSIRO, Advanced Materials Lab, Melbourne, Aust
Abstract: Fully stabilized ZrO//2-Y//2O//3 compositions are commonly used as electrolytes in several high temperature solid state cells for energy conversion, storage and saving. Due to segregation of impurities at grain boundaries during sintering, the total resistivity in polycrystalline materials consists of contributions from grain boundaries and lattice resistivity. These impurities are either deliberately added to enhance sintering or are incorporated during sample preparation. The impedance dispersion technique is commonly used to separate contributions due to grain boundaries and lattice resistivity. In single crystals the complications of grain boundaries are eliminated and thus both 4 probe dc and impedance techniques can be used to measure the lattice resistivity.

Authors with affiliations: Wilda, Douglas, Honeywell Inc, Process Control Div, USA, Honeywell Inc, Process Control Div, USA; Arcara, Sam, Honeywell Inc, Process Control Div, USA, Honeywell Inc, Process Control Div, USA
Abstract: Recent advances in instrumentation have lead to an examination of the effect of different measurement techniques on the overall accuracy achievable in energy flow measurement. In particular, past assumptions about gas quality encouraged measurement techniques which can introduce inaccuracies under today's changing conditions. This paper examines some various techniques used by the fuel gas industry in computing the energy flow at a measurement point. The authors show that sampling interval and response of the measurement equipment (particularly calorimeters and chromatographs) can introduce errors into the energy flow computation. Recommendations are made on how to achieve a desired level of accuracy.

Title: COOL STORAGE DESIGN AND OPERATION WITH TIME OF USE RATES.
Source title: Energy Technology: Proceedings of the Energy Technology Conference
Authors with affiliations: Hoffman, George H.; Nimmagadda, Muraldihar
Abstract: This presentation develops three main points: (1) What the principle of cool storage assisted air conditioning is and why it should be adopted, particularly in areas served by summer peaking utilities; (2) What the electric utility industry is doing to foster its acceptance; and (3) What additional steps might be taken by each utility to encourage architects and engineers to use this promising emerging technology. The latter point deals with control strategies aimed at optimum performance of a cool storage assisted air conditioning system given a particular climate and a particular time-of-day rate structure. Materials are included to make it easier for each utility to produce similar calculations to serve as examples for use by engineers considering cool storage assisted air conditioning for structures located within the utility's service area.

Abstract: Low temperature drying is a slow drying process with air heated only a few degrees. This paper proposes a low temperature drying system using liquid desiccants which finds widespread application in humid tropics. Packed bed tower is used in the analysis to carryout dehumidification process. During this process, due to latent heat the air is warmed up and dried. The governing equations are solved to study the performance of this process and presented in this paper. The weak desiccant can be regenerated using solar energy and the concentrated desiccant can be used as the storage medium during cloudy days and at nights.

Abstract: Ford Aerospace is continuing to make rapid progress in sodium-sulfur (Na/S) battery development for electric vehicle and stationary energy storage applications in a program sponsored by the U. S. Department of Energy. During 1983, a 480-cell electric vehicle battery designed for passenger vehicle operation was fabricated and tested. Stationary energy storage activities centered on the continued testing of three 25-kWh modules of a 100-kWh battery which have operated for 675 cycles in a 32-month period. Under U. S. Air Force funding, electric vehicle cells were modified for higher power capability to address satellite applications. Title: CRUDE OIL STORAGE IN A SYSTEM OF SALT CAVERNS.

Authors with affiliations: Dreyer, Wolfgang E., Technical Univ of Clausthal, Mining, Inst, Clausthal-Zellerfeld, West Ger, Technical Univ of Clausthal, Mining Inst, Clausthal-Zellerfeld, West Ger
Abstract: The finite element method (FEM) can be considered a standard tool in a modern approach to rock mechanics problems. New, however, is the description by the author of non-linear stress-strain relationships in rock salt by means of the NTIS Finite Element Program for those problems where rock salt is to be used to store energy fuels. To test the applicability of the NTIS Finite Element Program to evaluate rock stress and rock convergence during construction of underground storage caverns, theoretical solutions in the elasto-plastic, visco-elastic region of certain openings are compared with the FEM results. Within a certain degree of tolerance the NTIS program gives satisfactory useful answers. Of significant advantage is the relatively inexpensive acquisition cost of the computer source code, and the machine independent code (FORTRAN language) utilized.

Abstract: In spite of its small size (35gr weight and 17cc volume) the cell presented in this work shows quite a wide range of performance: 1) Current drain capability: starting from milliamperes up to 1A; 2) Operating temperature from minus 40 degree C to plus 72 degree C; 3) Capacities of 2Ah to 3. 5Ah; and 4) Long shelf life over a wide range of storage temperatures. With a nominal capacity of about 3. 5Ah at 50mA the cell still delivers about 2Ah at 1A rating. The apparent energy density of the cell appears to be 350Wh/Kg or 720 Wh/liter and the power density about 100 W/Kg or 200 W/liter. The diameter of the cell, which is equal to the standard D size cells, enables convenient use of the cell in standard equipment, or its incorporation within a battery which has similar dimensions to a D size cell.

Abstract: In the early 1960's, both NASA and the Department of Defense (DOD) recognized the potential gains to be made in spacecraft weight, volume, and endurance characteristics by the development of improved electrochemical energy storage systems. Title: ELECTRODYNAMIC TETHERS: I. POWER GENERATOR IN LEO. II. THRUST FOR PROPULSION AND POWER STORAGE.
Affiliations: NASA, Johnson Space Cent, Houston,, TX, USA, NASA, Johnson Space Cent, Houston, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: McCoy, James E., NASA, Johnson Space Cent, Houston,, TX, USA, NASA, Johnson Space Cent, Houston, TX, USA
Abstract: An electrodynamic tether consists of a long insulated wire in space whose orbital motion cuts across lines of magnetic flux to produce an induced voltage. In typical low orbits this averages about 200 v/km. Such a system should be capable of generating substantial electrical power, at the expense of IXB drag acting on its orbital energy. If a reverse current is driven against the induced voltage, the system should act as a motor producing IXB thrust. All systems discussed in this paper are conceptual, based on theoretical calculations that appear to be well founded but are impossible to confirm without direct measurement using an actual tether wire in orbit at 8 km/sec.

Authors with affiliations: Henriksen, G.L., Energy Development Associates,, Madison Heights, MI, USA, Energy Development Associates, Madison Heights, MI, USA; Carr, P., Energy Development Associates,, Madison Heights, MI, USA, Energy Development Associates, Madison Heights, MI, USA
Abstract: This paper describes the basic operation of the rechargeable reserve battery system and summarizes the status of zinc-chloride rechargeable batteries for all three applications. The load-leveling battery effort has continued to receive financial support from the Department of Energy (DOE) and the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI), as well as Gulf & Western (G&W). The electric vehicle and reserve battery efforts have been funded mainly by G&W.
Index Keywords: STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; ZINC COMPOUNDS - Applications; CHLORINE HYDRATE; CHLORINE STORAGE; ELECTRIC VEHICLE BATTERIES; LOAD-LEVELING BATTERIES; ZINC-CHLORIDE RECHARGEABLE BATTERIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF NICKEL-ZINC BATTERIES FOR TANKS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Leo, Anthony, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA; Charkey, Allen, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA
Abstract: A program was conducted at Energy Research Corporation to evaluate the feasibility of using sealed Ni-Zn batteries for starting and auxiliary power in tanks. The objective was to develop a battery capable of high discharge rates, low maintenance and long life over a wide range of temperature. The sealed Ni-Zn battery concept involves operating cells in an electrolyte starved condition in order to allow evolved oxygen to recombine at the zinc electrodes. The cells were charged with a square wave pulse charging technique, which has been found to improve zinc electrode stability. The design considered for the tank application was a 12v, 125Ah battery consisting of eight series connected cells. Tests were conducted on 125Ah cells with various zinc electrode and separator designs.
Index Keywords: MILITARY VEHICLES - Electric; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; DEEP DISCHARGE CAPACITY; DEPTH OF DISCHARGE (DOD); NICKEL-ZINC BATTERIES; SEPARATOR SYSTEMS; TANK BATTERIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Bondaletov V.N., Petrov S.R., Tyut'kin V.A.
Title: EFFICIENCY OF INDUCTIVE-STORE ENERGY CONVERSION.
Authors with affiliations: Bondaletov, V.N.; Petrov, S.R.; Tyut'kin, V.A.
Abstract: The influence of various factors on energy-conversion efficiency is considered for an inductive store supplying an electrodynamic conductor accelerator for the case in which the commutator disconnecting the store charging current is shunted by a nonlinear element with voltage-regulator volt-ampere characteristic. It is shown that there is an optimal relative mass of the accelerated body such that energy conversion efficiency is greatest and there is a monotonic increase in efficiency with decreasing initial inductance of the store, self-inductance of the commutator circuit, and resistances. The efficiency also arises with increasing length of the acceleration system and magnitude of overvoltages across the commutator. Approximate analytic dependences are obtained to describe the acceleration process. The possibility of increasing efficiency through utilization of an inductive energy store based on a transformer circuit is considered.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONDUCTORS - Acceleration; ELECTRIC INDUCTORS; ENERGY STORAGE; MAGNETIC FIELD EFFECTS; SOLIDS - Acceleration; ENERGY CONVERSION EFFICIENCY; INDUCTIVE STORES; ELECTRODYNAMICS

Title: SMALL AIR SOURCE HEAT PUMPS FOR HOT WATER SUPPLY IN COMMERCIAL PREMISES.
Authors with affiliations: Ure, J.W.
Abstract: Unlike countries such as France and West Germany, the small heat pump is not yet established on a large scale in the UK. Although the heat pump has demonstrated its ability to conserve energy, in the UK considerable doubt about its cost-effectiveness exists. The heat pumps's major advantage is its ability to heat and cool from one device. Therefore for such applications it will be at its most competitive. Calculations suggest that its payback periods, when compared with electric heating and separate cooling, could be less than two years. Compared with oil heating and electric cooling, payback periods would be longer but may often be acceptable. The major areas of the commercial sector which require simultaneous heating and storage area cooling are: pubs, licensed clubs, restaurants, hotels and butchers' shops. It is believed that demonstration would prove useful in such premises. For heating only, the heat pump has much greater competition.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Climate Control; HEATING; MAINTENANCE - Costs; REFRIGERATION; WATER HEATERS - Efficiency; COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS; PAYBACK; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Authors: Katayama T., Itano A., Noda A., Takanaka M., Yamada S., Hirao Y.
Title: DESIGN STUDY OF HEAVY ION FUSION DRIVER, HIBLIC.
Affiliations: Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Katayama, T., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Itano, A., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Noda, A., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Takanaka, M., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Yamada, S., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Hirao, Y., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: A heavy ion fusion (HIF) system, named HIBLIC (Heavy Ion Beam and LIthium Curtain) is conceptually designed of which the driver system consists of rf linacs (RFQ linacs, IH linacs and Alvare linacs), storage rings (one accumulator ring and three buncher rings) and beam transport lines with induction beam compressors. This accelerator complex provides 6 beams of 15 GeV **2**0**8Pb**1** plus ions to be focused simultaneously on a target. Each beam carries 1. 78 kA current with 25 ns pulse duration, i. e. , the total incidence of energy on the target becomes 4 MJ, 160 TW per shot. Superconducting coils are used in most parts of the magnet system to reduce power consumption.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions; BEAM BUNCHING; DRIVERS; HEAVY ION FUSION; HIBLIC; NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION

Authors: Al-Saleh N., Phillips V., Unsworth P.J.
Title: SALT GRADIENT SOLAR POND FOR SOLAR HEAT COLLECTION AND LONG TERM STORAGE.
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: Univ of Sussex, Engl, Univ of Sussex, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Al-Saleh, N., Univ of Sussex, Engl, Univ of Sussex, Engl; Phillips, V., Univ of Sussex, Engl, Univ of Sussex, Engl; Unsworth, P.J., Univ of Sussex, Engl, Univ of Sussex, Engl
Abstract: This report describes the construction, filling and operation of an outdoor pilot solar pond. To obtain high overall operating efficiency, the authors are experimenting with extracting heat from any region in the pond, including the non-convecting layer. This permits interception and extraction of heat flow in the non-convecting layer which would otherwise be lost at the surface. Laboratory experiments have been carried out to test whether this causes mixing in the non-convective zone, and to measure heat transfer coefficients achievable in that layer. A salinity densitometer has been redesigned to eliminate a persistent problem, and design drawings are shown. The 2-dimensional model to simulate pond behaviour has been improved to include variation in the wavelength dependence of atmosphere and pond absorption with solar altitude, Fresnel reflection from the pond surface and evaporative losses from the surface.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Measurements; SALTS; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; HEAT EXTRACTION LEVELS; LONG-TERM STORAGE; NON-CONVECTING LAYER; SALT GRADIENT; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM USING ORGANIC PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS WITH IMPROVED THERMAL CONDUCTIVITIES FOR STORAGE TEMPERATURES BETWEEN 35 AND 120 degree C.
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth
Authors with affiliations: van den Brink, G.J., Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth
Abstract: Research has been done on the possibility of improving the poor thermal conductivity of paraffins. Using two volume percents of aluminium thin-strip matrices, known under the trade name Explofoil, the thermal conductivity increases by a factor 5. Measurements have been carried out on a number of phase change materials with transition temperatures in the range of 30-140 degree C. Measured were solidification and melting range, latent heat and in some cases the specific heat. In a storage unit, the performance of a finned-tube heat exchanger has been compared to the performance of a metal-matrix heat exchanger, showing that the metal-matrix heat exchanger gives good results. A storage system of the heat exchanger/container type has been designed and built. A detailed computer simulation model for optimizing the dimensions of a storage tank of the heat exchanger/container type has been developed. A test facility for testing of storage tanks up to a temperature of 150 degree C is under construction.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Materials; HEAT EXCHANGERS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS - Thermodynamic Properties; PARAFFINS; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; ORGANIC PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; STORAGE TANKS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; TRANSITION TEMPERATURE RANGE; SOLAR ENERGY

Abstract: The paper presents the results of the measurements which have been performed in the South of France on a 12 m**3 solar powered cold store using the intermittent zeolithe-H//2O cycle. The main results of these measurements are that the front plate temperature ranges from 125 to 135 degree C; the thermal COP is 0,31; the thermal captation efficiency is 0,31; and the overall solar COP is 9,6%. The paper then presents the general conception of a solar powered ice maker. This unit which has been designed to produce 20 to 30 kg of ice per day (depending on the sunshine) consists in 4 collectors filled with activated carbon, an air cooled condensor, an evaporator which produces ice blocks.

Title: OPTIMIZATION OF CONTAINER STORAGE PLACE OPERATION.

Abstract: Numerical simulation of all activities taking place in a container terminal enables proper design of routes for terminal vehicles transporting containers to and from storage areas and performing loading operations. Storage areas in container terminals are used to store containers which cannot be taken out within a short time. Because storage areas are one part of the terminal, their simulation should work in a system desribing whole terminal. In simulation of storage areas there are two crucial points: synchronization of events and optimization of vehicle movements. In this paper two quality indices are taken into account, the first, minimizing energy, the second, minimizing time of the service.
Index Keywords: INDUSTRIAL TRUCKS; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Algorithms; CONTAINER STORAGE PLACE OPERATION; OPTIMIZATION ALGORITHMS; MATERIALS HANDLING

Title: SEASONAL HEAT STORAGE IN UNDERGROUND WARM WATER STORES (CONSTRUCTION AND TESTING OF A 500 m**3 STORE).
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den
Authors with affiliations: Hansen, Preben N., Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den; Hansen, Kurt K., Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den; Ussing, Vagn, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den
Abstract: Design, construction and testing of the efficiency of a 500 m**3 warm water pit has been carried through. The aims of the project were: gathering practical experience with the actual realization of the pilot plant; monitoring of the overall behaviour of the storage system; verification and modification of the digital computer program used to simulate the thermal behaviour of the pit. The store has performed very well. Only minor unforeseen problems developed during installation of the floating 'gasket' sealing the top lid at the edges. The results are that good agreement was obtained when comparing the measured thermal behaviour with both the numerical and analytical predicted performances.

Title: HELIOGEOTHERMAL DOUBLET: A REAL SCALE TEST FACILITY.
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: ARMINES, Paris, Fr, ARMINES, Paris, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Iris, P., ARMINES, Paris, Fr, ARMINES, Paris, Fr
Abstract: A system is proposed in order to make possible a large thermal use of aquifers, specially in urban areas: the 'heliogeothermal doublet' based on the seasonal thermal recharge of the energy extracted during winter, by solar energy collected during summer. A feasibility study of this system has been done in the case of 224 collective apartments which are now under construction near Paris, over a regional aquifer. The present work concerns the scientific control of the realization, the design of an acquisition data system and the interpretation of the global system with numerical models for the first year of heating.
