Affiliations: Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den
Authors with affiliations: Hansen, K.Kielsgaard, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den; Hansen, P.Nordgaard, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den; Ussing, V., Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den
Abstract: The aim of the project is to design a 30-50,000 m**3 seasonal heat storage executed as a warm water pit, which is partly dug into the ground, partly constructed above the ground by placing the excavated dirt in embankments. The soil interfaces of the pit are assumed to be uninsulated in order to lower the construction cost. The lid on the pit is assumed to be floating and made from foam plastic insulation. A series of prospective users of such a pit has been contacted and a district heating system with a coupling to an electric power plant and a possible interest in seasonal storage of heat has been selected as supplier of the design data, from which the pit design can proceed. This paper deals with certain of the design considerations completed so far under this contract.

Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings

Abstract: Heat transfer measurements are performed on two different types of heat exchangers submerged in a paraffin tank. From the overall heat transfer measurements only the range of the volumetric heat transfer coefficient could be determined. The paraffin store being used in the pilot facility for the validation of the model in real operating conditions has been built in a slab geometry. The experimental facility functions properly and measurements in view of model validation are being carried out. A one dimensional model of a paraffin wax store has been implemented in EMGP2 and has been tested with a complete system simulation.

Title: TRANSPARENT INSULATION FOR THERMAL STORAGE WALLS.
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den
Authors with affiliations: Olsen, L., Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den; Paludan-Mueller, C., Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den
Abstract: The aim of the project is to investigate the possibility of using different kinds of honeycomb-structures (transparent insulation) in connection with thermal storage walls in order to decrease the heat loss from the absorber and maintain a large solar transmission. Different kinds of transparent insulation were tested by building them into solar collectors. The qualities of the honeycombs then could be evaluated from the heat loss coefficient and the efficiency of the collectors. Afterwards one of the honeycomb structures was installed in an outdoor thermal storage wall. The performance was compared with a thermal storage wall with no transparent insulation between the outer glazing and the selective absorber.

Title: FUTURE PROSPECTS FOR HEAT PUMPS - A PERSONAL VIEW.
Authors with affiliations: Braham, G.D.
Abstract: Future historian will probably view the 1970s as the decade of the commercial birth of the heat pump. The factors responsible for its emergence were foundamental changes in the marketing environment for space and water heating. As a result, market change stimulated government legislation to improve energy conservation standards for new buildings. Commercial organizations reduced their dependence on sensitive fossil fuels and minimized their total energy demand and consumptions. The second oil crisis precipitated a panic switch from oil to gas for existing boiler systems. The demand for gas soon exceeded the supply. Thus began a period of rapid market change, which allowed the heat pump to penetrate markets hitherto the exclusive reserve of conventional boiler fuels. It also introduced a cost-effective means of integrating the newly available heat pumps into conventional heating systems. Both gas and electricity utilities being load factor dependent to varying degrees, recognized the heat pump as an economic substitution for oil in low temperature space and water heating applications. Radical breakthroughs in scientific knowledge with relation to heat pumps are improbable, but development of the applications of heat pumps will be an important marketing feature of the 1980s.
Index Keywords: ABSORPTION; ENERGY CONSERVATION; HEATING; VENTILATION; WATER HEATERS - Fuels; BIVALENT SYSTEMS; DEHUMIDIFICATION; HEAT RECOVERY; HEAT STORAGE; TARIFFS; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Abstract: Externally controlled diffuse discharges have attracted interest as submicrosecond opening switches for inductive energy storage systems. Their performance is determined by the basic fill gas parameters and their dependence on the reduced field strength E/N. An electron-beam controlled diffuse discharge system was constructed to study the behavior of pulsed discharges in various gas mixtures under repetitive operation. Experiments were performed with 1 atm N//2 and small additives of N//2O as fill gas in the switch. The experimental results are compared with numerical values, obtained from a code which allows modeling of the discharge voltage-current characteristics and its transient behavior in a discharge circuit.

Title: GENERATION OF STRIP HIGH POWER ION BEAM IN MAGNETICALLY INSULATED DIODE.
Affiliations: Polytechnic Inst, Tomsk, USSR, Polytechnic Inst, Tomsk, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Bistritsky, V.M., Polytechnic Inst, Tomsk, USSR, Polytechnic Inst, Tomsk, USSR; Didenko, A.N., Polytechnic Inst, Tomsk, USSR, Polytechnic Inst, Tomsk, USSR; Krasik, Ya E., Polytechnic Inst, Tomsk, USSR, Polytechnic Inst, Tomsk, USSR; Matvienko, V.M., Polytechnic Inst, Tomsk, USSR, Polytechnic Inst, Tomsk, USSR
Abstract: The operation of a magnetically self-insulated ion diode of strip configuration (80 multiplied by 6)cm**2 is described. High power ion beam (HPIB) generation was investigated on two different generators with 7. 8-ohm and 24-ohm impedances and 0. 5-MV and 1-MV voltages, respectively. HPIB generation of (70 multiplied by 3)cm**2 cross section started as the diode current level attained the value of parapotential flow. Overall efficiencies of HPIB generation in the 27% to 33% range were attained with storage energy of ion beams up to 370 J. The reproducibility of beam parameters was better than 80%.

Authors: Chang B.J., Schubert Franz H., Kovach Andy J.
Title: ALKALINE ELECTROLYTE REGENERATIVE FUEL CELL SYSTEM FOR ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: Life Systems Inc, Cleveland, OH, USA, Life Systems Inc, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chang, B.J., Life Systems Inc, Cleveland, OH, USA, Life Systems Inc, Cleveland, OH, USA; Schubert, Franz H., Life Systems Inc, Cleveland, OH, USA, Life Systems Inc, Cleveland, OH, USA; Kovach, Andy J., Life Systems Inc, Cleveland, OH, USA, Life Systems Inc, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Work has been directed toward the development of an alkaline regenerative fuel cell system. It is based on the highly efficient static feed electrolyzer. The development activities include characterization and endurance testing of electrochemical cells stacks, and key components; development of a 2- to 3-kW regenerative fuel cell system breadboard using a Shuttle Orbiter fuel cell power plant; scale-up of the process hardware and system definition and sizing studies. The primary application is for a low earth orbiting space station. Power needs studied ranged from 75 to 150 kW. This paper presents the results of the development work completed to date.

Abstract: The tools available to the architect and builder for installing thermal storage into a passive solar home have, until recently, been quite limited. The ENERPHASE Panel now gives the builder another tool, one especially well suited to typical construction methods. This paper discusses the installation of the ENERPHASE Panel, typical applications and relative performance of the various options for the use of this product.

Title: TFTR POWER CONVERSION AND PLASMA FEEDBACK SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Princeton Plasma Physics Lab,, Princeton, NJ, USA, Princeton Plasma Physics Lab, Princeton, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Neumeyer, C., Princeton Plasma Physics Lab,, Princeton, NJ, USA, Princeton Plasma Physics Lab, Princeton, NJ, USA
Abstract: Major components of the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor (TFTR) power conversion system include a thyristor rectifier power supplies, 12 energy storage capacitor banks, and 6 ohmic testing interrupters. These components are connected in various series/parallel configurations to provide controlled pulses of current to the Toroidal Field (TF), Ohmic (OH), Equilibrium (vertical) Field (EF), and Horizontal Field (HF) magnet coil systems. Real-time control of the power conversion system is accomplished by a centralized indicated computer; local control is minimal. Power supply firing angles, capacitor bank and discharge commands, interrupter commands, etc. , are all determined and issued by the central computer. Plasma Position and Current Control (PPCC) reference signals to power conversion (OH), EF, HF) are determined by separate analog electronics but invoked through the power conversion computer.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, POWER SUPPLY; THYRISTORS; PLASMA FEEDBACK SYSTEMS; TOKAMAK FUSION TEST REACTOR; TOKAMAK DEVICES

Abstract: At this last contractors meeting of the second 4-year Solar Energy R & D programme encouraging progress was reported on all aspects of this research field. There were in total 13 contracts of which nearly final results were presented. A good balance was evident between research items on short term and long term storage approaches. Also a few theoretical studies were presented both dealing with modelling of the thermal behaviour of various short and long term storage systems to be used as components of solar installations. Several researchers presented work on large scale experiments, the majority of which is still in the monitoring and evaluation phase. The paper discusses developments in terms of short-term, miscellaneous, and long-term storage systems.

Title: ROBOTIC FILAMENT WINDING.

Authors with affiliations: Bubeck, Kenneth B., Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy,, NY, USA, Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, NY, USA
Abstract: A thorough examination of the state-of-the-art in filament winding machines was the basis for developing the research in this unique processing technique. The benefits of using high modulus, low density composites in structural applications are bringing out many innovations in the use of reinforced plastics in the aerospace, automotive and energy related industries. This paper describes the work done to establish the feasibility of this processing technique. Early developments took place with a helicopter rotor hub mock-up. More recent developments are applied to reinforcing energy storage flywheels. Several major processing restrictions were overcome, opening the way for specific application development.
Index Keywords: COMPOSITE MATERIALS; PLASTICS MACHINERY - Robot Applications; PLASTICS, REINFORCED; WINDING MACHINES - Plastics Applications; MODULUS; PATH PROGRAMMING; PLASTICS

Authors: Benet J.C., Saix C., Jouanna P.
Title: PHYSICAL MODEL FOR THE STUDY OF MASS AND ENERGY TRANSFERS IN THE NON-SATURATED LAYER OF SOIL LOCATED ABOVE A SOLAR ENERGY STORAGE ZONE.
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: Univ Montpellier II, Montpellier, Fr, Univ Montpellier II, Montpellier, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Benet, J.C., Univ Montpellier II, Montpellier, Fr, Univ Montpellier II, Montpellier, Fr; Saix, C., Univ Montpellier II, Montpellier, Fr, Univ Montpellier II, Montpellier, Fr; Jouanna, P., Univ Montpellier II, Montpellier, Fr, Univ Montpellier II, Montpellier, Fr
Abstract: A test programme has made it possible to simulate heat storage at 60 degree C in a physical model. The surface of the soil was subjected to controlled conditions and then natural atmospheric conditions. The physical model serves as a prototype for the study of the behaviour of a natural site. The evolutions of the physical model make it possible to judge the modifications in the state of the non-saturated layer of soil and to come to conclusions regarding the harmful effects of storage. The physical model has given experimental results that confirm the validity of a local three-phase mathematical model. This confirmation allows this model to be used in the future for making forecasts for other sites.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; MASS TRANSFER; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MODELS - Testing; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; NON-SATURATED SOIL LAYER; SOLAR ENERGY STORAGE ZONE; TESTING PROGRAM RESULTS; SOILS

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF A SOLAR ENERGY INSTALLATION FOR SPACE HEATING AND COOLING BASED ON HYGROSCOPIC MATERIALS.
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Verdonschot, J.K.M., Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth
Abstract: This research work deals with the application possibilities for combined heating and cooling of an office building under Dutch climatic conditions. With respect to the solar heating part of the system it is concluded that only the direct use mode should be applied. Concerning the cooling part of the system some first theoretical results have been obtained, while an experimental test circuit has been developed and realised. The first results of a total system performance for the Dutch climatic conditions indicate that the system output may be in the order of 150 kWh/m**2.
Index Keywords: MATERIALS - Thermal Properties; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; COMBINED HEATING AND COOLING; DIRECT USE MODE; DUTCH CLIMATIC CONDITIONS; EXPERIMENTAL TEST CIRCUIT; HYGROSCOPIC MATERIALS; TOTAL SYSTEM PERFORMANCE; OFFICE BUILDINGS

Title: PERFORMANCE OF A PHASE CHANGE TROMBE WALL AS MEASURED IN A CALIBRATED HOT BOX.
Affiliations: Dow Chemical Co, Midland, MI, USA, Dow Chemical Co, Midland, MI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Moses, P.J., Dow Chemical Co, Midland, MI, USA, Dow Chemical Co, Midland, MI, USA; Strom, E.E., Dow Chemical Co, Midland, MI, USA, Dow Chemical Co, Midland, MI, USA
Abstract: The ENERPHASE Thermal Energy Storage Panel is a phase change based thermal energy storage system suitable for passive solar heating in Trombe wall and sunspace applications. Tests of the performance of the ENERPHASE panel have been conducted in several types of test systems. The most accurate testing program used the Calibrated Hot Box facility at Dow's Granville Research Center, located in Granville, Ohio. Additional testing has been conducted in unoccupied test houses and isolated wall modules, systems more typical of the testing generally done for passive solar systems. This paper discusses the results of the Calibrated Hot Box study and the general need for greater use of this type of test facility which very accurately controls key variables.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ENERPHASE THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE PANEL; PASSIVE SOLAR SYSTEMS; PHASE CHANGE SYSTEMS; TROMBE WALL; SOLAR ENERGY

Abstract: TARN is a storage ring of low energy ions (T//N to approx. 10 Mev/u) constructed in 1979 to verify the feasibility of intensity multiplication proposed at NUMATRON project. The scheme is a combination of the multi-turn injection into transverse phase space and the rf stacking into longitudinal phase space. In the present paper, achievements of beam experiment at TARN are given together with the recent result of stochastic momentum cooling experiment.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, CYCLOTRON - Beam Injection; ION BEAMS; NUMATRON; STOCHASTIC MOMENTUM COOLING EXPERIMENT; TARN; ACCELERATORS

Title: SOLID STATE PHASE CHANGE OF HYDRATES FOR PASSIVE SOLAR APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Calortherm Associates, Englewood,, NJ, USA, Calortherm Associates, Englewood, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: MacCracken, Calvin D., Calortherm Associates, Englewood,, NJ, USA, Calortherm Associates, Englewood, NJ, USA
Abstract: The long-standing bugaboo of most phase change materials used for thermal storage (i. e. , stratification and separation of the salt hydrates) has been solved by a new patented method using cross-linked polymers. The Calor Group Ltd. , Slough, England, a subsidiary of Intercontinental Gas Corp. , through research at Fulmer Laboratory discovered a number of polymers which, when mixed with salt hydrates, such as Glauber's salt, in concentrations of 3 to 5%, and then crosslinked with formaldehyde, create a gel-like solid in the melted state that promotes crystal formation but does not permit stratification.
Index Keywords: POLYMERS; SALTS; SOLAR ENERGY; HYDRATES; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; TROMBE WALL; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: GENERAL DESIGN METHOD FOR INTEGRAL PASSIVE SOLAR WATER HEATERS.
Affiliations: Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Panico, David, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA; Clark, Gene, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA, Trinity Univ, San Antonio, TX, USA
Abstract: A correlation has been developed which relates the performance of integral collector/storage (ICS) solar preheat systems to two nondimensional parameters. A detailed, hourly computer simulation program has identified several variables of importance to system performance. The program was used to examine the relationship between the monthly solar fraction, f, and the two dimensionless groups for a wide range of climates and system characteristics. The result is a general design method to accurately predict annual solar fractions by hand calculation. The effects of multiple tanks, or other ICS anti-mixing strategies, are discussed. The concept of heat storage efficiency has been used to quantify this benefit and relate it to system performance.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; DYNAMIC PERFORMANCE; HEAT STORAGE; ICS DESIGN CHART; INTEGRAL COLLECTOR/STORAGE SOLAR PREHEAT; WATER HEATERS

Title: BENEFITS OF VENEERING CERAMIC FIBRE IN REHEATING FURNACE.
Affiliations: China Steel Corp, China, China Steel Corp, China
Authors with affiliations: Ou, J.J., China Steel Corp, China, China Steel Corp, China; Ho, T.Y., China Steel Corp, China, China Steel Corp, China
Abstract: Among several advances made in energy saving at the plate mill, insulation improvements in slab reheating furnaces by veneering ceramic fibre on the roof and wall are presented. The author analyzes the properties of ceramic fibres supplied by different manufacturers, calculates the energy saved from decreasing the heat loss during operation and reducing heat storage during furnace heating and cooling. The results show that heat loss is reduced by 40% and slab fuel consumption is reduced by 6. 33%. Indirect savings of increased production and refractory life are also achieved.
Index Keywords: CERAMIC MATERIALS - Fibers; ENERGY UTILIZATION; FUEL ECONOMY; ROLLING MILL PRACTICE - Energy Conservation; ROLLING MILLS - Refractory Materials; HEAT LOSS; RE-HEATING FURNACES; SERVICE LIFE; TAIWAN; VENEERING; FURNACES, HEATING

Authors: Cohen R.R., Manley B.J.W., Wood R.J.
Title: DEVELOPMENT AND OPTIMISATION OF COST EFFECTIVE THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS FOR SOLAR SPACE HEATING BY MEANS OF A MICROPROCESSOR CONTROLLED TEST FACILITY.
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl, Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Cohen, R.R., Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl, Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl; Manley, B.J.W., Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl, Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl; Wood, R.J., Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl, Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl
Abstract: This paper summarises the results of three years research into thermal energy stores for active solar space heating. The final conclusions indicate that short term active solar space heating is fundamentally uneconomic under current criteria. If a system is to be installed, however, then the results suggest that for the same performance, encapsulated phase change material stores can offer significant savings in volume at a similar cost compared with water stores. Alternatively, for stores of the same volume, and less than 1m**3 , the phase change store gives improved performance at a similar life cycle cost compared with a water store. Stratification in a water store is likely to give only a marginal improvement in performance and therefore only a small expense, if any, should be devoted to enhancing it.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Solar, Active; CONTROL SYSTEMS - Computer Applications; ECONOMICS - Analysis; HEATING - Solar; MATERIALS - Thermal Properties; MICROPROCESSOR CONTROL; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; WATER STORES; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: van Dijk H.A.L., van Galen E., Hensen J., de Wit M.
Title: HIGH PERFORMANCE PASSIVE SOLAR HEATING SYSTEM WITH HEAT PIPE ENERGY TRANSFER AND LATENT HEAT STORAGE.
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: Inst of Applied Physics TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Inst of Applied Physics TNO-TH, Delft, Neth
Authors with affiliations: van Dijk, H.A.L., Inst of Applied Physics TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Inst of Applied Physics TNO-TH, Delft, Neth; van Galen, E., Inst of Applied Physics TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Inst of Applied Physics TNO-TH, Delft, Neth; Hensen, J., Inst of Applied Physics TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Inst of Applied Physics TNO-TH, Delft, Neth; de Wit, M., Inst of Applied Physics TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Inst of Applied Physics TNO-TH, Delft, Neth
Abstract: The aim of the project is to develop a passive solar heating system with a higher efficiency than conventional concrete thermal storage walls regarding accumulation and transfer of solar heat into dwellings and with restricted extra costs for manufacturing the system. This is to be achieved by the introduction of two special components: a heat pipe as a thermal diode tube for the efficient transfer of collected solar heat from the absorber plate to behind an insulation layer; a latent heat storage section with high storage capacity at moderate operating temperatures. Additional advantageous characteristics of such a high performance passive system are that the maintenance costs are negligable and the performance is highly insensitive to inadequate control of the system by the inhabitants. The project is divided into three phases: in the first phase the research is aimed at the global design of the system, in the second phase the characteristics of the various components are examined in detail. The project will be concluded with a third phase, the design of a prototype system.
Index Keywords: HEAT PIPES - Heat Transfer; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; THERMAL INSULATION; HEAT PIPE ENERGY TRANSFER; HIGH-PERFORMANCE SYSTEMS; LATENT HEAT STORAGE; STORAGE CAPACITY; THERMAL DIODE TUBE; HOUSES

Title: HIGH PERFORMANCE COLLECTOR FOR COOLING FACILITIES.
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: Dornier System GmbH, Friedrichshafen, West Ger, Dornier System GmbH, Friedrichshafen, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Hause, R., Dornier System GmbH, Friedrichshafen, West Ger, Dornier System GmbH, Friedrichshafen, West Ger
Abstract: An absorption cold storage system with an ammonia/water cooling machine has been tested with normal collectors under real ambient conditions in Cairo/Egypt. The result of the tests were later compared with corresponding results of selective coated collectors, of which operation curves are analysed by a computer simulation. The results showed a considerable improvement of the performance by the use of selective coated collectors. Depending on the ambient conditions the increase of daily cooling energy was in the range from 10 to 45%. The large improvements occur, when the limit of normal flat plate collectors is reached.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Solar Energy Systems; COMPUTER AIDED ANALYSIS; REFRIGERATING MACHINERY - Absorption; REFRIGERATION - Solar; AMMONIA/WATER SYSTEM; FLAT PLATE COLLECTORS; HIGH PERFORMANCE COLLECTORS; SELECTIVE COATED COLLECTORS; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: UNIT FOR LOCAL STORAGE OF SOLAR GAIN.
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den
Authors with affiliations: Svendsen, S., Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Lyngby, Den
Abstract: The aim of the project is to develop a unit for local storage of solar gain. The unit is based on the principle that excess heat in a room is stored in a latent heat storage placed in the room and released when needed. The storage medium is a salt water mixture based on the extra water principle and with a melting temperature close to room temperature. A parameter analysis of heat storage capacity, heat loss coefficients and heat transfer coefficients for the storage unit in typical rooms has been carried out. A 43. 6% CaCl//2 was selected as the most promising salt water mixture for this type of work. Two storage units have been designed and constructed. The two storage units are being tested under realistic conditions but it has already been proved that the principle is working for both storage units.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Solar, Passive; HEAT TRANSFER - Analysis; SALTS; LATENT HEAT STORAGE; LOCAL STORAGE; SALT HYDRATES; SOLAR GAIN; STORAGE MEDIUM; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: FIELD TEST TO INVESTIGATE THE PERFORMANCE OF AN UNDEEP PROTOTYPE SEASONAL HEAT STORAGE SYSTEM WITH A HEAT CAPACITY FOR 100 SOLAR HOUSES USING THE SOIL AS THE STORAGE MEDIUM.
Source title: Solar Energy R&D in the European Community, Series A: Solar Energy Applications to Dwellings
Affiliations: Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Wijsman, A.J.Th.M., Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth; de Feijter, J.W., Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth, Technische Physische Dienst TNO-TH, Delft, Neth
Abstract: The project contains the detailed engineering design, the execution and the investigation of the performance of a system for the seasonal storage of heat in a water saturated sandy soil with a heat capacity for approximately 100 houses. Recently developed techniques in geotechnical engineering will be used to install the soil storage heat exchanger. The heat storage will be charged and discharged according to the calculated thermal behaviour of a group of 100 solar houses with seasonal heat storage in the soil. Construction of the heat storage reservoir took place from June till December 1982. The experiments started last February. In this paper information about the construction techniques applied and the first results of the experiments are given.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; HOUSES - Solar, Active; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; CALCULATED THERMAL BEHAVIOR; CONSTRUCTION TECHNIQUES; SEASONAL STORAGE; TEST RESULTS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SOILS

Authors: Baert D.H.J., Simoens H.M., Bonte L.
Title: GRID-CONNECTED PHOTOVOLTAIC GENERATOR FOR RESIDENTIAL APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: State Univ at Ghent, Belg, State Univ at Ghent, Belg
Authors with affiliations: Baert, D.H.J., State Univ at Ghent, Belg, State Univ at Ghent, Belg; Simoens, H.M., State Univ at Ghent, Belg, State Univ at Ghent, Belg; Bonte, L., State Univ at Ghent, Belg, State Univ at Ghent, Belg
Abstract: For several years, a considerable effort has been made at the Laboratory for Electronics and Metrology (LEM) of the State University at Ghent in order to design mains-connected photovoltaic generator installations for residential use. The idea is that in countries with a high population density there is in general not enough room for large p. v. plants to be installed. A possible solution is to cover the roofs of the houses with p. v. panels. The dc power output of the panels can then be fed directly into the mains with a dc-ac inverter. In this way the electricity production could be reduced by about 20% in Belgium. If a minimum amount of battery storage is included then it becomes also possible to manage the energy flow of the consumer. The paper describes a grid-connected photovoltaic system which represents the model of a future 5 kW p. v. system designed for residential applications.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES; ELECTRIC POWER DISTRIBUTION; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SOLAR CELLS; GRID-CONNECTED SYSTEM; PHOTOVOLTAIC ARRAYS; POWER CONDITIONING; RESIDENTIAL APPLICATIONS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Gallo L., Peluso G., Tranquilli A.
Title: PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEM TO POWER A COLD STORE AND AN OZONIZER SYSTEM.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: PRAGMA SpA, Rome, Italy, PRAGMA SpA, Rome, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Gallo, L., PRAGMA SpA, Rome, Italy, PRAGMA SpA, Rome, Italy; Peluso, G., PRAGMA SpA, Rome, Italy, PRAGMA SpA, Rome, Italy; Tranquilli, A., PRAGMA SpA, Rome, Italy, PRAGMA SpA, Rome, Italy
Abstract: The plant includes two array subfields completely indipendent of each other. A water disinfection system composed of a 15 kWp array supplies energy which to a commercial ozonizer. A cold storage system which is composed of a 30 kWp array supplies energy to a compressor that runs a refrigeration cycle for a food conservation cold store.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS; REFRIGERATION - Solar; WATER TREATMENT - Disinfection; COLD STORAGE SYSTEM; OZONIZER SYSTEM; POWER CONDITIONING; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Theys B., Levy-Clement C., Gorochov O.
Title: LAMELLAR SEMICONDUCTORS FOR CONVERSION AND STORAGE OF SOLAR ENERGY.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: CNRS, Meudon, Fr, CNRS, Meudon, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Theys, B., CNRS, Meudon, Fr, CNRS, Meudon, Fr; Levy-Clement, C., CNRS, Meudon, Fr, CNRS, Meudon, Fr; Gorochov, O., CNRS, Meudon, Fr, CNRS, Meudon, Fr
Abstract: Structural and photoelectric characteristics of lamellar semiconductors are discussed. Intercalation and deintercalation of these materials are presented. By mixing photoelectrochemical and intercalation phenomena in lamellar compounds, the concept of photo (de)intercalation is introduced and experimental conclusions are drawn (with p-InSe and n-HfSe//2). It appears then that lamellar photoectrodes can really be thought of as part of a system which converts and simultaneously stores solar energy.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; INDIUM SELENIDE SEMICONDUCTOR; LAMELLAR SEMICONDUCTOR; PHOTOINTERCALATION; SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS

Title: PHOTOVOLTAIC PLANT AS A MEANS OF SUPPLYING ELECTRICITY TO ISOLATED DWELLINGS.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Ente Nazionale per l'Energia, Elettrica, Italy, Ente Nazionale per l'Energia Elettrica, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Previ, A., Ente Nazionale per l'Energia, Elettrica, Italy, Ente Nazionale per l'Energia Elettrica, Italy; Taschini, A., Ente Nazionale per l'Energia, Elettrica, Italy, Ente Nazionale per l'Energia Elettrica, Italy
Abstract: The report analyzes the possibility of supplying potential electricity consumers with low load values but high grid connection costs, by means of electric power produced by a small stand-alone photovoltaic plant. A method is proposed for the optimal design of a generating and storage system that will provide a given level of service continuity in supplying an isolated load. In addition, the results are presented of a survey conducted by ENEL among isolated dwellings that would involve high grid connection costs, located in various parts of Italy. The purpose of the survey was to define the electricity requirements of these potential consumers. It was found that, in a fairly good percentage of the cases examined, conditions might be favourable for photovoltaic experiments.
Index Keywords: PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS - Applications; SOLAR RADIATION - Concentrators; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; ISOLATED DWELLINGS; STAND-ALONE PLANT; SYSTEM DESIGN CURVES; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: PRESENT AND FUTURE CHALLENGES OF PHOTOVOLTAICS.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Authors with affiliations: Groumpos, P.P.
Abstract: Photovoltaic technology is a new and exciting energy source, an alternative to fossil fuel and nuclear power. For an idea with such unlimited promise, its growth towards maturity has remained a step away for various reasons. However, many experts believe that photovoltaics will play a major role in meeting the future energy needs of the world. In order for this to become a reality, many of the present and future challenges of this new field must be carefully addressed and resolved. These challenges are briefly surveyed with an emphasis on the areas of modeling, utility interface, control aspects, decentralized vs. centralized systems, energy storage and education and research needs.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR CELLS; SOLAR ENERGY; ENERGY CONVERSION EFFICIENCY; HYBRID POWER SYSTEMS; UTILITY INTERFACE CHALLENGES; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Griffin G.D., Sauers I., Easterly C.E., Ellis H.W., Christophorou L.G.
Title: DECOMPOSITION OF SPARKED SF//6 AND CYTOTOXICITY OF SF//6 DECOMPOSITION PRODUCTS.
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Griffin, G.D., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Sauers, I., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Easterly, C.E., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Ellis, H.W., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Christophorou, L.G., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: We previously reported that sparked SF//6 was cytotoxic to mammalian cells, although SF//6 itself was found to be without biological activity. Using quadrupole mass spectrometric analysis of sparked SF//6 over energy and pressure ranges of 4-94 kJ and 40-233 kPa, respectively, we have found that the by-products include SOF//2, SO//2F//2, SF//4, SOF//4, SiF//4, SO//2, and HF. Typical concentrations for 36 kJ deposited into a 60-cm**3 cell at 133-kPa SF//6 pressure following 24-h storage were 1. 2% SOF//2, 0. 03% SiF//4, 0. 22% SOF//4, 0. 02% SO//2F//2, and 0. 002% SO//2. We have investigated the cytotoxic activity of certain abundant decomposition products toward hamster lung cells using a colony formation assay. 'Synthetic' decomposition product gas mixtures in SF//6 were prepared to contain greater concentrations of decomposition products than are expected to result from sparking. One mixture containing 0. 2% SO//2F//2 and SiF//4, 2% SOF//2, and 4% HF was only weakly cytotoxic, exhibiting approximately 20% of the cytotoxic activity of sparked SF//6.
Index Keywords: BIOMEDICAL ENGINEERING - Cytology; GASES; COLONY FORMATION ASSAY; CYTOTOXICITY; GAS MIXTURES; HAMSTER LUNG; MAMMALIAN CELLS; SULFUR OXYFLUORIDES; BIOLOGICAL MATERIALS

Title: STUDY OF A 5 KWH EXPERIMENTAL FLYWHEEL FOR THE C. N. R. FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy, Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Genta, Giancarlo, Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy, Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy
Abstract: One of the goals of the Finalized Energy Program sponsored by C. N. R. (Italian National Research Council) was the construction of a flywheel energy storage system for peak levelling which could be used in near service conditions in an industrial plant. The present paper covers the choice of the flywheel configuration (an advanced medium-energy density flywheel was chosen) and the design of the flywheel. Some related topics as the calculation of the aerodynamic drag, the estimation of the ability of the housing to meet the burst containment requirements and a basic rotor-dynamics study of the rotating parts of the machine are also treated. A few experimental data, taken from Pirelli Final Report on the C. N. R. Flywheel Energy Storage System are reported.
Index Keywords: DYNAMICS; ENERGY STORAGE; STRESSES - Analysis; AERODYNAMIC POWER LOSSES; DYNAMIC BEHAVIOR; FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE; ROTOR-DYNAMIC CALCULATIONS; SYSTEM DYNAMIC BEHAVIOR; FLYWHEELS

Authors: Zhivkov Venelin, Berov Georgy, Stoev Teodosy, Pavlov Stefan
Title: LATERAL WHEEL SLIP OF A MOTOR VEHICLE WITH A KINETIC ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM.

Lenin', Sofia, Bulg; Pavlov, Stefan, Higher Inst of Mechanical &, Electrical Engineering 'V. I., Lenin', Sofia, Bulg, Higher Inst of Mechanical & Electrical Engineering 'V. I. Lenin', Sofia, Bulg
Abstract: The incorporation of a flywheel as a basic or auxiliary source of energy into a vehicle changes the dynamic properties and the character of its movement. The effect of the flywheel kinetic momentum on the vehicle drivability has been studied by means of a mathematical model for the vehicle movement when turning, taking into account the gyroscope relations. The paper presents a study of the lateral wheel slip of a model having a rigidly suspended flywheel. Solutions in their final form have been obtained, taking into consideration various effects, which allow for optimum solutions to be sought in the space of the parameters.

Abstract: A simulation program is described, which includes the interesting dynamical properties of the subsystem and of the combined operation for photovoltaic and wind generators in a weak diesel grid. Special attention is paid to the storage function and to the optimal strategies of operating the different subsystems. With simulated loads a great number of operational modes of alternative power sources on a weak grid can be tested. This experience together with simulation results for parameter variations will influence the design for a solar/wind plant on the island of Fernando de Noronha.

Abstract: This paper will describe the demonstration of CWM firing in Sundbyberg, Sweden. The demonstration is carried out as a cooperative effort between industry and government by the Swedish Thermal Engineering Research Institute with financial support from the Swedish National Energy Administration. The objective of the task is to demonstrate that CWM can be used as a fuel in a boiler designed for oil and to provide basic data for future conversions of oil fired boilers. The main interest has been placed on burner and boiler performance but experience on on-site handling and storage as well as transport of the CWM fuel has also been collected.

Abstract: The TRISTAN (Transposable Ring Intersecting Storage Accelerators in Nippon), an electron-positron collider, consists of a main ring (MR) and an accumulation ring (AR). The former is under construction, while the latter has been accelerating electrons since November 1983 at KEK. Principal parameters of the AR are 377 m circumference, 23. 3 m bending radius, 795 kHz revolution frequency, 6 - 8 Gev maximum energy, 60 ma beam current and 30 - 100 psec bunch length. Its synchrotron radiation at 6 Gev beam energy has a spectrum ranging continuously up to the x-ray region with 20 keV critical energy. This paper reports the beam diagnostics using only the visible component.

Abstract: This paper describes progress made on the development of test methods for solar storage devices by the European Solar Storage Testing Group during the last year. It begins by an introduction stating the aims and objectives of the group and then goes on to report on the main findings and results of the joint action programme on storage device characterization and model development. A summary is given of the state of the art of the special tasks commissioned to individual group members. The structure of the final report, giving draft Recommendations for European Solar Storage Test Methods is outlined. The consequences of this work for the Recommendations for a European Reporting Format on the Performance of Solar Heat Stores are discussed.

Abstract: The volume contains 50 papers presented at the meeting, five of which are in French and one in German. Specific subjects covered include solar collector testing, The European solar storage testing group, walls, facades, ventilated Trombe wall unit, shutters, window systems, temporary thermal insulation, passive solar architecture, control devices, local storage of solar gain, development of pure metal selective heat absorber surfaces, solar focusing collector using a deformable mirror, endothermic refrigerant/absorbent systems in absorption heat pumps, stores using latent heat, heat of absorption, long-term heat storage, and others.

Abstract: A 5000 square foot earth sheltered office and manufacturing facility located near Saxonburg, Pennsylvania, with one sided elevational scheme and above grade interior office atrium and above grade laboratory light well and mechanical room is described. Facility contains office and recreation spaces, conference room, kitchen, laboratory, manufacturing and storage/expansion areas. This paper discusses the integration of the owner's program requirements with energy conservation and passive solar design features in the moderately cool, cloudy 5800 degree day climate of west central Pennsylvania.

Abstract: In the original Westinghouse ICF power plant study a point design of a heavy ion driver was based on an rf linac storage ring system. The system developed in this study included the entire driver from ion source to reactor. This paper first outlines an interactive computer model which does not include the low beta and ion source end of the system. The author simply extends the high beta end to zero energy to have the correct total energy and some cost, which is less than 10% of the total included.

Authors: Modense Vieira Luiz Francisco, Mora-Camino Felix
Title: PORT OPERATIONS: SOME NEW CONSIDERATIONS FOR MODELLING AND SIMULATION.
Affiliations: Univ Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Braz, Univ Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Braz
Authors with affiliations: Modense Vieira, Luiz Francisco, Univ Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Braz, Univ Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Braz; Mora-Camino, Felix, Univ Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Braz, Univ Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Braz
Abstract: Recently, the transportation engineer has introduced the concept of 'TERMINAL' as the interface of two, or more, modes of transportation, or of one mode and the user of it. The efficiency of a terminal relies on the harmonization of the operation of the modes of transportation connected by it, influencing the national economy as a whole through its sensible export/import flows of goods. A port, as a terminal, is essentially the connecting place of maritime and land modes of transportation, with the corresponding transfer involved in the port is organized in the handling and storage areas, which constitute some of the many sub-systems of a port system. Recently, with the energy crisis, public agencies and privative companies of countries, such as Brazil, have developed studies for planning and operation of port systems. This paper tries to give some scientific subsidies for the elaboration of a general mathematical model of port operations, which may be used as an evaluation tool of alternative decisions in this area.
Index Keywords: PORT TERMINALS; PORT OPERATIONS; CARGO HANDLING

Title: RESPONSE OF A GLASS MELTER TO STEAM EXPLOSION.
Affiliations: DuPont, Aiken, SC, USA, DuPont, Aiken, SC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Yau, Wen-Foo, DuPont, Aiken, SC, USA, DuPont, Aiken, SC, USA; Durant, William S., DuPont, Aiken, SC, USA, DuPont, Aiken, SC, USA
Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy is proposing to build the nation's first Defense Waste Processing Facility (DWPF) at the Savannah River Plant (SRP) for large-scale immobilization of high-level radioactive wastes. The method of waste immobilization calls for a two-stage process. In the first stage, the sludge fraction of the waste is solidified with a borosilicate-type glass frit in a joule-heated ceramic melter at temperatures of about 1150 degree C. The molten glass is then poured into stainless-steel canisters for interim storage. The glass melter for the continuous pouring process is of multilayered design using a combination of structural materials to accommodate the severe thermal loading under normal operating conditions.

Affiliations: Illinois DOE, Springfield, IL, USA, Illinois DOE, Springfield, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Huelsman, Larry, Illinois DOE, Springfield, IL, USA, Illinois DOE, Springfield, IL, USA; Wilhelm, Tim, Illinois DOE, Springfield, IL, USA, Illinois DOE, Springfield, IL, USA
Abstract: The rising fuel costs for commercial greenhouse growers have drastically reduced the operational houses in the cold midwest climate. Growers simply have not maximized the energy provided by the sun on a daily basis. By researching the economics and concepts of a solar greenhouse (one that is oriented to maximize solar gain in the winter, contains insulation on the north, east and west walls and employs heat storage techniques to offset the night-time auxiliary heat requirements) the Illinois Department of Energy believes it has a cost-effective, energy efficient solution to the problem. A 52,000 grant was awarded in 1983 to the Stelle Group, a new age community in Northern Illinois to develop and research this concept. They have constructed a 100 foot by 32 foot barrel vaulted structure that is built with a metal tube tetrahedral space frame capable of supporting a 30 pound per square foot load.

Abstract: The paper presents the results of a thorough survey of passive solar buildings in Italy, conducted by the Italian Agency for Nuclear Energy and Alternative Energy Sources (E. N. E. A. ). More than 100 buildings have been identified and examined by means of a questionnaire filled out by operators responsible for the various projects. The projects cover a very broad range of passive solar technologies, such as direct gain, Trombe walls, attached sunspaces, and 'Barra-Costantini' configurations, that is, vertical thermosiphoning air panels, with heat storage provided by the concrete walls of the air-ducts contained in the ceiling structures.

Abstract: Refrigeration, cooling and/or chilling methods usually require rather large amounts of energy for operation. This system uses naturally frozen ice in long term storage to provide an economical source of ice for various cooling or chilling purposes. Initial research and computer simulations indicate that in areas where the winter is sufficiently cold and of sufficient duration, this system would be an economical, viable option for uses such as simple refrigeration, summer air conditioning, or simply for effective dehumidification.

Title: SOME DESIGN CONSTRAINTS FOR AN rf-LINAC/STORAGE-RING DRIVER.

Authors with affiliations: Wangler, Thomas P., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Abstract: In this paper the author reviews some equations that must be satisfied when generating rf-linac/storage-ring systems for heavy-ion fusion, including current amplification and space-charge limits. To treat the phase-space constraints, new formulas are derived for separate transverse and longitudinal available dilution factors in terms of parameters of the rf-linac/storage ring system. These formulas represent an extension of the 6-D available dilution-factor approach introduced by Judd, and they allow a more complete specification of the phase-space constraints.

Title: EVALUATION OF THERMAL STORAGE FOR SOLAR HEATING SYSTEMS.

Affiliations: Univ Coll Cardiff, Cardiff, Wales, Univ Coll Cardiff, Cardiff, Wales
Authors with affiliations: Marshall, R.H., Univ Coll Cardiff, Cardiff, Wales, Univ Coll Cardiff, Cardiff, Wales
Abstract: The work reported describes the three key storage parameters required; the measured storage capacity, the store loss coefficient, and the heat exchanger coefficient, and their influence on the design method's non-dimensional parameters. Of these the heat transfer fluid to storage material overall heat transfer product, UA, is the most important. The identification of the key storage parameters is the main objective of the Solar Storage Testing Group (SSTG) in deriving its test procedure. A generalised storage computer model has been developed which serves to identify the UA value based on the experimental SSTG test procedure results. A stratification parameter, Ks, has been derived which accounts for the small (maximum 7%) increase in energy collection when operating with a reduced collector flow rate feeding a stratified store.

Abstract: A programme to evaluate the performance of glazed roof spaces of varying pitches fitted with a solar blind and phase change storage materials has been completed. The performance was measured over the heating period October 1982 to April 1983 and operated in conjunction with a gas boiler as a back-up for space heating. The best performance of 50. 5 kWhr m** minus **2 was obtained from a glazed conservatory (i. e. 90 degree pitch) fitted with a solar blind and a phase change material store.

Abstract: This research is focused on designing and realizing a prototype of the CaCl//2 tank and on solving many difficulties encountered. These are, among others: It is most important to avoid hindering the CaCl//2 expansion during its absorption, and to obtain a great heat exchange surface with powder and also a great contact surface between gas and salt. With regard to technology a corrosion-proof material compatible with NH//3 and CaCl//2 must be chosen and a perfect tightness must be obtained between NH//3 and water and between NH//3 and atmosphere.

Title: QUANTITATIVE ANALYSIS OF POSITIVE BATTERY PLATES BY MEANS OF BSE IMAGE ANALYSIS.
Source title: Proceedings, Annual Conference - Microbeam Analysis Society
Affiliations: COMSAT Lab, Clarksburg, MD, USA, COMSAT Lab, Clarksburg, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Remmel, T.P., COMSAT Lab, Clarksburg, MD, USA, COMSAT Lab, Clarksburg, MD, USA; Kirkendall, T.D., COMSAT Lab, Clarksburg, MD, USA, COMSAT Lab, Clarksburg, MD, USA
Abstract: Nickel-hydrogen (Ni-H//2) battery cells, offering improved performance and higher energy density per pound, are rapidly replacing nickel-cadmium as the main power storage medium for longer-life spacecraft applications. The positive plates used in the Ni-H//2 cell consist of a nickel screen substrate, which acts as the backbone for a sintered nickel-powder network that is about 80% porous. Nickel hydroxide, which is electrochemically impregnated into the pores of the plate, serves as the active material for the cell. By quantitative image analysis, techniques were developed to measure the distribution of the components through the cross section of the plate. Backscattered electron (BSE) images of metallographically polished sections of the plates were digitized and gray-level analyzed to discriminate between the three components - nickel sinter, nickel hydroxide, and void. Quantitative analysis for intensity levels corresponding to the three components on a line-by-line basis yielded the distribution of the three phases through the thickness of the plate.
Index Keywords: SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; BACKSCATTERED ELECTRON (BSE) IMAGES; METALLOGRAPHICALLY POLISHED SECTIONS; NICKEL SINTERS; NICKEL-HYDROGEN; POSITIVE BATTERY PLATES; VOIDS; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Authors: Batty J.Clair, Riley J.Paul, Panahi Zahra
Title: WATER REQUIREMENT MODEL FOR SALT GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS.
Affiliations: Utah State Univ, Logan, UT, USA, Utah State Univ, Logan, UT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Batty, J.Clair, Utah State Univ, Logan, UT, USA, Utah State Univ, Logan, UT, USA; Riley, J.Paul, Utah State Univ, Logan, UT, USA, Utah State Univ, Logan, UT, USA; Panahi, Zahra, Utah State Univ, Logan, UT, USA, Utah State Univ, Logan, UT, USA
Abstract: A model for predicting the salt gradient solar pond area that could be maintained with a given water supply is presented together with several specific applications. For example, based on 30-year average water flows, the model predicts 1. 93 multiplied by 10**9 m**2 (477,000 acres) of solar ponds, 1. 02 multiplied by 10**9 m**2 (253,000 acres) of evaporation ponds to recycle salt of 0. 51 multiplied by 10**9 m**2 (125,000 acres) of fresh water storage reservoirs could be maintained at the Great Salt Lake of Utah. Water use requirements per unit of electrical energy from solar ponds are calculated as 600,000 m**3/MW multiplied by (times) yr. This is roughly 30 times the water use requirements per unit of electrical energy from coal fired generating plants but substantially less than water evaporation losses per unit of electrical energy produced from typical hydropower dams and reservoirs. It is concluded that water use requirements for solar ponds are substantial and in many locations may be the physical factor that limits solar pond development.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; SOLAR RADIATION - Solar Ponds; WATER SUPPLY - Energy Storage; SALINITY; SALT GRADIENTS; WATER RESOURCES

Authors with affiliations: Kunhardt, E.E., Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX, USA
Abstract: An overview of the switching requirements in pulsed power applications is given. At present, research emphasis is on switches for systems that operate repetitively and on opening switches for inductive energy storage. This paper focuses on basic topics associated with a mode in which these switches have been proposed to operate: using self-sustained or externally-sustained diffuse gas discharges. The topics discussed are: a) instabilities that can lead to the formation of hot, conducting, filaments; and b) the concept of gas engineering for pulsed power application.

Abstract: The aim of the project is the utilization of the photovoltaic energy to lift fresh water in a pipe line in order to demonstrate the feasibility of photovoltaic water pumping for industrial uses. The dimensioning of the pumps has not been made on the basis of the local consumption of water, higher in touristic periods. In fact the photovoltaic pumps utilize the available energy from the PV field without back-up from the local grid, but simply realizing an hydraulic storage. The integration needed to satisfy the water demand is supplied by two centrifugal pumps working at moment in the pumping station.

Abstract: The Photovoltaic Power (PV) system for a Solarex Industrial Facility has been designed and installed by the Solarex Corporation. Title: NASA CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE GLOBAL HABITABILITY PROGRAM.
Affiliations: NASA, Washington, DC, USA, NASA, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: McConnell, Dudley G., NASA, Washington, DC, USA, NASA, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: Over the last two decades, but especially since 1978, there has begun to emerge an increasing capability to acquire and update global-scale information on key aspects of the land, oceanic, and atmospheric environment. The data acquisition, storage, analysis, and transmission facilities are available to enable a concerted long-term interdisciplinary and international study of the global environmental system. Such a study is the essence of the Global Habitability concept. The aims of Global Habitability research are to understand the global processes of the earth's energy balance, the global hydrological cycle, and the biogeochemical cycling of carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, and sulfur; to obtain quantitative measurements of long-term changes in these processes; and to assess the impact of such changes on the continued habitability of the earth by man and other species.

Authors with affiliations: Lambarski, Timothy J., BDM Corp, Albuquerque, NM, USA, BDM Corp, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Schwinkendorf, William E., BDM Corp, Albuquerque, NM, USA, BDM Corp, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Photovoltaic/thermal (PVT) system design studies were performed for three commercial site applications which require both electrical and thermal energy. The applications, which were selected on the basis of low life cycle cost ratios (LCCR), consisted of a meat packing plant, a public school and a hospital. The system sizing was obtained from SOLCEL simulation analyses by minimizing the LCCR. Electrical power ratings of the PVT systems are 1000 kW, 100 kW, and 125 kW, respectively. LCCR considerations and key features of the electrical and thermal designs and operating characteristics of the systems are presented. All three systems are utility interactive. The meat packing plant and the hospital systems contain thermal storage for optimal LCCR; the public school obtains optimal LCCR with no thermal storage.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; INDUSTRIAL POWER SYSTEM PLANNING; PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER SYSTEMS; PHOTOVOLTAIC/THERMAL SYSTEMS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: PHOTOVOLTAICS--10 YEARS AFTER CHERRY HILL.
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ralph, E.L., Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA,, USA, Hughes Aircraft Co, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Abstract: Reference is made to the National Science Foundation sponsored Cherry Hill N. J. workshop conference to aid in the establishment of a national PV program. This took place in October 1973. The content of the Cherry Hill workshop, who was there and what was accomplished is summarized. The role of the government and future aspects are considered. It is recommended that a similar exercise be initiated to plan the 10 years of development.
Index Keywords: SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS - Photovoltaic Effects; ENERGY STORAGE; GOVERNMENTAL ACTIVITIES/FACTORS; PHOTOVOLTAIC MATERIALS/DEVICES; PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER SYSTEMS; PHOTOVOLTAIC EFFECTS

Authors: Hong C.S., Teng K.S., Juang M.T., Fu S.Y., Shieh F.M., Hwang H.L.
Title: DESIGN METHODOLOGY FOR THE SIMULATION OF PHOTOVOLTAICS CONVERSION SYSTEM.
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Research Inst for Industrial, Technology, Energy Research Lab,, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan, Research Inst for Industrial Technology, Energy Research Lab, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Hong, C.S., Research Inst for Industrial, Technology, Energy Research Lab,, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan, Research Inst for Industrial Technology, Energy Research Lab, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan; Teng, K.S., Research Inst for Industrial, Technology, Energy Research Lab,, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan, Research Inst for Industrial Technology, Energy Research Lab, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan; Juang, M.T., Research Inst for Industrial, Technology, Energy Research Lab,, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan, Research Inst for Industrial Technology, Energy Research Lab, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan; Fu, S.Y., Research Inst for Industrial, Technology, Energy Research Lab,, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan, Research Inst for Industrial Technology, Energy Research Lab, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan; Shieh, F.M., Research Inst for Industrial, Technology, Energy Research Lab,, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan, Research Inst for Industrial Technology, Energy Research Lab, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan; Hwang, H.L., Research Inst for Industrial, Technology, Energy Research Lab,, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan, Research Inst for Industrial Technology, Energy Research Lab, Hsin-Chu, Taiwan
Abstract: A design methodology for the simulation of a photovoltaics conversion system was developed which can be used as a design guide for PV applications in Taiwan. This methodology has features that are different from the SOLCEL program and is particularly suitable to areas (like Taiwan) in which the utility cannot be used as a storage system. The operating modes and component size are optimized according to: (1) the fraction of the electrical load that is supplied by solar energy; (2) the relationship of solar electric availability and battery capacity; and (3) the unit price ratio of the array and battery over a 20-year period. The results for a 200-Wp PV system were used to verify this methodology.
Index Keywords: PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS - Optimization; DESIGN METHODOLOGY; PHOTOVOLTAIC CONVERSION SYSTEMS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: BEAM ACCUMULATION AND MOMENTUM COOLING AT TARN.
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium
Affiliations: Univ of Tokyo, Inst for Nuclear, Study, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst for Nuclear Study, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Katayama, T., Univ of Tokyo, Inst for Nuclear, Study, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst for Nuclear Study, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: TARN is a low energy, approximately 10 MeV/nucleon, ion storage ring that has been constructed in order to develop technologies the technical development for the high-energy ion accelerator project at INS. This storage ring can accumulate the beam from the injector cyclotron in both the longitudinal and transverse phase spaces. Up to now, proton, He plus //2 , alpha and **3 He plus beams have been stored. Twenty-turn beams are injected in the 87-mm/rad betatron phase space area by the multiturn injection method, and 15 pulses are RF stacked in the 2. 2% momentum space DELTA p/p. Overall stacking number is then attained at around 300 turns. RF stacking is performed with a repetition rate of 30 Hz and it requires approximately 0. 5 s to fill the two-phase spaces with beam. A stochastic momentum cooling experiment was conducted with a proton beam of 7 MeV. The beam signal pick-up and kicker are traveling wave type couplers with helical inner conductors. With adjustment of the amplifier gain to 107 db, the cooling time was measured at approximately 20 s.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; HELIUM; ION BEAMS; PROTONS; MOMENTUM COOLING; PHASE SPACE; RF STACKING; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; ACCELERATORS, CYCLOTRON

Authors: Carbajo J.J., Martin J.F., Hall J.A.
Title: ENERGY SAVINGS RESULTING FROM A GROUND-COUPLED AIR-TO-AIR HEAT PUMP.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Carbajo, J.J., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Martin, J.F., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Hall, J.A., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: It is shown that energy savings can be obtained by preheating or precooling the air source of a heat pump using the heat or the coolness naturally stored in the earth under a house with a crawl space. Experiments have been performed during the winter and summer seasons with three identical unoccupied houses equipped with heat pumps in three different configurations: conventional, single pass, and total recirculation mode. The house with the total recirculation mode was found to have the highest energy savings in winter. The house with the single pass mode was the most advantageous configuration in summer. Recommendations concerning implementation of ground-coupled systems are outlined.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HOUSES - Climate Control; HEAT OR COOLNESS STORED NATURALLY IN EARTH; HOUSE CRAWL SPACE USED FOR THERMAL STORAGE; PREHEATING OR PRECOOLING OF AIR SOURCE; SINGLE PASS MODE; TOTAL RECIRCULATION MODE; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Authors: Tomlinson J.J., Olszewski M., Geist G.A.
Title: COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF COOL STORAGE SYSTEMS BASED ON ICE AND CLATHRATES.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Tomlinson, J.J., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Olszewski, M., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Geist, G.A., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: A technical and economic analysis of three cool storage configurations using ice or clathrates is presented. Results of this analysis show that a direct contact system with a 6 degree C clathrate is the most energy efficient of the storage systems analyzed. The economic viability of cool thermal energy storage TES systems is directly related to the cooling load that can be shifted. However, to break even with a simple air conditioning system, a nonpressurized storage medium is found to be a requirement for cool storage systems.
Index Keywords: ICE - Applications; CLATHRATES; COOL STORAGE SYSTEMS ECONOMIC VIABILITY; COOLING LOAD SHIFTING; NONPRESSURIZED STORAGE MEDIUM; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE (TES); ENERGY STORAGE

Title: POSSIBILITIES OF CONJUGATING BINARY SOLUTIONS FOR THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lockheed Missiles & Space Co,, Huntsville, AL, USA, Lockheed Missiles & Space Co, Huntsville, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Grodzka, P.G., Lockheed Missiles & Space Co,, Huntsville, AL, USA, Lockheed Missiles & Space Co, Huntsville, AL, USA
Abstract: A concept for thermal energy storage (TES) has recently emerged that depends on the heats of mixing of a pair of different liquids at a critical solution temperature. The possibilities of the concept for chill and heat storage for residential and commercial purposes are reviewed and the results of material searches for the different applications are reported. An economic analysis of the concept for commercial chill storage shows that the concept compares favorably with ice storage systems.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Climate Control; LIQUIDS - Mixing; CHILL AND HEAT STORAGE; CONJUGATED BINARY SOLUTIONS; CRITICAL SOLUTION TEMPERATURE; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE (TES); ENERGY STORAGE

Title: FIELD TESTING OF AQUIFER THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kannberg, L.D., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Allen, R.D., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: Results of recent field and laboratory studies of aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) indicate both the problems and promise of the concept. Geohydrothermal modeling and field testing have demonstrated the ability to recover substantial quantities of aquifer-stored energy. However, the local hydrologic conditions play an important role in determining the recovery temperature and storage efficiency. Geochemistry is also an important factor, particularly for higher temperature ATES systems. Whereas available hydrothermal models are adequate to estimate the thermal performance of ATES systems, ATES geochemical models are still in their infancy. A description is given of geotechnical issues and the results of recent ATES research. The role of geohydrothermal analysis is explored, with particular attention to ATES modeling and field results. Geochemical issues are discussed in relation to recent field, laboratory, and modeling studies.
Index Keywords: GEOTHERMAL ENERGY - Hydrology; AQUIFER THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE (ATES); AQUIFER-STORED ENERGY; ENERGY RECOVERY; GEOCHEMICAL MODELS; GEOHYDROTHERMAL MODELING; AQUIFERS

Abstract: Seasonal energy storage aims to preserve energy for the needs of a sizable area and over an extended time span. The authors review characteristic experimental facilities for large-scale thermal energy storage in Canada, Scandinavia, and the rest of Europe.

Abstract: Three concepts for thermal energy storage at 900 degree C are discussed. Design and performance criteria for a raft thermocline system, a two-tank system, and a dual-media thermocline system are presented. Preliminary design and cost analyses are also included.

Abstract: A molten-salt-to-liquid metal direct contact heat exchanger is being developed for phase change thermal storage in central receiver solar thermal plants. The heat exchanger consists of a column of liquid metal into which molten salt is injected. Salt droplets that form at the injector orifices rise through the column and solidify as they transfer heat to the liquid metal. Initial experimental work to determine the heat exchanger performance limits is documented. Also, results of analyses to estimate costs for representative system designs are given.

Abstract: The authors report on an investigation into the addition of supporting electrolytes and dendrite inhibitors to the electrolyte of zinc bromide batteries and the improvement of the carbon-plastic electrodes. A 1-kw class (8 kWh) battery was produced for evaluation. This battery showed a good and stable energy efficiency of 80% after 130 cycles of 1. 25 kW 8 hours charge and 1. 0 kW 8 hours discharge. It is believed that this battery will meet the requirement of electrical power utilities in the future.

Title: FLYWHEEL PERFORMANCE: CURRENT STATE-OF-THE-ART.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Abstract: The fabrication and performance testing of advanced flywheels using composite media are described and discussed. Disk and rim concepts were examined. The flywheel materials consisted of S-glass, Kevlar, or graphite fibers with epoxy resins. Energy densities, at ultimate speed, of 80 Wh/kg were achieved with rim configurations. A design using an S-glass disk with a graphite rim proved to be an especially good performer; after completing a 10,000-cycle fatigue test, it was evaluated in the ultimate speed mode, where it attained a total stored energy of 644 Wh at an energy density of 63. 5 Wh/kg.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ADVANCED FLYWHEELS; FLYWHEEL MATERIALS; FLYWHEELS

Abstract: It is reported that superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) has potential for use in leveling electric utility loads on a large scale. The advantage of SMES over other energy-storage technologies is its high net energy efficiency. In 1981, the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) commissioned Bechtel Group, Inc. (Bechtel), in association with GA Technologies, Inc. (GA), to identify and detail an appropriate SMES configuration for the purpose of establishing a baseline capital cost. The authors briefly summarize the overall design, tabulate the costs, and discuss potential cost reductions.

Abstract: The design and performance characteristics of zinc-bromine batteries are described. Results of a detailed design/cost analysis on a 500-kWh/100 kW zinc-bromine system are presented. The 500-kWh system is conceived as a demonstration unit to be tested at the BEST facility. Using the BEST battery design as a starting point, a preliminary design study has been conducted on large-scale utility load leveling systems. The system configuration, cost, and balance of plant requirements were estimated.

Abstract: A sodium-sulfur battery for electric energy storage developed by the Yuasa Battery Company is described. The 1. 5-KW battery is composed of 10 units connected in series, each unit consisting of six 150 Ah cells connected in parallel. This battery was subjected to constant power discharge at 1. 46 kW and charge at 1. 70 kW. An average discharge current density of 63 mA/cm**2 , an average discharge voltage of 18. 2 V, and an energy efficiency (dc-dc) of approximately 85% have been obtained in tests. The 1. 5-kW battery is now under cycle life test by means of charge/discharge at constant current and constant power, showing a favorable results to date.
Index Keywords: SODIUM COMPOUNDS - Applications; SODIUM SULFUR BATTERY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Abstract: A latent thermal energy storage unit with pentaerythritol was developed, and in the storage unit an active heat transfer enhancement was performed. The phase change material, pentaerythritol, was mixed with a hydrocarbon heat transfer oil, and this two-phase storage medium was stirred in a shell-coil type heat exchanger. Through preliminary experiments in a glass vessel, a lab-scale storage unit of 1-kWh storage capacity was developed. The storage unit demonstrated the feature of latent thermal energy storage; constant-temperature output in both charge and discharge periods was observed.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; LATENT THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Abstract: Heat transfer experiments have been carried out on a 30-kWh latent heat storage unit using form-stable, high-density polyethylene. A numerical simulation has also been made to study the performance of the storage unit under various operating conditions. The thermal efficiency, storage capacity, and thermal insulation are discussed. It is shown that this storage unit possesses excellent performance characteristics.

Abstract: Results are discussed which established that the Tacoma superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit is a versatile and responsive device for power system testing and control. Endurance tests were run to assess the reliability of the SMES subsystems with a narrowband noise input, which is characteristic of the modulation signal for stabilizer operation.
