Authors with affiliations: Allen, R.D., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Doherty, T.J., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Schainker, R.B., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Istvan, J.A., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Pereira, J.C., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: A field experiment to examine the feasibility of full-scale compressed air energy storage (CAES) within aquifer reservoirs, initially sponsored by the US Department of Energy and currently sponsored by the Electric Power Research Institute, is described. Parameters investigated encompass storage and recovery operations within a single-well and two-well environment. Testing to date has demonstrated injection, storage, and cycling of air in an aquifer suitable for CAES application. Relationships between pressure, mass flow rate, temperature, and time are presented for some of the injection and withdrawal cycles.
Index Keywords: COMPRESSED AIR - Storage; AQUIFERS; COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Ariga Y., Nanahara T., Ishikawa R., Horiuchi N., Kaminosono H., Misaki H.
Title: OPTIMUM CAPACITIES OF BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM FOR UTILITY NETWORK AND THEIR ECONOMICS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Central Research Inst of Electrical, Power Industry, Komae, Jpn, Central Research Inst of Electrical Power Industry, Komae, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ariga, Y., Central Research Inst of Electrical, Power Industry, Komae, Jpn, Central Research Inst of Electrical Power Industry, Komae, Jpn; Nanahara, T., Central Research Inst of Electrical, Power Industry, Komae, Jpn, Central Research Inst of Electrical Power Industry, Komae, Jpn; Ishikawa, R., Central Research Inst of Electrical, Power Industry, Komae, Jpn, Central Research Inst of Electrical Power Industry, Komae, Jpn; Horiuchi, N., Central Research Inst of Electrical, Power Industry, Komae, Jpn, Central Research Inst of Electrical Power Industry, Komae, Jpn; Kaminosono, H., Central Research Inst of Electrical, Power Industry, Komae, Jpn, Central Research Inst of Electrical Power Industry, Komae, Jpn; Misaki, H., Central Research Inst of Electrical, Power Industry, Komae, Jpn, Central Research Inst of Electrical Power Industry, Komae, Jpn
Abstract: The size selected for battery storage capacity is shown to be influenced by the site, the load demand patterns of subtransmission and distribution substations, and the policies of a utility. The optimum size of the battery energy storage system used for load leveling has been determined, after analysis of several hundred load demand curves and the system operating mode, to be 10 to 30% of the subtransmission and distribution substation transformer capacity. In addition, the economics of a dispersed battery energy storage system are investigated.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Optimization; BATTERY STORAGE CAPACITY; SIZE SELECTION; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Landgrebe Albert R., Brodd Ralph, Ferrell D.T., Weinstock Irwin B.
Title: OPERATIONAL CHARACTERISTICS OF HIGH-PERFORMANCE BATTERIES FOR STATIONARY APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: US DOE, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Landgrebe, Albert R., US DOE, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Washington, DC, USA; Brodd, Ralph, US DOE, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Washington, DC, USA; Ferrell, D.T., US DOE, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Washington, DC, USA; Weinstock, Irwin B., US DOE, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The storage capacity, performance, life, and cost requirements for batteries in selected stationary energy storage applications are presented, and the technological status of the high-performance batteries being developed for these applications is reviewed. Candidate batteries are evaluated relative to their physical, environmental, and operational characteristics and the impacts of these on the suitability of the batteries for the target applications. Observations are made on issues such as hazardous operation, kind and degree of maintenance, and type and amount of gas evolution.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HIGH-PERFORMANCE BATTERIES; STATIONARY ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: SIZING A THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEM OF A SOLAR ELECTRIC PLANT FOR PEAKING APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace,, Denver, CO, USA, Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, Denver, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sterrett, R.H., Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace,, Denver, CO, USA, Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, Denver, CO, USA
Abstract: The methods used to size the storage system and formulate the dispatch strategy of a solar power plant to be used as a peaking facility are described. The requirements used to establish the sizing and dispatch logic are based upon maximizing the revenue stream and maintaining the operating limits of the equipment. The interactions of the receiver, storage, and power generation subsystems are analyzed graphically. The resulting dispatch strategy is compared with that of a stand alone solar power plant. The results indicate that the annual capacity for the peak period is increased by a factor of 3.
Index Keywords: SOLAR POWER PLANTS; DISPATCH STRATEGY; THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEM; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Fujiwara K., Fujii Y., Watakabe Y., Misaki H.
Title: DEVELOPMENT OF AN 8 KWH ZINC-CHLORIDE BATTERY.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Furukawa Electric Co, Jpn, Furukawa Electric Co, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Fujiwara, K., Furukawa Electric Co, Jpn, Furukawa Electric Co, Jpn; Fujii, Y., Furukawa Electric Co, Jpn, Furukawa Electric Co, Jpn; Watakabe, Y., Furukawa Electric Co, Jpn, Furukawa Electric Co, Jpn; Misaki, H., Furukawa Electric Co, Jpn, Furukawa Electric Co, Jpn
Abstract: The development of an 8-kWh zinc-chloride battery for energy storage is discussed. The development efforts have centered on electrode structure, techniques of dendrite prevention, activation of chlorine electrodes, and chlorine hydrate storage. In 1983 a trial 1-kW (8-kWh) battery was produced and was given its first interim test at the Government Industrial Research Institute in Osaka. The battery has since been receiving a cycle test, from which a charge-discharge energy efficiency of 75-80% is reported.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; CHARGE-DISCHARGE EFFICIENCY; ZINC CHLORIDE BATTERY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Petri Randy J., Ong Estela T., Olszewski Mitchell
Title: HIGH TEMPERATURE COMPOSITE THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Inst of Gas, Technology, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Inst of Gas Technology, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Petri, Randy J., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Inst of Gas, Technology, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Inst of Gas Technology, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Ong, Estela T., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Inst of Gas, Technology, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Inst of Gas Technology, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Olszewski, Mitchell, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Inst of Gas, Technology, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Inst of Gas Technology, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: An advanced thermal energy storage (TES) subsystem being developed by the Institute of Gas Technology, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, which uses composite phase change material (PCM)/sensible heat material media is described. This medium/subsystem is useful for high temperature thermal storage applications such as industrial reject/process heat recovery and utilization, off-peak utility and solar thermal power system applications. The concept allows for direct contact heat exchange between the latent/sensible storage media and compatible working fluids.
Index Keywords: WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; COMPOSITE PHASE CHANGE MATERIAL; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: CONCEPTUAL ENGINEERING DESIGN OF A 50-KW RECHARGEABLE ALKALINE ZINC/REDOX BATTERY.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Illinois Inst of Technology, Dep of, Chemical Engineering, Chicago, IL,, USA, Illinois Inst of Technology, Dep of Chemical Engineering, Chicago, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Selman, J.Robert, Illinois Inst of Technology, Dep of, Chemical Engineering, Chicago, IL,, USA, Illinois Inst of Technology, Dep of Chemical Engineering, Chicago, IL, USA; Hollansworth, Roger P., Illinois Inst of Technology, Dep of, Chemical Engineering, Chicago, IL,, USA, Illinois Inst of Technology, Dep of Chemical Engineering, Chicago, IL, USA
Abstract: A conceptual engineering design for a 50-kW solar storage battery system has been formulated on the basis of performance data of 60, 200, and 1000 cm**2 cells and physical property data collected from the literature or determined earlier. Starting with a cell performance model and a crystallizer model, mass and energy balances are analyzed using a modular design. Isothermal and adiabatic operations are considered, and thermal storage requirements are estimated.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; MASS TRANSFER; ENERGY BALANCES; MASS BALANCES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE FOR SPACECRAFT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gross, Sidney, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: Flywheel energy storage systems have been studied to determine their potential for use in spacecraft. The system described was found to be superior to alkaline secondary batteries and regenerative fuel cells in most of the areas that are important in spacecraft applications. The major disadvantages of flywheel energy storage systems are that power is not available during the launch phase without special provisions; and inflight failure of units may force shutdowns of good counter-rotating units, amplifying the effects of failure and limiting power distribution system options. Additional advantages and disadvantages are discussed.
Index Keywords: SPACECRAFT - Energy Resources; SPACE-VEHICLE ELECTRICAL SYSTEMS; FLYWHEELS

Authors: Mullin J.P., Byers D.C., Ambrus J.H., Loria J.C.
Title: NASA'S SPACE ENERGY TECHNOLOGY PROGRAM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Washington, DC, USA, NASA, Washington, DC, USA

Abstract: Recent technical progress in the areas of photovoltaics, chemical energy conversion and storage, thermal-to-electric conversion, power management and distribution, and thermal management are summarized. Technical options which enable and significantly benefit the exploitation and exploration of space are identified and evaluated for applications ranging from near-term to the next century.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; PHOTOVOLTAIC EFFECTS - Applications; SPACE ENERGY TECHNOLOGY; SPACE-VEHICLE ELECTRICAL SYSTEMS; SPACECRAFT

Title: ELECTROCHEMICAL ENERGY STORAGE TECHNOLOGY FOR FUTURE MILITARY SPACECRAFT NEEDS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Hughes Aircraft Co, El Segundo, CA,, USA, Hughes Aircraft Co, El Segundo, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Marcoux, Lynn, Hughes Aircraft Co, El Segundo, CA,, USA, Hughes Aircraft Co, El Segundo, CA, USA; Stedman, James K., Hughes Aircraft Co, El Segundo, CA,, USA, Hughes Aircraft Co, El Segundo, CA, USA
Abstract: Projected missions are grouped generically, and these generic missions are then equated with specific electrochemical energy storage technologies. The generic needs for spacecraft energy storage and the ongoing and recommended approaches to meeting these needs are discussed. Advanced nickel-hydrogen technology is described as are regenerative fuel cells and high energy density rechargeable battery systems.
Index Keywords: FUEL CELLS; SPACECRAFT - Military Purposes; MILITARY SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: SPACE STATION ELECTRICAL POWER SYSTEM TECHNOLOGY.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sorensen, Albert A., TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Abstract: The results of power system technology studies as applied to manned space stations including tradeoffs for power distribution system selection are described. Sizing and cost factors are provided for the more probable combinations of power sources, storage, and distribution approaches. The energy selection criteria and current system options are detailed.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Analysis; SPACE FLIGHT - Manned Flight; SPACE STATIONS; SPACE-VEHICLE ELECTRICAL SYSTEMS; SPACECRAFT

Title: ELECTRICAL POWER SYSTEMS FOR SPACE STATION.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent,, Houston, TX, USA, NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, Houston, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Simon, William E., NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent,, Houston, TX, USA, NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, Houston, TX, USA
Abstract: Challenges in power system development are described. Evolutionary growth, operational lifetime, and other design requirements are discussed. A pictorial view of weight-optimized power system applications shows which systems are best for missions of various lengths and required power level. Following definition of the major elements of the electrical power system, an overview of element options and a brief technology assessment are presented. Selected trade-study results show end-to-end system efficiencies, required photovoltaic power capability as a function of energy storage system efficiency, and comparisons with other systems such as a solar dynamic power system.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS; SPACE PLATFORMS; SPACE STATIONS; SPACE-VEHICLE ELECTRICAL SYSTEMS; SPACECRAFT

Authors: Manzo Michelle A., Hoberecht Mark A.
Title: 37. 5-KW POINT DESIGN COMPARISON OF THE NICKEL-CADMIUM BATTERY, BIPOLAR NICKEL-HYDROGEN BATTERY, AND REGENERATIVE HYDROGEN-OXYGEN FUEL CELL ENERGY STORAGE SUBSYSTEMS FOR LOW EARTH ORBIT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Manzo, Michelle A., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Hoberecht, Mark A., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Nickel-cadmum batteries, bipolar nickel-hydrogen batteries, and regenerative fuel cell storage subsystems were evaluated for use as the storage subsystem in a 37. 5-kW power system for a space station. Design requirements were set in order to establish a common baseline for comparison purposes. The storage subsystems were compared on the basis of effective energy density, round trip electrical efficiency, total subsystem weight and volume, and subsystem lifetime.
Index Keywords: FUEL CELLS; SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; NICKEL-CADMIUM BATTERIES; NICKEL-HYDROGEN BATTERIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: MULTI-KILOWATT SOLAR POWER SYSTEM CONCEPT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: GE, Valley Forge, PA, USA, GE, Valley Forge, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kirpich, A., GE, Valley Forge, PA, USA, GE, Valley Forge, PA, USA; Chung, A., GE, Valley Forge, PA, USA, GE, Valley Forge, PA, USA
Abstract: The conceptual design of a multikilowatt solar power system is presented. The concept uses two flat-pack SEP solar arrays having beginning-of-life output of 25 kW. A limited amount of energy storage is used to maintain the payload during eclipse periods. The system has been designed for a geosynchronous orbit. Key technical issues of this concept are the use of a high distribution voltage and the effects of electrostatic discharge associated with the large solar array area. Assessments of these issues are presented together with approaches for reducing deleterious effects to acceptable levels.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; ELECTROSTATICS; SOLAR CELLS; GEOSYNCHRONOUS ORBITS; SATELLITE COMMUNICATION; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Watanabe Toshiharu, Menjoh Atsuhiko, Ishikawa Michihiro, Kumagai Junpei
Title: STACKED SIO//2 /SI//3 N//4 /SIO//2 DIELECTRIC LAYER FOR RELIABLE MEMORY CAPACITOR.
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Jpn, Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Watanabe, Toshiharu, Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Jpn, Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Jpn; Menjoh, Atsuhiko, Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Jpn, Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Jpn; Ishikawa, Michihiro, Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Jpn, Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Jpn; Kumagai, Junpei, Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Jpn, Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Jpn
Abstract: The leakage current of an MIS capacitor with a stacked film is sufficiently small. It is explained by a model with Fowler-Nordheim current in SiO//2 and Poole-Frenkel current in Si//3 N//4 . Using this model, the flat band voltage shifts of the MIS capacitor are estimated to be less than 1 V under an operating voltage of 5 V. Compared with MOS capacitors, the stacked MIS capacitors show a lower failure rate of time-zero dielectric breakdown, a smaller electric field acceleration factor, and a comparable activation energy of time dependent dielectric breakdown. The stacked layer appears useful as a dielectric layer for dynamic memories with small geometry.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Random Access; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MIS - Reliability; DIELECTRIC BREAKDOWN; FOWLER-NORDHEIM CURRENT; LEAKAGE CURRENT; MIS CAPACITORS; POOLE-FRENKEL CURRENT; FILMS

Authors: Boucher M., Pottier M., Lenoir Y., Lidin R., Cardi JM., Morand P.
Title: OPTIMAL CONTROL STRATEGY OF SOLAR HEATING SYSTEMS USING A LONG TERM HEAT STORAGE.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Gaz de France, Paris, Fr, Gaz de France, Paris, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Boucher, M., Gaz de France, Paris, Fr, Gaz de France, Paris, Fr; Pottier, M., Gaz de France, Paris, Fr, Gaz de France, Paris, Fr; Lenoir, Y., Gaz de France, Paris, Fr, Gaz de France, Paris, Fr; Lidin, R., Gaz de France, Paris, Fr, Gaz de France, Paris, Fr; Cardi, JM., Gaz de France, Paris, Fr, Gaz de France, Paris, Fr; Morand, P., Gaz de France, Paris, Fr, Gaz de France, Paris, Fr
Abstract: The principal purposes of this research are estimation of the energy gain expected from optimizing the control of a given gas/solar heating system using long term heat storage in the ground and development of a design tool able to take optimal strategies into account. Computer simulations show that for the studied system, energygains of around 20% for auxiliary energy consumption can be obtained through optimized management.

Title: DESCRIPTION AND EXPERIMENTAL LONG RANGE EVALUATION OF A SOLAR ELECTRIC PLANT INSTALLED IN A RESIDENTIAL BUILDING IN SOUTHERN ITALY.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: ENEL, Milan, Italy, ENEL, Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Parrini, F., ENEL, Milan, Italy, ENEL, Milan, Italy; Viadana, R., ENEL, Milan, Italy, ENEL, Milan, Italy; Viti, N., ENEL, Milan, Italy, ENEL, Milan, Italy; Biondo, A., ENEL, Milan, Italy, ENEL, Milan, Italy; Filinceri, C., ENEL, Milan, Italy, ENEL, Milan, Italy
Abstract: In 1979/80 ENEL installed and monitored heating and DHW solar system in a six-flat building located near the Rossano Calabro (Cosenza) thermal power plant. The main purpose of the installation was to verify the solar contribution to the winter building load in a climatically favourable site with a plant built of non-selective solar collectors. The measurements during five winter seasons had a value of solar fraction about 20-25% and an average collecting efficiency of about 20-25%.

Title: COMBINED SOLAR SYSTEM FOR SPACE HEATING AND DOMESTIC HOT WATER SUPPLY: PERFORMANCE MEASURING DATA FROM THE DANISH PILOT TEST FACILITY.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Denmark, Technical Univ of Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Andersen, N.B., Technical Univ of Denmark, Technical Univ of Denmark
Abstract: A combined space heating system is introduced. The solar storage consists of a hot water preheating tank submerged in a bigger outer storage unit. The heat distribution system is extended by a separate radiator. A computer model of the system is confirmed by measured data and the yearly performance is found by extrapolation.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION - Denmark; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; WATER HEATERS - Solar; EFFICIENCY; SOLAR PILOT TEST FACILITY; SPACE HEATING SYSTEM; TEST RIGS; HEATING

Title: ACTIVE SOLAR BUILDING OF BOURGOIN-JALLIEU - LESSONS FROM 5 YEARS OF MEASUREMENTS.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: CNRS, Grenoble, Fr, CNRS, Grenoble, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Kuhn, G., CNRS, Grenoble, Fr, CNRS, Grenoble, Fr; Pataud, P., CNRS, Grenoble, Fr, CNRS, Grenoble, Fr
Abstract: General purpose of this work was to measure actual performances of a big active solar heating system and to test detailed computer models. The Bourgoin-Jallieu Solar Building is a very good example of first generation active solar systems, which has proved at least the reliability of the components and the interest of heating floors associated to solar collectors. The mean productivity of the vertical collectors is about 160 kWh/m**2. The thermal mass of the building, increased by the heating floors, provides good thermal inertia (one week effects) leading to a small auxiliary energy consumption. A sensitivity study of the size of the main solar components was also performed.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Solar, Active; ENERGY CONSERVATION - France; ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; COMPUTER APPLICATIONS; FLOOR HEATING; HEAT STORAGE; MASOL SIMULATION METHOD; TRNSYS SIMULATION METHOD; HEATING

Title: PERFORMANCE OF AIR COOLED COLLECTOR SYSTEMS IN DUTCH FIELD TESTS.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: TNO, Delft, Neth, TNO, Delft, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Brethouwer, D.E., TNO, Delft, Neth, TNO, Delft, Neth
Abstract: Since 1975 the Technisch Physische Dienst TNO-TH in Delft has monitored five solar assisted heating systems that have air cooled collectors. The data gathered is used to record performance and validate a computer simulation model. In general, the performance of the systems was disappointing. The annual output per m**2 of collector area ranged from 35 to 300 MJ (10 to 80 kWh). This was caused by incorrect assumptions in the design phase and many small technical failures. As an example of a system in which some recommendations have been brought into practice, the double flow solar heater of Isomur is presented.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; ENERGY CONSERVATION - Netherlands; ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; AIR COOLED COLLECTORS; FLAT PLATE COLLECTORS; HEAT STORAGE; HEATING

Title: MEASUREMENT OF PASSIVE SOLAR GAIN WITHIN THE PROJECT 'LANDSTUHL'.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Fraunhofer-Inst fuer Bauphysik, Stuttgart, West Ger, Fraunhofer-Inst fuer Bauphysik, Stuttgart, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Oswald, D., Fraunhofer-Inst fuer Bauphysik, Stuttgart, West Ger, Fraunhofer-Inst fuer Bauphysik, Stuttgart, West Ger
Abstract: In the Landstuhl project, the investigations take place with people living in the houses. The 26 buildings contain both active and passive solar components, but the investigations concentrated on passive solar gains. The most important aim was to determine the annual heating energy consumption and the solar contribution. The efficiency of the individual components was also of interest. A computer simulation shows an annual heating energy consumption of 75 kWh/m**2 and a solar contribution of 54%.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Solar, Passive; COMPUTER SIMULATION; ENERGY CONSERVATION - Federal Republic of Germany; ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT STORAGE; LANDSTUHL PROJECT; PASSIVE SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEMS; HEATING

Authors: van Hattem D., Actis Dato P., Tebaldi P.
Title: THREE YEARS OF ARRAY PERFORMANCE OF DIFFERENT TYPES OF EVACUATED TUBULAR SOLAR COLLECTORS.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Commission of the European, Communities, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Ispra, Italy
Authors with affiliations: van Hattem, D., Commission of the European, Communities, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Ispra, Italy; Actis Dato, P., Commission of the European, Communities, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Ispra, Italy; Tebaldi, P., Commission of the European, Communities, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Ispra, Italy
Abstract: The scope of the work presented in this paper is to make a detailed experimental performance assessment of arrays of different types of evacuated tubular collectors operating between 80 and 100 degree C. The arrays were mounted on the Solar Laboratory of the Joint Research Centre in Ispra for various cooling experiments. The evacuated collectors used are the Sanyo STC-CU-250, Philips VTR 261 and Philips VTR 361. The experiments showed that good efficiencies may be obtained with evacuated tubular collectors. During summer conditions, daily collector efficiencies of around 50% have been measured at operating temperatures of about 60 degree C above ambient temperature. The results demonstrate that evacuated tubular collectors could be promising for applications where high operation temperatures are required.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION - Italy; ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; EVACUATED TUBE COLLECTORS; HEAT STORAGE; HIGH TEMPERATURE; SOLAR COOLING; HEATING

Title: SWEDISH SOLAR HEATING PLANTS WITH SEASONAL STORAGE - SYSTEM DESIGN INFLUENCE ON THERMAL PERFORMANCE AND ECONOMY.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Chalmers Univ of Technology, Goteborg, Swed, Chalmers Univ of Technology, Goteborg, Swed
Authors with affiliations: Dalenback, J.-O., Chalmers Univ of Technology, Goteborg, Swed, Chalmers Univ of Technology, Goteborg, Swed; Jilar, T., Chalmers Univ of Technology, Goteborg, Swed, Chalmers Univ of Technology, Goteborg, Swed
Abstract: Two Swedish group solar heating plants with seasonal storage connected to residential areas with about 50 single-family houses have been in operation for four years. The Lambohov Plant has a total of 2700 m**2 of flat plate collectors and a 10,000 m**3 rock pit storage. The Ingelstad plant has a total of 1300 m**2 of concentrating collectors and a 5000 m**3 free-standing tank. The emphasis of the assessment has been on system performance.

Authors: Marshall R.H., Kenna J.P., Lloyd P.B.
Title: SEU DESIGN METHOD.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Univ Coll, Cardiff, Wales, Univ Coll, Cardiff, Wales
Authors with affiliations: Marshall, R.H., Univ Coll, Cardiff, Wales, Univ Coll, Cardiff, Wales; Kenna, J.P., Univ Coll, Cardiff, Wales, Univ Coll, Cardiff, Wales; Lloyd, P.B., Univ Coll, Cardiff, Wales, Univ Coll, Cardiff, Wales
Abstract: The SEU Design Method (SEUDM) is an algorithm for predicting the performance of liquid-based solar heating systems. It is applicable to domestic hot water (DHW), space heating and combined systems and is intended as an aid to architects and design engineers in rapid assessment of design options. The derivation of the method is based on putting the differential equation for the heat store into a non-dimensional form. The performance of the system is represented by the 'solar fraction', F, the fraction of the heating load that is met with solar energy.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; WATER HEATERS - Solar; HEAT STORAGE; SEU DESIGN METHOD (SEUDM); SOLAR FRACTION; HEATING

Title: SIMULATION OF SOLAR AIR-HEATING SYSTEMS.

Affiliations: Univ Stuttgart, West Ger, Univ Stuttgart, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Fisch, N., Univ Stuttgart, West Ger, Univ Stuttgart, West Ger; Hahne, E., Univ Stuttgart, West Ger, Univ Stuttgart, West Ger
Abstract: The application of air collectors and pebble bed storage bins in solar heating of houses and domestic hot water was investigated. Based on measured meteorological data and fixed building parameters and component parameters, the solar fraction is determined using a computer program. This program (SIMUL) is capable of four air collector constructions and eight system configurations. Using hourly weather data of three locations in the Federal Republic of Germany, a parametric study was performed.

Abstract: The work provides an easy-to-use design tool that avoids the computer time needed by large simulation models. Simple correlations can be found between the solar fraction and functions of the input parameters (characteristics of the collector array, storage units, distribution pipes, heat demand and meterological data). The agreement between the computer model and the simple method is better than 10% for small values of the solar fraction.

Abstract: The easy-to-use calculation methods presented concern heating systems using air or liquid solar collectors connected to a packed bed or liquid short term storage unit. Abstract: The optimal size of the short term storage system in a solar hot water system depends on meteorological data. The crucial link connecting these data with the properties of the collectors, the heat demand and the storage size, is the amount of backup energy per year which has to be secured from secondary sources. The authors propose that this connection can be formulated by statistical concepts.

Title: BUILDING COMPONENTS WITH INTEGRATED LATENT HEAT STORAGE.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR

Authors with affiliations: Pellegrini, G., Commission of the European, Communities, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Ispra, Italy; Colombo, R., Commission of the European, Communities, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Ispra, Italy
Abstract: In many climates the fluctuation of indoor air temperature in passive solar buildings can be reduced by an appropriate design of the thermal mass. An optimization of the thermal mass can be achieved using advanced storage concepts like latent heat salts, implying that the storage component is an integral part of the building envelope as part of the ceiling, floor and walls. Latent heat storage materials are attractive because of their relatively high storage capacity and because of the isothermal nature of the storage process which improves living comfort.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Solar, Passive; ENERGY STORAGE; LATENT HEAT STORAGE; PASSIVE SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEMS; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; POLYMER CONCRETE BLOCKS; HEATING

Abstract: In dwelling with mechanical ventilation systems the fresh air can be preheated by simple solar air systems. These can be an integral part of the building facade or roof and the costs are expected to be low. By means of computer experiments, a number of systems were evaluated. These systems can provide energy gains providing the system is well dimensioned and has a storage system.

Abstract: Transparent PMMA insulation material has the property of being transparent or translucent to solar radiation while at the same time acting as heat insulation. Elements made of this material can be attached to the walls of buildings thus permit utilization of solar energy for heating. Relations are given for the dependence of heat flux and conversion efficiency of radiation into useful heat on the thermal resistance of the components. The beneficial effect of masonry walls with regard to heat storage and damping of temperature fluctuations is also demonstrated.

Abstract: South-facing vertical walls (trombe walls) forming the structural support for a building and acting at the same time as solar collector-storage elements are being evaluated theoretically and experimentally in various laboratories. The characteristics and design of a latent heat storage curtain wall for air conditioning integrated in a hybrid solar building are discussed from the point of view of the local climatological data and energy saving potential. The wall combines the functions of collecting, storing and releasing solar heat at ambient temperature through fan-assisted air circulation.

Abstract: The aim of this project was to develop a passive solar heating system with a higher efficiency than concrete thermal storage walls and with restricted extra costs for manufacturing the system. This is to be achieved by three special components: 1) a heat pipe as a thermal diode tube for efficient transfer of collected solar heat from the absorber to the back of an insulation layer; 2) a heat storage section with water or a phase change material; and 3) an extra insulation sheet with vents between the storage and the room for controlled transfer of heat into the room.

Abstract: The paper covers the goals and experience from the solar program from 1976 onwards. Seasonal storage concepts and solar collector development have been successful and energy costs for domestic hot water in multifamily buildings, solar collectors connected to small district heating networks, and solar seasonal storage are almost competitive to oil fired plants.

Abstract: A small size room model using a Trombe wall system has been designed to study a qualitative as well as quantitative approach to convection and heat transfer aspects. The results show air flow motion inside the room, the influence of each wall on the thermal balance and convective heat transfer inside the system.

Abstract: A low cost, durable coating suitable for constructing passive walls and for applying to flat plate solar collectors which was developed by Inco Alloy Products Technical Centre and marketed under the trade name MAXORB, consists of a nickel oxide coating produced continuously on a thin nickel foil. The material is supplied in three forms: a dry foil which can be applied to walls pre-treated with an adhesive; with the reverse side coated with a silicone pressure sensitive adhesive; and, with the foil bonded to a copper or aluminium strip. Selective surfaces are a cost effective means of increasing the thermal output of storage walls for space heating.

Abstract: The author studied ethanol production from fermented lactoserum. The raw fermented liquor is processed in a distillation plant able to produce 5 to 10 l/h of azeotropic ethanol. Selective flat plate collectors deliver the required energy to the column. Authors with affiliations: Reuss, M., Bayerische Landesanstalt fuer, Landtechnik, Freising-Weihenstephan,, West Ger, Bayerische Landesanstalt fuer Landtechnik, Freising-Weihenstephan, West Ger; Meuren, K., Bayerische Landesanstalt fuer, Landtechnik, Freising-Weihenstephan,, West Ger, Bayerische Landesanstalt fuer Landtechnik, Freising-Weihenstephan, West Ger; Vogt, S., Bayerische Landesanstalt fuer, Landtechnik, Freising-Weihenstephan,, West Ger, Bayerische Landesanstalt fuer Landtechnik, Freising-Weihenstephan, West Ger
Abstract: Some farms in Germany have a demand of heat at low temperatures (30 degree C-50 degree C) for heating stables, feeding calves or heating domestic hot water which could be provided by solar-assisted heating systems. Two self-built low cost collectors and a storage tank have been installed and tested. The solar contribution in 1983 was 100% in summer and 90% in autumn. The total investment was about 24,000 DM, the costs of maintenance are 250 DM/a and the energy savings are 1,900 DM/a.

Abstract: Measured data on a test installation comprising 12 m**2 of Philips heat pipe evacuated tubular collector, connected to a single pressurized storage device for both hot water and heating supply, have been used for validation of a computer model. Based on this, monthly and annual system performance for a typical central European domestic application has been analyzed. The useful solar energy of a hot water system, overdimensioned with respect to the collector area, is improved by coupling to the heating circuit. Simulation results are presented concerning performance with respect to flat plate collectors, different heating loads and varying collector and storage dimensions.

Authors with affiliations: Pedersen, Peder Vejsig, Technical Univ of Denmark, Den, Technical Univ of Denmark, Den
Abstract: An experimental solar water heater with natural circulation has been in operation since 1981. In a building project for 55 houses the compact thermosyphon solar water heater has been integrated as part of a south facing wall with a tilt of 59 degree . The solar collector has a selective stainless steel absorber and the wall storage tank has a volume of 150 litres. This solar system represents an extra investment of 1000 compared to a normal electric water heater.

Abstract: The performance of the solar hot water system at Changi International Airport Services, Singapore, is presented. This system uses about 630 m**2 of a solar collector with storage to provide a daily average hot water consumption of 46. 7 m**3 at 70 degree C. The system can provide a solar fraction of 0. 60 of the load.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION - Singapore; WATER HEATERS - Solar; MALAYSIA; SOLAR FRACTION; HEATING

Title: ANALYSIS AND DESIGN OF SOLAR PROCESS WATER HEATING SYSTEMS WITHOUT STORAGE FOR INDUSTRIAL AND COMMERCIAL APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Univ Coll, Galway, Irel, Univ Coll, Galway, Irel
Authors with affiliations: Monaghan, P.F., Univ Coll, Galway, Irel, Univ Coll, Galway, Irel; Golem, P.J., Univ Coll, Galway, Irel, Univ Coll, Galway, Irel
Abstract: The objective of this project is to determine under what conditions it is cost-effective to eliminate thermal storage from solar process water heating systems. Five actual buildings in the southern Ontario area of Canada were selected. For each situation, solar heating systems with and without storage were designed and construction cost estimates and estimates of solar energy collection were made. In a majority of the situations evaluated, it is cost-effective to design solar process water heating systems without storage.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ENERGY CONSERVATION - Canada; ENERGY STORAGE; WATER HEATERS - Solar; HEAT STORAGE; SOLAR FRACTION; HEATING

Title: COMPARISON OF FIVE SOLAR SYSTEMS FOR HEATING GREENHOUSES.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Fraunhofer-Inst fuer Systemtechnik, und Innovationsforschung, Karlsruhe,, West Ger, Fraunhofer-Inst fuer Systemtechnik und Innovationsforschung, Karlsruhe, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Reichert, J., Fraunhofer-Inst fuer Systemtechnik, und Innovationsforschung, Karlsruhe,, West Ger, Fraunhofer-Inst fuer Systemtechnik und Innovationsforschung, Karlsruhe, West Ger
Abstract: Five greenhouses equipped with different solar heating systems have been built in Bonn. Performance of the systems has been monitored for about two years to establish energy balances for the houses. The systems considered are groundwater heat pump, rock bed storage and the greenhouse itself acting as collector, concentrating collectors with water storage, venetian blind air collectors with rock bed storage, flat plate collectors consisting of rotating lamellas with stratified water storage and a heat pump. The payback periods of the air systems are about 20 years and have been calculated on the basis of estimated costs for rock bed storage and climatic data of Hamburg and Bonn.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ENERGY CONSERVATION - Federal Republic of Germany; GREENHOUSES - Space Heating; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; SOLAR ENERGY - Collectors; CONCENTRATING COLLECTORS; ENERGY STORAGE; FLAT PLATE COLLECTORS; HEAT STORAGE; HEATING

Title: SOLAR HEATING OF A LARGE OFFICE BUILDING USING SEASONAL AQUIFIER THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Heidemij Adviesbureau BV, Heidemij Adviesbureau BV
Authors with affiliations: Snijders, A.L., Heidemij Adviesbureau BV, Heidemij Adviesbureau BV; de Wit, K., Heidemij Adviesbureau BV, Heidemij Adviesbureau BV
Abstract: A technical and economical comparison has been made between two different solar systems for the space heating of a large office building. One system is based on high performance solar collectors in combination with aquifer thermal energy storage at a high temperature level; the other system, on low performance collectors and aquifer heat storage at a low temperature level. A heat pump is applied in the latter system. From a technical point of view the system with high performance collectors achieves higher fossil fuel savings. From an economical point of view, the high temperature system will not be attractive before the year 2000, even under favourable conditions. The low temperature system will be attractive under favourable conditions in 1990.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS; ECONOMICS; ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; FUEL SAVINGS; HEAT STORAGE; HEATING

Abstract: In northern France, an industrial building is heated by an air solar collector and a system of air pipes buried in the soil below the building in such a way that the whole energetic chain works half as an inter-seasonal system and half as a direct heating system. Authors with affiliations: Jaffrin, A., CNRS, Valbonne, Fr, CNRS, Valbonne, Fr; della Faille, M., CNRS, Valbonne, Fr, CNRS, Valbonne, Fr
Abstract: Natural excess heat generated during sunny days can be used for night requirements provided one finds a suitable storage medium and an efficient exchanger geometry. A phase change material derived from calcium chloride with a fusion temperature range of 20 degree to 24 degree C was developed. Full scale experiments were conducted in greenhouses operating both with an air loop for solar heat recovery and an air exchanger structure for PCM storage. Thermal performance as well as economic prospects are analysed for a rose plantation and a plant nursery on tables.

Abstract: Sensible and latent heat techniques are used for short-term storage. The paper stresses costs and required material characteristics.

Title: WORK WITHIN THE INTERNATIONAL ENERGY AGENCY ON CENTRAL SOLAR HEATING PLANTS WITH SEASONAL STORAGE.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR

Authors with affiliations: Boysen, Arne, Bengt Hidemark Gosta Danielson, Arkitektkontor HB, Stockholm, Swed, Bengt Hidemark Gosta Danielson Arkitektkontor HB, Stockholm, Swed
Abstract: An agreement was signed in 1979 by 10 member countries of the International Energy Agency (IEA) to determine the technical feasibility and cost effectiveness of large scale, seasonal storage solar energy systems for heating of buildings. The first phase reports present engineering data and cost information for five generic types of solar collectors, six heat storage concepts, and heat distribution systems for the collector/storage loop as well as for the storage/house load loop. Mathematical models of all subsystems are combined in computer codes, which can be used for simulation as well as optimization of design. Ten designs have been presented. The work is being continued in Phase II as a parametric analysis in order to evaluate different system configurations.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; HEAT STORAGE; SEASONAL STORAGE; HEATING

Abstract: The system uses two underground concrete storage tanks filled with water as the heat store and makes use of an existing tunnel network for placement of the heat distribution pipe network. The system includes a heat pump and is designed to supply about 1000 MWH of solar heat to displace the hot water and space heat demand.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION - United States; ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; FLAT PLATE COLLECTORS; HEAT STORAGE; SEASONAL STORAGE; HEATING

Title: VALIDATION OF THE GENERALIZED MODEL BASED STORAGE TEST PROCEDURE BY MEANS OF DYNAMIC SIMULATION TESTS.

Affiliations: Univ Coll Cardiff, Cardiff, Wales, Univ Coll Cardiff, Cardiff, Wales
Authors with affiliations: Marshall, R.H., Univ Coll Cardiff, Cardiff, Wales, Univ Coll Cardiff, Cardiff, Wales
Abstract: Using a test procedure under development by the Solar Storage Testing Group, sponsored by the Commission of European Communities, a solar storage device is to be characterized by six or more parameters using step response tests. After defining a suitable dynamic test sequence and the criteria for judging the outcome, a typical result for one of three dynamic tests aimed at validating the generalized model is described. Comparisons are made between the measured solar fraction and that derived from the SEU simplified design method.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT STORAGE; SEU METHOD; HEATING

Title: SALT GRADIENT SOLAR POND FOR SOLAR HEAT COLLECTION AND LONG TERM STORAGE.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Univ of Sussex, Brighton, Engl, Univ of Sussex, Brighton, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Unsworth, P.J., Univ of Sussex, Brighton, Engl, Univ of Sussex, Brighton, Engl; Al-Saleh, N., Univ of Sussex, Brighton, Engl, Univ of Sussex, Brighton, Engl
Abstract: An experimental salt gradient has been built to study the modelling, construction, operation, and monitoring of solar ponds. A new method of heat extraction is described whereby heat is extracted via heat exchangers placed in both the insulation and storage zones of the pond. Extraction from the insulation layer intercepts heat which would otherwise be lost to the surface and permits increases in pond efficiency. The external surface heat transfer coefficient between a tubular heat exchanger and the non-convecting pond fluid has been measured.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT EXCHANGERS; HEAT TRANSFER - Tubes; HEAT STORAGE; SOLAR PONDS; HEATING

Affiliations: Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Morofsky, Edward, Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Chant, Verne, Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont, Can; LeFeuvre, Thomas, Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Hickling, James F., Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont,, Can, Public Works Canada, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: The Scarborough Government of Canada Building will have seasonal aquifer thermal energy storage associated with it. The building also has short-term storage tanks for heating and cooling. Possible energy sources for aquifer storage include solar, building waste heat, and ambient air temperatures. This paper examines the feasibility of using the upper aquifer for hot water storage while simultaneously storing cold water in the lower aquifer. Such an option would involve waste heat recovery, solar energy collection, and heat pumps to meet the space heating requirements of the building. Construction costs are based on actual project costs.

Abstract: Computer simulation programs have been used for determining the performance and energy flows of a district solar heating system with annual heat storage at the Kerava solar village (60 degree N). Simulated performance has been compared to measured values. On a yearly basis, a 40-50 percent solar fraction may be expected in the Kerava solar village. The study also reveals the importance of system control on overall performance.

Abstract: In Groningen, a project with seasonal storage of solar heat in the upper layer of the soil will be realized. The total solar energy system will involve 96 solar houses. In this paper, the results of validation of heat storage models are discussed.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION - Netherlands; GREENHOUSES - Energy Storage; GROUND STORAGE; HEAT STORAGE; SEASONAL STORAGE; HEATING

Title: SUNCLAY AND KULLAVIK PROJECTS - HEAT STORAGE IN CLAY AT LOW AND HIGH TEMPERATURE.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR

Authors with affiliations: Olsson, S., AB Anderson & Hultmark, Goteborg, Swed, AB Anderson & Hultmark, Goteborg, Swed
Abstract: The Sunclay-project is the heating system of a school in Kungsbacka, Sweden. It is one of the first projects where clay is used for heat storage. The temperature of the clay is raised to 14-15 degree C by solar collectors during the summer months. During the winter diesel heat pumps lower the temperature to 9 degree C. Results from the operating period are presented. In Kullavik, 58 dwellings are supplied with heat and domestic hot water from a heating system which consists of solar collectors, ground heat storage, zones, a heat pump and boiler.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION - Sweden; ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; WATER HEATERS - Solar; CLAY STORAGE; GROUND STORAGE; HEAT STORAGE; HEATING

Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR

Abstract: In 1982 a solar heated one-family home with 130 m**2 heated area was completed at the site of the Fachhochschule Luebeck. The heat storage concept utilizes the insolation surplus in summer and winter insolation. This was achieved by a heat pump-assisted solar heating system centered around a twin water storage tanks of different function: a tank kept at 35 to 50 degree C takes care of the heat demand of the heating system and another tank serves as a heat reservoir and mid-winter heat source for the heat pump. The good performance and the low energy consumption during the first two years of operation demonstrate the feasibility of the concept.

Abstract: This paper analyses the results of step input tests on a direct water store. Three common types of inlet port configuration were studied over a range of flow conditions. The depth of penetration of the inlet flow obeys a correlation derived using dimensional analysis. The outlet temperature response and thermal effectiveness of the store are determined by this depth of penetration. A one-dimensional, finite difference computer model to predict the response behaviour is described.

Abstract: The results from experimental testing of a latent heat storage unit containing calcium chloride hexahydrate are presented. Thermal performance data are evaluated by a quasi-stationary heat transport model. The procedure employed seems well suited for the rating and optimization of latent heat storage units.

Abstract: The thermochemical reaction of silicagel-water is suitable for long term storage of solar energy. There is no thermal degradation and charging temperatures of 75 degree C are sufficient. The useful heat from the storage depends on temperature and humidity of the inlet air, and line temperature of the heating system at discharge. A computer model investigated the annual performance of a system in a low energy house commercially available in Germany.

Abstract: The paper covers selection of optimum storage for solar heating systems for domestic hot water supply and gives rules-of-thumb for storage volume and collector area. Design of heat exchange spirals and heat transfer calculations are discussed.

The aim of this project has been to design large underground warm water storage as a pilot project for seasonal storage. In order to minimize construction costs the pit has been left uninsulated and the lid floats on the water surface.

Abstract: Warm water pits, uninsulated towards the soil, are suited for seasonal heat storage. Limiting the insulation to the top surface will contribute to a construction price reduction which is important if seasonal storage is to be economically feasible. The design work was based on geotechnical investigations of the site.

Abstract: The equivalent storage temperature method for determining the overall heat transfer coefficient of thermal storage embedded materials is presented. Abstract: A chemical heat store using sodium sulphide as absorbent and water as the working medium utilizing the chemical heat pump principle was constructed and tested. The system has a quick response to changes in discharging rates but much of the stored energy is required to heat the system from storage temperature to working temperature and energy is lost to the surroundings through the surface of the storage tank.

Abstract: From field trials between 1980 and 1983 in (Grenoble, France, 45 degree north lattitude, a simplified numerical model of the storage behaviour was validated. Abstract: The volumetric heat loss coefficient G//S//E (W m** minus **3 k** minus **1) is a sufficient parameter to determine the annual heat losses of a storage unit when the annual average outdoor temperature is taken as the reference temperature. This work aims to replace numerical techniques by a simple method that leads to determination of the volumetric heat loss coefficient of heat storage. The walls of an in-ground heat storage are divided in typical elements, the heat losses of which have been predetermined by a finite element program.

Abstract: The system uses passive solar energy, the facade as a warm air collector, a transparent insulation system, hollow ceilings and inside walls as air ducts and distribution system, internal building components as energy storage devices, and integration of storage material in internal building components. The system was installed in Stuttgart.

Abstract: For application of phase change materials in heat storage devices, there is a need for a simple description of the heat transfer process with apparent thermal conductivity, particulary if an embedded metal structure is used to enhance conductivity. Measurements show that apparent thermal conductivity could be determined from temperature measurements during cooling down. Numerical calculations were carried out to investigate the influence of properties of the phase change material.

Abstract: A rock bed thermal storage was built in 1981 at the Sophia Antipolis campus. It has been used for various cycles corresponding to the heat charge, discharge and thermal relaxation. Conduction losses combined with convective effects in the air/pebble medium make use of such a system unefficient for storage over periods longer than one or two months.

Title: PROJECT WOLFSBURG-GLOCKENBERG, IEA-TASK VII: CENTRAL HEATING PLANTS WITH SEASONAL STORAGE.

Abstract: Within the IEA-Task VII 'Central Solar Heating Plants with Seasonal Storage, a solar-assisted low temperature district heating system has been designed for a new housing area in Wolfsburg-Glockenberg. 80 % of the total heat load has to be covered by solar energy. It is the aim of the study to optimize the system and prove the technical and economical feasibility of the concept. System optimization was performed with a simulation programme (SEASON) with hourly data for a year. The study shows that solar assisted district heating systems are an option for utilization of solar thermal. A high solar factor can be reached by seasonal storage.

Abstract: The experimental observations support an analytical description of the charge and discharge process of an encapsulated PCM storage. A numerical model is used to predict the transient behavior of the unit during charging, discharging and relaxation periods. The computer code is TRNSYS compatible. The performance of systems relying on either PCM or rock bed storage units are compared on a daily and seasonal basis. The conclusions are processed by a micro-economic model to determine payback periods.

Abstract: A heat storage system can be applied if heat supply and heat demand are out of phase. The main characteristics of the heat store are the temperature-dependent storage capacity, heat exchange capacity rate from storage material to heat transfer medium for both charging and discharging and the heat loss rate. Optimization of the different storage parameters is dependent on system design.

Title: IN FLIGHT PERFORMANCE OF A SIX AMPERE-HOUR NICKEL-CADMIUM BATTERY IN LOW EARTH ORBIT.

Authors with affiliations: McDermott, Joseph K., Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace,, Denver, CO, USA, Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, Denver, CO, USA
Abstract: A low earth orbit spacecraft has successfully completed over 17,000 orbital cycles. The energy storage system for this spacecraft supplies eclipse power and power for peak loads, and is a 28 volt, 6 ampere-hour Nickel-Cadmium battery system. There are two batteries per spacecraft, and each battery consists of 21 series connected, hermetically sealed Nickel-Cadmium cells. The cells utilize a pellon separator, a standard positive plate and a silver-treated negative plate. This paper reviews and summarizes flight data for 17,000 orbital cycles. Discussion focuses on battery trend analysis used in determining the feasibility of extending mission life.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Performance; ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; FLIGHT EXPERIENCE; LOW EARTH ORBIT; NICKEL CADMIUM SYSTEM; SPACECRAFT

Abstract: Many years of full-scale experiments show that, in working with a water-based heat store, inertia is observed, i. e. , the necessary stored heat is not completely transmitted to the surrounding medium at the required time. Thus, the energy reserve accumulated during the charging process is not adequately used. To remedy this, a combined heat store consisting of water- and sand-based stores is proposed. Is is established that versions of a combined heat store are most suitable for single-slope hothouses. Water is in a tank (140 multiplied by 15 multiplied by 50 cm) and sand on shelves (60 multiplied by 50 multiplied by 15). Each shelf consists of nine compartments filled with sand. The total mass of water and sand is 200 kg.

Source title: CRC Critical Reviews in Clinical Neurobiology

Abstract: This review will briefly outline the major steps of glycogen metabolism in muscle and the role of glycogen as a source of energy in different types of exercise. There are nine specific enzyme defects of glycogen metabolism or glycolysis affecting muscle. Each of the nine glycogenoses will be discussed in terms of typical and variant clinical presentation, genetic transmission, muscle biopsy and biochemical findings. The proposed pathophysiology of the various symptoms and signs will be presented and the many unsolved problems in this area will be discussed.

Abstract: The design and hydraulic performance of the vortex-flow drop structures recommended for the Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage District (MMSD) Inline Storage System are presented. The drop structures comprise a tangential inlet, a circular drop-shaft connected to a larger-diameter deaeration chamber, and an air-vent pipe connected to the top of the dropshaft. The drop-structure configuration is very simple, consisting of only plane surfaces, circular sections, and their intersections. A significant amount of energy is dissipated in the dropshaft. The flow is highly stable, and the boundary pressures are nearly atmospheric everywhere.

Abstract: Testing of a complete battery pack with an electric vehicle on a chassis dynamometer or on the road/track is considered in this chapter. Many electric vehicles have been tested in recent years. Most of those tests have involved only determination of range and acceleration performance; measurements were not made and recorded from which in-vehicle battery performance could be determined for comparison with cell/module test data and computer simulation results. This review will be concerned primarily with electric vehicle testing, such that battery performance can be inferred from the data obtained. Available test data for vehicles utilizing some of the batteries characterized are presented and discussed.

Authors with affiliations: Morrow, George W., NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Abstract: Nine packs of General Electric sealed aerospace nickel-cadmium cells were put on life test at the Naval Weapons Support Center in Crane, Indiana in February 1979 under the Design Variable Program. Each 5 cell pack contained one cell with a standard sensor signal electrode and one cell with a new heart-pacer sensor signal electrode. Testing was discontinued in May 1983 and the signal electrode performance data were studied. It was found that the heart-pacer electrode generally provided a greater voltage swing over a cycle; that both types of electrodes lost significant sensitivity during life, and that both types of electrodes show great signal variation from cell to cell.

Abstract: Recent development and test effort at Sandia National Laboratories and Honeywell Power Sources Center has been directed at high rate Lithium-Thionyl Chloride batteries which address applications previously specifying thermal batteries. Abstract: As described in The Defense Waste Management Plan, the defense TRU program goal is to achieve permanent disposal and to end interim storage. TRU waste is currently stored at six Department of Energy (DOE) sites, and new waste is generated at several more sites. The Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) project is well-defined, and it has been necessary to integrate the activities of other parts of the TRU program in support of DOE Headquarters policy and the WIPP schedules and technical requirements. The strategy is described in the Defense Transuranic Waste Program Strategy Document.

Abstract: As space vehicles become larger and mission times become longer double-gimbaled control moment gyros (CMGs) will be used more and more for attitude control, angular momentum storage and energy storage. Therefore, a need exists for a simple, but universally applicable CMG steering law which takes the control torque command and generates gimbal rate commands in such a way that, in spite of the highly nonlinear CMG behavior, the resulting torque on the vehicle is ideally equal to the commanded one.

Abstract: Hughes has developed a mathematical model which predicts life of nickel-cadmium batteries designed for geosynchronous orbit satellites. A statistical analysis technique called regression was used to analyze orbital data on second-generation trickle-charged batteries. The model gives average cell voltage as a function of design parameters, operating parameters and time. The voltage model has the properties of providing a good fit to the data, good predictive capability, and agreement with known battery performance characteristics. Average cell voltage can almost always be predicted to within 0. 02 volts for up to 8 years. This modeling shows that these batteries will operate reliably for 10 years.

Authors with affiliations: Teer, Bill R., Transnuclear Inc, White Plains, NY,, USA, Transnuclear Inc, White Plains, NY, USA; Clark, James, Transnuclear Inc, White Plains, NY,, USA, Transnuclear Inc, White Plains, NY, USA
Abstract: Nuclear Fuel Services, Inc. and the Department of Energy's Idaho Operations Office have signed a cost sharing contract to demonstrate dual purpose shipping and storage casks for spent nuclear fuel. Transnuclear, Inc. has been selected by NFS to design and supply two forged steel casks - one for 40 PWR assemblies from the Ginna reactor, the other for 85 BWR assemblies from the Big Rock Point reactor. The casks will be delivered to West Valley in mid-1985, loaded with the fuel assemblies and shipped by rail to the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory. The shipments will be made under a DOE Certificate of Compliance which will be issued based on reviews by Oak Ridge National Laboratory of Transnuclear's designs.

Authors with affiliations: Milden, Martin J., Aerospace Corp, El Segundo, CA, USA, Aerospace Corp, El Segundo, CA, USA
Abstract: In late 1981 customers of General Electric Battery Business Department (GE/BBD) were notified that supplies of Pellon 2505ML separator would be exhausted in about 2 years. A joint Government program to qualify a new separator for nickel cadmium (NiCd) cells was proposed. The joint program eliminates duplication of effort between Agencies and Contractors. Cell buys are being made by NASA/GSFC and Naval Weapons Support Center, Crane (NWSC). Cells will be acceptance tested and several cells will be operated in a charge/discharge characterization matrix. Cell packs will be life tested at NWSC in low earth orbit and geosynchronous orbit under real time and accelerated conditions.

Abstract: Diurnal energy storage using Superconductive Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) for use of electric utility systems is currently under study at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The proposed interface between the SMES coil and the ac utility is a Graetz bridge. A large number of thyristors and converter modules must be paralleled to achieve current ratings of several hundred thousand amperes. A typical bridge circuit module is shown. The operational parameters for an idealized power cycle patterned after the Wisconsin Electric Utility Company demand cycle are listed.

Title: Inhibitors of the rate of carbohydrate and lipid absorption by the intestine
Affiliations: Institute of Pharmacology, Bayer AG, D 5600 Wuppertal 1, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Puls, W., Institute of Pharmacology, Bayer AG, D 5600 Wuppertal 1, Germany; Krause, H.P., Institute of Pharmacology, Bayer AG, D 5600 Wuppertal 1, Germany; Muller, L., Institute of Pharmacology, Bayer AG, D 5600 Wuppertal 1, Germany; Schutt, H.; Sitt, R.; Thomas, G.
Abstract: The rate of energy storage in adipose tissues is, at least in part, dependent on the concentration of nutrients and hormones in the blood. A delayed absorption of ingesta from the intestine should cause lower concentrations of fat, glucose and insulin and, thus, reduce the triglyceride storage rate. Non-selective agents retard the absorption irrespective of composition of food. Inhibitors of intestinal α-glucosidases delay the degradation of complex carbohydrates to absorbable monosaccharides and thus decrease the rate of their absorption. Inhibitors of pancreatic lipase interfere with the degradation of dietary triglycerides and decrease the postprandial triglyceride increment in blood and tissues. Recently a compound was found which inhibits the absorption of carbohydrates as well as triglycerides.

Abstract: Space power systems of the future are projected to require power levels that extend far beyond those currently in the 1 kW range. High power systems will most likely utilize either higher battery voltages in the 200v-300v range or special power processing equipment to convert low battery voltage to high system voltage. This second option will demand batteries with high capacity (greater ampere-hours per cell or cells configured in parallel), and high discharge current capability. The energy storage for such large systems becomes a challenging battery engineering problem. A study was initiated in late spring of 1981 at the NASA Lewis Research Center to design and evaluate a new design concept for nickel-hydrogen cells.

Abstract: Although Li/CF cells and batteries have an excellent safety record, they have been included with other battery systems that require additional safety precautions. One precaution that has been suggested is the inclusion of shunt diodes into these batteries.

Title: DEFENSE HIGH-LEVEL WASTE MANAGEMENT AT THE IDAHO CHEMICAL PROCESSING PLANT.
Affiliations: Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho, Falls, ID, USA, Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Authors with affiliations: Berreth, J.R., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho, Falls, ID, USA, Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Knecht, D.A., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho, Falls, ID, USA, Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Abstract: The Idaho Chemical Processing Plant reprocesses Department of Energy nuclear fuels for recovery of uranium. Acidic high-level liquid wastes are temporarily stored in stainless-steel tanks prior to solidification using a fluidized-bed calcining process. After solidification, the granular solid waste is stored in stainless-steel bins located within concrete vaults. Approximately 20,000 m**3 of liquid waste has been reduced to 2800 m**3 of solidified waste during 20 years of routine calcining operations. Alternative strategies for long-term waste management include in-place immobilization and repository disposal. Glass and ceramic are candidate waste forms to immobilize the waste.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL PLANTS; MILITARY ENGINEERING; CALCINED WASTE STORAGE; CHEMICAL PROCESSING; HIGH-LEVEL RADIOACTIVE WASTES; NUCLEAR FUELS

Title: EQUIVALENT STIFFNESS AND DAMPING COEFFICIENTS FOR SQUEEZE FILM DAMPERS.
Source title: I Mech E Conference Publications (Institution of Mechanical Engineers)
Affiliations: Univ of New South Wales, Sch of, Mechanical & Industrial, Engineering, Kensington, Aust, Univ of New South Wales, Sch of Mechanical & Industrial Engineering, Kensington, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Hahn, E.J., Univ of New South Wales, Sch of, Mechanical & Industrial, Engineering, Kensington, Aust, Univ of New South Wales, Sch of Mechanical & Industrial Engineering, Kensington, Aust
Abstract: Analyses of multi-degree of freedom rotor-bearing systems incorporating non-linear elements, such as squeeze film dampers, generally necessitate time-consuming transient solution. Consequently, it is often too expensive to carry out parametric design studies on such systems. A general technique for linearizing the non-linear element forces using equivalent stiffness and damping coefficients is based on energy dissipation and energy storage-release concepts. The approach is tested for both centrally preloaded squeeze film dampers and for squeeze film dampers without centralizing springs under a combination of unidirectional and unbalance loading. The results predicted by using such equivalent stiffness and damping coefficients agree quite well with those obtained from the full transient solution, even where the unidirectional load exceeds the dynamic load and the damper is operating at high eccentricity. An iterative procedure is proposed which should significantly reduce the computation time.
Index Keywords: MACHINE VIBRATIONS - Absorption; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Linearization; DAMPING COEFFICIENT; ROTOR BEARING SYSTEMS; SQUEEZE FILM DAMPERS; STIFFNESS COEFFICIENT; SHOCK ABSORBERS

Title: USING SCR'S AS TRANSIENT PROTECTION STRUCTURES IN INTEGRATED CIRCUITS.
Affiliations: RCA, David Sarnoff Research Cent,, Princeton, NJ, USA, RCA, David Sarnoff Research Cent, Princeton, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Avery, L.R., RCA, David Sarnoff Research Cent,, Princeton, NJ, USA, RCA, David Sarnoff Research Cent, Princeton, NJ, USA
Abstract: There has been a heightened awareness of the need to protect even bipolar integrated circuits from the effects of ESD and EOS. Shrinking geometries, and the use of ICs in ever more hazardous environments, have made systematic protection of these devices almost as essential as protecting their MOS counterparts. Of prime concern to RCA is the reliability of the ICs used by the Consumer Electronics Division under kine arc induced electrical overstress. This is a severe requirement as the energy storage capacitor can be in excess of 2000 pF and peak discharge currents into the IC can be an order of magnitude greater than those obtained using the standard human body ESD model of 100 pF and 1. 5 K ohms. RCA C. E. are currently requesting a plus or minus 4 KV requirement using a 200 pF/150 ohm model for certain critical applications.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; ELECTROSTATICS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, BIPOLAR - Transients; BIPOLAR IC PROTECTION; ELECTROSTATIC DISCHARGE; ENERGY STORAGE CAPACITOR; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS

Title: ASSESSMENT OF INTEGRATED FLYWHEEL SYSTEM TECHNOLOGY.
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 25 papers presenting the current state of the technology in flywheel energy storage systems and ancillary components. Other objectives of the conference are to define the technology shortfalls and critical items in light of application requirements, and to identify and prioritize the technology needs and issues to rectify the denoted shortfalls. Evaluations are provided of applications of flywheels in various satellites and spacecraft systems.

Authors with affiliations: Keckler, Claude R., NASA, Langley Research Cent,, Hampton, VA, USA, NASA, Langley Research Cent, Hampton, VA, USA
Abstract: The use of flywheels to perform the functions of attitude control and/or energy storage on a variety of space missions has been of interest to NASA for several years. Preliminary studies were initiated in the early 1970's and have been carried forward by both government and industrial concerns ever since. Recent interest in this technology, on the part of NASA, resulted in the Integrated Flywheel Technology - 1983 Workshop held at the Goddard Space Flight Center in August 1983. Results and objectives of the workshop are presented.

Authors with affiliations: Kuang, Yuan-Zhu, Acad Sinica, Electric Propulsion, Lab, Beijing, China, Acad Sinica, Electric Propulsion Lab, Beijing, China
Abstract: This paper describes the effects of propellant geometry on performance of teflon pulsed plasma thruster (PPT) with parallel-rail electrodes. Experiments with thrusters having same areas of propellant profile and different propellant geometry at given discharge energy have demonstrated that when the ratio of height to width of the propellant profile (H/W) increases, the propellant ablated per discharge, the impulse bit, the specific impulse, the specific thrust (i. e. thrust/power ratio) and thruster efficiency all increase. The waveforms of discharge current for four pair thrusters having same areas of propellant profile and different (H/W) were recorded by a storage oscilloscope and the electric parameters of discharge circuit were measured. The results are discussed.

Title: EFFECTIVENESS OF CONCENTRATION OF GAS FLOWS.
Authors with affiliations: Borisenko, T.M.; Ushakov, S.S.
Abstract: The emerging pattern of gas flows from fields in the northern areas of Tyumen Region to the European part of the nation creates the prerequisites for concentration of gas flows and the development of an energy corridor with installation of several courses of gas pipelines. Flow concentration in a course of 138-184 billion m**3/year and flow concentration in an energy corridor of 276-368 billion m**3/year will be very effective; this corresponds to 3-4 gas pipelines (1420 mm diameter at 9. 8 MPa working pressure) in a course and the uniting of two courses by connecting links.

Authors with affiliations: Ritterman, Paul F., COMSAT, El Segundo, CA, USA, COMSAT, El Segundo, CA, USA
Abstract: The nickel-oxide electrode common to the nickel hydrogen and nickel cadmium cell is by design the limiting or capacity determining electrode on both charge and discharge. The useable discharge capacity from this electrode, and since it is the limiting electrode, the useable discharge capacity of the cell as well can and has been optimized by rate of charge, charge temperature and additives to electrode and electrolyte. Recent tests at COMSAT Labs with nickel hydrogen cells and tests performed almost 25 years ago with nickel cadmium cells indicate an improvement of capacity as a result of using increased electrolyte concentration.

Affiliations: Scientific Research Coal &, Chemistry Inst, USSR, Scientific Research Coal & Chemistry Inst, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Ryazanova, T.A., Scientific Research Coal &, Chemistry Inst, USSR, Scientific Research Coal & Chemistry Inst, USSR; Preobrazhenskii, B.P., Scientific Research Coal &, Chemistry Inst, USSR, Scientific Research Coal & Chemistry Inst, USSR; Ulanovskii, M.L., Scientific Research Coal &, Chemistry Inst, USSR, Scientific Research Coal & Chemistry Inst, USSR; Popova, V.A., Scientific Research Coal &, Chemistry Inst, USSR, Scientific Research Coal & Chemistry Inst, USSR
Abstract: One of the main coal-treatment problems at the present time in the economic, technological, and social aspects is shortening the sludge-water cycle within the ranges of coal-treatment plants, i. e. , eliminating the discharges of the suspensions belonging to the flotation wastes in the sludge storage device. To solve the problem, what is needed is a reliable method of condensing and dehydrating the wastes so that a transportable residue or suspension containing no more than 600 kg/m**3 solid is obtained which is suited to subsequent heat treatment. The results of the investigations make it possible to recommend (for industrial introduction) a most effective method of thickening flotation wastes - granulating them in a liquid phase containing flocculant. What can also be recommended for industrial introduction is a two-stage waste thickening technology using the cationically active flocculant PEI and anionic PAA.

Authors with affiliations: Frea, Ward J., Michigan Technological Univ,, Mechanical Engineering &, Engineering Mechanics Dep, Houghton,, Michigan Technological Univ, Mechanical Engineering & Engineering Mechanics Dep, Houghton, MI,
Abstract: Pre-drying of forest residue fuel was compared economically with direct burning of green wood fuel in a modern boiler using heat recovery equipment. Heat sources for the pre-drying were obtained from unheated forced air, natural air circulation during storage, and boiler flue gas. Two cases considered were the conversion of an existing boiler to wood fuel, and the purchase of a new wood fired boiler. Estimated return on investment was calculated for three systems each incorporating a different pre-drying heat source.
