Authors with affiliations: Faymon, Karl A., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Fordyce, J.Stuart, NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: This paper discusses the space power systems of the early 21st century. The focus is on those capabilities which are anticipated to evolve from today's state-of-the-art and the technology development programs presently in place or planned for the remainder of the century. The power system technologies considered include solar thermal, nuclear, radioisotope, photovoltaic, thermionic, thermoelectric, and dynamic conversion systems such as the Brayton and Stirling cycles. Energy storage technologies considered include nickel hydrogen biopolar batteries, advanced high energy rechargeable batteries, regenerative fuel cells, and advanced primary batteries. The present state-of-the-art of these space power and energy technologies is discussed along with their projections, trends and goals.

Abstract: Silver-hydrogen cells have been on test at TRW since July, 1982. The objective of the test is to estimate useful life by operation at accelerated, simulated geosynchronous orbit conditions. Ten simulated seasons have been run and are summarized. The results to-date reflect stable, trouble-free performance and indicate that the silver-hydrogen couple shows promise as a lightweight alternative to the nickel systems.

Abstract: The stability or long term storage capability of a battery is a function of several factors, each important to the overall storage life and, therefore, each potentially a problem area if not addressed during the design, development and evaluation phases of the product cycle. Abstract: Within the framework of the R & D program on Management and Storage of Radioactive Waste of the European Atomic Energy Community, one project is dedicated to the development of containers for vitrified high-level waste to be disposed of in geological formations. In particular, a joint testing program has been established for the assessment of the corrosion behavior of potential materials in the different disposal environments considered, respectively granite, salt and clay. As a result of previous screening tests on a number of materials, a detailed testing program is presently concentrated on three most promising reference materials, respectively Hastelloy C4, Ti-Pd (0. 2%Pd) and a mild steel.

Title: POTENTIAL FOR A CYCLING STEAM POWER PLANT WITH TES TO SUPPLY DISTRICT HEATING IN WASHINGTON D. C.
Authors with affiliations: Hobson, Michael J.
Abstract: The Energy Offce of the District of Columbia is planning the conversion of a 1500 TPD incinerator for district heating and the generation of electric power for sale to the local utility, PEPCO. Records are presented of a preliminary evaluation of whether hot water storage would be appropriate at the heat source plant to maximize power sales and improve the reliability of the district heat service. Hot water storage is being employed successfully at Herning, Denmark, in conjunction with a cogeneration plant heat source, and this concept is adapted to Washington D. C. area needs for heating and cooling service.

Abstract: This is one of a three-volume set of lecture notes presenting data generally restricted to those aspects of non-nuclear energy technologies dealing with new developments, some of which promise to bring important modifications to the U. S. energy-supply base. The authors begin with an assessment of oil recovery from tar sands and oil shale and conclude this analysis with a discussion of proper methodologies involved in net energy calculations. The book contains detailed descriptions of coal utilization, energy-storage systems, direct energy conversion, tidal- and wave-energy utilization, and electrical power production, transmission, and distribution. Also included are assessments of the potential large- and small-scale solar-energy application techniques and of related topics involving utilization of wind energy and hydroelectric-power generation. The authors' personal involvement with the development of new fossil-fuel technologies, the hydrogen economy, the solar-sea power plant and hydrothermal energy generation is reflected by comprehensive current coverage of these topics. Refs.

Title: ENERGY STORAGE FOR THE ELECTRICITY SUPPLY SYSTEM IN THE NETHERLANDS.

Affiliations: N. V. SEP, Neth, N. V. SEP, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Halberg, N., N. V. SEP, Neth, N. V. SEP, Neth
Abstract: If wind energy is eventually to be used on a large-scale, integrated into the Dutch electricity supply system, it will be required to operate alongside conventional plants. Because of the variability of the wind, system integration problems are likely to be a major factor in determining the extent to which wind energy can be utilized economically. When there is a substantial component of wind power generating capacity on the Dutch Electricity Supply System, the potentially devastating effect of the load following and spinning reserve penalities may encourage the installation of some form of energy storage facilities. Related to the Dutch situation the low-head pumped hydro is potentially the ideal storage technology for a system containing intermittent generation.

Abstract: The US Department of Energy is evaluating a densely welded tuff located above the water table at Yucca Mountain on the Nevada Test Site as a potential high-level nuclear waste repository. These effects remain an unknown factor for worst-case repository conditions. Alloys being considered for waste containment barriers at this site include austenitic stainless steels 304L, 316L and the stabailized grades 321 and 347 and high-nickel alloy 825.

Title: HEAVY ION ACCELERATORS AS DRIVERS FOR INERTIAL CONFINEMENT FUSION.

Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Warwick, A.I., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Keefe, D., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Herrmannsfeldt, W.B., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: An aspect of the inertial confinement approach to fusion is that the problems of a practical fusion power plant are simplified by the separation of the driver from the reactor vessel. The authors indicate that among the candidates for a power plant driver, an accelerator of intense beams of heavy ions seems closest to meeting the engineering and economic requirements of power production. Heavy ions are described to have efficient and straightforward collisional mechanisms by which they give up their kinetic energy to the outer target shell. As the deposition layer becomes ionized, there is no fundamental change in the beam target coupling mechanism.

Title: DEVELOPMENT AND COMMERCIALIZATION OF A SYSTEM FOR PROCESSING, STORAGE, AND UTILIZATION OF WOODCHIP FUELS.
Source title: Symposium Papers - Energy from Biomass and Wastes
Affiliations: Univ of Maine at Orono, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, Orono, ME, USA, Univ of Maine at Orono, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Orono, ME, USA
Authors with affiliations: Riley, John G., Univ of Maine at Orono, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, Orono, ME, USA, Univ of Maine at Orono, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Orono, ME, USA; Smith, Norman, Univ of Maine at Orono, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, Orono, ME, USA, Univ of Maine at Orono, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Orono, ME, USA
Abstract: Over the past ten years an extensive research and development program has been conducted to produce an efficient, automatic, economically viable system for using particulate biomass fuels, principally woodchips, as a substitute for fossil fuels burning equipment in residential, commercial and institutional applications. As the combustion equipment was developed, effort was directed towards setting up integrated systems for fuel storage, processing and delivery. Equipment has been built for drying chips either in storage or immediately prior to combustion; successful systems have been designed to utilize ambient air, solar-tempered air, and flue gases. Several different home delivery systems are being evaluated and it is envisioned that the complete fuel supply network will be in place by the time the production version of the furnace is marketed early in 1984.
Index Keywords: BIOMASS - Energy Utilization; COMBUSTION - Equipment; BIOMASS FUELS; FUEL SUPPLY DEVELOPMENT; RESIDENTIAL APPLICATIONS; WOODCHIP DRYING; WOOD

Title: CAROLINA POWER & LIGHT'S LICENSED AT-REACTOR DRY STORAGE DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM.

Abstract: This paper describes the Carolina Power & Light (CP&L) program, which will use the Nutech Horizontal, Modular, Storage System (NUHOMS). The primary operations of the NUHOMS system are: cask preparation, canister preparation, cask-canister loading, cask lifting, canister-assembly loading, cask head placement, cask lifting, cask-canister drying, canister sealing, helium filling, transporter-skid loading, transfer, cask-module preparation, cask head removal, module loading, storage, and retrieval.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC UTILITIES; LEGISLATION; DRY STORAGE DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; NUCLEAR WASTE POLICY ACT; U. S. DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY; NUCLEAR FUELS

Title: METROPOLITAN WASTE MANAGEMENT PLANNING IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES.
Source title: Managing Solid Wastes in Dev Countries
Affiliations: WHO, UK, WHO, UK
Authors with affiliations: Patrick, P.K., WHO, UK, WHO, UK
Abstract: This paper describes in outline a project in which the author was engaged for two years in Istanbul. The project was set up by WHO/UNDP in conjunction with the Turkish government, the object being to prepare a master plan for solid waste management in the Istanbul metropolitan area. The World Bank was also associated with the studies. The feasibility studies covered the whole field of solid waste management: waste collection; waste disposal; transport; materials and energy recovery; industrial wastes; hospital wastes; training requirements; legislation; and organization and administration.
Index Keywords: URBAN PLANNING; WASTE DISPOSAL; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ISTANBUL AREA; METROPOLITAN WASTES; WASTE ANALYSIS; WASTE STORAGE AND COLLECTION; REFUSE DISPOSAL

Title: RECENT TRENDS AND CONCEPTS IN THE BULK HANDLING OF COAL IN CIL MINES.
Affiliations: Central Mine Planning & Design, Inst Ltd, E&M Engineering, Services Div, Ranchi, India, Central Mine Planning & Design Inst Ltd, E&M Engineering Services Div, Ranchi, India
Authors with affiliations: Sahu, S.P., Central Mine Planning & Design, Inst Ltd, E&M Engineering, Services Div, Ranchi, India, Central Mine Planning & Design Inst Ltd, E&M Engineering Services Div, Ranchi, India
Abstract: Coal is the prime energy source, contributing as much as 60% to the Indian national energy scene. The development of the coal industry in India has undergone a revolutionary change. The rate of growth envisaged after nationalisation was unprecedented compared with most advanced countries of the world. Due mainly to economic considerations, most of the mines taken over from the pre-nationalization period had smaller production capacities (between 0. 1 and 0. 3 Mt/a), with manual handling of coal or small coal handling plants (CHPs). A higher volume of coal was needed to flow between the coal mines and these consuming points. Obviously, this changed situation could only be met with a much faster rate of handling, loading, and transportation. Such a changed situation also demanded a very high degree of planning from the Central Mine Planning and Design Institute Ltd. (CEMPDIL) to meet the challenge of future coal requirements of the country. Such a demanding and indispensable situation has made it necessary for CEMPDIL to possess the newest and latest concepts and technologies in the field of designing bulk handling coal plants and flood loading stations.
Index Keywords: CONVEYORS - Belt; MINES AND MINING - Surface Transportation; COAL LOADING; CONVEYING; CRUSHING; STORAGE; TRUCKING; COAL HANDLING

Title: LINEAR ACCELERATOR AND PULSE COMPRESSOR OF THE SNQ-PROJECT.
Affiliations: Kernforschungsanlage Juelich,, SNQ/ABT, Juelich, West Ger, Kernforschungsanlage Juelich, SNQ/ABT, Juelich, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Zettler, Clemens, Kernforschungsanlage Juelich,, SNQ/ABT, Juelich, West Ger, Kernforschungsanlage Juelich, SNQ/ABT, Juelich, West Ger
Abstract: The concept of the accelerator part of the SNQ-project, in particular the Linac, is described. The Linac may be subdivided into three sections, namely the Injector with two RFQ-structures and a beam merging by funneling, the Alvarez-Accelerator and the High Energy Linear Accelerator with its single cell structure. For the ring shaped pulse compressor two technical solutions are being investigated. One is an isochronous storage ring and the other is a FFAG-synchrotron, which can also accelerate at a fast rate.
Index Keywords: NEUTRONS - SOURCES; ALVAREZ ACCELERATORS; PULSE COMPRESSORS; RF QUADRUPOLES; SNQ-PROJECT; ACCELERATORS, LINEAR

Abstract: New applications for lead-acid batteries, such as electric vehicle propulsion, demand high specific energy and power and good cycle life. A research and development program at Johnson Controls, Inc. , sponsored in part by the United States Department of Energy through Argonne National Laboratory, has been underway since 1978 to develop advanced electric vehicle batteries. The original goals for the first phase of this program, development of an Improved State of the Art (ISOA) lead-acid battery, are shown. Two sizes of ISOA batteries were designed.

Title: EXPERIENCE WITH CABLES USED IN RADIATION AREAS AT CERN.
Source title: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Schonbacher, H., CERN, Geneva, Switz, CERN, Geneva, Switz
Abstract: This paper describes the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) use of large accelerators and storage rings for research in high-energy particle physics. In three installations the materials and components are exposed to ionizing radiation; the yearly absorbed dose levels range from 10**3 to 10**5 Gy. Therefore, particular attention is given at CERN to the effects of ionizing radiation, notably on organic materials. Within these material tests, cable insulation and sheath represent an important quantity.

Abstract: The Longxihe River hydropower system consists of four hydropower plants in series. The four reservoirs are used for flood control and power generation. Among the four reservoirs, only reservoir 1 has enough storage capacity for over-year regulation and the other three are for daily regulation. The study determines the optimal distribution of hourly load to the four plants to minimize the total discharge per mega-watt-hour of generated energy in a period of 24 hours.

Department of Energy (DOE) solicitation for a cooperative agreement proposal, Virginia Electric and Power Company (VEPCO) has proposed to participate in a spent fuel storage demonstration program utilizing the dry cask storage technology. Title: FLYWHEEL CONTAINMENT AND SAFETY CONSIDERATIONS.
Affiliations: GE, Space Systems Div, Philadelphia,, PA, USA, GE, Space Systems Div, Philadelphia, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Coppa, Anthony P., GE, Space Systems Div, Philadelphia,, PA, USA, GE, Space Systems Div, Philadelphia, PA, USA
Abstract: The issue of flywheel safety is a subject of growing interest. With greater quantification of composite rotor burst effects and corresponding containment requirements, attention is being focussed on possible development of 'limited failure' or even 'fail-safe' rotor designs. An evaluation is presented of previous containment technology developments and recommendations are given of performing rotor open testing in order to obtain a 'fail-safe' or 'limited-failure' rotor design.

Title: GENERAL CORRELATION FOR NATURAL CONVECTION IN LIQUID SATURATED BEDS OF SPHERES.
Affiliations: CSIRO, Div of Energy Technology,, Highett, Victoria, Aust, CSIRO, Div of Energy Technology, Highett, Victoria, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Close, D.J., CSIRO, Div of Energy Technology,, Highett, Victoria, Aust, CSIRO, Div of Energy Technology, Highett, Victoria, Aust
Abstract: A general correlation for the effective Nusselt number Nu in liquid saturated beds of spheres, is presented. The parameters are derived from a detailed examination of the heat transfer mechanisms, including the local fluid to particle heat transfer coefficient, and the conduction processes. Comparisons between data reported in the literature and the correlation, show excellent agreement for values of Nu below 10. For higher values, arguments are advanced attributing deviations to inadequacies of the Darcy equation.

Abstract: A solid residual regarded as waste from copper smelters, known as copper slag, offers and excellent medium for the storage of heat energy. Conceptual designs for copper slag thermal storage systems have been proposed wherein a packed bed of copper slag is thermally cycled with air or some other gases utilized as transport media. A specifc design for a solar combined cycle system is evaluated. Refs.

Title: ALKALI METAL CARBONATES
Affiliations: Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Maru, Hansraj C., Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT,, USA, Energy Research Corp, Danbury, CT, USA
Abstract: Among the carbonate melts, the class of alkali metal carbonates (Li//2CO//3, Na//2CO//3, and K//2CO//3) and their mixtures are the most prominent. These melts are fairly stable in the temperature range of 400 to 1000 degree C, exhibit low vapor pressures, can be easily contained in common ceramic and alloy materials, and are environmentally safe. The alkali carbonate melts offer a wide range of physicochemical and kinetic characteristics desirable for various reaction media and electrolytes. Melting points of mixtures vary from 400 to 900 degree C. Other properties, such as viscosity, electrical conductivity, and gas solubility can also be varied by changing the compositions of the mixtures. Applications of carbonate melts include fuel cells, thermal energy storage, coal gasification, desulfurization of gases, oxygen regeneration, carbon dioxide concentration, nuclear and toxic waste processing, and recovery of silver.
Index Keywords: ALKALI METALS - Physical Properties; HAZARDOUS MATERIALS - Safety Codes; LITHIUM COMPOUNDS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; ALKALI METAL CARBONATES; CARBONATES; HYGROSCOPICITY; SALTS

Abstract: Combined evaporative and drip loss costs the United Kingdom meat industry in excess of POUND 200,000,000 per annum. The use of existing refrigeration technology to produce efficient well controlled cooling and storage systems would result in a minimum saving of POUND 60,000,000 per annum. To achieve further savings a more fundamental understanding of the factors influencing heat and mass transfer within meat is required.

Abstract: A new pattern definition method using atomic intermixing induced by focused-ion-beams (FIBs) is proposed; the intermixed region produced by FIB irradiation in the Al/Au system has a higher sputtering yield than Al and is selectively etched by a low-energy ion shower. With this method, X-ray masks were fabricated. Sub-quarter-micron patterns with high aspect-ratio were replicated from the fabricated mask in 1- mu m thick PMMA layers with synchrotron radiation from the electron storage ring.

Affiliations: Ford Aerospace & Communications, Corp, Palo Alto, CA, USA, Ford Aerospace & Communications Corp, Palo Alto, CA, USA

Abstract: Space platforms and many other future spacecraft are expected to operate at electrical power levels of 20 to 125 kW and beyond. To reduce distribution losses, the electrical power systems are likely to operate at higher bus voltages (150-250V) than commonly used today. Space qualified energy storage systems compatible with these high-power and high-voltage requirements do not exist and must be developed. One energy storage system which has been identified as an excellent candidate for these applications is the bipolar nickel-hydrogen battery.

Title: FACT VERSUS FICTION? THE SOCIO-ECONOMIC BENEFITS TO BE FOUND IN TEACHING CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS ON NUCLEAR WASTE ISSUES IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS.
Affiliations: Univ of New Mexico, Dep of Chemical, & Nuclear Engineering,, Albuquerque, NM, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Dep of Chemical & Nuclear Engineering, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, Harold M., Univ of New Mexico, Dep of Chemical, & Nuclear Engineering,, Albuquerque, NM, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Dep of Chemical & Nuclear Engineering, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: The safe storage of radioactive wastes has been the topic of much heated debate. Many of the concerns raised demonstrate that the public is poorly informed about nuclear matters, bewildered by conflicting testimony and lacking the intellectual skills required to discriminate between statements of fact versus opinion or motive. Recently, the National Council for the Social Studies (NCSS) adopted a set of guidelines intended to encourage a stronger emphasis on urgent science-related social issues in the classroom and to provide for social studies teachers, rationale and structure for the presentation of these issues. In this way, the NCSS is moving to meet the needs of the community for greater technological awareness.

Abstract: New investigations of lead-acid batteries are stimulated by planned applications to energy storage in photovoltaic solar technology. This work attempts to identify the processes involved in the loss of energy dissipation during charging and discharging i. e. with irreversible processes giving rise to a dissipative part of the electrode impedance. The most trivial origin of energy dissipation is the ohmic drop, but diffusion and charge transfer are likely to participate in a greater extent. These various contributions may be separated on the basis of the individual frequency response.

Abstract: Extended burnup is described to offer savings in enriched uranium and in the unit costs of both fabrication and storage. When achieved by batch size reduction, the savings are even larger because end-of-cycle fission product inventory is reduced but maximum burnups may be substantially increased. This paper describes a study in which reinsertion of previously discharged fuel was used to obtain the benefits of extended burnup through reduced batch size without a major increase in maximum assembly burnup.

Authors with affiliations: Ziogas, Phoivos D., Concordia Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Montreal, Que, Can, Concordia Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Montreal, Que, Can; Khan, Shahidul I., Concordia Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Montreal, Que, Can, Concordia Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Montreal, Que, Can; Rashid, M.H., Concordia Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Montreal, Que, Can, Concordia Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Montreal, Que, Can
Abstract: Full automation in manufacturing processes has generated a considerable demand for ac motor drives and in particular static frequency changers. Forced commutated cycloconverters (FCC's) are frequency changers that can provide a wide output frequency range with minimum energy storage requirements. For this reason they can be manufactured in integrated form with significant savings in price, weight and volume. These factors have generated a considerable research activity towards the development of FCC structures that can compete with the typical rectifier inverter structures. The work presented in this paper focusses on some advanced FC cycloconverter structures with improved performance characteristics. Areas of improvement include; voltage utilization and generated harmonic distortion.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC MOTORS, AC - Electric Power Supplies; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, POWER SUPPLY; AC MOTOR DRIVES; FULL AUTOMATION IN MANUFACTURING PROCESSES; STATIC FREQUENCY CHANGER; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, FREQUENCY CONVERTER

Title: REACTION WHEELS FOR KINETIC ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Studer, Philip A., NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Abstract: Combining reaction wheels with energy storage wheels may seem an unlikely marriage between two elements with opposing requirements. This paper shows that they are not incompatible. The power required for control torques is a function of wheel speed but this energy is not dissipated; it is stored in the wheel. The I**2R loss resulting from a given torque is shown to be constant, independent of the design speed of the motor. What remains, in order to efficiently use high speed wheels (essential for energy storage) for control purposes, is to reduce rotational losses to acceptable levels.
Index Keywords: FLYWHEELS - Applications; ARMATURE DISSIPATION VS. DESIGN SPEED; OPTIMAL DESIGN SPEED; PERMAMENT MAGNET MOTORS; POWER TRANSFER EFFICIENCY; REACTION WHEEL OPTIMIZATION; ROTATIONAL LOSSES; WHEELS

Title: POROSITY OF COASTAL DELTAIC SANDSTONES, CERRO PRIETO GEOTHERMAL FIELD, BAJA CALIFORNIA, MEXICO.
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Earth, Sciences Div, Berkeley, CA, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Earth Sciences Div, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Vonder Haar, Stephen P., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Earth, Sciences Div, Berkeley, CA, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Earth Sciences Div, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: Core porosity values for sandstones and density log-derived porosities for sandstone-siltstone-shale sequences indicate a range from less than 1% to 40% at the Cerro Prieto geothermal field, Baja California, Mexico. Mean porosity values indicate that a general trend of decreasing porosities with increasing depth from 35% at 600 m to 10% at 2300 m is complicated by the 15 to 30% porosities in the 350 degree C hot water zone at about 2700 m depth. Scanning electron microscopy documents secondary dissolution porosity, mineral overgrowths, and abundant clay minerals. The porosity variability indicates that geothermal systems provide an ideal setting for testing concepts of dissolution porosity and increased secondary dissolution permeability that could be useful for nuclear waste storage as well as petroleum reservoir engineering. Refs.
Index Keywords: GEOPHYSICS - Rock Properties; ROCK - Porosity; CERRO PRIETO GEOTHERMAL FIELD; CORE POROSITY VALUES; DELTAIC SANDSTONES; DENSITY LOG-DERIVED POROSITIES; POROSITIES WITH INCREASING DEPTH; SECONDARY DISSOLUTION POROSITY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY

Title: MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE PROGRAM: CURRENT STATUS.
Source title: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
Affiliations: Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab,, Richland, WA, USA, Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hall, R.J., Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab,, Richland, WA, USA, Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: The Nuclear Waste Policy Act (NWPA) of 1982 defines the federal policy for management of radioactive waste from commercial nuclear power generation. This policy is based on the provision of mined geologic repositories for the ultimate disposal of these wastes. However, the Act also requires the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) to study the need for, and the feasibility of, monitored retrievable storage (MRS). This paper discusses developments in the MRS program since the passage of the ACT, including the evaluation of R&D needs, the early multiple concept definition studies, the selection of MRS concepts for further design, and supporting technical programs.

Abstract: The instrument for carrying out Department of Energy (DOE) actions with respect to spent fuel storage in the next decade and a half will be the Commercial Spent Fuel Management Program. This paper reviews the accomplishments of the CSFM Program in the last year, the status of ongoing activities, and the schedule for the availability of dry storage and rod consolidation as licensed options for utility deployment. The plans and strategy for meeting DOE's obligations, stemming from the NWPA, are described.

Authors with affiliations: Johnson, Chris J., Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: Once charged, rechargeable lithium cells retain their charge for years. This feature, along with 90 WH/Kg energy density, makes rechargeable lithium cells appealing for several aerospace applications. Since the cells remain charged for long time periods, the need for periodic recharging to assure full-up battery performance is greatly reduced.

Title: CONTROL OF POWER TRANSMISSION IN A FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE UNIT.
Affiliations: Bristol Polytechnic, Dep of, Engineering, Bristol, Engl, Bristol Polytechnic, Dep of Engineering, Bristol, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Jefferson, C.M., Bristol Polytechnic, Dep of, Engineering, Bristol, Engl, Bristol Polytechnic, Dep of Engineering, Bristol, Engl
Abstract: Continuously variable electrical transmission is a viable option in applications such as wind energy or flywheel energy storage, where the input and output speeds are independent. In this application, a naturally commutated DC link converter is to be used to provide bidirectional power transmission between an energy storage flywheel and the traction motors of a hybrid vehicle. In order to guard against commutation failure and to control the level of power transmitted, the link current must be adequately controlled. Digital computer simulation of the scheme shows that during flywheel regeneration, with the converter in the inverter mode, the link current is inherently unstable and must be stabilised by the compensating action of the controller. This paper describes a method for link current control by modulation of the thyristor firing angle of the flywheel machine converter.

Title: FLYWHEEL-POWERED X-RAY GENERATOR.
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of, Medical Physics, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Medical Physics, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Siedband, Melvin P., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of, Medical Physics, Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Medical Physics, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: In order to have stop-action image quality of radiographs, high instantaneous power levels are required. When medical x-ray systems are installed in hospitals, three-phase power lines can provide power levels in excess of 100 kWp to meet this need. Mobile x-ray systems or systems for field use are limited by their power sources. The use of a small flywheel appears to be a practical alternative to these power sources for mobile x-ray system applications. A 5 kg flywheel has been constructed which runs at 10 krpm and stores 30 kJ while requiring less than 500 W to bring the system up to speed. The wheel is coupled to an aircraft alternator and can yield pulsed power levels over 50 kWp.

Authors with affiliations: Eisenhaure, D., Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc,, Cambridge, MA, USA, Charles Stark Draper Lab Inc, Cambridge, MA, USA
Abstract: The Charles Stark Draper Laboratory is developing a new system that performs satellite attitude control, attitude reference, and energy storage utilizing inertia wheels. The baseline approach consists of two counter-rotating flywheels suspended in specially designed magnetic bearings, spin-axis motor/generators, and a control system. The control system regulates the magnetic bearings and spin-axis motor/generators and interacts with other satellite subsystems (photovoltaic array, star trackers, sun sensors, magnetic torquers, etc. ) to perform the three functions.

Authors with affiliations: Giudici, Bob, NASA, Marshall Space Flight Cent,, Huntsville, AL, USA, NASA, Marshall Space Flight Cent, Huntsville, AL, USA
Abstract: Inertial energy storage, or flywheels, emerged as a promising alternative to electrochemical storage methods with the concept of Integrated Power and Attitude Control (IPAC). Energy stored in the flywheel during sunlight portions of the orbit was used to supply spacecraft power during Earth occultation. This analysis, a Space Station application study, rediscovered IPAC and found the approach to have lower initial and resupply weight and lower initial and resupply cost than eiher battery/CMG or regenerative fuel cell/CMG systems. This study found order-of-magnitude advantages over conventional or advanced electrochemical/CMG systems when potential performance improvements were considered.

Abstract: The Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 (Section 304(d)) requires the General Accounting Office to perform an annual audit of DOE's Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management. The first annual audit report (to be issued in spring 1984) will focus on DOE's organization and management structure, progress in siting decisions for a geologic repository, and establishment of a Nuclear Waste Fund to finance the program. As the DOE program progresses, GAO will be addressing a variety of other issues surrounding development of a waste repository, interim spent fuel storage, and DOE research and development.

Abstract: The Nuclear Waste Policy Act (NWPA) of 1982 identifies Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) as an option for providing safe and reliable management of high-level radioactive waste or spent fuel. The Act requires the Department of Energy (DOE) to complete by June 1, 1985, a study of the need for and feasibility of MRS facilities for interim storage of nuclear wastes and to submit to Congress a proposal for the development of such facilities. This paper describes the status of the program established by DOE to comply with the MRS provisions of the Act.

Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA, Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Otzinger, Burton, Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA, Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA; Somoano, Robert, Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA, Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA
Abstract: An ambient temperature rechargeable Li-TiS//2 cell has been cycled under conditions which simulate aerospace applications. A novel charge/discharge state-of-charge control scheme was used, together with tapered current charging, to overcome deleterious effects associated with end-of-charge and end-of-discharge voltages. The study indicates that Li-TiS//2 cells hold promise for eventual synchronous satellite-type applications. Problem areas associated with performance degradation and reconditioning effects are identified.

Authors: Blevins Melvin L., Williams Dennis E.
Title: MANAGEMENT OF GASOLINE LEAKS - A POSITIVE OUTLOOK.
Affiliations: Los Angeles Dep of Water &, Power, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Los Angeles Dep of Water & Power, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Blevins, Melvin L., Los Angeles Dep of Water &, Power, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Los Angeles Dep of Water & Power, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Williams, Dennis E., Los Angeles Dep of Water &, Power, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Los Angeles Dep of Water & Power, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Abstract: It is important that early discovery and containment of any suspected leak be made as soon as possible so that recovery procedures may be started and the area of gasoline removal minimized. The first phase of the clean-up process involves removal of free gasoline to the point where no more drains by gravity resulting in only pellicular gasoline adhering as films to the surfaces of the porous media. Once recovery of all free gasoline is complete, areation of the contaminated zone is accomplished, (when geohydrologic conditions permit) by lowering the water table below the zone of suspected contamination. This areation promotes rapid bacteriological degradation of the remaining pellicular gasoline be several bacterial species (Pseudomonas and Arthrobacter) which utilize gasoline as a source of energy.
Index Keywords: GASOLINE - Storage; TANKS - Leak Detection; WATER POLLUTION - Control; BIODEGRADATION; GASOLINE SPILL CLEANUP PROCEDURES; LEAK CONTAINMENT; UNDERGROUND STORAGE TANKS; WATER RESOURCES

Title: FURTHERING BETTER COMMUNICATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF NUCLEAR ISSUES THROUGH PUBLIC EDUCATION: A PUBLIC SCHOOL TEACHER'S PERSPECTIVE.
Affiliations: Jackson Middle Sch, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Jackson Middle Sch, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Danfelser, Maryanne, Jackson Middle Sch, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Jackson Middle Sch, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Recent reports of national commissions and study groups have pointed out that the American educational system is not meeting the needs of its students. Uniformly, the reports call for a new instructional focus designed to achieve the goal of 'universal scientific and technological literacy for citizenship. ' The population's inability to deal with numerous controversial science-related social issues forms the basis for this call for educational reform. Foremost on the list of science-related social issues are nuclear issues in general and the storage of nuclear waste in particular. This paper discusses the dilemmas faced by educators who attempt to deal with science-related social issues. Also, it addresses the need for instructional materials in order to effectively address nuclear issues in the classroom.
Index Keywords: EDUCATION - Teaching; CONTROVERSIAL SCIENCE-RELATED SOCIAL ISSUES; NUCLEAR ISSUES INSTRUCTION; SCIENCE EDUCATION; SCIENTIFIC LITERACY FOR CITIZENSHIP; NUCLEAR ENERGY

Authors: O'Brien Paul D., Shirley Clinton G.
Title: EFFECT OF WASTE AGE ON THE DESIGN OF A GEOLOGIC REPOSITORY.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: O'Brien, Paul D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Shirley, Clinton G., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: The age of the waste influences the deposition of decay energy in the waste packages themselves and in the geologic medium in which the waste packages are emplaced for disposal. In the short term, there is a local temperature pulse that is the principal consideration in the design of waste canisters - which, of course, are tailored to the individual waste forms to be emplaced. In the longer term, and on a more regional scale, the thermomechanical response of the host rock to areal energy deposition determines the design of the disposal arrays within the repository. This paper is concerned with the latter problem. It is shown that the effect of waste age variability on the thermomechanical stability of the host geology can be minimized by the proper choice of waste canister spacings.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR REACTORS - Spent Fuels; AREAL ENERGY DEPOSITION; CANISTER SPACING; NEVADA NUCLEAR WASTE STORAGE INVESTIGATIONS; SOLIDIFIED HIGH-LEVEL WASTE; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS

Title: FUEL MANAGEMENT FOR EXTENDED FUEL BURNUP IN PWRs.
Source title: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
Affiliations: Westinghouse Electric Corp, Nuclear, Fuel Div, Pittsburgh, PA, USA, Westinghouse Electric Corp, Nuclear Fuel Div, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kapil, Sushil, Westinghouse Electric Corp, Nuclear, Fuel Div, Pittsburgh, PA, USA, Westinghouse Electric Corp, Nuclear Fuel Div, Pittsburgh, PA, USA; Dziadosz, David, Westinghouse Electric Corp, Nuclear, Fuel Div, Pittsburgh, PA, USA, Westinghouse Electric Corp, Nuclear Fuel Div, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Abstract: Extension of the region average discharge burnup in pressurized water reactors (PWRs) beyond the current 35 GWd/MTU would reduce spent fuel storage requirements and improve uranium resource utilization. This paper summarizes the results of a U. S. Department of Energy-sponsored design study to extend the discharge burnups using realistic fuel management schemes. To evaluate the impact of extended burnup on reactor safety and to determine whether special licensing initiatives would be required, four major accidents were analyzed for all transition cycles and kinetics parameters evaluated for the fourth cycle. The reference analysis approach was used with current Surry unit licensing requirements as the basis.

Abstract: Since 1970, defense transuranic (TRU) waste has been placed into 20-yr retrievable storage at the Radioactive Waste Management Complex at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL). A major objective of the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) Nuclear Waste Management Program is to remove all retrievably stored transuranic waste from the INEL. To minimize costs, the Stored Waste Examination Pilot Plant (SWEPP) is being developed to certify INEL-stored transuranic waste without container opening or waste processing. The nondestructive examination (NDE) and assay techniques described in this paper that will be used in SWEPP include assay, radiological surveys, real-time radiography (RTR), and container integrity examinations.

Abstract: Large volumes of transuranic (TRU) waste forms are generated annually in defense-related activities at several Department of Energy (DOE) contractor sites. Knowledge of radionuclide identification and quantification is required for accountability and classification for subsequent processing, storage, or burial. For several years Los Alamos has been developing and applying techniques of TRU assay for a variety of material matrixes and package geometries. This paper describes these systems which have been based on several detection techniques, including active and passive gamma spectroscopy, active and passive neutron detection and interrogation, and electron accelerator-based interrogation.

Abstract: Liquid-based solar heating systems with different types of long-term heat storages for northern high latitudes are considered. The computer models developed describe the energy system as a whole, taking into account the dynamical couplings and restrictions. The models have been applied to various thermal performance analyses and to different case studies regarding the general feasibility of a district solar heating system for a cold climate.

Abstract: The Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 confirms the Federal responsibility for nuclear waste management and provides for unprecedented involvement by States, Indian tribes and the public. The Act provides a comprehensive framework for disposing of spent nuclear fuel and high-level radioactive wastes of domestic origin generated by civilian nuclear power reactors. This paper does not attempt to cover all provisions of the Act, but will instead center on the schedule and current status and siting of the first two geologic repositories.

Abstract: This paper discusses U. S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) preparation of regulations to provide for the licensing of long-term storage by the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) of spent fuel and high-level waste (HLW) in monitored retrievable storage (MRS) facilities. Proposed regulations are being developed so that MRS licensing may proceed without undue delay, should Congress approve siting, construction, and operation of such an installation.

Abstract: The authors state that defense transuranic (TRU) waste retrievably stored at U. S. Department of Energy waste storage and waste generating sites will ultimately be disposed of in a permanent waste disposal facility in Carlsbad, New Mexico. This waste storage facility known as the WIPP (Waste Isolation Pilot Plant) is scheduled for routine operation in 1989. In preparation for meeting the WIPP waste receipt schedule, the Transuranic Waste Systems Office of Rockwell International has the responsibility to fund, establish, coordinate, and monitor milestones pertaining to development of transportation systems and waste containers. Waste containers have been developed for compatibility with licensable transportation systems now under development.

Authors with affiliations: Roman, Charles L., Roberts & Schaefer Co, Power, Systems Div, Chicago, IL, USA, Roberts & Schaefer Co, Power Systems Div, Chicago, IL, USA
Abstract: To put some perspective on the magnitude of the U. S. coal reserves, the total of identified and estimated coal resources remaining in the ground in 1980 was approximately 4 trillion tons. Total coal production last year was 800 million tons, and if we assume a 7% compound growth rate annually until our reserves are depleted, it would take 125 years to use up our known coal reserves. The electric power industry, as consumer of two-thirds of the nation's coal output, is thus assured of a reliable, long-term fuel supply for at least the next century, while energy alternatives are explored and new technologies are developed. The purpose of this paper is to describe state-of-the-art concepts, sub-systems and equipment used in the flow of coal from the mine to the power plant storage silos.

Abstract: An energy flow control diagram is presented for an energy storage flywheel system. Authors with affiliations: Kuriki, K., Inst of Space & Astronautical, Science, Tokyo, Jpn, Inst of Space & Astronautical Science, Tokyo, Jpn; Harada, H., Inst of Space & Astronautical, Science, Tokyo, Jpn, Inst of Space & Astronautical Science, Tokyo, Jpn; Gohnai, T., Inst of Space & Astronautical, Science, Tokyo, Jpn, Inst of Space & Astronautical Science, Tokyo, Jpn; Yoshida, T., Inst of Space & Astronautical, Science, Tokyo, Jpn, Inst of Space & Astronautical Science, Tokyo, Jpn; Ijichi, K., Inst of Space & Astronautical, Science, Tokyo, Jpn, Inst of Space & Astronautical Science, Tokyo, Jpn; Obara, H., Inst of Space & Astronautical, Science, Tokyo, Jpn, Inst of Space & Astronautical Science, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: The capacitor as an energy storage for quasi-steady MPD arcjet thruster (MPD thruster) is required to be light, compact and endurable to a large number of pulses. While the electrolytic capacitor is excellent in energy density, it has inherent limitation in life and endurance. An alternative capacitor may be the metallized plastic film capacitor which has semipermanent life and potentiality of smaller specific mass. A 15% reduction in coefficient of mass per energy was attained by using thin film and improving capacitor design. For further mass reduction, sample capacitors were fabricated and tested to determine which type is better, impregnated or not impregnated with dielectric fluid; of 3 mu m or 3. 8 mu m thick film; flat or cylindrical; and small or large size. Experimental results proved that the plastic film can be almost competitive with electrolytic capacitor with respect to energy density.
Index Keywords: PROPULSION - Aerospace Applications; DIELECTRIC FLUIDS; ENERGY DENSITY; MASS REDUCTION; METALLIZED PLASTIC FILM CAPACITORS; MPD THRUSTERS; SMALL SPECIFIC MASS; CAPACITORS

Authors with affiliations: Groom, Nelson J., NASA, Langley Research Cent,, Hampton, VA, USA, NASA, Langley Research Cent, Hampton, VA, USA
Abstract: The basic concept of the Annular Momentum Control Device (AMCD) is that of a rotating annular rim suspended by noncontacting magnetic bearings and driven by a noncontacting electromagnetic spin motor. Highlights are presented of some of the design requirements for AMCD's in general and descriptions are provided of how these requirements were met in the implementation of a laboratory test model AMCD. An AMCD background summary is presented.

Abstract: The Goddard Space Flight Center (GSFC) and the University of Maryland (UM) Mechanical Engineering Department have a common interest in flywheels and have cooperated since the mid-1970's in designing and testing flywheel components. GSFC/UM is currently involved in studying application of a graphite/epoxy, magnetically suspended, pierced disk flywheel for the combined function of spacecraft attitude control and energy storage (ACES). The results of applying design and analysis computer codes to a magnetically suspended interference assembled rotor show specific energy densities of 42 Wh/lb (92. 4 Wh/kg) are obtained for a 1. 6 kWh system.

Title: MERITS OF FLYWHEELS FOR SPACECRAFT ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gross, Sidney, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA,, USA, Boeing Aerospace Co, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: Flywheel energy storage systems have a very good potential for use in spacecraft. This system can be superior to alkaline secondary batteries and regenerable fuel cells in most of the areas that are important in spacecraft applications. Of special importance, relative to batteries, are lighter weight, longer cycle and operating life, and high efficiency which minimizes solar array size and the amount of orbital makeup fuel required. The major advantages and disadvantages of flywheel energy storage systems are evaluated.

Authors with affiliations: Brown, F.T., Lehigh Univ, Bethlehem, PA, USA, Lehigh Univ, Bethlehem, PA, USA
Abstract: Various control circuit concepts are presented in which fluid control valves switch between discrete states. From consideration of the load dynamics it is seen that the control likely should be separated into two distinct modes: A mode with aperiodic, relatively infrequent and precisely timed switching, and a pulse-width-modulation mode. The considerations include the predictability of the control action and energy dissipation. Particular attention is focused on the idea of an optimum inertive fluid coupling between the valve(s) and the load, and on limitations imposed on the bandwidth and the energy efficiency by the switching time of the valve(s).

Abstract: The power tool which will be used to replace the attitude control system in the SMM spacecraft is being modified to operate from a self contained battery. The extravehicular mobility unit (EMU) battery was tested for the power tool application. The results obtained during this study show the EMU battery is capable of operating the power tool within the pulse current range of 2. 0 to 15. 0 amperes and battery temperature range of minus 10 to 40 degrees Celsius.

Abstract: APL has used several different types of charge control systems on their spacecraft. Some have used dissipative shunts to get rid of the excess solar array power; some have used non-dissipative shunts and some have used a hybrid system. Although they have all worked reasonably well, there are tradeoffs to be made between the impact on the thermal design caused by the dissipative devices and the generation of conducted emissions caused by the switching of non-dissipative devices.

Title: WHAT KIND OF BATTERY FOR ELECTRIC VEHICLES?
Affiliations: Royal Inst of Technology, Dep of, Chemical Technology, Stockholm, Swed, Royal Inst of Technology, Dep of Chemical Technology, Stockholm, Swed
Authors with affiliations: Lindstrom, Olle, Royal Inst of Technology, Dep of, Chemical Technology, Stockholm, Swed, Royal Inst of Technology, Dep of Chemical Technology, Stockholm, Swed
Abstract: Prospects for electric vehicles (EV) are considered and storage battery options are assessed. US and Japanese efforts to develop EV batteries for energy and resource conservation are reported, with some prototypes reaching approx. 7 Wh/kg. The life, cost and reliability of new batteries are examined. The lead/acid battery and its challenges, the nickel/iron battery are still considered to be the most popular, however the zinc/bromide battery is closing in as the top contender. Key data for other batteries are summarized.

Title: IMAGE PICKUP TUBES.
Affiliations: Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab,, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ishioka, Sachio, Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab,, Tokyo, Jpn, Hitachi Ltd, Central Research Lab, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: When we consider the three well-known applications of amorphous selenium, in solar cells, electrophotography, and the image pickup tubes, it is not surprising that the material that has shown such great promise for practical photovoltaic cells should also be useful in the other two applications. Similarly, since hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) has shown itself useful in solar cells, it ought to be regarded as a candidate for the other two uses. However, certain additional properties that go beyond the needs of energy conversion are required if a-Si:H is to be used for image processing. That is why much more time is needed for the development of imaging applications than for solar cell applications. This section focuses on a-Si:H image pickup tubes and presents a-Si:H property requirements and fabrication and impurity doping techniques, as well as the structure of photoconductive targets. Pickup tube characteristics that have been attained and some of their applications will be described.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON TUBES, IMAGE STORAGE; SEMICONDUCTING SILICON - Amorphous; A-SI:H IMAGE PICKUP TUBES; IMPURITY DOPING TECHNQIUES; STRUCTURE OF PHOTOCONDUCTIVE TARGETS; IMAGE PROCESSING

Affiliations: Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK,, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ramakumar, R., Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK,, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK, USA
Abstract: After breifly reviewing the wind characteristics, basic components of a wind electric conversion system (WECS), types, characteristics, classification, and a state-of-the-art of wind electric conversion technology are presented. Energy storage and reconversion options and other utilization aspects are discussed, followed by a simplified approach to assess the economics of WECS. Research and development needs, and some of the key technical, operational, and economic issues involved in the large-scale and small-scale entry of WECS into the energy systems of the future are also examined. A selected bibliography and a reasonably comprehensive list of references are included for the benefit of readers seeking additional and more detailed information.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WIND TURBINES; ENERGY STORAGE AND RECONVERSION SYSTEM; WECS; WIND CHARACTERISTICS; WIND POWER

Abstract: India's first experimental communication satellite, APPLE, carried a 12 AH Ni-Cd battery for supplying power during eclipse. Failure to deploy one of the two solar panels resulted in the battery operating in a high temperature environment - around 40 C. This also resulted in the battery being used in diurnal cycles rather than just half yearly eclipse seasons. This paper describes the management and performance of the battery during its life of two years. An attempt to identify the probable degradation mechanisms is also made.

The batteries were discharged at several rates and temperatures both before and after environmental testing. Batteries were heated inside a closed chamber until they vented. Samples of the vented gases were analyzed, especially for components which might be toxic. The test results reported in this paper raise concerns about each of the proposed batteries.

Abstract: A study was undertaken to develop a comprehensive reservoir operation simulation model of the Cumberland River Basin, located in the states of Kentucky and Tennessee. Hydropower production from nine multipurpose projects was simulated using the computer program 'HEC-5, Simulation of Flood Control and Conservation Systems. ' Simulations were made for periods having both severe droughts and floods. Alternatives were evaluated and criteria yielding the most energy benefit using existing operating constraints, storage allocations and installed capacities were determined. Simulation model results using these criteria were used as a basis for determining management for best utilization of the existing system and for evaluating potential increases in energy production due to changes in system management, storage reallocation or increasing plant capacity.

Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) has a program to identify and develop potential repository sites in salt formations for storage of commercial high-level nuclear waste. Parsons-Redpath, a Joint Venture of The Ralph M. Parsons Company and the J. S. Redpath Corporation, is the Construction Manager (CM) for the Exploratory Shaft Facility (ESF) in Salt Project. A large diameter vertical shaft will be excavated to provide access to the referenced horizon in a salt formation for in-situ testing and site characterization.

Authors with affiliations: Bauer, R.H., US DOE, Office of Civilian, Radioactive Waste, Washington, DC,, USA, US DOE, Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The reactor spent fuel storage capacity must be expanded between now and the projected availability of geologic repositories and/or monitored retrievable storage facilities. The Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 (NWPA) charges the Department of Energy with the responsibility for encouraging and expediting new techniques for storing spent fuel at reactor sites. This paper briefly recounts the assignments of responsibility under NWPA and describes the concepts being pursued by the Department of Energy and its partners and why they may offer attractive alternatives provided they can be licensed in a timely manner.

Abstract: As part of a Department of Energy sponsored program to develop energy storage systems, Sandia National Laboratories (Sandia) is involved in the development of sealed lead-acid batteries capable of deep-discharge operation. These batteries will be particularly attractive for photovoltaic power systems since they are totally maintenance-free. This effort is an extension of existing technology employing an immobilized, starved electrolyte system with internal recombination of oxygen.

Abstract: The paper discusses a passive solar 'Low Energy Requirement' home, which incorporates an R37 insulation envelope and vapor barrier on all six sides of the structure, very heavy thermal storage, and an integrated air handling system. The houses are characterized by low air infiltration, stable humidity levels of 45-50 percent, and comfortable interior temperatures. Through the use of innovative construction techniques LER homes have avoided many of the limitations that have characterized energy efficient solar heated residences.

Abstract: New applications for lead-acid batteries, such as electric vehicle propulsion, demand high specific energy and power and good cycle life. Cell test results on two Improved State of the Art (ISOA) battery designs are described. Capacities and material utilization are shown as a function of both discharge rate and temperature. Cycle life data at 80 and 100% depth of discharge are presneted and failure modes are discussed.

Abstract: The fraction of theoretical discharge capacity available in practical PbO//2 electrodes generally lies between 15-40%. This compares unfavourably with other battery positives such as the Nickel electrode, where utilizations in the region of 100% are obtainable, even at high discharge rates. Any improvement in the utilization of active material in PbO//2 cathodes would bring immediate benefit in increasing the achievable energy density, which is the one area where the Pb/acid battery contrasts adversely with other battery types. Energy density is particularly important for new applications, such as electric vehicles. This paper is concerned with the investigation of higher active material utilization by optimizing electrode microstructure, and exploring whether there is a fundamental limitation to this in the PbO//2 electrode.

Abstract: The successful flights of space shuttles Columbia and Challenger initiated an entirely new generation of space research. Considerable research has been conducted to determine the operational advantages and disadvantages of a variety of rotating electrical interface devices. An evaluation is presented of the patented roll ring, a concept with over 550,000 circuit hours of test in 400 circuits. This device performs the same function as a slip ring/brush assembly, but does so by means of rolling instead of sliding electrical contact. The roll ring consists of two concentric conductive rings and at least one rolling flexible conductive element. This latter flexure is fitted to and captured in the annulus space between the two rings.

Abstract: As a first step in a longer term investigation of transient natural convection from multiple horizontal cylinder geometries which govern the transient response of many energy storage devices, and analysis of information available on the transient natural convective response of a suddenly heated single fine wire is presented. Experiments have been performed which, through a detailed comparison of optically observed fluid motion development and simultaneously measured wire temperature response, give the clearest physical picture yet of the onset of convection under these circumstances. Optical measurements were obtained with a Mach-Zehnder interferometer while wire temperatures were recorded using an unbalanced resistance bridge arrangement.

Abstract: The design and characteristics of the neutral detector based on NaI(Tl) crystals with a total weight of 2.6 t for experiments at the electron-positron storage ring VEPP-2M are described. The solid angle of the detector is 65% of 4π sr. The energy resolution for photons in the energy range 50-1000 MeV is from 20% to 10% (fwhm). For events with the detection of all final particles a further improvement of the detector resolution by means of the kinematic reconstruction method is possible. For the decay φ{symbol} → ηγ → 3γ an effective mass resolution of 10% is obtained for the η-meson mass. By the energy deposition in NaI(Tl) layers an electron/pion separation of 0.001 is achived at an energy of 500 MeV. © 1984.

Abstract: The United States is continuing to rely upon nondomestic and nonsecure sources of energy. Large quantities of energy are lost as a result of time mismatches between the supply and the demand for power. Substantial improvements in energy efficiency are possible through the use of improved energy storage; advanced energy storage can also improve the utilization of domestic energy resources (coal, geothermal, solar, wind, and nuclear) by providing energy in accordance with a user's time-varying needs. Advanced storage technologies offer potentially substantial cost and performance advantages but also have significant technical risk.

Title: NUCLEAR WASTE TRANSPORTATION: LEGAL AND REGULATORY ENVIRONMENT.
Source title: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society

Authors with affiliations: Bishop, Robert W., Northeast Utilities Service Co,, Hartford, CT, USA, Northeast Utilities Service Co, Hartford, CT, USA
Abstract: This paper describes efficient and reliable transportation as essential if nuclear energy is to be a feasible energy source. Transportation is a crucial link at every stage in the nuclear fuel cycle, from mine to mill, through enrichment to fabrication, to the plant for use in generating electricity, and ultimately to a storage or disposal site. The U. S. Department of Transportation (DOT) is responsible for enacting regulations governing the transportation of radioactive and other hazardous materials. In accordance with this responsibility, DOT enacted a highway routing rule for radioactive materials which became effective February 1, 1982. The rule, designated HM-164, applies routing requirements to carriers and shippers of both low- and high-level radioactive shipments.

Abstract: Cyclonic incinerators that operate with low excess air and high combustion intensity offer many advantages over commercially available incineration systems. The cyclonic incinerator allows incineration of liquid and gaseous wastes at minimal equipment and operating costs while simultaneously minimizing ashing/slagging problems inherent in conventional incinerators. A pilot-scale prototype cyclonic incineration system jointly developed by the Institute of Gas Technology and York-Shipley, Inc. has demonstrated stable, highly efficient combustion of a liquid waste having a low (3200 Btu/lb) heating value.

Title: CHANGES IN STORED, PASTEURIZED AND STERILIZED MILK - A DESCRIPTION BY REACTION KINETICS.
Source title: American Institute of Chemical Engineers, National Meeting
Affiliations: Technical Univ Munich, Inst for, Dairy Science & Food Process, Engineering, Munich, West Ger, Technical Univ Munich, Inst for Dairy Science & Food Process Engineering, Munich, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Kessler, H.G., Technical Univ Munich, Inst for, Dairy Science & Food Process, Engineering, Munich, West Ger, Technical Univ Munich, Inst for Dairy Science & Food Process Engineering, Munich, West Ger
Abstract: Chemical changes in heated milk, as loss in thiamine and lysine as well as formation of hydroxymethylfurfural and browning effects were investigated in a wide range of temperatures (4 to 150 degree C) and holding times (2 s to 15 months). It was found by a reaction kinetical study - determination of the order of reaction kinetics, of the velocity constant and activation energy that changes in the product, caused by the heat load, can be described by one equation for all process. The time/temperature-conditions of stored milk could be treated in the same manner as UHT-heated milk. Therefore the storage of milk can be considered as a low temperature/long time process compared to a high temperature/short time process, where in all cases the same laws of the reaction kinetics are to be used.

Abstract: Under a contract from the Department of Energy (DOE), Foster Wheeler Development Corporation performed a conceptual design study of a solar-powered steam generation system for a 92**3 dm/s (50,000 bbl/d) crude oil refinery to be constructed near Phoenix, Arizona. As a part of the study, the fossil/solar boiler interface and impact of buffer storage on ramp rates of refinery fossil-fueled boilers was effectively analyzed using dynamic models of the boilers. The result of the analysis show that 3-minute buffer storage would be sufficient to isolate the refinery from short-term solar transients. The dynamic analysis was also used to determine the limit of solar fractions for process systems without buffer storage. The analysis show that this limit will depend on the maximum steam pressure drop the process system can tolerate.

Authors: Molz Fred J., Raymond John R.
Title: STORE HEAT UNDERGROUND.
Affiliations: Auburn Univ, Engineering Experiment, Station, Auburn, AL, USA, Auburn Univ, Engineering Experiment Station, Auburn, AL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Molz, Fred J., Auburn Univ, Engineering Experiment, Station, Auburn, AL, USA, Auburn Univ, Engineering Experiment Station, Auburn, AL, USA; Raymond, John R., Auburn Univ, Engineering Experiment, Station, Auburn, AL, USA, Auburn Univ, Engineering Experiment Station, Auburn, AL, USA
Abstract: If hot or chilled water is pumped into an aquifer, stored for a period of time, and then recovered, one has produced an aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) system. The major purpose of such a system is to store energy and thereby correct a mismatch between the availability and the demand for heat or chill. The three main components of an ATES system are the heat source, the storage aquifer, and the heat sink. Subsystems include the supply and injection wells, pumps, heat exchangers, and piping. A typical duty cycle would be as follows: During a time of surplus heat, water is pumped from the supply well, heated in the heat exchanger using waste heat, and reinjected into the storage aquifer. It then remains stored for weeks or months until there is a net demand for heat. The hot water is then recovered from the aquifer, moved to the heat sink, e. g. , a district heating system, and finally returned to the supply zone of the storage aquifer. After the stored heat is exhausted, the system is ready for another injection-storage-recovery cycle. A discussion is also presented of site work and various pilot plant experiments.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS; ENERGY CONSERVATION; INJECTION WELL; STORED ENERGY; SUPPLY-INJECTION WELL; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM; HEATING

Affiliations: City Univ, Electric Vehicle, Development Group, London, Engl, City Univ, Electric Vehicle Development Group, London, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Aldous, A., City Univ, Electric Vehicle, Development Group, London, Engl, City Univ, Electric Vehicle Development Group, London, Engl
Abstract: It is debatable whether, given similar investment to that which has gone into internal-combustion engined vehicles (ICEVs) during the past hundred years, that electric vehicles could by now rival them in terms of performance, flexibility and fuel economy, as well as having the ability to use lower-grade fuels and contribute to environmental improvement. Certainly to the first inventors, electric vehicles appeared to have all the advantages that the customer wanted: of comfort, convenience and speed. The potential for electric vehicle improvement seemed unlimited. This chapter presents a historical review of electric vehicles.

Title: DEEP RECONDITIONING TESTING FOR NEAR EARTH ORBITS.

Authors with affiliations: Betz, F.E., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA; Barnes, W.L., US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA, US Naval Research Lab, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: A test plan was developed to perform deep reconditioning in direct comparison with an alternative trickle charge approach. Assuming a near earth orbit with a precession rate that produces periods of 100% sun, battery reconditioning opportunities appear. The option of trickle charge or reconditioning the batteries occurs when the satellite solar array can support the loads in 100% sun with little or no battery support (depending on battery redundancy). The results of these tests clearly demonstrate that the deep reconditioning procedure described and reported here for near earth orbit application is inferior to the alternative of trickle charging.

Title: HEAT STORAGE AND PASSIVE DISCHARGE IN STRUCTURAL MASONRY WALL: THE CALGARY CHINESE ALLIANCE CHURCH.
Affiliations: Univ of Calgary, Calgary, Alberta,, Can, Univ of Calgary, Calgary, Alberta, Can
Authors with affiliations: Lee, Tang G., Univ of Calgary, Calgary, Alberta,, Can, Univ of Calgary, Calgary, Alberta, Can
Abstract: The Calgary Chinese Alliance Church project demonstrates the potential for using a concrete block wall for storing heat collected by an array of air cooled solar air collectors. In this manner, solar heat is stored in a masonry wall for use when there is a higher heating load. The results of monitoring an existing masonry wall inside a church gymnasium built for the purpose of storing heat charged by a 100 m**2 solar collector array is described. Monitoring results indicate concrete block walls can be used effectively to store solar heat on a diurnal cycle. The storage system does not require the concrete block industry to develop a new block, nor would the masons have to modify their construction methods.

Title: Radon in earth-sheltered structures
Affiliations: U.S. Geological Survey, Reston, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Landa, E.R., U.S. Geological Survey, Reston, VA, United States
Abstract: Radon concentration in the indoor air of six residential and three non-residential earth-sheltered buildings in eastern Colorado was monitored quarterly over a nine-month period using passive, integrating detectors. Average radon concentrations during the three-month sampling periods ranged from about 1 to 9 pCi/L, although one building, a poorly ventilated storage bunker, had concentrations as high as 39 pCi/L. These radon concentrations are somewhat greater than those typically reported for conventional buildings (around 1 pCi/L); but they are of the same order of magnitude as radon concentrations reported for energy-efficient buildings which are not earth-sheltered. © 1984.
Index Keywords: ENVIRONMENTAL TESTING; HOUSES - Underground; RADON - Monitoring; EARTH-SHELTERED BUILDINGS; BUILDINGS

Abstract: A power supply unit for a pulsed plasma engine on the Engineering Test Satellite-IV is described. The engine produces an impulse of about 3 mg multiplied by (times) s by an electric discharge of an energy storage capacitor of 2 mu F charged up to 1. 5 kV. To satisfy an interface specification between the engine and the satellite, a power supply unit with high efficiency is designed and fabricated to charge the energy storage capacitor. Filters are installed to reduce a current ripple and electromagnetic noise. Protection circuits are also installed to avoid overload and runaway of the engine by its electromagnetic noise.

Abstract: For production reasons power capacitors are built up from modular units. These are then connected in series or parallel to obtain the desired performance. The air-insulated capacitor banks hitherto normally used require a lot of space at higher system voltages. To improve competitiveness and reduce space requirements, the insulation system of capacitors needs further development. This presupposes the optimization of the characteristics of the insulating material. Now that gas-insulated substations (GIS) are gaining a growing share of the market, ASEA has also developed gas-insulated capacitor designs in parallel with air-insulated capacitor banks.

Abstract: With the present approximating method, comparisons can be made between the cost of energy from renewable sources combined with storage and multi-source systems in specific situations. It turns out that, in many cases, with current investment costs lower energy prices can be reached by multi-source systems. Acceptable energy prices seem possible in many cases, using well-designed multi-source systems.

They cover other topics than the simple application of energy-saving technique, such as cogeneration, boiler efficiency, thermal insulation, refractory linings, fuel handling and storage, improved steam utilization, heat recovery and electric consumption savings. By proper management energy costs may be controlled, with pay-backs for investments in months.

Title: DESING CONSIDERATIONS FOR MODULAR GLYCOL ICE STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Calmac Manufacturing Corp,, Englewood, NJ, USA, Calmac Manufacturing Corp, Englewood, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: MacCracken, Valvin D., Calmac Manufacturing Corp,, Englewood, NJ, USA, Calmac Manufacturing Corp, Englewood, NJ, USA
Abstract: The design process for cool storage in commercial, industrial, governmental, and institutional buildings, or places of assembly is reviewed with particular reference to modular ice storage using standard chillers. Decisions regarding partial versus full storage, indoor versus outdoor storage location, use of heat exchangers, low temperature versus standard duct air temperatures, control options, and conventional heat versus heat pumping are discussed. An economic comparison of various alternative systems versus standard air conditioning is given. Finally, a design method, cost analysis, and detailed energy and demand calculations are presented for a specific example. The case for modular glycol ice storage systems that are not only lower in first cost than standard nonstorage chilled water systems but also lower in both demand and energy consumption is analyzed.

Abstract: The kinetics of the heat producing processes in undischarged lithium thionyl chloride cells under open circuit conditions have been measured by heat-conduction microcalorimetry. The cells studied, Honeywell type G2666 reserve cells, were activated as needed and the rate of open circuit heat output determined as a function of time since activation and temperature.
