Title: PERFORMANCE AND SAFETY CHARACTERISTICS OF LITHIUM-MOLYBDENUM DISULFIDE CELLS.
Affiliations: Moli Energy Ltd, Burnaby, BC, Can, Moli Energy Ltd, Burnaby, BC, Can
Authors with affiliations: Stiles, J.A., Moli Energy Ltd, Burnaby, BC, Can, Moli Energy Ltd, Burnaby, BC, Can
Abstract: Moli Energy Limited (Moli) has developed a technology base that is leading to the commercialization of a new family of electrochemical batteries. These batteries utilize the phenomenon of intercalation in a lithium-molybdenum disulfide system. The molybdenum disulfide electrode, which had been rejected for practical use, has been thoroughly investigated by Moli. The underlying causes of the early failures were carefully analyzed and the results utilized to create modifications in the molecular structure of the material. The consequent results are dramatic improvements in the utility of the material as an electrode active material. In addition Moli has developed a practical lithium electrode, which vastly reduces the problem of limited reversibility encountered in other developmental secondary lithium cells. The first product under development is a C cell, utilizing a spirally wound 'jelly roll' electrode configuration.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; FUEL CELLS - Research; JELLY ROLL ELECTRODE CONFIGURATION; LITHIUM CELL TECHNOLOGY; MOLYBDENUM DISULFIDE ELECTRODE; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: REGENERATIVE HYDROGEN-OXYGEN FUEL CELL - ELECTROLYZER SYSTEMS FOR ORBITAL ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sheibley, Dean W., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Fuel cells have played a major role in spacecraft power generation. The Gemini and Apollo programs used fuel cell power plants as the primary source of mission electrical power, with batteries as the backup. The current NASA use for fuel cells is in the orbiter program. Here, low temperature alkaline fuel cells provide all of the on-board power with no backup power source. Three power plants per shipset are utilized. The original fuel cell power plant configuration contained two 32-cell substacks connected in parallel. This configuration was flown on STS-1 through STS-8. Starting with STS-9, a three substack configuration (three 32-cell substacks connected in parallel) will be used to obtain longer life and better voltage performance.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE - Research; ELECTROLYSIS; ADVANCED ENERGY STORAGE PROGRAMS; ELECTROLYZER TECHNOLOGY; REGENERATIVE FUEL CELL SYSTEM; SPACECRAFT

Title: LiAl/FeS CELL DESIGN FOR IMPROVED SPECIFIC POWER AND ENERGY.
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Chemical, Technology Div, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Chemical Technology Div, Argonne, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kaun, T.D., Argonne Natl Lab, Chemical, Technology Div, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Chemical Technology Div, Argonne, IL, USA; Anderson, M.E., Argonne Natl Lab, Chemical, Technology Div, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Chemical Technology Div, Argonne, IL, USA
Abstract: Concomitant increases in specific power and energy are goals in developing Li-alloy/metal sulfide cells for electric vehicle batteries. Cell designs which successfully withstood electrode expansion during cell cycling have had significant hardware-weight penalties. By designing the cell to be somewhat self-restraining, a lower hardware-weight contribution was achieved along with lower cell-resistance. With the development of a deep-dischargeable LiAl-electrode, the LiAl-electrode-limiting cell design became practical. This design could use thicker electrodes because cell resistance as a function of depth of discharge is relatively constant. A new cell design integrating these aspects has demonstrated improved cell kinetics for higher specific power and energy.
Index Keywords: ELECTRODES, ELECTROCHEMICAL - Iron Sulfide; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; CELL DISCHARGE DEPTH; ELECTRODE AND COUPLE CHARACTERISTICS; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; IMPROVED CELL KINETICS; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors with affiliations: Stipanuk, D.M., Cornell Univ, Sch of Hotel, Administration, Ithaca, NY, USA, Cornell Univ, Sch of Hotel Administration, Ithaca, NY, USA; Ludington, D.C., Cornell Univ, Sch of Hotel, Administration, Ithaca, NY, USA, Cornell Univ, Sch of Hotel Administration, Ithaca, NY, USA
Abstract: Dedicated heat pump water heaters (HPWHs) are being marketed. Product literature and field studies imply that the power consumption of the HPWHs is mainly affected by ambient air temperatures and only slightly affected by the temperature of the water supply. Based on the experimental results presented, the operational efficiency of HPWHs is also affected by quantity of hot water drawoff and capacity of storage tank. These two factors influence water temperature entering the HPWH. The suggestion is made that standard tests for predicting HPWH operational performance should not be confined to just cold-start recovery tests.
Index Keywords: WATER HEATERS - Energy Utilization; COLD-START RECOVERY TESTS; DEDICATED HEAT PUMP WATER HEATERS; HOT WATER DRAWOFF; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: SUPERCONDUCTING ACCELERATING STRUCTURES FOR HIGH ENERGY ACCELERATORS.

Authors with affiliations: Piel, H., Univ of Wuppertal, Dep of Physics,, Wuppertal, West Ger, Univ of Wuppertal, Dep of Physics, Wuppertal, West Ger
Abstract: Superconducting accelerating systems are presently under design, test or construction for large e** plus -e** minus -storage rings and Linear Accelerators for Nuclear Physics research. Recent results from different laboratories and the progress in rf superconductivity of the past year is summarized briefly. New experiments with superconducting acceleratng structures for velocity of light particles at frequencies between 350 MHz and 3 GHz show that an accelerating field of 5 Mv/m is within reach today. The thermal stability of s. c. cavities has been increased significantly by improving the thermal conductivity of niobium with different techniques or by sputtering niobium onto copper cavities. Experiments with high thermal conductivity cavities at 500, 1500 and 3000 MHz and new developments in the design of superconducting structures are discussed.
Index Keywords: PHYSICS - Nuclear; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; QUENCH FIELDS; SUPERCONDUCTING STRUCTURES; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ACCELERATORS, LINEAR

Authors with affiliations: Gupta, B.P., Lord Corp, Erie, PA, USA, Lord Corp, Erie, PA, USA; Hannibal, A.J., Lord Corp, Erie, PA, USA, Lord Corp, Erie, PA, USA
Abstract: An energy storage flywheel consisting of a quasi-isotropic composite disk overwrapped by a circumferentially wound ring made of carbon fiber and an elastomeric matrix is proposed. Through analysis it has been demonstrated that with an elastomeric matrix to relieve the radial stresses, a laminated disk/ring flywheel can be designed to store at least 80. 3 Wh/kg or about 68% more than previous disk/ring designs. At the same time the simple construction is preserved.

Abstract: The disc type homopolar machine is the simplest form of an electrical machine. The machine consists of a disc rotating in an axial field provided by an electric coil positioned at the disc outside diameter. Advances in high current density current collectors and the need for high power density power supplies have resulted in increased interest in homopolar machines. In pulsed applications, the disc is accelerated to speed, thus acting as an energy storage flywheel. The characteristics of Pulsed Homopolar systems are discribed.

Authors with affiliations: Edgar, Tim A., Eagle-Picher Industries Inc,, Colorado Springs, CO, USA, Eagle-Picher Industries Inc, Colorado Springs, CO, USA
Abstract: Bi-Polar nickel hydrogen design studies have indicated a potential improvement in energy density and specific energy if positive electrodes could be manufactured in configurations of twice or more of the present 'normal' thickness. Such electrodes would have to achieve similar active material loading, utilization, and cycle life to conventional 0. 8mm I. P. U. nickel hydrogen electrodes. Eagle-Picher's experience with D. O. Abstract: The conceptual engineering design of a large-scale zinc/redox battery for solar electrical energy storage involves the management of considerable heat flows. Abstract: In order to develop a long life nickel electrode for a nickel hydrogen cell, cycle life tests of nickel electrodes were carried out. A 19 test cell matrix was made of various nickel electrode designs including three levels each of plaque mechanical strength, median pore size of the plaque, and active material loading. Title: DRY STORAGE OF LWR SPENT FUEL IN THE US: A STATUS REPORT.
Affiliations: Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab,, Richland, WA, USA, Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Newman, Darrell F., Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab,, Richland, WA, USA, Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: Dry storage is emerging as an important alternative to wet storage for mangement of LWR fuel. Dry storage is modular, passive, and can be implemented on a relatively short lead time, once it has been licensed. Thus, it is attractive for United States utilities which are nearing the limit of wet storage capacities. Dry storage of irradiated fuel has already been licensed in several countries. In the United States, dry storage concepts, including dry wells, silos (sealed concrete casks) and vaults, have been tested by the Department of Energy (DOE). Actions are also under way, in cooperation with utilities, to conduct additional unlicensed tests on metal storage casks at DOE facilities and to demonstrate licensed dry storage in metal casks and concrete silos at utility sites.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR REACTORS, LIGHT WATER - Spent Fuels; CASKS; DRY FUEL STORAGE; US DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY; NUCLEAR FUELS

Title: MANAGEMENT OF DEFENSE HIGH-LEVEL WASTE IN THE UNITED STATES.
Affiliations: US DOE, Office of Defense Waste, & Byproducts Management,, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Office of Defense Waste & Byproducts Management, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Oertel, Goetz K., US DOE, Office of Defense Waste, & Byproducts Management,, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Office of Defense Waste & Byproducts Management, Washington, DC, USA; Walton Jr., Ray D., US DOE, Office of Defense Waste, & Byproducts Management,, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Office of Defense Waste & Byproducts Management, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: Defense high-level waste (HLW) is in interim storage at three sites, the Savannah River Plant in South Carolina, the Hanford Reservation in Washington, and the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory in Idaho. The goal of the Department of Energy's program is to utilize or dispose of all new and old HLW routinely, safely, and effectively. 'Reference plans' for each of the sites describe the approaches for this disposal. The reference plans can be carried out after the National Environmental Policy Act process has been completed, funds authorized and appropriated, and results of pilot-plant experiments (or operational experience from other sites) are at hand. Major elements of the reference plans for permanent disposal of defense HLW are summarized.
Index Keywords: WASTE DISPOSAL - Military Purposes; DEFENSE WASTE; HIGH LEVEL WASTE; NUCLEAR WASTE MANAGEMENT; PERMANENT DISPOSAL PLANS; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS

Authors: Gaston Stephen J., Schiffer Stephen F.
Title: RCA SATCOM BATTERY IN-ORBIT PERFORMANCE UPDATE AND ACCELERATED LIFE TEST RESULTS.
Affiliations: RCA Astro-Electronics, Princeton,, NJ, USA, RCA Astro-Electronics, Princeton, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gaston, Stephen J., RCA Astro-Electronics, Princeton,, NJ, USA, RCA Astro-Electronics, Princeton, NJ, USA; Schiffer, Stephen F., RCA Astro-Electronics, Princeton,, NJ, USA, RCA Astro-Electronics, Princeton, NJ, USA
Abstract: The oldest operating RCA Astro geostationary spacecraft, SATCOM F1 and F2, have now completed almost 8 and 7-3/4 years in orbit, respectively, with no significant degradation of their nickel-cadmium battery performance. Battery minimum discharge voltage data are presented for these spacecraft. In addition, 2 groups of nickel-cadmium cells which are representative of those in orbit are undergoing real time eclipse-reduced suntime cycling in the laboratory. These groups of cells, which are being cycled at a maximum of 53% and 62% depth of discharge (based on actual capacity), have completed 14 and 15 eclipse seasons, respectively. Data for these groups of cells are presented and are compared with the in-orbit battery data.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Performance; ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; FLIGHT EXPERIENCE; GEOSTATIONARY ORBIT; NICKEL CADMIUM SYSTEM; SPACECRAFT

Title: INERTIAL ENERGY STORAGE FOR SPACECRAFT.
Affiliations: NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rodriguez, G.Ernest, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Abstract: The feasibility of inertial energy storage in a spacecraft power system is evaluated on the basis of a conceptual integrated design that encompasses a composite rotor, magnetic suspension, and a permanent magnet motor/generator for a 3-kw orbital average payload at a bus distribution voltage of 250 volts dc. Critical technologies identified are those pertaining to the energy storage element and are prioritized as composite wheel development, magnetic suspension, motor/generator, containment, and momentum control. Comparison with a 3-kw, 250-Vdc power system using either NiCd or NiH//2 for energy storage results in a system in which inertial energy storage offers potential advantages in lifetime, operating temperature, voltage regulation, energy density, charge control, and overall system weight reduction. The key disadvantages are attitude control interface and launch constraints.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; FLYWHEELS - Design; ADVANCED ENERGY STORAGE PROGRAMS; INERTIAL ENERGY STORAGE; MECHANICAL CAPACITOR; SPACECRAFT

Abstract: The Solar Total Energy Project (STEP) at Shenandoah, Georgia is a cooperative effort between the United States Department of Energy (DOE) and Georgia Power Company to help maximize the potential of solar energy. Sandia National Laboratories provides technical management for the U. S. Department of Energy. The design, operation, and analysis of this point focus system have been supported by a wide range of institutional and industrial organizations. When funded by DOE in 1977 as part of the National Solar Thermal Energy Program, it was the world's largest industrial application of solar cogeneration.

Abstract: According to the present-day international safeguards practices, separated plutonium is considered to be direct use material and, therefore, requires fairly intensive safeguards measures. Cost benefit analysis of alternative measures is, therefore, pertinent, particularly when the application of such measures is conditioned by a limited budget. The present paper describes an integrated system for IAEA safeguards of plutonium containers in long-term storage areas for which special conditions exist which may permit the use of simplified safeguards measures.

Title: SINGLEPASS STRATEGY FOR SOLAR WATER HEATING.
Affiliations: Lab Nacional de Engenhari e, Technologia Industrial, Dep de, Energias Renovaveis, Lisbon, Port, Lab Nacional de Engenhari e Technologia Industrial, Dep de Energias Renovaveis, Lisbon, Port
Authors with affiliations: Collares Pereira, Manuel, Lab Nacional de Engenhari e, Technologia Industrial, Dep de, Energias Renovaveis, Lisbon, Port, Lab Nacional de Engenhari e Technologia Industrial, Dep de Energias Renovaveis, Lisbon, Port
Abstract: Conventional forced circulation solar hot water systems are designed with high flow rates resulting in a well mixed storage tank and in many passes of the storage contents through the collectors during a single day. This design strategy is contrasted here with a design strategy in which each fluid element passes only once through the collector system during each day. It is explained why this singlepass strategy is thermally superior to a multipass strategy such as the first one described, resulting in solar fractions as much as 20-25% higher, for the same collecting area. The average annual energy performances of four hot water collector types are then compared for the two strategies - for a clear and temperate climate (Lisbon, Portugal) and for a colder climate with less available radiation (Ottawa, Canada).
Index Keywords: SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; 'MULTIPASS' DESIGN; 'SINGLEPASS' DESIGN; DOMESTIC HOT WATER; FLAT PLATE COLLECTOR; THERMOSYPHON; WATER HEATERS

Title: COAL, ITS PROPERTIES AND HANDLING SYSTEMS FOR INDUSTRIAL BOILERS.
Affiliations: ORBA Corp, Fairfield, NJ, USA, ORBA Corp, Fairfield, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mahr, D., ORBA Corp, Fairfield, NJ, USA, ORBA Corp, Fairfield, NJ, USA
Abstract: Coal is an attractive fuel because of its relatively low energy cost. Unlike gas or oil, however, its characteristics vary and the delivery-storage-boiler feed/discharge systems are complex. There are a variety of different technologies and arrangements available. The choices for the type of coal and handling systems are dependent upon boiler capacity and design, the mode of transportation, environmental considerations, plant layout, real estate availability, cost and reliability. Since operation and maintenance are significant factors, a present worth analysis should be completed before a system is selected. Making the right choice helps to insure that both fuel savings and system reliability are maximized.

Abstract: A fusible nitrate-nitrite-amide melt, consisting of 13% by weight K, Na, NO//3, and NaNO//3 and 87% by weight acetamide is proposed. This melt can reduce the operating temperature of a thermal storage device to 55 degree C. The authors studied the possibility of lowering the operating temperature of a thermal storage device by using fusible nitrate-nitrite-carbamide and nitrate-nitrite-acetamide solutions as storage media. These solutions meet such requirements as high phase-transformation heat, high thermal capacity and thermal conductivity, minimum cost, availability, chemical stability at operating temperature, convenience for cycling, and nontoxicity.

Abstract: A battery composed of twelve lithium/sulfur dioxide 'D' size cells in series was forced discharged at 21 amperes. This current was established by the proposed use of the battery and represented a discharge condition which the battery manufacturer felt might produce venting. Discharge of the battery into voltage reversal resulted not only in cells venting but also in the violent rupture of at least one cell.

Abstract: The first Nickel Hydrogen battery deployment onboard a commercial geosynchronous communications satellite was realized with the launch of the INTELSAT V, Flight 6 spacecraft on 19 May 1983. The initial five spacecrafts in this series are equipped with Nickel Cadmium batteries. Based on the data available on both types of batteries, design and operational performance comparisons of INTELSAT-V Nickel Hydrogen and Nickel Cadmium batteries are presented. General characteristics of the INTELSAT-V spacecraft as related to electrical-power-subsystem functions and battery operations are summarized.

Authors with affiliations: Tiller, Smith E., NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent,, Greenbelt, MD, USA, NASA, Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, MD, USA
Abstract: The IUE spacecraft was launched on January 26, 1978 into an eccentric synchronous orbit with inclinations of 28. 94 degree to the equator. The IUE power system contains two 6 ampere hour nickel-cadmium batteries designed to provide a beginning life of 145 watts during the eclipse seasons. In addition, battery power is required when the main buss exceeds the solar array output. The spacecraft design life was for three years with a design goal for 5 years. As of November 1983 the batteries have supported the spacecraft requirements for 70 months with excellent performance.

Authors: Bechtold Richard L., Timbario Thomas J.

Authors with affiliations: Bechtold, Richard L., Mueller Associates Inc, Baltimore,, MD, USA, Mueller Associates Inc, Baltimore, MD, USA; Timbario, Thomas J., Mueller Associates Inc, Baltimore,, MD, USA, Mueller Associates Inc, Baltimore, MD, USA
Abstract: The most important factor affecting the economic feasibility of fleet conversions is the amount of fuel used by that fleet over a year. Simple payback alone should not be used to determine economic feasibility for vehicle conversion to natural gas. A detailed economic analysis in which parameters can be quickly and easily changed provides a substantial advantage when trying to determine the economic feasibility of conversion. A computer program designed for this purpose is an effective and practical analysis tool. As the compressor size is increased in fast-fill systems, the need for intermediate natural gas storage decreases. Due to the complexity of economic feasibility analyses, it is not possible to generalize results to other fleets.

Abstract: Today, the steel industry is becoming more dependent on process control and data acquisition systems. The industry has decided to increase its involvement in automation and digital process control. There is an increased emphasis on the production of high quality steel and on more efficient operations. The steel industry as a whole is tightening the coupling between its processes. Closer cooperation between processes will reduce manufacturing costs, especially energy costs. For example: direct rolling is a steel industry version of 'Just in time production'. The goal is to roll steel into products immediately, without expensive storage at high temperature. The fuel savings can be significant. This paper discusses the process control system which can provide scheduling for this kind of operation.

Abstract: The cycle life of secondary batteries decreases exponentially with depth of discharge. The optimum depth of discharge was determined for selected lead-acid, Ni-Zn and Zn-Br batteries. Affiliations: Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK,, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK, USA
Authors with affiliations: Parker, Jerald D., Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK,, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK, USA
Abstract: There is increasing interest in the use of solar energy to produce electricity. The solar thermal system uses collected solar thermal energy to operate heat engines which in turn rotate convential electric generators. The Carnot principle requires that the solar energy be collected at temperatures that are high relative to ambient, and this is usually accomplished by the use of concentrating collectors. The collected energy may or may not be stored depending upon the load requirements and economics. The more common types of solar heat engines use either the Rankine, the Sterling, or the Brayton cycle. This paper discusses the basic components that make up a typical solar thermal energy conversion system - concentrating collectors, thermal storage systems and heat engines.

Abstract: The inverse relationship between membrane resistivity and selectivity, and the resultant effect on cell coulombic and energy efficiency, has been quantified. In-cell membrane evaluations have shown that by increasing operating temperatures and using a low resistivity membrane, higher voltage and energy efficiencies are obtained, in spite of lower coulombic efficiencies. Stack costs can be reduced because less selective membranes are readily available and less expensive than their selective counterparts. Capacity utilization is near 90 percent even at high current densities.

Abstract: In both normal movement and in sports performance most fast movements take place in the presence of slower ongoing eccentric or concentric motion. That such movement patterns are needed for optimal performance seems beyond question. Studies of gross human performance suggest that ongoing slower movements effect fast movement trajectories, and that certain muscle properties, especially the force-velocity relation and the series elastic storage capacity of muscle, are of special significance. The purpose of the present study has been to expand recent simulation work on fast-slow eye movement interaction to more complex situations such as movements about the elbow and knee joints. Highly nonlinear eighth-order antagonistic muscle models have been developed and are used here to investigate such interaction phenomena in detail.

Abstract: Computer and manual calculational procedures to optimize the size of cooling thermal energy storage systems for buildings with time-of-use electric rates are developed. Authors with affiliations: Forward, Robert L., Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA, Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA
Abstract: The antimatter should be in the form of antiprotons since, unlike positrons or antielectrons, the antiproton does not convert into gamma rays upon annihilation, but instead two-thirds of the energy is emitted as charged particles (pions) whose kinetic energy can be converted into thrust by interaction with a magnetic field nozzle or a working fluid. Antiprotons are already being generated, captured, cooled, and stored at a number of particle physics laboratories around the world, albeit in small quantities. A number of techniques for the efficient generation, long-term storage, and effective utilization of milligram quantities of antiprotons for space propulsion are discussed.

In particular the authors selected the sulfospinel CuCo//2S//4 which performed well in previous studies. CuCo//2S//4 has been prepared from stoichiometric mixtures of copper sulfide, CuS in combination with either Co(metal) or CoS or CoS//2 and sulfur in a quartz furnace under a sulfur atmosphere. The preparation procedure involved cooling of the material after the first firing, subsequent grinding to achieve a better uniformity and a second firing.

Abstract: The HDR-concept initially invented and tested at Los Alamos Scientific Laboratories has been considered for domestic heating in Sweden. The technique to produce large heat exchanger surfaces, by hydraulic fracturing, within the bedrock has in Sweden been tried at shallow depth, in order to create a subsurface energy storage. The initial tests have been very promising and it is concluded that it is possible to produce a competitive low cost energy storage in this way. Experiences from the hydraulic fracturing experiments at shallow depths will be considered when planning a program for the new test site at Fjallbacka, SW Sweden.

Abstract: One of Europe's most important rivers, the Rhine, flows into the North Sea near Rotterdam. Rotterdam is known as one of the largest ports in the world, not only for oil and bulk material, but also for containers. More than 30,000 seagoing vessels visit this port annually and, presently, huge bulk carriers with a draught of 72 ft can be received. At the mouth of Rhine near Rotterdam, a vast sand flat, called the Maasvlakte, was turned into an outer port in the 1960s, where large ships could be received for bulk and container handling. Abstract: The hydrogen-bromine redox couple is a good medium for electric energy storage. Hydrogen and bromine electrode reactions are quite reversible. Therefore, high electric to electric efficiency can be expected. Hydrogen bromine cells are capable of operating at high current density and thus power density. This should lead to lower capital cost. Since the hydrogen-bromine system is a flow cell, the reactants are stored outside the cell stack. This makes the operation and storage size very flexible. The system can be operated in peak load leveling or stand-by mode.

Abstract: The net thermal decomposition of ammonium hydrogen sulfate (AHS) in the presence of ZnO has been studied as part of an energy storage cycle. Optimum temperature and ZnO/AHS mole ratio have been determined. The rate of reaction has been evaluated as a function of temperature, and an Arrhenius activaiton energy of 24. 7 plus or minus 0. 6 kcal/mol calcualted. This agrees well with the activation energies calculated in a sepatrate investigation of the decomposition of AHS in the presence of the group IA metal sulfates. A reaction mechanism that involves the formation of ammonium pyrosulfate and triammonium hydrogen sulfate as intermediates, and ammonia, water and zinc oxysulfate as end products is proposed.

Abstract: A superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit is suitable for power system stablization because it can provide positive damping by absorbing or releasing energy with a relatively fast response time, 10 ms. In the fall of 1982, a SMES unit was installed at the Tacoma Substation of the Bonneville Power Administration as an experiment in monitoring, predicting and improving system stability. This paper reports principally on the system testing.

Title: THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE IN NORTH CAROLINA PUBLIC SCHOOLS.
Affiliations: E. A. LeBlanc & Associates,, Raleigh, NC, USA, E. A. LeBlanc & Associates, Raleigh, NC, USA
Authors with affiliations: LeBlanc, Edmond A., E. A. LeBlanc & Associates,, Raleigh, NC, USA, E. A. LeBlanc & Associates, Raleigh, NC, USA
Abstract: In the fall of 1982, a number of related factors began coming together to encourage in-depth evaluation of widespread application of thermal energy storage. This paper reports on studies to evaluate the potential for widespread application of thermal energy storage within the public school sector. Preliminary research was conducted into the technical and economic implications of potential widespread application of thermal energy storage. The resulting conclusion was that widespread application of thermal energy storage had the potential of significantly benefiting the public school sector and its taxpayers as well as the electric utility industry and all electric ratepayers throughout the State of North Carolina.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Energy Conservation; ELECTRIC UTILITIES - Rates; DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS; ECONOMIC IMPACT ANALYSIS; ELECTRIC RATE SCHEDULE DESIGN; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SCHOOL BUILDINGS

Affiliations: EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Authors with affiliations: D'Ambrosia, J.T., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Anderson, B.C., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Alrich, D.A., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Brown, B.W., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Cook, J.F., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Scown, V.S., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Abstract: Transuranic waste results from the Department of Energy's (DOE) national defense and energy research and development activities. This paper provides a review of DOE TRU waste certification activities at waste generating and waste storage sites. These activities include development and documentation of certification procedures, integration of waste generator activities, and the development of nondestructive examination equipment. Real-time radiography is being utilized to nondestructively identify waste contents, ultrasonics is used for verifying container integrity of waste packages, and passive and active neutron measurements are used to assay the waste package.
Index Keywords: RADIOGRAPHY - Applications; WASTE DISPOSAL - Ultrasonic Applications; CONTAINER INTEGRITY; REAL-TIME RADIOGRAPHY; TRANSURANIC (TRU) WASTE RESULTS; WASTE CERTIFICATION PROGRAM; WASTE ISOLATION PILOT PLANT (WIPP); WASTE STORAGE SITES; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS

Title: SEASONAL STORAGE FOR DISTRICT HEATING AND COOLING.
Source title: Official Proceedings - Annual Conference of the International District Heating Association
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Dep of, Civil Engineering, Milwaukee, WI,, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Dep of Civil Engineering, Milwaukee, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gyuk, Imre, Univ of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Dep of, Civil Engineering, Milwaukee, WI,, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Dep of Civil Engineering, Milwaukee, WI, USA
Abstract: Seasonal energy storage is described as a means to preserve energy for the needs of a sizeable area and over an extended time span. The amount of energy involved will, therefore, be very large. The author states that the medium of energy storage will be extremely inexpensive. It must also have a reasonably high heat capacity and it must be environmentally acceptable. Water is ideally suited for this. A particularly effective approach when water is used is to inject it into an aquifer. This way the container is free and also flexible in size. The method can be used with hot or cold water. Projects are discussed which have been conducted in North America, Scandinavia and Europe. It is concluded that seasonal storage must be considered as part of a cogeneration or district heating system.
Index Keywords: COGENERATION PLANTS; ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Energy Conservation; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; INDUSTRIAL EFFLUENTS; LOW GRADE HOT WATER; MUNICIPAL WASTE; HEATING

Title: BLANKET CONCEPT FOR NEUTRON-FEEDBACK ICF REACTORS.
Source title: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
Affiliations: Univ of Illinois, Urbana, IL, USA, Univ of Illinois, Urbana, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kislev, Hanoch, Univ of Illinois, Urbana, IL, USA, Univ of Illinois, Urbana, IL, USA; Miley, G.H., Univ of Illinois, Urbana, IL, USA, Univ of Illinois, Urbana, IL, USA
Abstract: The interest in a 'neutron-feedback'-type inertial confinement fusion (ICF) reactor left bracket i. e. , one where neutrons from the microexplosions power a nuclear-pumped laser (NPL) that serves as the driver right bracket is reviewed along with two recent developments. First, power flow analyses have shown the concept to be very attractive, e. g. , energy self-sufficiency can be achieved for low-gain targets. Second, it appears that energy storage requirements can be achieved using a nuclear-pumped transfer laser. This paper addresses a unique blanket design that provides an NPL section and is consistent with other generic requirements for ICF reactors, e. g. , first-wall protection, adequate tritium breeding, energy removal, and adequate shielding. Drawings of several key sections of the blanket are shown.
Index Keywords: TRITIUM; BLANKET CONCEPT; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; INERTIAL CONFINEMENT FUSION; NEUTRON FEEDBACK; NUCLEAR PUMPED LASER; NUCLEAR REACTORS

Title: NUCLEAR CRITICALITY SAFETY OVERSIGHT PROGRAM AT THE ROCKY FLATS PLANT.
Source title: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant,, Golden, CO, USA, Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant, Golden, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: McCarthy, J.D., Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant,, Golden, CO, USA, Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant, Golden, CO, USA
Abstract: The Rocky Flats Plant, a U. S. Department of Energy (DOE)-owned facility operated by Rockwell International, is engaged in operations that involve handling significant quantities of fissile material. Operations described in this paper include production processing, waste treatment, research and development, storage, and transportation. Due to the magnitude and complexity of these operations, nuclear criticality safety is one of the primary concerns.
Index Keywords: PERSONNEL TRAINING; FISSILE MATERIAL; PRODUCTION PROCESSING; ROCKY FLATS PLANT; SAFETY OVERSIGHT PROGRAM; SUMMARY ONLY; WASTE TREATMENT; NUCLEAR REACTORS

Title: COOLING WITH OFF-PEAK ENERGY: DESIGN IMPLICATIONS OF DIFFERENT RATE SCHEDULES.
Affiliations: RCF Inc, Chicago, IL, USA, RCF Inc, Chicago, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Townsend, S.B., RCF Inc, Chicago, IL, USA, RCF Inc, Chicago, IL, USA; Asbury, J.G., RCF Inc, Chicago, IL, USA, RCF Inc, Chicago, IL, USA
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to examine the system design implications of alternative electric utility rate structures. Rate schedules from over 30 electric utilities were collected and analyzed to identify representative schedules currently faced by commercial-building customers in the United States. Three representative rate forms, having the following characteristics, were selected for the analysis, namely, demand charge with rachet and a declining-block energy charge; declining-block energy charge with the block-widths dependent on billing demand; and seasonally varying demand charge and time-of-day energy charge. Each of the three representative rates provides a substantial incentive to reduce demand by shifting the daily cooling load from the peak to the off-peak hours.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER UTILIZATION - Costs; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ELECTRIC UTILITY RATE SCHEDULES; OFF-PEAK COOLING; POWER DEMAND REDUCTION; COLD STORAGE

Authors: Allen R.D., Kannberg L.D., Raymond J.R.
Title: Seasonal thermal energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Allen, R.D.; Kannberg, L.D.; Raymond, J.R.
Abstract: Seasonal thermal energy storage (STES) using heat or cold available from surplus, waste, climatic, or cogeneration sources show great promise to reduce peak demand, reduce electric utility load problems, and contribute to establishing favorable economics for district heating and cooling systems. Heated and chilled water can be injected, stored, and recovered from aquifers. Potential energy sources for use in an aquifer thermal energy storage system include solar heat, power plant cogeneration, winter chill, and industrial waste heat source.-from STAR, 22(23), 1984

Title: NUCLEAR WASTE REPOSITORY IN BASALT: A DESIGN DESCRIPTION.
Source title: US Department of Energy, Technical Information Center, (Technical Report) DOE/TIC
Affiliations: Kaiser Engineers Inc, USA, Kaiser Engineers Inc, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ritchie, John S., Kaiser Engineers Inc, USA, Kaiser Engineers Inc, USA; Schmidt, Birger, Kaiser Engineers Inc, USA, Kaiser Engineers Inc, USA
Abstract: The conceptual design of a nuclear waste repository in basalt is described. Nuclear waste packages are placed in holes drilled into the floor of tunnels at a depth of 3700 ft. About 100 miles of tunnels are required to receive 35,000 packages. Five shafts bring waste packages, ventilation air, excavated rock, personnel, material, and services to and from the subsurface. The most important surface facility is the waste handling building, located over the waste handling shaft, where waste is received and packaged for storage. Two independent ventilation systems are provided to avoid potential contamination of spaces that do not contain nuclear waste. Because of the high temperatures at depth, an elaborate air chilling system is provided. Because the waste packages deliver a considerable amount of heat energy to the rock mass, particular attention is paid to heat transfer and thermal stress studies.
Index Keywords: BASALT; MINE SHAFTS - Design; MINE VENTILATION - Design; TUNNELS AND TUNNELING - Design; WASTE DISPOSAL - Deepwell Disposal; AIR CHILLING SYSTEM; NUCLEAR WASTE PACKAGES; NUCLEAR WASTE REPOSITORY; THERMAL STRESSES; WASTE HANDLING FACILITY; WASTE HANDLING SHAFTS; INDUSTRIAL WASTES

Title: INDUSTRIAL BOILERS - COAL AND WASTE HANDLING.
Affiliations: Orba Corp, Fairfield, NJ, USA, Orba Corp, Fairfield, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mahr, Daniel, Orba Corp, Fairfield, NJ, USA, Orba Corp, Fairfield, NJ, USA
Abstract: Coal is an attractive fuel because of its relatively low energy cost. Unlike gas or oil, however, its characteristics vary and the delivery-storage-boiler feed/discharge systems are complex. There is a variety of different technologies and arrangements available. The choices for the type of coal and handling systems depend on boiler capacity and design, the mode of transportation, environmental considerations, plant layout, real estate availability, cost and reliability. Since operation and maintenance are significant factors, a present worth analysis should be completed before a system is selected. Making the right choice helps insure that both fuel savings and system reliability are maximized.
Index Keywords: BOILERS - Waste Heat; BOILER CAPACITY; BOILER FEED/DISCHARGE SYSTEMS; INDUSTRIAL BOILERS; MODE OF TRANSPORTATION; PLANT LAYOUTS; REAL ESTATE AVAILABILITY; COAL HANDLING

Title: INVESTIGATION OF PPT'S POWER CONDITIONER.
Affiliations: Acad Sinica, Electric Propulsion, Lab, Beijing, China, Acad Sinica, Electric Propulsion Lab, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Lui, Wen-Xi, Acad Sinica, Electric Propulsion, Lab, Beijing, China, Acad Sinica, Electric Propulsion Lab, Beijing, China
Abstract: This power conditioner is specially designed for Pulsed Plasma Thruster (PPT). Its function is to convert the bus bar voltage into the necessary one. It is able to charge the main energy storage capacitor of 2 mu f to 2 Kv, and the ignition capacitor of 10 mu f to 150 v separately. In addition the conditioner completes the logic control of two nozzles working alternatively and monitors the thruster situation. In order to obtain high efficiency of the power conditioner a more reasonable charger of inductive energy storage type has been used.
Index Keywords: PROPULSION - Aerospace Applications; BUS BAR VOLTAGE; INDUCTIVE ENERGY STORAGE; LOGIC CONTROL; POWER CONDITIONERS; STORAGE CAPACITORS; PLASMA DEVICES

Title: MONITORED, RETRIEVABLE STORAGE IN NUCLEAR WASTE POLICY.
Affiliations: US Senate, Committee on Energy &, Natural Resources, Washington, DC,, USA, US Senate, Committee on Energy & Natural Resources, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cooper, Benjamin S., US Senate, Committee on Energy &, Natural Resources, Washington, DC,, USA, US Senate, Committee on Energy & Natural Resources, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 establishes a program for the siting and construction of deep geologic repositories and also provides for the development of a proposal to Congress for the construction of facilities for the long-term monitored, retrievable storage of spent fuel and high level waste. The fundamental difference between these approaches to the long-term isolation of nuclear waste is that the former is irreversible and the latter is not. This paper discusses the motivations of the sponsors of the MRS provisions of the ACT, the legislative history of these provisions, and the current status of the implementation of the provisions by the Department of Energy.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR REACTORS - Spent Fuels; WASTE DISPOSAL - Legislation; 1982 NUCLEAR WASTE POLICY ACT; DEEP GEOLOGIC REPOSITORIES; LEGISLATIVE HISTORY; MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE (MRS) PROGRAM; SPENT FUEL STORAGE; NUCLEAR FUELS

Abstract: There is a strong relationship between the depth of discharge of a battery and the cycle life. The parameters of a battery for starting, lighting, and ignition (SLI) are different from those of a battery for traction purposes. While a SLI battery is normally not discharged below 90% state of charge a traction battery is operated to at least 80% depth discharge.

Title: WHITESHELL NUCLEAR RESEARCH ESTABLISHMENT IMMOBILIZED FUEL TEST FACILITY.
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: AECL, Whiteshell Nuclear Research, Establishment, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Whiteshell Nuclear Research Establishment, Pinawa, Manit, Can
Authors with affiliations: Ryz, Marvin A., AECL, Whiteshell Nuclear Research, Establishment, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Whiteshell Nuclear Research Establishment, Pinawa, Manit, Can
Abstract: The Immobilized Fuel Test Facility at the Whiteshell Nuclear Research Establishment of Atomic Energy of Canada Limited allows a wide range of experiments with radioactive materials to be performed in support of the Canadian Nuclear Fuel Waste Management Program. The main emphasis of the program is to characterize the behaviour of nuclear waste forms under the conditions that might be present in a waste disposal vault. Generally, these conditions will be simulated in concrete canisters that will contain experiments to test various proposed irradiated-fuel and waste-form containment systems. The facility has a canister loading area, a canister storage area, five lead-shielded cells, a mock-up and maintenance area, three laboratories, change-room facilities and offices.

Abstract: The energy storage systems covered include pumped hydro storage; compressed air storage; electric batteries; hydrogen storage in metals as metal hydrides; flywheels; thermal energy storage; and chemical heat pump systems.

Title: OPERATION OF THE KEK 2. 5 GeV ELECTRON LINAC.
Affiliations: Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, Jiro, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Oho-machi, Jpn
Abstract: Construction of the KEK 2. 5 GeV electron linac was completed at the end of January 1982 and the initial operation was started at the beginning of February 1982. A general description of the operational behavior of the linac since that time is given. The goal of the linac performance was completely satisfied on March 16 with the measured value of 2. 5 GeV at 55 mA. At the high current test, 2. 5 mu s 300 mA beam was obtained at 1. 81 GeV. Scheduled operation of the linac for the Photon Factory 2. 5 GeV storage ring was opened in June 1982 and injection into the TRISTAN accumulation ring has been continued since November 1983. Energy, energy spread and profile of the accelerated beam are stable. In addition, some of the technical developments concerning the linac are reported.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON BEAMS; BEAM BUNCH; BEAM CAPTURE; KEK ACCELERATOR; OPERATING PERFORMANCE; ACCELERATORS, LINEAR

Authors: Gellings C.W., Stovall J.P., Quade A.W., Taylor R.W.
Title: GENERATION SYSTEM IMPACTS OF STORAGE HEATING AND STORAGE WATER HEATING.
Affiliations: EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA, EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gellings, C.W., EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA, EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA; Stovall, J.P., EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA, EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA; Quade, A.W., EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA, EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA; Taylor, R.W., EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA, EPRI, Palo Alto, CA, USA
Abstract: Thermal energy storage systems offer the electric utility a means to change customer energy use patterns. At present, however, the costs and benefit to both the customers and utility are uncertain. As part of a nationwide demonstration program Public Service Electric and Gas Company installed storage space heating and water heating appliances in residential homes. This paper is organized into three main sections. The first gives background data on PSE&G and their experience in a nationwide thermal storage demonstration project. The second section details results of the demonstration project and studies that have been performed on the impacts of thermal storage equipment. The last section reports on the conclusions arrived at concerning the impacts of thermal storage on generation.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS; GENERATION PLANNING; LOAD MANAGEMENT; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors with affiliations: Bloom, Jeremy A., General Public Utilities Service, Corp, Parsippany, NJ, USA, General Public Utilities Service Corp, Parsippany, NJ, USA
Abstract: Many questions in utility planning and rate design require evaluating the marginal cost to meet hourly loads. This paper presents an efficient calculation method which is consistent with modern probabilistic production costing methods (e. g. Booth/Baleriaux or Gram-Charlier series) and which can incorporate the variety of generating technologies, thermal, limited energy, and storage, used in modern utility systems.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC UTILITIES - Rates; ENERGY STORAGE; GENERATION COST CURVES; HOURLY COST CALCULATIONS; PROBABILISTIC COSTING METHODS; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION

Title: DYNAMIC SIMULATION OF THE HEATING LOAD OF OFFICES COUPLED WITH MEASURED OCCUPANCY DISTRIBUTION.
Affiliations: Technion-Israel Inst of Technology,, Energy Engineering Cent, Haifa, Isr, Technion-Israel Inst of Technology, Energy Engineering Cent, Haifa, Isr
Authors with affiliations: Levy, Moshe, Technion-Israel Inst of Technology,, Energy Engineering Cent, Haifa, Isr, Technion-Israel Inst of Technology, Energy Engineering Cent, Haifa, Isr; Shitzer, Avraham, Technion-Israel Inst of Technology,, Energy Engineering Cent, Haifa, Isr, Technion-Israel Inst of Technology, Energy Engineering Cent, Haifa, Isr
Abstract: Dynamic simulation of the heat load of a top floor of offices constructed of heavy masonry walls is presented. The system was assumed to operate for ten hours daily. Calculation was performed for a repeated daily temperature distribution representing a very cold day in the coastal region in Israel. Results were also compared to those obtained by representative monthly data. Results indicate that after two days of operation the system reaches a periodic condition. Dynamic occupancy distributions were measured for the installation. These distributions indicate possible reductions in total heating load to about 88%, 77%, and 62% of the calculated values by use of the upper decile, upper quartile, and mean distributions, respectively.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT TRANSFER; THERMAL INSULATION; DYNAMIC OCCUPANCY DISTRIBUTION MEASUREMENT; HEAT LOSSES; HEATING LOAD ANALYSIS; OFFICE BUILDINGS

Title: POTENTIAL IMPACT OF NEW POWER SYSTEM TECHNOLOGY ON THE DESIGN OF A MANNED SPACE STATION.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Fordyce, J.Stuart, NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Schwartz, Harvey J., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Larger, more complex spacecraft of the future such as a manned Space Station will require electric power systems of 100 kw and more, orders of magnitude greater than the present state of the art. In this report, several promising technology options including concentrator solar photovoltaic arrays, solar thermal dynamic and ultimately nuclear dynamic systems to reduce area are discussed. Also higher energy storage systems such as nickel-hydrogen and the regenerative fuel cell (RFC) and higher voltage power distribution which add system flexibility, simplicity, and reduce weight are examined. Emphasis is placed on the attributes and development status of emerging technologies that are sufficiently developed that they could be available for flight use in the early to mid 1990's.
Index Keywords: PROPULSION - Space Applications; ROCKET ENGINES - Electric Propulsion; SATELLITES - Orbital Laboratories; MANNED SPACE STATION; SPACECRAFT

Title: IMPROVED ACCURACY OF SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEM TESTING AND MEASUREMENTS.

Authors with affiliations: Waterman, Robert E., Vitro Corp of America, Washington,, DC, USA, Vitro Corp of America, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: A discussion is presented of a method for increasing the accuracy of information obtained during the testing of solar energy systems. The method, based on Kalman filtering, is illustrated through an example involving the testing of a solar energy domestic hot water system. The focus of the paper is on testing and measurement using field deployed, unattended sensors, data loggers and microcomputers. The example presented examines data analysis of the collector loop of a solar energy domestic hot water system in which measurements of flowrate and temperatures contain significant errors.

Authors: Becker W., Blatt R., Werth G.
Title: HIGH RESOLUTION MICROWAVE SPECTROSCOPY ON TRAPPED Ba** plus IONS.
Source title: National Bureau of Standards, Special Publication
Affiliations: Univ Mainz, Inst fuer Physik, Mainz,, West Ger, Univ Mainz, Inst fuer Physik, Mainz, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Becker, W., Univ Mainz, Inst fuer Physik, Mainz,, West Ger, Univ Mainz, Inst fuer Physik, Mainz, West Ger; Blatt, R., Univ Mainz, Inst fuer Physik, Mainz,, West Ger, Univ Mainz, Inst fuer Physik, Mainz, West Ger; Werth, G., Univ Mainz, Inst fuer Physik, Mainz,, West Ger, Univ Mainz, Inst fuer Physik, Mainz, West Ger
Abstract: An optical double resonance experiment is performed on the ground state of **1**3**7Ba** plus and **1**3**5Ba** plus ions. About 10**5 particles were confined in an rf quadrupole trap for many hours. Hfs state selection by pulsed laser optical pumping was followed by microwave transitions, which were observed via change in the ionic fluorescence intensity. Linewidths of the order of the laser repetition frequency (1-20 Hz) and a complicated line structure were observed in the 'field independent' F equals 1, m equals 0 yields F equals 2, m equals 0 transitions. The statistical uncertainty of the line center was below 0. 1 Hz. The results for the hyperfine separations, including corrections to zero magnetic and electric field, are presented.
Index Keywords: MICROWAVES; ENERGY LEVELS; HYPERFINE STRUCTURE; ION STORAGE; TRAPPED BARIUM IONS; FREQUENCY STANDARDS

Abstract: To help HVAC engineers, the latest techniques for cutting energy use in commercial, institutional, and industrial structures are described. These schemes embrace cogeneration, EMS (energy management systems) and DDC (direct digital control) in the control sector, daylighting, heat pumps, variable-air volume, thermal storage, and heat recovery in commercial/institutional buildings and industrial plants.

Abstract: In this paper, concepts of electric load management have been discussed for effective energy conservation. It has been shown that the conservation program must be comprehensive to provide solutions to the problems facing the electric consumer, the electric utility and the society by reducing the rate of growth of energy consumption and power system peak demand requirements. The impact of energy management programs on electric energy conservation is examined, with emphasis on efficiency, storage, cogeneration and controls with computers.

Authors: Stafford G.C., Kelley P.E., Syka J.E.P., Reynolds W.E., Fies W.J., Todd J.F.J.
Title: MASS SELECTIVE INSTABILITY HIGH PRESSURE OPERATION OF THE ION TRAP.
Source title: Annual Conference on Mass Spectrometry and Allied Topics
Affiliations: Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA, Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Stafford, G.C., Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA, Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA; Kelley, P.E., Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA, Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA; Syka, J.E.P., Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA, Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA; Reynolds, W.E., Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA, Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA; Fies, W.J., Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA, Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA; Todd, J.F.J., Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA, Finnigan Mat, San Jose, CA, USA
Abstract: The quadrupole ion storage trap, first named the 'QUISTOR' by the group at the University of Kent, is a three-electrode structure having cylindrical symmetry. Ions are created within the trap and may be held in stable orbits by ac and dc applied to the ring electrode. The theory of ion motion within the trap, which has been described in detail elsewhere, is essentially analogous to that of the mass filter in that trapping may be mass selective or occur in a 'wide-band' mode over a range of masses. The detection of ions differs, however, in that one may either use resonance energy absorption techniques related to the detailed motion of ions in the trap, or cause the ions to be ejected through holes in one of the end-cap electrodes on to a multiplier.
Index Keywords: GASES - Ionization; IONS; ABSTRACT ONLY; ION TRAP; MASS SPECTROMETERS

Title: EVALUATION OF DEVELOPMENTAL MEMBRANES FOR THE MIXED REACTANT IRON-CHROMIUM REDOX SYSTEM.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ling, Jerri S., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The advent of operating the NASA Redox Storage System at 65 degree C with premixed iron-chromium reactant solutions has changed membrane requirements. These new conditions allow the use of low resistivity membranes having relatively poor selectivity compared to membranes developed for system operation with separate reactants at 25 degree C. This paper presents the results of in cell evaluations of developmental membranes for the new conditions. Data reported include diffusion rate, area resistivity, and coulombic and energy efficiencies over a wide range of current densities. Use of these membranes has resulted in peak round trip energy efficiencies greater than 80 percent at current densities as high as 80 mA/cm**2.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ION EXCHANGE; MEMBRANES; NASA REDOX ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: INTERFACING THE SIN RING CYCLOTRON TO A RAPID CYCLING SYNCHROTRON WITH AN ACCELERATION AND STORAGE RING ASTOR.
Affiliations: Swiss Inst for Nuclear Research, Villigen, Switz, Swiss Inst for Nuclear Research, Villigen, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Joho, W., Swiss Inst for Nuclear Research, Villigen, Switz, Swiss Inst for Nuclear Research, Villigen, Switz
Abstract: A rapid cycling synchrotron is the most economic solution for producing intense proton beams of the order of 20 GeV for research with antiprotons, kaons, neutrinos, hyperons and mesons. The ASTOR isochronous acceleration and storage ring offers itself as an interface between the SIN 590 MeV ring cyclotron and such a synchrotron. The so-called phase expansion effect is used to stack more than a hundred turns at the extraction radius of ASTOR. Extraction of this stack with a fast kicker produces an intense pulsed beam with a repetition rate of 3000 Hz. Parking the ASTOR pulses in a four-level accumulator makes this beam suitable for further acceleration in a rapid cycling synchrotron. In order to minimize overall costs of both machines, a final energy of 1. 3 GeV has been chosen for ASTOR. With a 50-Hz repetition rate for the synchrotron an average beam current of 80 mu A can be expected.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON; PROTONS; KAONS; MESONS; NEUTRINOS; SIN RING CYCLOTRON; STORAGE RING ASTOR; ACCELERATORS, CYCLOTRON

Title: OCEAN-CURRENT ELECTRIC GENERATION: THE UNDERWATER ELECTRIC KITE.
Affiliations: UEK Corp, Annapolis, MD, USA, UEK Corp, Annapolis, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Vauthier, Philippe, UEK Corp, Annapolis, MD, USA, UEK Corp, Annapolis, MD, USA; Dement, Donald K., UEK Corp, Annapolis, MD, USA, UEK Corp, Annapolis, MD, USA
Abstract: The Underwater Electric Kite (UEK) is a long-sought solution for utilizing the potential energy from slow streams and ocean currents. Although conventional turbo-generators cannot be operated in slow streams because the water head is inadequate, the UEK provides a artificially-increased head. Since the entire structure is rotated by the stream flow, the resultant centrifugal force acting on the internal stream increases its rate and head to levels consistent with conventional turbine-generator requirements. With the UEK, substantial, competitive-cost electric energy from these sources is now a realistic expectation. Hydrogen produced by electrolysis using the UEK's low-cost electricity could provide energy storage for load-leveling, and could be an exportable product for areas where tidal currents are reliably available.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROGEN - Manufacture; OCEAN-CURRENT ELECTRIC GENERATION; UNDERWATER ELECTRIC KITE; TURBOGENERATORS

Title: HYDROGEN PRODUCTION AT HYDRO POWER PLANTS.
Affiliations: US Federal Energy Regulatory, Commission, Washington, DC, USA, US Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Tarnay, Dennis S., US Federal Energy Regulatory, Commission, Washington, DC, USA, US Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: Hydroelectric power has the advantage of being a clean resource that is perpetually renewable. Alternative sources of energy such as thermal plants, are becoming less attractive because of public opposition, spiraling costs, and excessive delays. Many utilities have actively explored the possibilities of increasing output at existing hydro plants by replacing or supplementing existing generating units. But hydroelectric plants are still utilizing only portion of the river's hydraulic energy due to hydrologic and economic restrains. One possibility of increasing the efficiency of hydro power plants would be the conversion of water to hydrogen by electrolysis by using the excess energy or wasted energy not yet utilized, and then conversion of hydrogen to electricity via a gas turbine. The concept described in this paper would improve the economy of the project and generate additional revenues to the owner.
Index Keywords: GAS TURBINE POWER PLANTS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; WATER - Electrolysis; HYDRO POWER PLANTS; HYDROGEN PRODUCTION; HYDROGEN STORAGE; HYDROGEN

Title: HYDROGEN ENERGY RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENTS IN JAPAN.
Affiliations: Yokohama Natl Univ, Hydrogen Energy, Research Lab, Yokohama, Jpn, Yokohama Natl Univ, Hydrogen Energy Research Lab, Yokohama, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ohta, Tokio, Yokohama Natl Univ, Hydrogen Energy, Research Lab, Yokohama, Jpn, Yokohama Natl Univ, Hydrogen Energy Research Lab, Yokohama, Jpn; Abe, Isao, Yokohama Natl Univ, Hydrogen Energy, Research Lab, Yokohama, Jpn, Yokohama Natl Univ, Hydrogen Energy Research Lab, Yokohama, Jpn
Abstract: Hydrogen energy research and development programms in Japan can be divided into four categories: (1) The Sunshine Project conducted by MITI since 1974. This is the most prominent and ambitious national programs. More than 20 million has been spent for hydrogen energy development since its beginning in 1974. (2) The program of windpower storage developed by Science and Technology Agency. Two 20KW wind mills convert wind energy into heat which is stored by metalhydride system and is used to green house farming in winter time. Other activities are due to mostly alloy development. (3) Basic studies in Universities are mostly on the hydrogen production by the semiconductor-liquid junction, by photochemical reaction and by biological processes. (4) Some activities in private enterprises, for examples, are the application of metal hydride, hydrogen liquefaction plant, direct reduction of ore and so on, but not for the thermochemical method at all. This paper reviews the major prominent programs & activities on hydrogen energy systems in Japan.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION - Research; HYDROGEN FUELS - Safe Handling; HYDROGEN ENERGY; HYDROGEN UTILIZATION; HYDROGEN

Authors: Johnson Jr. A.B., Gilbert E.R., Beeman G.H., Creer J.M.
Title: TECHNICAL ISSUES AND APPROACH TO LICENSE DRY STORAGE OF LWR FUEL IN THE UNITED STATES.
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Johnson Jr., A.B., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Gilbert, E.R., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Beeman, G.H., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Creer, J.M., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: Dry storage is emerging as an important alternative to wet storage for US utilities, even though wet storage will remain the principal storage method, at least until the federal government begins to accept fuel in 1998. Dry storage has been licensed in several countries. In the USA, dry storage issues are related to storage system performance and behavior of spent fuel during storage. There is a coordinated US effort among electric utilities, the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI), the Department of Energy (DOE) and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) to license two dry storage concepts: metal casks, and horizontal storage modules.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; NUCLEAR REACTORS - Spent Fuels; APPROACH TO LICENSING; DRY STORAGE; LIGHT WATER REACTOR; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: ULTRA SLOW METASTABLE ION DECOMPOSITIONS.
Source title: Annual Conference on Mass Spectrometry and Allied Topics
Affiliations: Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr, Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr
Authors with affiliations: Lifshitz, C., Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr, Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr; Malinovich, Y., Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr, Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr; Arakawa, R., Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr, Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr; Gefen, S., Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr, Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr; Haase, G., Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr, Hebrew Univ of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Isr
Abstract: Authors have combined a cylindrical ion trapping device (CIT) with photoionization mass spectrometry. The experiment enables determination of time-resolved photoionization efficiency (PIE) curves and breakdown curves from the microsecond to the millisecond range. Slow fragmentations are observable and are unperturbed by radiative decay if only low extents of overall (radiative and dissociative) decay of the metastable ion are allowed. Authors have demonstrated that appearance energies of daughter ions shift to lower values upon increasing storage time, as expected.

Title: TEST TECHNIQUES FOR MODEL DEVELOPMENT OF REPETITIVE SERVICE ENERGY STORAGE CAPACITORS.
Source title: Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena (CEIDP), Annual Report
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, M.Clark, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA; Mauldin, G.Howard, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Abstract: Advanced development in repetitive pulse capacitor technology has produced new testing requirements that include high-average power modulator test platforms and developed instrumentation. The Capacitor Test Facility at Los Alamos has been used to evaluate the performance of the Sandia perfluorocarbon family of energy storage capacitors. Thermal response to power loading and the importance of average and spot heating in the bulk regions require technical advancements in real-time temperature measurements. Reduction and interpretation of thermal data are crucial to the accurate development of an intelligent thermal transport model. The thermal model is of prime interest in the high repetition rate, high-average power applications of power conditioning capacitors. The main thrust of the work is to make meaningful interpretations for model development. The results of instrumentation development and subsequent data examples are discussed.
Index Keywords: CAPACITIVE ENERGY STORAGE; REPETITIVE PULSE CAPACITOR; CAPACITORS

Authors: Cuomo K.M., Niesciur L.M., Hitchcock R.N., Dettman D., Dollinger R., Sarjeant W.J.
Title: COMPUTER TECHNIQUE FOR CALCULATING OPENING SWITCH LOSSES.
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: State Univ of New York at Buffalo,, Dep of Electrical & Computer, Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA, State Univ of New York at Buffalo, Dep of Electrical & Computer Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cuomo, K.M., State Univ of New York at Buffalo,, Dep of Electrical & Computer, Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA, State Univ of New York at Buffalo, Dep of Electrical & Computer Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA; Niesciur, L.M., State Univ of New York at Buffalo,, Dep of Electrical & Computer, Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA, State Univ of New York at Buffalo, Dep of Electrical & Computer Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA; Hitchcock, R.N., State Univ of New York at Buffalo,, Dep of Electrical & Computer, Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA, State Univ of New York at Buffalo, Dep of Electrical & Computer Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA; Dettman, D., State Univ of New York at Buffalo,, Dep of Electrical & Computer, Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA, State Univ of New York at Buffalo, Dep of Electrical & Computer Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA; Dollinger, R., State Univ of New York at Buffalo,, Dep of Electrical & Computer, Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA, State Univ of New York at Buffalo, Dep of Electrical & Computer Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA; Sarjeant, W.J., State Univ of New York at Buffalo,, Dep of Electrical & Computer, Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA, State Univ of New York at Buffalo, Dep of Electrical & Computer Engineering, Amherst, NY, USA
Abstract: An iterative technique has been developed which has obtained switch loss as a function of time for three different types of opening switches in both single and multiloop commutation circuits. Historically, the standard method for determining the arc voltage needed for calculating losses is to subtract the stray internal inductance voltage drop from the measured terminal voltage. For the switches under investigation, neither the terminal voltage nor the time rate of change of arc current is sufficiently smooth to do the subtraction; therefore, it is infeasible to calculate the arc voltage with that method. The method presented is to use measured arc current and known circuit parameters to calculate the true arc voltage and the resultant switch loss. Knowledge of switch losses allows the generation of characteristic curves in parameter space. Such curves aid in the experimental studies of the switch opening in inductive energy storage environments. This modeling, done on a HP-85 desktop computer, aids in the tailoring of control variables for the switch.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS - Applications; METAL PLASMA ARC SWITCHES; SWITCH LOSSES; ELECTRIC SWITCHES

Authors: Dietrich E., Bourgogne P., Le Goff P., Steranka P.
Title: SIZING STORAGE CAPACITIES FOR CONSTITUENTS OF AN ABSORPTION HEAT PUMP FOR HEATING BUILDINGS.
Affiliations: CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie, Chimique, Nancy, Fr, CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chimique, Nancy, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Dietrich, E., CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie, Chimique, Nancy, Fr, CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chimique, Nancy, Fr; Bourgogne, P., CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie, Chimique, Nancy, Fr, CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chimique, Nancy, Fr; Le Goff, P., CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie, Chimique, Nancy, Fr, CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chimique, Nancy, Fr; Steranka, P., CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie, Chimique, Nancy, Fr, CNRS, Lab des Sciences du Genie Chimique, Nancy, Fr
Abstract: The heating of buildings is to be produced by the association of a furnace and an absorption heat pump which work alternatively. In order to size and optimize the three storage capacities, the power of the absorption heat pump and that of the furnace, and to fix the optimum value of the cut-off-temperature T//c, we have conducted a statistical analysis of climatic data for 10 years for different French sites. In each case, we have calculated the 'Consumption Ratio', which is defined as the ratio of the consumption of fuel of the SHPF system to that a convention furnace providing the same service. This method is applied to a worked example of heating a standard building.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Space Heating; ENERGY UTILIZATION; REFRIGERATING MACHINERY - Absorption; STATISTICAL METHODS - Applications; COMSUMPTION RATIO CALCULATIONS; STORAGE HEAT PUMP FURNACE (SHPF); STORAGE TANKS; THERMAL ENERGY BALANCE; THERMAL POWER; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: OPERATING REGIMES OF SYNCHRONOUS SALIENT-POLE MACHINES IN ELECTROMECHANICAL ENERGY STORES.
Authors with affiliations: Mann, E.G.; Denisov, S.A.
Abstract: The possibility of operating synchronous salient-pole machines as the electromechanical element of kinetic energy accumulators is considered. An engineering method of calculating regimes of operation of a generator at varying rotation frequency on a valve load is proposed.

Title: PERFORMANCE EVALUATION OF A LOW-ENERGY PASSIVE-SOLAR HOUSE WITH ATTACHED SUNSPACE.
Affiliations: Scanada Consultants Ltd, Ottawa,, Ont, Can, Scanada Consultants Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Swinton, Michael C., Scanada Consultants Ltd, Ottawa,, Ont, Can, Scanada Consultants Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: A low-energy passive-solar house with an attached sunspace, was monitored using a Level B monitoring approach to determine its energy performance, solar utilization and comfort, from December 1982 to July 1983. The house features a sunspace collection system, crawlspace storage, north room buffer zones, a very tight air barrier, an air-to-air heat exchanger, and super energy efficient levels of insulation. The monitoring results indicated a very low auxiliary heating requirement from December to May.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; ATTACHED SUNSPACE; LOW ENERGY HOUSE; PERFORMANCE EVALUATION; HOUSES

Title: CODE AND INTERLEAVER DESIGN FOR DATA TRANSMISSION OVER FADING CHANNELS.
Affiliations: DFVLR, West Ger, DFVLR, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Lutz, Erich, DFVLR, West Ger, DFVLR, West Ger
Abstract: The Rice-channel model, which is relevant to maritime satellite communications, is adopted. Data transmission with forward error-correction coding and interleaving is considered. Assuming full interleaving of the code symbols, the code performance is analyzed. The bit error rate is numerically evaluated for Reed-Solomon codes with varying block lengths and code rates. It is shown that an optimum code rate exists with respect to minimum necessary signal energy. Results of computer simulations are presented that show the penalty in signal energy arising when interleaving is limited to a finite depth. It is concluded that the expense of interleaving (proportional to storage requirement and signal delay) increases both with block length and rate of the code. In addition, it is shown that BCH block codes and convolutional codes require a higher degree of interleaving than Reed-Solomon codes.
Index Keywords: DATA TRANSMISSION; TELECOMMUNICATION SYSTEMS, MOBILE; TELECOMMUNICATION SYSTEMS, SATELLITE RELAY; DATA COMMUNICATION; ERROR-CORRECTION CODING; MARINE-VEHICLE COMMUNICATION; SATELLITE COMMUNICATION; CODES, SYMBOLIC

Title: COMPARATIVE STUDY OF DIFFERENT DESIGNS FOR THE METAL HYDRIDE HYDROGEN STORAGE BEDS USING TOBA COMPUTER CODE.
Affiliations: Nuclear Power Plants Authority, Cairo, Egypt, Nuclear Power Plants Authority, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: El Osery, I.A., Nuclear Power Plants Authority, Cairo, Egypt, Nuclear Power Plants Authority, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: The storage of hydrogen in the form of metal hydride is one of the largest areas of research and development in connection with the planning and implementation of hydrogen energy systems. The paper presents a comparative study of some different alternatives for metal hydride hydrogen storage beds used for energy storage applications. The alternatives considered include slab, cylindrical (with internal, external and internal-external flow of the heat transfer fluid), and spherical designs of metal hydride beds. To make this study possible, a space-time dependent computer code was developed; called TOBA. The code solved numerically the mass and heat transfer problem associated with hydrogen reaction in metal hydride storage beds of different geometries and performance characteristics.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER AIDED DESIGN; ENERGY STORAGE; METALS AND ALLOYS - Applications; HYDROGEN STORAGE BEDS; METAL HYDRIDES; TOBA COMPUTER CODE; HYDROGEN

Abstract: The determination of proper control set points for active solar energy systems has been discussed by numerous authors. Varying the differential-off set point has been thought to contribute only additional parasitic energy costs. This work shows that the effect of varying the differential-off set point is much more significant than that. Laboratory testing at the Solar Energy Research Institute has shown that sensor response can drift by as much as 12 degree C. The sensor testing and results are briefly reviewed.

Abstract: A number of storage rings are under design or being discussed as additions to existing accelerator laboratories. One such project is the IUCF (Indiana University Cyclotron Facility) Cooler, a light ion storage ring with electron cooling, being developed as a research tool for increased precision in intermediate-energy nuclear science. Some of the general features of ring designs and of the limitations to their performance are reviewed, using the Indiana Cooler as an illustrative example. The status of the Cooler is described.

Abstract: Impure, technical grade hydrates of calcium chloride and sodium hydroxide appear technically promising and economically attractive as low temperature energy storage media. The use of direct-contact heat exchange to overcome this problem is examined.

Abstract: Recently, builders have shown considerable interest in combining the features of active and passive solar space heating systems into a hybrid system employing active collection and some form of passive discharge/storage device. In addition to space heating, the system provides domestic hot water heating and summer cooling by night venting of the slab.

Abstract: In the two years since the institution of a Solar Hot Water System Certification Program, over 40 different solar DHW systems have been tested.
