Abstract: The thermal and operating performance of a flat plate solar energy system, monitored for three months, is presented. A comparison is made between the actual and design values. Findings from commissioning and operation are presented and areas are highlighted for future design improvements. Results from the system performance evaluation and economic analysis are discussed.
Index Keywords: HOT WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; MONITORING SENSORS LOCATIONS; SYSTEM PERFORMANCE; THERMAL STORAGE; TRUCK WASHING FACILITY; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Ivey Douglas G., Northwood Derek O.
Title: THERMODYNAMIC, ELECTRONIC AND HYDROGEN PROPERTIES OF Zr(Fe//xCr//1// minus //x)//2.
Source title: Metallurgical Society of AIME, TMS Paper Selection
Affiliations: Univ of Windsor, Dep of Engineering, Materials, Windsor, Ont, Can, Univ of Windsor, Dep of Engineering Materials, Windsor, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Ivey, Douglas G., Univ of Windsor, Dep of Engineering, Materials, Windsor, Ont, Can, Univ of Windsor, Dep of Engineering Materials, Windsor, Ont, Can; Northwood, Derek O., Univ of Windsor, Dep of Engineering, Materials, Windsor, Ont, Can, Univ of Windsor, Dep of Engineering Materials, Windsor, Ont, Can
Abstract: Relationships between hydrogen capacities, heats of formation and electron-to-atom ratios of hydrogen storage compounds are reported. Alloy and hydride stabilities are calculated based on Miedema's models of binary alloy formation and the Rule of Reversed Stability for ternary hydride formation. Electron-to-atom ratios are determined using an expanded form of Pauling's covalent compound, bond distance equation. Hydrogen capacity and hydride stability increase with decreasing alloy stability (i. e. , lower iron concentration). Alloy electron-to-atom ratio is dependent on alloy stability and inversely proportional to hydride stability.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROGEN; ZIRCONIUM COMPOUNDS - Thermodynamic Properties; ALLOY STABILITY; ELECTRON TO ATOM RATIO; HYDRIDE STABILITY; HYDROGEN CAPACITY; ZIRCONIUM IRON CHROMIUM ALLOYS

Authors: Sadykov B.S., Baramidze S.S., Dzhamdar M.K.
Title: RESEARCH ON THE CHARACTERISTICS OF SOLAR UNITS IN KABUL.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Sadykov, B.S.; Baramidze, S.S.; Dzhamdar, M.K.
Abstract: The test results of hot box type solar units located in Kabul are presented. The heat collector of one of the units is made of sheet steel with dimensions of 1 multiplied by 600 multiplied by 1200 mm**3 painted black. The collector has a solar radiation absorption coefficient of alpha //s equals 0. 86-0. 90. Rectangular metal tubes with dimensions of 20 multiplied by 20 multiplied by 20 mm**3 are fastened firmly to the sheet steel. The collector is inside a thermally insulated box covered on top with ordinary window glass. The heat carrier in the pipes is water. Tests for a planned solar-heated bath house in Afghanistan are briefly described.
Index Keywords: ASPHALT - Energy Storage; HEATING - Solar; HOT WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS; ROOFS; WATER HEATERS - Solar; HEAT STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION

Affiliations: G. K. Salter & Associates, G. K. Salter & Associates
Authors with affiliations: Morris, David, G. K. Salter & Associates, G. K. Salter & Associates
Abstract: There are numerous instances where the introduction of ambient alternative energy or heat pump schemes are not able to financially compete with the conventional fuels already available. This should not prevent the introduction of an alternative conventional fuel into existing buildings and secure all the advantages that alternative energy can offer, while making provision for ambient energy introduction at some later date. This paper specifically discusses the ways these bivalent projects can be approached.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES - Costs; DIRECT SUPPLY FUELS; DUAL FUEL SYSTEMS; FUEL COSTS; FUEL SUPPLY INTERRUPTIONS; STORAGE FUELS; FUELS

Authors with affiliations: Perlovskii, G.A.; Obyden, S.K.; Saparin, G.V.; Popov, S.I.
Abstract: The temperature relaxation of stimulated local cathode luminescence in GaN:Zn is investigated. Two rates of relaxation are observed. The two relaxation times and the corresponding activation energies are found. The storage time of the activated state in the temperature range 0-100 degree C is estimated.
Index Keywords: CATHODOLUMINESCENCE; RELAXATION PROCESSES; GALLIUM NITRIDE; TEMPERATURE RELAXATION; SEMICONDUCTING GALLIUM COMPOUNDS

Title: VARIABLE OXYGEN SUPPLY SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Lotepro Corp, New York, NY, USA, Lotepro Corp, New York, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Springmann, H., Lotepro Corp, New York, NY, USA, Lotepro Corp, New York, NY, USA
Abstract: Cost saving load variation is a highly important feature of modern oxygen production plants. In this paper methods of varying the load are described. They are dependent on the type of the consumers requirements. There are some load changes, characteristic for certain types of consumer industries. They are used as a basis for the description. There are four basically different load adaption systems. They are energy and cost-wise evaluated and compared. It is mentioned, how and why certain load adaption systems are preferrably used for specific load change problems. One of these systems, which is called 'liquid alternating storage system' is assumed to be less known. It is described more in detail.

Authors: Salzano F.J., Skaperdas G., Mezzina A.
Title: WATER VAPOR ELECTROLYSIS: SYSTEMS CONSIDERATIONS AND COST/PERFORMANCE BENEFITS.
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied, Science, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied Science, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Salzano, F.J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied, Science, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied Science, Upton, NY, USA; Skaperdas, G., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied, Science, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied Science, Upton, NY, USA; Mezzina, A., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied, Science, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied Science, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: The energy intensiveness of conventional liquid water electrolysis has inhibited the universal acceptance of this established technology as a resource conversion, storage and transport option. New developments in recent years have focused on the goal of reducing electric energy requirements as well as overall system capital cost. Major gains are envisioned in meeting these goals if water vapor electrolysis were conducted at elevated temperatures. The fundamental thermodynamics of a high temperature electrolysis process operating at approximately 1000 degree C are presented. Further, process considerations are examined in terms of engineering requirements which indicate the tradeoff between thermal efficiencies and cost. These gains in efficiency can be of the order of 40 to 50% over energy efficiencies attained via conventional liquid water electrolysis. Process tradeoffs are discussed in terms of overall thermal efficiencies, voltage/thermal requirements, steam conversions and heat recovery.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ELECTROLYSIS - Design; ENERGY UTILIZATION; HYDROGEN PRODUCTION; WATER VAPOR ELECTROLYSIS; HYDROGEN

Title: CAES: THE UNDERGROUND PORTION.
Affiliations: Fenix & Scisson Inc, Tulsa, OK,, USA, Fenix & Scisson Inc, Tulsa, OK, USA
Authors with affiliations: Allen, Kermit, Fenix & Scisson Inc, Tulsa, OK,, USA, Fenix & Scisson Inc, Tulsa, OK, USA
Abstract: The storage of compressed air underground is a proven and acceptable technique. Solution mined salt caverns, hard rock conventionally mined caverns, and aquifers can be used to successfully store compressed air. This paper reviews the experience of underground containers and discusses the storage of compressed air for Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) type facilities. Since the technique of storing air is identical to storing natural gas, the successful long-term experience of natural gas storage projects is reviewed.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS; ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENERGY STORAGE; GEOLOGY; UNDERGROUND STORAGE TECHNIQUES; COMPRESSED AIR

Abstract: Investigations of two-loop hot-water solar systems for public buildings with plane collectors on mathematical models established the limits of rational variation of the collector area, optimal values of the heat-carrier flow rates, the number of sections, and the volume of the storage tank. It is shown that the productivity of the solar system can be calculated without a computer if the results of the calculations are written in the form of a regression equation.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Utilization; OPTIMAL DESIGN; RATIONAL-PLANNING METHODS; SANITARY-ENGINEERING SYSTEMS; STORAGE-TANK VOLUME; HEATING

Authors: Azaev P.F., Velieva B.A., Mamedova A.N.
Title: THERMAL CALCULATION OF A SOLAR THERMOSTAT WITH A HEAT-TUBE COLLECTOR.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Azaev, P.F.; Velieva, B.A.; Mamedova, A.N.
Abstract: The operating principle of the solar unit is described. The method of calculating the working volume and the dimensions is given. The mass of the heat-storage material and the heat tube is calculated. The solar thermostat proposed has two functional units: a hot box and a thermostat. The thermal contact between the two is a heat tube. The solar energy, concentrated by the 'hot box' heats the heat carrier (water), located in the branched boiling zone of the heat tube, up to the boiling point. This heat melts the heat-storage elements. Paraffin, which has a melting temperature of 50 degree C and a latent heat of fusion of about 40 W multiplied by (times) hr/kg, is the heat-storage material.

Title: COMPARATIVE ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF A SOLAR-POWERED/FUEL-ASSISTED HYBRID RANKINE SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Meeting - American Section of the International Solar Energy Society
Affiliations: Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia,, PA, USA, Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA

Abstract: A present-value life-cycle economic analysis was performed for the SSPRE solar-powered/fuel-assisted hybrid Rankine system used for cooling. This cycle obtains about 80% of its energy from a solar source at about 100 degree C, and 20% from a fuel-fired superheater and operates at an efficiency of 15-20%, double from that of comparable all-solar cycles. It was found that the present-value life-cycle cost of solar energy is the predominant cost component, and the economic advantage of this cycle in halving the solar collector area was quantified.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; COOLING SYSTEM; HYBRID RANKINE SYSTEM; THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEM; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: APPLICATION OF THREE STATISTICAL METHODOLOGIES IN THE DESIGN AND ANALYSIS OF EXPERIMENTS WITH DEEP-DISCHARGE LEAD-ACID BATTERIES, LEADING TO PREDICTABLE LIFE CYCLE PERFORMANCE WITHOUT ACCELERATED TESTING.
Source title: Extended Abstracts, Meeting - International Society of Electrochemistry

Abstract: The first stage of our studies was an additional analysis of life cycle data obtained in an experiment planned by NASA and conducted by TRW, with 108 electric vehicle batteries. A second predictive method, pattern recognition analysis (PRA), was also found to apply to this NASA/TRW experiment. In our next phase of study the authors used Weibull distribution factors in a computer program for modeling cycle life performance of modular arrays (Fig. 3) such as cells in an EV battery or a utility energy storage plant. The authors have under test a group of 324 motive power lead acid cells, each of 2080 Ah capacity. It is found that with several statistical planning and analysis techniques the authors are able to predict cycle life performance of lead-acid cells and batteries without the use of accelerated test methods that risk distorting realistic operating or design conditions.

Abstract: An investigation was conducted of a molten fluoride generator based on Al-NiF//2, in fused LiF-NaF-KF eutectic, at 550 degree C, with an alumina electrode separator. It is shown that with new alumina membranes, prepared chiefly by plasma jet projection (porosity approximately equals 10%, pore diameter equals 0. 2 to 5 mu m), high energy densities close to 100 Wh multiplied by (times) kg** minus **1 were obtained, with specific intensities of 10 to 40 mA. cm** minus **2 and lifetimes increased from 1000 to 3000 hours (of which 680 hours with cycling current carrying). In most cases and to check the proper reversibility of the generator these tests, unlike those reported earlier, were carried out with discharged Al-NiF//2 elements mounted in the sequence.

Abstract: New applications for lead-acid batteries, such as electric vehicle propulsion, demand high specific energy and power and good cycle life. A research and development program at Johnson Controls, Inc. , has been underway since 1978 to develop advanced electric vehicle batteries. The original goals for the first phase of this program, development of an Improved State of the Art (ISOA) lead-acid battery, are presented. Two sizes of ISOA batteries were designed. Specifications for these two designs are given.

Title: INVESTIGATION OF THE SAFETY ASPECTS IN THE USE OF HYDROGEN AS A GROUND TRANSPORTATION FUEL.
Affiliations: Chemetics Int Co, Vancouver, BC, Can, Chemetics Int Co, Vancouver, BC, Can
Authors with affiliations: Knowlton, R.E., Chemetics Int Co, Vancouver, BC, Can, Chemetics Int Co, Vancouver, BC, Can
Abstract: There are numerous suggestions for the use of hydrogen in energy systems, particularly in transportaion systems. While economic factors predominate, safety aspects are an important issue particularly as hydrogen fuel would be used in close proximity with the general public. This paper is based on the work carried out by Chemetics International Company, on behalf of the National Research Council. Potential systems for the transmission, storage, distribution, refuelling and in-vehicle storage were selected. Schematic designs were developed and each subjected to the Hazard Identification procedure known as 'Hazard & Operability Studies. ' This paper outlines the strategy, the Hazard Identification approach and the results achieved with particular reference to an LH//2 refuelling station. An outline is given of some of the conclusions and recommendations including the creation of a National Hydrogen Safety Committee.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HAZARDOUS MATERIALS - Transportation; GROUND TRANSPORTATION; HAZARD IDENTIFICATION; LIQUID HYDROGEN REFUELLING STATION; HYDROGEN FUELS

Title: BREAK-EVEN AND OPTIMIZATION FOR OVERALL ENERGY SYSTEMS WHEREIN HYDROGEN STORAGE FACILITIES ARE USED.
Affiliations: DFVLR, Stuttgart, West Ger, DFVLR, Stuttgart, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Carpetis, C., DFVLR, Stuttgart, West Ger, DFVLR, Stuttgart, West Ger
Abstract: Technoeconomic aspects of large scale hydrogen storage are discussed, especially in concern to their impact on the overall economics of the energy system wherein hydrogen storage is used. In the case of the hydrogen cycle electricity storage direct economic advantages are at best marginal, but there is a number of indirect benefits (due to modularity and fast response properties) to be accounted for. In hydrogen energy systems with hydrogen end use following the usual load duration curve the economic advantages of hydrogen storage are very clear. Diurnal and seasonal hydrogen storage offer a considerable potential for optimization and cost reduction especially for solar powered hydrogen systems as shown in the case of a system using photovoltaic power for hydrogen production.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ENERGY STORAGE - Costs; ENERGY UTILIZATION; HYDROGEN CYCLE ELECTRICITY STORAGE; PHOTOVOLTAIC ELECTROLYSIS SYSTEMS; HYDROGEN

Title: STUDIES ON THE EFFECTS OF ENERGY DEPOSITION AND BACKSCATTERED ELECTRONS ON MAGNETIC MEDIA.
Affiliations: IBM Research Lab, San Jose, CA, USA, IBM Research Lab, San Jose, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pacansky, J., IBM Research Lab, San Jose, CA, USA, IBM Research Lab, San Jose, CA, USA; Waltman, R.J., IBM Research Lab, San Jose, CA, USA, IBM Research Lab, San Jose, CA, USA
Abstract: A knowledge of the energy deposition by high energy electron beams in coatings used for magnetic media is required to begin to understand the limits of line speed. In this report, energy deposition curves are calculated for magnetic coatings with thicknesses and densities nominally used for tapes, floppy disks and rigid disks. As a result of the thinness of the coatings, the results show that most of the dose available for the electron beam cure is deposited in the Al-Mg or Mylar substrates. Experiments also presented on electron backscattering, show that the dose administered to the film may be increased by placing a metal substrate with a high atomic number beneath the sample. If the additional dose from backscattered electrons is not sufficient for the desired cure or line speed, then the only resort is to dramatically decrease the incident beam voltage.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC - Disk; ELECTRON BEAMS - Applications; INK - Radiation Effects; PLASTICS FILMS - Radiation Effects; BACKSCATTERING; ELECTRON BEAM CURING; FLOPPY DISKS; MYLAR; RIGID DISKS; PROTECTIVE COATINGS

Abstract: Texas Instruments has developed a unique approach to the conversion of solar energy to electrical and thermal energy in a closed loop system that integrates the energy conversion and storage function in a novel way. The solar energy system consists of five major subsystems: solar chemical converter, hydrogen storage, fuel cell, heat exchanger, and an inverter for converting D. C. power to A. C. power. The solar chemical converter is the key subsystem. The system is expected to operate for 20 years in an on-the-roof environment. Fuel cell efficiencies of 88% have been obtained at reasonable power outputs.

Abstract: A prototype water electrolyzer designed to operate from a solar photovoltaic (PV) array without power conditioning was operated for 3 months at the Florida Solar Energy Center. A 1 kWpk PV array was used to operate the electrolyzer at internal gas pressure from 0 to 40 psig. Performance of the electrolyzer/ PV array was measured and characterized in terms of charge efficiency and power efficiency calculated from the operating data. The economics of residential production of hydrogen for energy purposes were calculated and summarized. While the near-term outlook for this energy storage technique was not found to be favorable, the long-term outlook was encouraging.

Authors with affiliations: Erokhovets, V.K.
Abstract: The diffraction performance eta of a microhologram determines the brightness in the reconstructed pattern, the data capacity, and the speed in a holographic memory. A new method of serial microhologram reproduction is proposed for use with two data channels. It is shown that maximum use can be made of the laser energy.

Abstract: In 1970, Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL) began investigating concepts for dry storage of used nuclear fuel. Beginning in 1974, the concrete canister was selected for demonstration and development, at the Whiteshell Nuclear Research Establishment. Details of the demonstration and development program are described.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR REACTORS - Spent Fuels; CANADIAN NUCLEAR EXPERIENCE; CONCRETE CANISTERS; DRY STORAGE; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: BURNELY LOW ENERGY GREENHOUSE.
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Agricultural Engineering Cent, Werribee, Aust, Agricultural Engineering Cent, Werribee, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Rigby, A.R., Agricultural Engineering Cent, Werribee, Aust, Agricultural Engineering Cent, Werribee, Aust
Abstract: The need for energy saving in greenhouse horticulture is reiterated. The design philosophy of the Burnley Low Energy Greenhouse is explained and details of design and construction of each facet of the project are presented. The use of microprocessors for datalogging and control tasks, the storage of thermal energy under benches, and the modular construction of solar air heaters receive special attention. Methods of disseminating information to the horticultural industry are discussed.

Title: SELF-BREAKDOWN SPARK GAP STABILITY UNDER REP-RATE CONDITIONS.
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rinehart, L.F., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Buttram, M.T., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: The statistical distribution of self-breakdown voltages of a spark gap was measured at low repetition rates ( less than equivalent to 1 Hz) and at 20 and 40 pulses per second. For the high repetition rate experiments, the test switch discharged a resistively charged energy storage capacitor into a resistive load, producing a simple R-C relaxation waveform across the spark gap. Typical discharge parameters were in the 10 to 35 kV, 10 to 20 kA range with about 1 mu s pulse width. For the low-rate work, a 20% reversal ringing waveform was used to reach higher discharge currents (up to 100 kA). An online computer data acquisition system was used to record and process large numbers of breakdowns, thus producing good statistical samples.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BREAKDOWN - Measurements; SELF-BREAKDOWN VOLTAGES; STATISTICAL DISTRIBUTION; ELECTRIC SPARK GAPS

Abstract: Hydrogen storage and transportation methods using metal hydrides are regarded as promising as the liquid hydrogen method in future hydrogen energy systems. The authors had been studying to develop a hydrogen storage and transportation technique based on the use of metal hydrides as part of researches for hydrogen energy technology. On the basis of the results of basic experiments and studies conducted so far, hydrogen storage vessel using 1,000 kg metal hydride (LR) Ni//4//. //8Al//0//. //2) were manufactured and put to tests, from which data necessary for future hydrogen storage and transportation systems in handling large amounts of metal hydrides and hydrogen were obtained.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION; RARE EARTH COMPOUNDS - Applications; HYDROGEN STORAGE VESSEL; METAL HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN

Authors: Avery W.H., Richards D., Dugger G.L.
Title: HYDROGEN GENERATION BY OTEC ELECTROLYSIS, AND ECONOMICAL ENERGY TRANSFER TO WORLD MARKETS VIA AMMONIA AND METHANOL.
Affiliations: Johns Hopkins Univ, Applied Physics, Lab, Laurel, MD, USA, Johns Hopkins Univ, Applied Physics Lab, Laurel, MD, USA

Abstract: OTEC plantships sited in tropical oceans would generate 150 to 400 MWe (net) of low cost electric power per plantship. These plantships would tap a virtually unlimited source of energy for economical production of hydrogen by water electrolysis. Hydrogen could be delivered to U. S. users from such plantships via hydrogen liquefaction, transport and storage, or by incorporation in a chemical carrier and shipment by conventional transport methods. Costs of OTEC energy in the form of liquid fuels delivered to U. S. users are estimated to be favorable compared with equivalents derived from land based sources after 1990. The paper briefly reviews the status of OTEC technology and projected costs for plantship construction and deployment.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; OCEAN THERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; WATER - Electrolysis; OCEAN ENERGY; OTEC PLANTSHIPS; HYDROGEN

Abstract: A simulation computer program for the design analyses of a solar thermal electric plant with single axis tracking parabolic trough collectors is presented. The model system was developed using TRNSYS, a general purpose solar energy simulating program. The model was based on the 150 kW Solar Power Deep Well Irrigation Facility located in Coolidge, Arizona. Two new TRNSYS subroutines were developed for the plant model: A Distributed Solar Energy Collector Field and an Organic Rankine Cycle Energy Conversion System. Parametric analysis studies were done to determine the effects of collector field orientation and the heat storage capacity on the plant performance efficiency.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; THERMODYNAMICS; COLLECTOR FIELD MODEL; RANKINE CYCLE; THERMAL STORAGE TANK; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: SYSTEM FOR PRODUCING AND STORING NATURALLY FROZEN ICE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Meeting - American Section of the International Solar Energy Society
Affiliations: Illinois State Univ, Normal, IL, USA, Illinois State Univ, Normal, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Francis, C.E., Illinois State Univ, Normal, IL, USA, Illinois State Univ, Normal, IL, USA
Abstract: Refrigeration, cooling and/or chilling method usually require rather large amounts of energy for operation. This system uses naturally frozen ice in long term storage to provide an economical source of ice for various cooling or chilling purposes. Initial research and computer simulations indicate that in areas where the winter is sufficiently cold and of sufficient duration, this system would be an economical, viable option for uses such as simple refrigeration, summer air conditioning, or simply for effective dehumidification. System coefficient of performance (COP) will approximate 5. 2 for a representative size system located in Chicago, Illinois.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Cooling; FOOD PRODUCTS - Refrigeration; DEHUMIDIFICATION; FOOD STORAGE; NATURALLY FROZEN ICE; ICE

Abstract: Since 1970, defense-generated transuranic waste has been placed into 20-year retrievable storage at the Radioactive Waste Management Complex at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL). A major objective of the U. S. Department of Energy Nuclear Waste Management Program is to remove all retrievably stored transuranic waste from the INEL. The Stored Waste Examination Pilot Plant (SWEPP) and the Process Experimental Pilot Plant (PREPP) are currently being constructed. SWEPP will certify waste, using nondestructive examination techniques, for shipment to the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant. PREPP will process uncertifiable waste into a certifiable waste form.

Authors with affiliations: Braun, P., AECL, Mississauga, Ont, Can, AECL, Mississauga, Ont, Can
Abstract: Due to limited space in underwater storage facilities for irradiated fuel in some existing CANDU nuclear generating stations, a method of increasing the storage density of fuel was devised which avoids the cost of constructing additional storage bays on site until future off-site permanent storage facilities are developed. This paper describes the remotely controlled and operated system developed by Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, (AECL), CANDU Operations, to transfer irradiated fuel underwater from the original storage containers to high density storage modules.

Authors with affiliations: Sadler, Gerald W., Univ of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta,, Can, Univ of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Can; Fung, Philip T.N., Univ of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta,, Can, Univ of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Can
Abstract: Module 6 at the Alberta Home Heating Research Facility has an air solar heating system consisting of an 11. 1 square metre double glazed south facing solar collector tilted at 67 degrees, a rockbed storage unit, one air handling unit, motorized dampers, a two stage electric furnace and a system controller. The operating characteristics, the energy flows and the solar contributions for the period September 1981 to March 1982 are presented. The monthly and period solar contributions were calculated using the measured solar energy and the electric power to the module and by comparing the difference in power required for module 6 and module 5, a module of similar construction.

Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 78 papers. Various aspects of energy conservation, solar energy and wind power applications are covered. The topics discussed include solar buildings, greenhouses, photovoltaic cells, thermal energy storage, solar radiation, passive and active solar buildings, window performance, heat exchangers, indoor air quality and air pollution control. Other topics covered are agricultural applications of solar energy and wind power; biomass energy utilization, community planning, and energy economics.

Abstract: A study was carried out to evaluate the benefits and costs of incorporating passive solar design features into a wood-frame rowhouse design, including the addition of a steel/concrete composite floor system as return air plenum and mass for heat storage. The project, funded by the Solar Energy Program, NRC, involved the modelling of the design by a minute-by-minute dynamic heat transfer model to assess the role of the mass floor in the house's energy system.

Title: LONG TERM CHARACTERISTICS OF A SOLAR COLLECTOR-STORAGE WALL IN COLD CLIMATES.
Source title: Paper - American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Univ of Saskatchewan, Dep of, Agricultural Engineering, Saskatoon,, Sask, Can, Univ of Saskatchewan, Dep of Agricultural Engineering, Saskatoon, Sask, Can
Authors with affiliations: Sokhansanj, Shahab, Univ of Saskatchewan, Dep of, Agricultural Engineering, Saskatoon,, Sask, Can, Univ of Saskatchewan, Dep of Agricultural Engineering, Saskatoon, Sask, Can; Barber, E.M., Univ of Saskatchewan, Dep of, Agricultural Engineering, Saskatoon,, Sask, Can, Univ of Saskatchewan, Dep of Agricultural Engineering, Saskatoon, Sask, Can
Abstract: The effectiveness of solar collector and storage systems normally is measured in terms of the long term contribution to the supplemental heat demand. A concrete solar wall added to a farrowing barn provided 60 percent of the annual supplemental heat. To evaluate the size and effectiveness of the collector and the storage separately, a new technique based on two hypothetical limits is proposed. One limit is a system with zero thermal storage, and the other is a system with infinite thermal storage. The application of the procedure to the experimental solar concrete wall showed that the storage size was not adequate for the collector size.

Authors with affiliations: Schoenbach, K.H., Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA; Schaefer, G., Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA; Kristiansen, M., Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA; Krompholz, H., Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA; Harjes, H.C., Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA; Skaggs, D., Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA, Texas Tech Univ, Dep of Electrical Engineering, Lubbock, TX, USA
Abstract: Inductive energy storage is attractive in pulsed power applications because of its intrinsic high energy density compared to capacitive storage systems. The key technological problem in developing inductive energy discharge systems, especially for repetitive operation (rep rates larger than kpps), is the development of opening switches. An e-beam tetrode was designed for the investigation of e-beam-controlled conductivities in switch gases. The operating characteristics are: burst mode operation in the Mpps (mega pulses per second) range; variable pulse duration and pulse separation; turn-on and turn-off times in the range of 10 ns; variation of e-beam energy (E//B less than equivalent to 250 keV); variation of e-beam current density (J//B less than equivalent to 4 A/cm**2 ). Diffuse discharge investigations were performed in the gas mixtures N//2 :N//2 O, N//2 :SO//2 , and N//2 :CO//2 .
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC SWITCHES; ELECTRON TUBES, STORAGE; DIFFUSE DISCHARGE SWITCH; ELECTRON BEAM CONTROL; ELECTRON BEAMS

Abstract: Hydrogen has the potential to become an almost perfect fuel, given that cost-effective production and storage methods can be developed. It makes more sense to produce hydrogen from renewable energy sources than from fossil fuels because of feedstock availability, energy input requirements, and environmental considerations. The international program discussed herein is specifically oriented toward basic research and experimentation on the production, storage, transmission, and utilization of hydrogen derived from renewable energy sources. Hawaii, with its Hawaii Natural Energy Institute and newly formed Pacific International Center for High Technology Research, is proposed as an international hydrogen research center.

Abstract: In this paper, a modification to the utilizability design method for active collection-passive storage systems is presented which allows for combination of active collection-passive storage and direct-gain solar systems. Authors: Vadie Henry H., Lee Stephen T.
Title: HOUSTON LIGHTING AND POWER COMPANY EVALUATION OF COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: Houston Lighting & Power Co,, Houston, TX, USA, Houston Lighting & Power Co, Houston, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Vadie, Henry H., Houston Lighting & Power Co,, Houston, TX, USA, Houston Lighting & Power Co, Houston, TX, USA; Lee, Stephen T., Houston Lighting & Power Co,, Houston, TX, USA, Houston Lighting & Power Co, Houston, TX, USA
Abstract: Compressed air energy storage (CAES) is a resource being evaluated by Houston Lighting and Power Company (HL&P). There is underground salt formation suitable for CAES developement around HL&P's service area. This paper presents the results of a preliminary economic analysis of a 660 MW CAES plant in 1994 in comparison with a coal/lignite plant. Sensitivity analysis was conducted to examine the effect of off-peak charging energy from outside systems and the effect of gas prices. Results indicated that the CAES plant had a benefit to cost ratio of 1. 15 which would be raised above 1. 5 if off-system charging energy at a reasonable price could be obtained. Decreasing gas price would favor CAES in comparison with coal or lignite. The CAES plant in operation would save 5 to 13 million mcf of gas per year.
Index Keywords: COST ACCOUNTING; ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ELECTRIC UTILITIES - Rates; COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE; HOUSTON LIGHTING AND POWER COMPANY; COMPRESSED AIR

Title: SOLAR PROPELLED LATERAL MOVE TRAVELING TRICKLE IRRIGATION SYSTEM.

Affiliations: USDA, Fresno, CA, USA, USDA, Fresno, CA, USA

Abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) panels were installed on a laser-guided lateral move irrigation system to provide driving power. The system was designed to irrigate 2. 5 ha using wet cell storage batteries for operation during dark hours. The PV system generated all power necessary to propel the traveling irrigation system during the whole irrigation season. Although present costs are prohibitive for application in irrigated agriculture, future improved manufacturing processes and tax incentives could make PV a valuable alternative during an energy shortage.

Abstract: The development of sodium-sulfur-batteries has been progressed to a level, where not only single cells but also full batteries can be operated: A 512-cell, 100 kWh battery simulating stationary energy storage has been on test more than three years or greater than 700 cycles. A 76 cell-battery was subjected to greater than 100 cycles both on laboratory and vehicle tests. Two 224-cells, 12 kWh batteries have been used to propel a van during a 9 months period of time. The latter two batteries were composed of all necessary traction battery components such as cells, superinsulated thermal enclosure and heating/cooling system. Problem areas are highlighted.

Authors with affiliations: Froment, M., CNRS, Paris, Fr, CNRS, Paris, Fr
Abstract: The author tries to identify some aspects of fundamental research needed to solve corrosion problems in different energy conversion or storage systems. Three topics seem of special interest for the future: Development of in situ techniques and accelerated tests of corrosion - Hydrodynamic effects in corrosion systems - Properties of the passive layer and its consequences on the mechanism of localized corrosion. Some results will be given about the determination of the nature and the structure of passive layers by optical and EXAFS methods. Besides the development of new materials, surface treatments and surface modifications seem very promising. The effect of intergranular sulfur segregation will be discussed in connection with the corrosion behaviour of nickel for alkaline water electrolysis.

Abstract: Design concepts and system components are presented for a flow battery whose overall cell reaction during discharge is the formation of ZnBr//2, (or ZnCl//2 respectively), whereas zinc is plated at the cathode and halogen (Br//2 or Cl//2) evolved at the anode from the aqueous electrolyte in the charging process, providing reversible cell voltages of 1,82 and 2,12 V. The theoretical energy densities amount to 430 Wh/kg (Zn/Br//2) and 837 Wh/kg for the Zn/Cl//2-system, which is reduced to 465 Wh/kg on account of the losses caused by the chlorine hydrate storage.

Abstract: This paper consolidates relevant reliability and maintainability (R&M) information based on documented findings from field installations. Data from government sponsored demonstration projects, utilities, private consultants, and owner surveys are included. Failure rates and problem frequencies are emphasized rather than guidelines and experiences, which have been compiled elsewhere. R&M issues concerning solar energy systems, subsystems, and components are reviewed. The information presented is based upon 20 applicable R&M studies. Authors with affiliations: Clarke, R.L., Chevron Research Co, Richmond, CA,, USA, Chevron Research Co, Richmond, CA, USA; Wasson, A.R., Chevron Research Co, Richmond, CA,, USA, Chevron Research Co, Richmond, CA, USA
Abstract: The slurry zinc-air battery is a developed system, utilizing the highest energy density couple of the metal-air systems that are truly rechargeable. The zinc-air battery holds promise because it is a system that delivers energy at ambient temperature and provides sufficient power to give the vehicle a reasonable performance on the road, i. e. , acceleration, hill climbing, etc. Unfortunately, the vehicle performance is reduced, at least in range, by the contribution of the weight and bulk of ancillary equipment such as electrolyte tanks, pumps, heat exchanger compressors, and carbon dioxide scrubbers needed to make the system perform. The authors present practical cell designs and operating data for the recharge cycle of the zinc-air cell at two levels: (a) the typical home charger and (b) a larger facility using hydrogen as a fuel at the anode. The overall performance of an integrated system will be extrapolated from known operating parameters of the relevant systems.
Index Keywords: ANODES; CATHODES; HYDROGEN; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; DISCHARGE CELLS; ELECTRIC VEHICLES; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; HOME CHARGER; OXYGEN EVOLUTION; SLURRY ZINC-AIR BATTERY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: HYDRO POWER IN THE UK - PAST PERFORMANCE AND POTENTIAL FOR FUTURE DEVELOPMENT.
Affiliations: North of Scotland Hydro-electric, Board, Scotl, North of Scotland Hydro-electric Board, Scotl
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, F.G., North of Scotland Hydro-electric, Board, Scotl, North of Scotland Hydro-electric Board, Scotl
Abstract: Great Britain has little hydro power although experience gained in the intensive period of exploitation in Scotland over the 20 years following the last War resulted in a wide range of schemes and designs being developed. In recent years, with the majority of the conventional hydro sites already utilised, the growing demand for electricity led to the construction of pumped storage schemes both in Wales and Scotland. As the great majority of British schemes are located in the Highlands, this paper will be primarily concerned with the Scottish scene.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES - Scotland; COST SAVINGS; HYDRO DEVELOPMENT; HYDRO RESOURCES; SOCIAL ADVANTAGES; UNDEVELOPED HYDRO IN SCOTLAND; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Affiliations: Colorado Mountain Coll, Glenwood, Springs, CO, USA, Colorado Mountain Coll, Glenwood Springs, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: McCarney, Steven P., Colorado Mountain Coll, Glenwood, Springs, CO, USA, Colorado Mountain Coll, Glenwood Springs, CO, USA
Abstract: This paper contains a detailed description of a batch water heater (integral collector storage system) freeze protection strategy for cold climates. The design goals of this strategy are to maximize thermal performance while retaining the best features of a batch heater, such as comparatively low system cost, simplicity, no parasitic power requirements, and near zero maintenance. Peak winter night and day data is presented, as well as summer peaks. Construction details and lessons learned are included.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; PIPING SYSTEMS; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; CONSUMER ACCEPTANCE; PEAK WINTER AND SUMMER CONDITIONS; SYSTEM SPECIFICATIONS; WATER HEATERS

Title: NEW HIGH POWER P. W. M. GTO INVERTER FOR HIGH VOLTAGE POWER SUPPLIES.
Source title: Proceedings of Powercon: International Solid-State Power Electronics Conference
Affiliations: GE (USA) Electromedicina, R&D, Dep, Madrid, Spain, GE (USA) Electromedicina, R&D Dep, Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Manueco, C., GE (USA) Electromedicina, R&D, Dep, Madrid, Spain, GE (USA) Electromedicina, R&D Dep, Madrid, Spain; Quevedo, J.M., GE (USA) Electromedicina, R&D, Dep, Madrid, Spain, GE (USA) Electromedicina, R&D Dep, Madrid, Spain; Lopez, F., GE (USA) Electromedicina, R&D, Dep, Madrid, Spain, GE (USA) Electromedicina, R&D Dep, Madrid, Spain
Abstract: Today's state of art in high power inverter, using power GTO's, has severe limitations such as the need for large snubber capacitors and the very high losses of currently commercially available devices at turning on and off periods. Until now, these severe limitations have caused the power GTO applications to be constrained to low frequency operation such as 1 kHz so as to drastically diminish both the device losses and the snubber storage energy, which is normally dissipated in large resistors and is proportional to the operating frequency. This paper introduces the first GTO pulse width modulated inverter in the power range of 100-200 KW, 2-8 kHz frequency range, with very simple lossless snubber circuitry, short-circuit proof operation, specifically designed for high voltage power supplies and multiprocessor controller with very fast kilovolts feedback loop response within the range of fractions of millisecond.
Index Keywords: PULSE WIDTH MODULATION; THYRISTORS - Switching; GATE TURN-OFF THYRISTORS; HIGH POWER INVERTER; LARGE SNUBBER CAPACITORS; ELECTRIC INVERTERS

Abstract: Energy costs for heating and cooling greenhouses will vary greatly throughout Australia and will depend on the location, the crop grown, the type of structure and the fuel used. Conventional energy requirements were only 18% of those required by a conventional structure of the same size.

Abstract: In connection with the limited energy capacity of sources used to supply electric vehicles (electromobiles) the range of an electromobile is a fundamental characteristic. It is not suitable for evaluating a chosen electric-drive system, however, or comparison of such a system with others since different electromobiles use different storage batteries with differing energy capacities while the vehicles themselves have different resistances to motion, net weights, etc.

Abstract: A new technique to determine the flat-band potential of semiconductors as well as to distinguish the direct photoresponse from the indirect processes has been developed. Chopped light was used for illuminating the SC and the oscillating photocurrent was measured in a storage oscilloscope at varying potentials. Cathodic photo-response was observed with TiO//2 prepared by thermal oxidation of Ti without further thermal hydrogenation or doping. V//f//b of this was different from that of the former one. Their energy level diagrams and nature of surface states have been discussed.

Abstract: The proposed programme 'Solid Polymer Electrolyte Electrolyzer Development' (SPEED) aims at establishing a 50 KW demonstration electrolyzer module as a consequence of a co-ordinated technology research. Authors: Fara Vladimir, Bucur Adrian, Atanasiu Mircea
Title: NUMERICAL SOLUTION OF A PHYSICO-MATHEMATICAL MODEL OF SOLAR ENERGY THERMAL STORAGE USEFUL FOR HIGH TEMPERATURES.
Affiliations: Polytechnical Inst of Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom, Polytechnical Inst of Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom
Authors with affiliations: Fara, Vladimir, Polytechnical Inst of Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom, Polytechnical Inst of Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom; Bucur, Adrian, Polytechnical Inst of Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom, Polytechnical Inst of Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom; Atanasiu, Mircea, Polytechnical Inst of Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom, Polytechnical Inst of Bucharest, Bucharest, Rom
Abstract: The study of the solar energy thermal storage systems using molten salts crossed by an organic fluid represents a very important research problem for solar power plants. The knowledge of the time-distance evolution of such a system allows the acquisition of important information for the optimum dimensioning of thermal solar energy tanks at high temperatures. The physico-mathematical model considered is that of an exchange column of molten salt and organic fluid. Because of the difficulties arising during the analytical solution of the thermal transfer equations system (storage equation), we applied the numerical solution to the network method. The main new points of the method applied by the authors are: the use of a simple iteration method, the use of matrix form, the outline of a correspondence between temperatures and certain angles which allow a physical interpretation of the results obtained.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SALTS - Fused; PHYSICO-MATHEMATICAL MODEL; SOLAR ENERGY

Abstract: In 1976 ERDA, now known as DOE, funded the design and construction of a 22,000 sq. ft. solar collector system with 700 tons of rock storage and a heat recovery wheel. This system was placed in operation in April of 1978 and has operated and been monitored each drying season since. This paper covers the operation and required maintenance since its installation. Subjects covered include typical performance data, pressure drop, availability efficiency, and others.

Abstract: A preferred method for sizing energy systems based on economic considerations was developed in this paper. The use of rules of thumb developed for residential applications is not valid because of the underlying assumptions of the air entering the collector and the need to provide sufficient ventilation air for animal wellbeing. The problems of determining a heat balance from field measurements of solar energy available are minor; however, the determination of the amount of purchased energy which can be replaced by solar energy is complex and requires careful evaluation of system leaks, animal heat production, transient storage of heat, and ventilation rates.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; FARM BUILDINGS; VENTILATION; LIFE CYCLE COSTS; LIQUID COLLECTOR SYSTEMS; SEASONAL ENERGY UTILIZATION; SOFTWARE PACKAGE; SOLAR ENERGY

Abstract: Using monitored results, this paper investigates several applications of thermal mass in built passive homes. The available data on monitored passive solar residential buildings has been carefully surveyed. Little comprehensive monitoring of passive buildings' thermal storage systems has been performed beyond the VITRO /National Solar Data Network (NSDN). However, some hope remains that the National Association of Homebuilders - Research Foundation Class B project will enhance its low-cost monitoring procedures to generate more valuable thermal mass data.

Title: CHEMICAL STORAGE OF SOLAR ENERGY BY USE OF SILICON ELECTRODES.
Source title: Extended Abstracts, Meeting - International Society of Electrochemistry
Affiliations: Osaka Univ, Toyonaka, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Toyonaka, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Tsubomura, Hiroshi, Osaka Univ, Toyonaka, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Toyonaka, Jpn; Nakato, Yoshihiro, Osaka Univ, Toyonaka, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Toyonaka, Jpn; Hiramoto, Masahiro, Osaka Univ, Toyonaka, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Toyonaka, Jpn
Abstract: The authors found that a noble metal coating could prevent the corrosion of silicon and other semiconductor photoelectrodes. The photovoltage of the electrodes became smaller by the Fermi level pinning due to the metal-semiconductor junctions. To solve this dilemma, the authors developed a photoelectrochemical cell, composed of a noble metal coated p,n-junction silicon photoanode, a counter platinum electrode, and a cation exchange membrane, by which hydrogen iodide is efficiently decomposed into hydrogen and iodine (or triiodide ions, I//3). The authors also used a 2 M HI / 0. 01 M I//2 solution in the anode compartment and a 2 M HBr solution in the cathode compartment, the DELTA G was 0. 41 eV per electron. Based on this data, a solar to chemical conversion efficiency of 8. 2% was obtained under AM-1 radiation from a solar simulator, with current density of 20 mA cm** minus **2.
Index Keywords: DIRECT ENERGY CONVERSION; ELECTRODES - Materials; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS; CHEMICAL STORAGE OF SOLAR ENERGY; CONVERSION EFFICIENCY; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; GIBBS ENERGY; PHOTOELECTROCHEMICAL CELLS; SOLAR SIMULATOR; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: AIR STORAGE REQUIREMENTS FOR A 220 MWe CAES PLANT AS A FUNCTION OF TURBOMACHINERY SELECTION AND OPERATION.

Authors with affiliations: Karalis, A.J., United Engineers & Constructors, Inc, Philadelphia, PA, USA, United Engineers & Constructors Inc, Philadelphia, PA, USA; Sosnowicz, E.J., United Engineers & Constructors, Inc, Philadelphia, PA, USA, United Engineers & Constructors Inc, Philadelphia, PA, USA; Stys, Z.S., United Engineers & Constructors, Inc, Philadelphia, PA, USA, United Engineers & Constructors Inc, Philadelphia, PA, USA
Abstract: This paper examines the effects of compressor train selection, turbine operation and the generation/compression cycle for a 220 MWe CAES plant which operates with a HP turbine inlet pressure of 44 bar (638 psia). The volumetric requirements of the underground cavities are examined as a function of geologic formation and inlet pressure. While constant volume air storage in a salt formation is emphasized air storage in a variable volume compensated rock cavern, and variable pressure storage in an aquifer are also discussed. Both a daily and weekly compression cycle are addressed and the effect of duty cycle on the compressor train selection is shown. For a given turbine design the effect of constant vs. variable pressure operation on overall plant performance is noted.
Index Keywords: COMPRESSED AIR MOTORS; ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS; ENERGY STORAGE; GEOLOGY; COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE; COMPRESSED AIR

Title: ULTRAVIOLET DEGRADATION OF CORRUGATED PLASTIC TUBING.
Source title: Paper - American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Ohio State Univ, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Columbus, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Desmond, E.D., Ohio State Univ, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Columbus, OH, USA; Schwab, G.O., Ohio State Univ, Agricultural, Engineering Dep, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Agricultural Engineering Dep, Columbus, OH, USA
Abstract: Corrugated plastic tubing (CPT) storage shelf life predictions were based on the effect of ultraviolet (UV) light exposure. The embrittlement rates of tubing resulting from two accelerated UV exposure methods were compared with that of natural sunlight exposure in Ohio. Fourteen average months of Ohio exposure, or 5600 MJ/m**2 of solar energy, is the minimum recommended shelf life for storage of CPT. These shelf life tests can be made by accelerated exposure of 450 MJ/m**2 of concentrated sunlight or by 800 Weatherometer hours of exposure both followed by a flat plate impact of 30-J. Protection from UV embrittlement during the recommended shelf life is adaquate if all samples exposed on accelerated machines pass the impact test.
Index Keywords: MATERIALS TESTING - Impact; PLASTICS - Radiation Effects; ULTRAVIOLET RADIATION; ACCELERATED ULTRAVIOLET EXPOSURE METHODS; CORRUGATED PLASTIC TUBING; STORAGE SHELF LIFE PREDICTIONS; ULTRAVIOLET DEGRADATION; ULTRAVIOLET EMBRITTLEMENT; TUBES

Title: INTERNATIONAL ENERGY AGENCY COOPERATIVE PROGRAMS ON HYDROGEN: PAST ACHIEVEMENTS AND FUTURE POTENTIAL.

Abstract: Work under the Hydrogen Agreement of the International Energy Agency was started in 1977. A cooperative research and development program has evolved around the production of hydrogen by thermochemical, electrolytic and photochemical methods. There has recently been added a new subject area relating to storage, energy conversion and safety. The first five years of the IEA program on hydrogen have seen considerable progress made towards the common goal of developing cost-effective, high efficiency water-splitting technologies for use with renewable or inexhaustible energy sources. The past achievements and present programs are described.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY STORAGE; COOPERATIVE PROGRAMS; HYDROGEN ENERGY; INTERNATIONAL ENERGY AGENCY; HYDROGEN

Authors: Friesel D.L., Pollock R.E., Ellison T.E., Jones W.P.
Title: LOW ENERGY STORAGE RING FOR PULSE STACKING AT IUCF.
Affiliations: Univ of Indiana, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA, Univ of Indiana, Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Friesel, D.L., Univ of Indiana, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA, Univ of Indiana, Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN, USA; Pollock, R.E., Univ of Indiana, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA, Univ of Indiana, Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN, USA; Ellison, T.E., Univ of Indiana, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA, Univ of Indiana, Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN, USA; Jones, W.P., Univ of Indiana, Cyclotron Facility,, Bloomington, IN, USA, Univ of Indiana, Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN, USA
Abstract: A method for providing a highly variable duty factor for coupled cyclotron systems without sacrificing beam brightness has been developed. A low energy isochronous storage ring is used to store a beam from the 0. 62 MeV ion source preinjector. The stored beam current is allowed to accumulate to the transverse phase space limit before being extracted for injection into the cyclotron at a pulse rate selected by the user. The device, which is called a stripper loop, was constructed to test the feasibility of the approach and to explore the space charge limits of the injector cyclotron with more intense beams. The design and operating details of the stripper loop and the preliminary results of the initial development efforts are described.
Index Keywords: ION SOURCES; BEAM CURRENT; PULSE STACKING; SPACE CHARGE LIMITS; ACCELERATORS, CYCLOTRON

Title: ELECTRONIC-COMMUTATOR AC/DC MOTOR-DRIVEN TRACKED ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES WITH EXTREMELY HIGH MOBILITY.
Affiliations: Thaddeus Kosciuszko Memorial Cracow, Polytechnic, Cracow, Pol, Thaddeus Kosciuszko Memorial Cracow Polytechnic, Cracow, Pol
Authors with affiliations: Fijatkowski, B.T., Thaddeus Kosciuszko Memorial Cracow, Polytechnic, Cracow, Pol, Thaddeus Kosciuszko Memorial Cracow Polytechnic, Cracow, Pol
Abstract: Tracked all-terrain vehicles is a general term which includes all types and sizes of soft wet land- and snow-traversing vehicles. All such equipment must meet the highest standards of safety, comfort, reliability, flexibility, durability and mobility and work under the most arduous operating conditions. Because of their unique all-terrain capabilities, the tracked all-terrain vehicles are also used for nonmilitary purposes, particularly in those cases where extremely high mobility over difficult terrain is required. Brushless electronic-commutator AC or DC motors and motorized wheels are well established today in energy-saving toothed-gearless hybrid-electric propulsion systems for tracked all-terrain vehicles with extremely high mobility. Growing attention is being shown in the use of trigistor electronic-commutator AC or DC motors for these propulsion systems.
Index Keywords: ALL-TERRAIN CAPABILITIES; ENERGY-SAVING PROPULSION; STATIC ELECTRONIC COMMUTATORS; TRACKED ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES; TRACTION-DUTY STORAGE BATTERIES; ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT; VEHICLES

Authors: Jackson William D., Feero W.E., Gish W., Seikel George R.
Title: INTEGRATION OF MHD PLANTS INTO ELECTRIC UTILITY SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: HMJ Corp, HMJ Corp
Authors with affiliations: Jackson, William D., HMJ Corp, HMJ Corp; Feero, W.E., HMJ Corp, HMJ Corp; Gish, W., HMJ Corp, HMJ Corp; Seikel, George R., HMJ Corp, HMJ Corp
Abstract: This paper considers the behavior of an MHD/steam combined cycle plant under the dynamic operating conditions prescribed by the transient stability regime (50 msec to 10 sec after a disturbance on the power system). Using a three phase fault to ground to test the model developed, it is shown that (1) in this regime, the MHD generator acts as a current source to provide damping and consequent increased network stability; (2) the low energy storage capability of the MHD generator reduces fault currents and plant surges relative to those of a similarly rated conventional plant; and (3) load tripping introduces special requirements which are discussed in the paper.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; TURBOMACHINERY; FARADAY CHANNELS; MHD CHANNELS; MAGNETOHYDRODYNAMIC CONVERTERS

Title: NUMERICAL STUDY OF UNSTEADY NATURAL CONVECTION IN A STORAGE TANK.
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Meeting - American Section of the International Solar Energy Society
Affiliations: Univ of Florida, Gainesville, FL,, USA, Univ of Florida, Gainesville, FL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Shyu, R.J., Univ of Florida, Gainesville, FL,, USA, Univ of Florida, Gainesville, FL, USA; Hsieh, C.K., Univ of Florida, Gainesville, FL,, USA, Univ of Florida, Gainesville, FL, USA
Abstract: The decay of thermal stratification is analyzed in this paper using a numerical study. The fluid flow and heat transfer in the storage medium and the tank wall are solved using two-dimensional models, and the entire problem is treated as a conjugate heat transfer problem. The medium is initially stratified near the middle of the tank, and the tank wall is at a uniform temperature. Buoyancy driven flows develop first in the lower region, which rapidly diminishes while those in the upper region grow and finally extend to full length because of the heat loss from the wall. In the paper, the isotherms, velocities, and streamlines are examined in detail.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Convection; WATER HEATERS - Solar; ISOTHERM PLOTS; STORAGE TANK; TEMPERATURE VARIATION; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: RECENT RESULTS FROM THE NATIONAL BATTERY TEST LABORATORY.
Source title: Extended Abstracts, Meeting - International Society of Electrochemistry
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hornstra, F., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA; Yao, N.P., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Abstract: The National Battery Test Laboratory (NBTL) is an Argonne National Laboratory facility for testing, evaluating, and studying advanced electric storage batteries. The facility tests batteries developed under Department of Energy programs and from private industry. These include batteries intended for future electric vehicle (EV) propulsion, electric utility load leveling, and solar energy storage. The authors focus on the testing of EV batteries as this application is the most demanding and requires the most versatile test program. Of the spectrum of tests performed at the NBTL, one of the most useful is the mapping of the specific energy available from a battery as a function of the specific power level at which it is discharged. The resulting relationship is defined as a Ragone Plot. The Ragone plot clearly shows which batteries manifest the highest specific energies and which exhibit the most sensitivity to power demands. In addition, the plot can be used to project the expected ranges of an electric vehicle if the battery-power demands of the vehicle are known for the operating conditions of interest.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR ENERGY; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; BATTERY PERFORMANCE; CYCLE LIFE; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; NATIONAL BATTERY TEST LABORATORY; POWER LEVEL; RAGONE PLOT; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Abstract: Seasonal storage of electrical energy is an important goal in the future struggle of oil substitution. The excellent storage properties of aluminum were the reason for our investigations on this storage cycle. Several properties like high energy density and ease of storage qualify aluminum as a good medium for energy storage. An improvement of the efficiency of the aluminum smelter would make the storage system even more attractive. The conversion of the stored energy can be made in a simple aluminum powder burner or in aluminum/oxygen batteries. First experiments with high temperature batteries showed very promising results.

Title: MECHANICAL LOSSES IN CARBON-BLACK-FILLED RUBBERS.
Affiliations: Phillips Petroleum Co, Bartlesville,, OK, USA, Phillips Petroleum Co, Bartlesville, OK, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kraus, Gerard, Phillips Petroleum Co, Bartlesville,, OK, USA, Phillips Petroleum Co, Bartlesville, OK, USA
Abstract: The effects of carbon black specific surface area and structure on the viscoelastic behavior of carbon-black-reinforced elastomers in the rubbery response region are reviewed. The evidence favors agglomeration-deagglomeration of particles as the principal mechanism by which carbon blacks contribute to energy dissipation in these materials. A semiquantitative theory of this mechanism is developed which explains the most important features of the dynamic viscoelastic behavior of carbon-black-filled rubbers, particularly the unique amplitude dependence of the dynamic storage and loss moduli, which has no counterpart in unfilled rubbers.

Abstract: Besides the setting up of nuclear power plants which, from 1986 onwards, will generate 65 % of her electricity, Belgium has during the last 30 years developed important activities aimed at a sound management of spent nuclear fuels and radioactive wastes. In the recent years, both the authorities and the industry have taken decisions and actions aimed at the promotion of spent fuel reprocessing, the recycling of plutonium and the long-term management of the wastes. The present paper describes the institutional, technical and financial aspects of these decisions and measures.

Abstract: The Soyland CAES Project (Illinois, USA) was to have been the world's first hydraulically compensated, hard rock, compressed air energy storage scheme. Whilst in the event the unsuitable rock characteristics at the chosen site together with a decline in power demand at the time, led to the cancellation of the project, the feasibility of such a system is not in question and the particular design aspects are of special interest. The paper describes the geotechnical investigations and the proposed design and construction parameters for the underground system which comprised a 245,000 m**3 network of caverns in hard dolomite at 600 m depth together with water and air shafts connected to the surface plant.

Abstract: A prediction model was developed to quantify the influence of the freeze-concentration effect on quality degradation rate during frozen food storage. Inputs to the model include rate constants, activation energy and reaction order. Apparent reaction rates or rate constants at sub-freezing temperatures are the outputs. Autoxidation of oxymyoglobin in acetate buffer was used to verify the prediction model.

Authors with affiliations: Hatzinikolas, M.A., Alberta Masonry Inst, Alberta, Can, Alberta Masonry Inst, Alberta, Can
Abstract: This paper deals with the development of a top mounted chimney damper and a double shutter fresh air intake which when incorporated in a new or an existing masonry fireplace can substantially increase its efficiency. It also presents test data obtained when these devices are installed in a fireplace and makes reference to the effects of the location of a masonry fireplace when heat storage from passive solar heating are considered. Efficiency for the purpose of this paper is defined as the amount of heat generated by burning a unit of fuel which can be turned into usable energy in the form of heat to be utilized in heating a house.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Space Heating; CHIMNEYS; AIR LEAKAGE TESTS; FIREPLACE DAMPER; FRESH AIR INTAKE CONTROL; HOUSES

Title: POWER SUPPLY FILTER CAPACITOR.

Abstract: Modern Switch Mode Power Supplies can deliver dramatically more power, per unit volume weight or price, than linear equivalent designs. This is true because higher switching frequencies reduce the requirements on transient energy storage in the passive components. To operate at higher frequencies, the passive components must be significantly lower in non-linear and parasitic parameters than those presently available. We have extensively analysed the individual contributions to the total impedance of solid tantalum capacitors and have identified many of the design and processing details responsible for it. In this paper additional changes in the design and manufacturing program further improve the capacitor we reported.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SUPPLIES TO APPARATUS; FILTER CAPACITORS; IMPEDANCE; SWITCH MODE POWER SUPPLIES; CAPACITORS

Title: BASIS FOR SELECTING VEHICLES FOR THE TRANSPORT OF HORTICULTURAL PRODUCE.
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Redlands Horticultural Research, Station, Ormiston, Aust, Redlands Horticultural Research Station, Ormiston, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Schoorl, D., Redlands Horticultural Research, Station, Ormiston, Aust, Redlands Horticultural Research Station, Ormiston, Aust; Holt, J.E., Redlands Horticultural Research, Station, Ormiston, Aust, Redlands Horticultural Research Station, Ormiston, Aust
Abstract: Transport is a major cost in the distribution of fruit and vegetables accounting for 15 to 25% of the wholesale price. To this capital and running cost must be added the cost of quality loss and wastage losses ranging from nil to over 50% in journeys to and from markets. For example 50% wastage of perishables such as lettuce are common on the road journey from southern markets to Darwin. Damage to produce can be divided into two categories, that due to the storage environment (temperature, humidity and gas composition) and that due to mechanical energy inputs (transport shocks and handling hazards). The authors present a paradigm for the quantification of damage during transport based on two developments in understanding, viz. the temperature-time-tolerance (TTT) hypothesis and road-vehicle-load interactions.
Index Keywords: FOOD PRODUCTS - Preservation; VEHICLES - Selection; HORTICULTURAL PRODUCE; POSTHARVEST SHELFLIFE; ROAD-VEHICLE-LOAD INTERACTIONS; TEMPERATURE-TIME-TOLERANCE HYPOTHESIS; AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS

Abstract: The development and production of the Delta Transfer Stage (DTS) as a high-energy upper stage for space shuttle utilization are described. The DTS provides operational advantages inherent with a storable liquid upper stage, namely high specific impulse, multiple burns, commanded engine cut-off, in-orbit storage, and a propellant load that can be varied to match mission requirements. Topics covered include program and technical descriptions and launch site processing.

Title: AUSTRALIAN HYDROGEN CAR.

Authors with affiliations: Watson, H.C., Univ of Melbourne, Dep of Mechanical, & Industrial Engineering,, Melbourne, Aust, Univ of Melbourne, Dep of Mechanical & Industrial Engineering, Melbourne, Aust; Milkins, E.E., Univ of Melbourne, Dep of Mechanical, & Industrial Engineering,, Melbourne, Aust, Univ of Melbourne, Dep of Mechanical & Industrial Engineering, Melbourne, Aust; Martin, W.R.B., Univ of Melbourne, Dep of Mechanical, & Industrial Engineering,, Melbourne, Aust, Univ of Melbourne, Dep of Mechanical & Industrial Engineering, Melbourne, Aust; Edsell, J., Univ of Melbourne, Dep of Mechanical, & Industrial Engineering,, Melbourne, Aust, Univ of Melbourne, Dep of Mechanical & Industrial Engineering, Melbourne, Aust
Abstract: This paper describes the development of a hydrogen fuelled 4 cyl. 2 litre automotive engine using the delayed port admission system of low pressure hydrogen supply. This admission system overcomes the problem of residual gas ignition of hydrogen air premixtures. Surface ignition problems are overcome by stringent oil control measures, selection of a synthetic lubricating oil, a high thermal conductivity aluminium coating of the combustion chamber surfaces, and by water injection at high power output. With these modifications unthrottled operation is satisfactory at all loads and speeds, with improved thermal efficiency, particularly at low loads, and adequate power output. Spark advance, fuel and water control systems are described. The design and control of a Fe Ti Mn alloy for metal hydride fuel storage is reported. The low emissions and 63% improvement in energy economy of the test car is documented.
Index Keywords: FUELS - Storage; HYDROGEN FUELS - Applications; INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINES - Water Injection; HYDROGEN CAR; THERMAL EFFICIENCY; AUTOMOBILE ENGINES

Authors with affiliations: Ono, S., Natl Chemical Lab for Industry,, Tsukuba Research Cent, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Chemical Lab for Industry, Tsukuba Research Cent, Ibaraki, Jpn; Imanari, K., Natl Chemical Lab for Industry,, Tsukuba Research Cent, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Chemical Lab for Industry, Tsukuba Research Cent, Ibaraki, Jpn; Nomura, K., Natl Chemical Lab for Industry,, Tsukuba Research Cent, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Chemical Lab for Industry, Tsukuba Research Cent, Ibaraki, Jpn; Sato, H., Natl Chemical Lab for Industry,, Tsukuba Research Cent, Ibaraki, Jpn, Natl Chemical Lab for Industry, Tsukuba Research Cent, Ibaraki, Jpn
Abstract: Mg//2Ni hydride is one of the promising hydrogen storing materials. The present investigation is concerned with the solubility of hydrogen into Mg//2Ni phase. The hydrogen solubiity and the change of lattice constants were measured at various temperatures and pressures up to 400 degree C and 1 MPa, by the volumetric method and the high pressure x-ray powder diffraction, respectively. The linear correlation of the hydrogen solubility and the change of lattice parameters has been shown. The volume increase with hydrogen solution was determined as 2. 8A**3/H at 355 degree C. The enthalpy and entropy change of solution were obtained as DELTA H equals minus 3. 2 kcal/H mol, DELTA S equals minus 5. 7 cal/H mol. K.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; MAGNESIUM NICKEL ALLOYS - Applications; METALLOGRAPHY; LATTICE PARAMETER; METAL HYDRIDE; HYDROGEN

Authors: Bittner H.F., Quinzio M.V., Babcock C.C.
Title: METAL HYDRIDES FOR HYDROGEN STORAGE IN NICKEL HYDROGEN BATTERIES.
Affiliations: Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bittner, H.F., Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Quinzio, M.V., Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Babcock, C.C., Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Abstract: Metal hydride hydrogen storage in nickel hydrogen (Ni/H//2) batteries has been shown to increase battery energy density and improve battery heat management capabilities. However the properties of metal hydrides in a Ni/H//2 battery environment, which contains water vapor and oxygen in addition to the hydrogen, have not been well characterized. This work evaluates the use of hydrides in Ni/H//2 batteries by fundamental characterization of metal hydride properties in a Ni/H//2 cell environment. Hydrogen sorption properties of various hydrides have been measured in a Ni/H//2 cell environment. Results of detailed thermodynamic and kinetic studies of hydrogen sorption in LaNi//5 in a Ni/H//2 cell environment are presented. Long-term cycling studies indicate that degradation of the hydride can be minimized by cycling between certain pressure limits. A model describing the mechanism of hydride degradation is presented.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Reaction Kinetics; LANTHANUM NICKEL ALLOYS - Applications; HYDRIDE DEGRADATION; METAL HYDRIDES; NICKEL HYDROGEN BATTERIES; HYDROGEN

Title: LIQUID AND SOLID STORAGE OF HYDROGEN.
Affiliations: Ergenics Inc, Wyckoff, NJ, USA, Ergenics Inc, Wyckoff, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Huston, E.Lee, Ergenics Inc, Wyckoff, NJ, USA, Ergenics Inc, Wyckoff, NJ, USA
Abstract: In recent years hydrogen storage in liquid and 'solid' forms has received considerable attention. This paper reviews the general state of art in liquid and solid storage of hydrogen. Liquid hydrogen storage consists not only of cryogenic liquid hydrogen in its elemental form, but also various liquids in which the hydrogen is chemically bonded to non-hydrogen atoms. Examples are ammonia (NH//3) and various organic liquids that can be hydrogenated and dehydrogenated. 'Solid' hydrogen storage consists of metal hydrides, zeolites, cryoadsorbents, and other solids which have the capability of storing atomic or molecular hydrogen under appropriate conditions of temperature or pressure. All of these are reviewed briefly; however, metal hydride technology is emphasized because hydrides appear to be more highly developed and have already advanced into the commercial marketplace.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROGEN INORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; LIQUID HYDROGEN; METAL HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN

Abstract: The following topics are dealt with: newly operating accelerators; theory, magnets; injections, sources, extraction, and cryogenic systems; advanced superconducting magnet concepts; status reports on existing systems; theoretical aspects of systems; radio frequency systems; ion sources by injection; radio frequency, controls, beamlines, targets systems; radiation therapy and medical diagnostic techniques; control techniques; high energy systems; cooling and storage rings and advanced and new cyclotrons concepts. 147 papers were presented, all of which are published in full in the present proceedings. Authors with affiliations: Val, Christian M., CIMSA, Velizy, Fr, CIMSA, Velizy, Fr; Gerard, A.M., CIMSA, Velizy, Fr, CIMSA, Velizy, Fr
Abstract: Very High Speed Integrated circuit (VHS IC) packaging is evolving very rapidly. Under an in-house THOMSON-CSF project, the concept of decoupling capacitor integration in ceramic packages has been employed to improve electrical performances. By extending this concept of integrated decoupling, the authors have been able to obtain integrated circuits (ICs) with 272 inputs/outputs (I/Os) dissipating about 5 watts, as well as use integrated decoupling capacitors in the cap having 60 I/Os. The inductances between the energy storage area and the IC pads are considerably reduced. The authors measured the inductance, the resistance, and the capacitance vs. frequency, and found inductance to be below 1 nanohenry. The main reason for this low value is due to the additional network of energy distribution above the IC.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS; ELECTRICAL SIMULATION OF PACKAGE; INTEGRATED DECOUPLING CAPACITOR PACKAGES; VHSIC PACKAGING; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS

Abstract: Australian greenhouse opertors are adopting many different approaches in an attempt to contain supplementary heating costs. Abstract: In the late 1950's, the Atomic Energy Commission announced that they would receive and process spent fuels from defense and research reactor programs. The Savannah River Plant, operated by Du Pont, was selected as one of the sites to receive and handle spent fuel. The Receiving Basin for Offsite Fuels facility at SRP was built and in mid 1964 received the first shipment of offsite fuel. This paper discusses the experience gained in the handling and storage of spent fuel, control of basin water activity, and elements of safe facility operation.
