Title: HYDROGEN TRANSMISSION BY A CHEMICAL CLOSED-LOOP CYCLE, AN ALTERNATIVE OPTION FOR LONG DISTANCES TRANSPORT OF ENERGY.
Affiliations: CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi, e Processi Chimici per la, Trasformazione e l'Accumulo, CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi e Processi Chimici per la Trasformazione e l'Accumulo dell'Ene
Authors with affiliations: Cacciola, G., CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi, e Processi Chimici per la, Trasformazione e l'Accumulo, CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi e Processi Chimici per la Trasformazione e l'Accumulo dell'Ene; Giordano, N., CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi, e Processi Chimici per la, Trasformazione e l'Accumulo, CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi e Processi Chimici per la Trasformazione e l'Accumulo dell'Ene
Abstract: Transportation of renewable energetic sources (hydro, geothermic, solar, eolic etc. ) can be conveniently accomplished only after their transformation into a secondary form, generally electricity. Therefore, end-costs of energy would greatly depend upon the transmission costs of the energetic vector. A possible alternative to electricity predicts the use of hydrogen as a medium for both storage and transportation of energy by a chemical closed-loop cycle based upon the catalytic reversible reaction Cyclohexane reversible reaction Benzene plus 3 H//2. This process, has very interesting characteristics because it allows the energy vector to be transferred in a liquid form at ambient temperature. In the present work a real example of application of the proposed system for transportation of secondary energy was considered. In particular, choosing a large hydroelectric source as a reference, a comparison was made between costs and efficiencies in transferring energy as hydrogen (in its different forms), over distances up to one thousand miles, with respect to transportation of this same energy as electricity.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY UTILIZATION; CHEMICAL CLOSED-LOOP CYCLE; ENERGY TRANSMISSION; HYDROGEN TRANSMISSION; HYDROGEN

Title: RATIONALE FOR U. S DOE ENERGY STORAGE PROGRAM IN HYDROGEN TECHNOLOGY.
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied, Science, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied Science, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Beller, M., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied, Science, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied Science, Upton, NY, USA; Mezzina, A., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied, Science, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Dep of Applied Science, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: This study provides a systems analysis of the present status and future potential of various hydrogen production, storage, transmission, and use options. It concludes that research and development priorities should focus upon these options in the order stated above. Additionally, within each category selected technologies are outlined for specific research effort based upon a multi-objective analysis. In particular, hydrogen production options should stress work in the areas of high temperature electrolysis and anode depolarization. In the storage area, a variety of novel options seem amenable for investigation at reduced levels of expenditure. Transmission/distribution system requirements are also outlined.
Index Keywords: ELECTROLYSIS; ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY UTILIZATION; HYDROGEN ENERGY SYSTEMS; R/D PLANNING; US DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY (DOE); HYDROGEN

Authors: Marquand C.J., Winspear K.W., Tassou S.A., Wilson D.R.
Title: HEAT PUMPS IN GREENHOUSE ENERGY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Polytechnic of Central London, London, Engl, Polytechnic of Central London, London, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Marquand, C.J., Polytechnic of Central London, London, Engl, Polytechnic of Central London, London, Engl; Winspear, K.W., Polytechnic of Central London, London, Engl, Polytechnic of Central London, London, Engl; Tassou, S.A., Polytechnic of Central London, London, Engl, Polytechnic of Central London, London, Engl; Wilson, D.R., Polytechnic of Central London, London, Engl, Polytechnic of Central London, London, Engl
Abstract: Heating accounts for about 40% of the direct cost of crop production in the U. K. Horticultural Industry. Measures such as double glazing of greenhouses save energy but result in excessive air humidity which must be vented in order to prevent damage to the plants. Alternatively, the greenhouse environment may be dehumidified by a heat pump which can also be used to heat the incoming air to the house. Such heat pump systems have pay back periods of between 4 and 6 years depending upon the fuel used in the prime mover.

Title: SOLAR THERMOCHEMICAL HYDROGEN: THE HEAT SOURCE-PROCESS INTERFACE.
Affiliations: Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA, Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Funk, J.E., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA, Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA; England, C., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA, Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA
Abstract: A discussion of issues and considerations related to the interface between a solar heat source and a thermochemical hydrogen process and some details of a tubular heat exchanger operating as such an interface in a cavity type receiver are presented. The issues include the temperature-heat input requirements for the endothermic reaction, type of receiver, heat storage, transient operations, and control. A thermal performance analysis of a tubular reactor/heat exchanger operating in a cavity type solar receiver is applied to SO//3 decomposition. The analysis produces axial distributions of temperature - tube wall and process fluid, reaction rate, conversion, velocity, density, pressure and residence time. Process fluid conditions at the inlet, tube characteristics, reaction kinetics and cavity operating temperature are inputs. The cavity temperature affects average heat flux and, therefore, heat exchanger cost and receiver efficiency and, therefore, mirror field cost. A design which minimizes the combined cost may be found and examples are shown.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; HEAT EXCHANGERS - Applications; HYDROGEN - Manufacture; SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; SOLAR HEAT EXCHANGERS; SOLAR INTERFACE; SOLAR THERMOCHEMICAL HYDROGEN; SOLAR RADIATION

Authors: Lin F.N., Moore W.I., Walker S.W.
Title: ECONOMICS OF LIQUID HYDROGEN FROM WATER ELECTROLYSIS.
Affiliations: NASA, Kennedy Space Cent, FL, USA, NASA, Kennedy Space Cent, FL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lin, F.N., NASA, Kennedy Space Cent, FL, USA, NASA, Kennedy Space Cent, FL, USA; Moore, W.I., NASA, Kennedy Space Cent, FL, USA, NASA, Kennedy Space Cent, FL, USA; Walker, S.W., NASA, Kennedy Space Cent, FL, USA, NASA, Kennedy Space Cent, FL, USA
Abstract: Using the data from vendors and open literature, we have constructed a preliminary cost model to predict the cost of liquid hydrogen (LH2) from water electrolysis. The model has been applied to two LH2 plants. Both have a production rate of 10,886 kilograms (kg) per day. The first plant (Plant 1) consists of a tank-type electrolyzer and a liquefier and runs all day at the base-load (or equivalent base-load) power rate. The second plant (Plant 2) consists of a tank-type electrolyzer, a liquefier, a compressor, and storage vessels. The electrolyzer and the compressor shall run only during the off-peak hours at the off-peak power rate. However, the liquefier shall run all day at the base-load (or equivalent base-load) power rate. The costs of LH2 from both plants are presented. Unless the base-load power rate is high and the off-peak power rate is substantially low, Plant 1 appears to be economically more feasible than Plant 2. Based on the early 1983 energy cost, Plant 1 predicts a cost of 3. 64 per kg of LH2.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; WATER - Electrolysis; LIQUID HYDROGEN ECONOMICS; PRODUCTION COST; HYDROGEN FUELS

Abstract: District heating provides convenient and almost maintenance free systems energy to nearly one half of Sweden's population, and about one third in Finland. By hot water utilization, alternate energy sources can be utilized because of low temperature, low pressure systems. Solar integrated systems provide a meaningful portion of total energy needs. Systems may vary considerably, but they are mainly composed of three parts: collectors, distribution lines, and seasonal rock cavern energy storage for large systems, storage in district heating lines and storage tanks in smaller systems.

Abstract: California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo, under the Industrial Process Division of the Department of Energy, assisted by TRW (Energy Systems Group) of Redondo Beach, and Pacific Gas and Electric Company, has designed, constructed, and is operating an industrial hot air raisin and prune drying system at the Lamanuzzi and Pantaleo Drying Plant in Fresno, California. The solar heating system consists of 1951 m sq. (21,000 sq. ft. ) of solar collectors, a 396 m cu. (14,000 cu. ft. ) rock storage facility, and a heat recovery unit. The system has operated for five seasons and has supplied about 80 per cent the heating requirements for one drying tunnel.

Abstract: The potential transients in the fluidized bed electrode and the moving bed electrode were analyzed and the variations of these transients with position in the electrodes were determined. In the fluidized bed electrode, the potential fluctuations of different kinds of particles show distinct differences in behavior, and these fluctuations are also affected by bed expansion and applied current density, i. e. , local resistivity and local electric field. As can be seen, the potential transients show random behavior. Time averaged potential distributions were calculated from the measured transient potentials and compared with the predictions of mathematical models for potential distribution. The effective resistivities of particulate electrodes were also measured. The effect of local resistivities of electrodes on potential fluctuation was found to be important.

Title: COMMERCIAL SOLAR GREENHOUSE WITH AN INTERNAL SOLAR COLLECTION/ROCKBIN STORAGE SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Meeting - American Section of the International Solar Energy Society

Abstract: Inspiration for this greenhouse came from two observations. First, some conventional commercial greenhouse operations have failed due to increasing heating energy costs. Secondly, conventional commercial operations often vent excess heat on sunny winter days only to find heating systems operating later the same day. Numerous solar and energy conservation options exist to reduce heating loads, yet commercial operations have opted for few. We have designed, built, begun monitoring and growing in a prototype commercial solar greenhouse attached to a small building. Features include a passive solar water tempering system, an internal solar collection system and a horizontal flow rockbin thermal storage system.

Title: EXPERIMENTAL PASSIVE SOLAR PERFORMANCE ASSESSMENT OF AN EARTH-SHELTERED HOUSE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Meeting - American Section of the International Solar Energy Society
Affiliations: Univ of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN,, USA, Univ of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Goldberg, Louis F., Univ of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN,, USA, Univ of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, USA
Abstract: A simple mathematical model describing the performance of energy efficient housing is delineated. The experimental energy performance data obtained from a passive solar, earth-sheltered house over a monitoring period in excess of one year is used to investigate the applicability of the model. The water heater energy consumption unavailable for space heating and the data integration period are parametrically varied to determine their effect on the model applicability. Linear regression analyses performed on the data yield an index which is a candidate for a generally applicable energy efficient housing performance label. The passive solar performance of the house is discussed in terms of the effectiveness of the concrete floor slab as a thermal storage medium and the contribution made by the solar input to the overall space heating requirements.

Abstract: The results of electrochemical and in situ optical studies (during electrochemical doping) of polyacetylene, poly(thiophene) and poly(isothianaphthene) are summarized. Electrochemical voltage spectroscopy (EVS) is used to characterize the energies of charge injection and removal, as well as the kinetics of these processes. In situ optical spectroscopy provides complementary information on the energy of the electronic states where charge is stored (after injection). The results of recent studies of a new polymer, poly(isothianaphthene), are also presented. Spectroscopy of thin films prepared by electrochemical polymerization indicate a band edge at 1 eV, fully 1 eV smaller than the parent poly(thiophene) and even smaller than the energy gap in trans-(CH)//x.

Title: MICROCOMPUTER BASED SENSOR SYSTEM FOR RESISTANCE WELDING STUDIES.
Affiliations: Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Waters, David G., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA; Lee, Kuo-Chu, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA; Mayhan, Robert J., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA; Dickinson, David W., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA
Abstract: The hardware and programs for a microcomputer based sensor system designed for use in the study of the short-lived phemonena which occur in resistance welding are described. Three sensors which monitor the electrode voltage, current, and displacement were connected to a 75 kVA, single-phase spot welder. The outputs of the sensors are input to an Apple computer through a multichannel A/D converter and the digitized data are stored in the computer. After a weld, the data can be plotted on the display screen, printer, or strip chart recorder. The data can also be processed according to any desired algorithm to study various characteristics of the weld phemonena. Typical outputs of the sensors are presented and discussed. Examples of processed data shown include the workpiece dynamic resistance, energy input to the weld, and pre-weld resistance. Finally, some preliminary results of an on-going study of spot welding galvanized steel are given. Here the discussion centers on irregularities in the dynamic resistance curve which occur in the first few cycles of the weld.

Title: Optical recording by reducing a metal salt complexed to a polymer host
Affiliations: Corporate Research and Development, General Electric Company, Schenectady, NY 12301, United States
Authors with affiliations: Auerbach, A., Corporate Research and Development, General Electric Company, Schenectady, NY 12301, United States
Abstract: An alternative approach which makes use of a laser to reduce a polymer/complexed metal ion matrix to generate small reflective surfaces is described. The thermal energy provided by the laser promotes an electron transfer from the polymer to the metal ion to form metal. Since the reduction occurs within the thermal profile of the focused laser beam, the reflective area has a diameter close to that of the beam waist. We have formed ∼l-μm-diam reflective areas using a pulsed diode laser. Application of this method to optical disk recording is discussed.

Title: Au/Ti resistors used for Nb/Pb-alloy Josephson junctions. II. Thermal stability
Affiliations: IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Murakami, M., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Kim, K.K., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: In the preceding paper bilayered Au/Ti resistors were found to have excellent electrical stability during storage at room temperature after preannealing at an elevated temperature, which is essential to design logic and memory circuits of Nb/Pb-alloy Josephson junction devices. The resistors could contact directly with the Pb-alloy control lines in which Pb and In atoms which are known to intermix easily with Au atoms are contained. Since Pb and In atoms in the control lines are separated from Au atoms of the resistors by thin Ti layers, thermal stability at the contacts is a major concern for use of the Au/Ti resistor material in the Josephson devices. In the present study, surface morphology change and diffusion mechanism at the resistor/control-line contacts were studied using x-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscopy for square-shaped Au/Ti resistors covered by Pb-In layers. The samples were isothermally annealed at temperatures ranging from 353 to 423 K. The diffusion did not occur immediately after annealing at these temperatures. After the incubation period, the interdiffusion was observed to initiate at the edges of the resistors facing to the center of the cathode. Significant amounts of the In atoms in the Pb-In layers were observed to diffuse into the Au layers of the resistors, forming AuIn2 compounds under the Ti layers. By measuring growth rates of the AuIn2 layers, the diffusion coefficients and the activation energy for the layer growth were determined. Also, by analyzing changes in the In concentration in the Pb-In layers during annealing, interdiffusion coefficients of In atoms in the Pb-In layers were determined using a computer simulation technique. The activation energy was about 1.1 eV. Since these diffusion coefficients were found to be very close to those determined previously in bulk materials, the diffusion kinetics is believed to be controlled by the lattice diffusion. Based on the present results, several methods to reduce the interdiffusion between Pb-alloy and Au/Ti resistors were proposed.
Index Keywords: GOLD AND ALLOYS; NIOBIUM LEAD ALLOYS; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES - Josephson Junctions; TITANIUM AND ALLOYS; BILAYERED GOLD/TITANIUM FILMS; RESISTORS

Authors: Murakami M., Alessandrini E.I., Kim K.K.
Title: Au/Ti resistors used for Nb/Pb-alloy Josephson junctions. I. Electrical stability
Affiliations: IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Murakami, M., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Alessandrini, E.I., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Kim, K.K., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: Bilayered Au/Ti films are very attractive for use as resistor materials of experimental Nb/Pb-alloy Josephson junction devices. In order to predict the electrical stability of the Au/Ti resistors during storage at room temperature, changes in microstructure and electrical resistivity of Ti and Au/Ti films during isothermal annealing at temperatures ranging from 298-473 K were studied using transmission electron microscopy, x-ray diffraction, and electrical measurements. Growth of Ti grains during annealing was observed in these films. The activation energy for the grain growth was determined to be 1.51 eV. Decreases in the sheet resistance measured at 4.2 K were observed at the early stages of isothermal annealing. By analyzing the annealing temperature dependence of rates of resistance changes, the activation energy of 1.49 eV was obtained. This energy value is very close to that obtained for the grain growth and, therefore, one of the main causes in the resistance decrease is believed to be due to the growth of Ti grains. Based on the present results, a model to predict the electrical resistance change for the Au/Ti films during storage at room temperature was established. The model predicted that change in the resistance can be significantly reduced by preannealing the resistors at an elevated temperature. The prediction was supported by the experiment and an excellent quantitative agreement between measured resistance values and those predicted by the model was obtained. Based on this model, the change was predicted to be -1.5% after about 3 years at room temperature, if the resistors were preannealed at 353 K for 10 h. This resistor stability is satisfactory for designing logic and memory circuits of Josephson devices, and it can be increased simply by preannealing for longer times at 353 K.
Index Keywords: GOLD AND ALLOYS; NIOBIUM LEAD ALLOYS; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES - Josephson Junctions; TITANIUM AND ALLOYS; BILAYERED GOLD/TITANIUM FILMS; RESISTORS

Title: Trapping kinetics in high trap density silicon nitride insulators
Affiliations: Solid State Electronics Laboratory, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH 45221, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bibyk, S.B., Solid State Electronics Laboratory, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH 45221, United States; Kapoor, V.J., Solid State Electronics Laboratory, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH 45221, United States
Abstract: An analytical method has been developed to investigate the trapping kinetics of multiple trap levels in a silicon nitride insulator under very complex conditions. Solutions for the trapped-charge distribution are given for the case of a nonuniform single carrier current in an insulator having very strong charge trapping and various detrapping mechanisms such as Poole-Frenkel emission or photoionization. The trapped-charge distribution is given in terms of a series in the position and time variables, and is given for a single trap level, several trap levels, and an energy distribution of traps. In the more complex models, the series are terminated after a finite number of terms and are used to calculate the trapped-charge centroid as a function of the total trapped charge. The trapped-charge centroid calculations are shown to be useful for studying silicon nitride or other strong trapping insulating materials used for long term charge storage applications.
Index Keywords: DIELECTRIC MATERIALS; SILICON NITRIDE; SILICON COMPOUNDS

Authors: Kania D.R., Bartlett R.J., Wagner R.S., Hammond R.B., Pianetta P.
Title: Pulsed soft x-ray response of InP:Fe photoconductors
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kania, D.R., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Bartlett, R.J., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Wagner, R.S., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Hammond, R.B., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Pianetta, P., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: We report measurements of the energy-dependent pulse response of InP:Fe photoconductors to soft x rays in the energy range 200 eV-3 keV. The experiments were performed with x-ray pulses from the Stanford Positron Electron Asymmetric Ring storage ring at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory. The detector had an optical impulse response of 180 ps (full width at half-maximum) and an active area of 1×1 mm. An array of filters (carbon, magnesium, and beryllium) was used to unfold the energy response of the detector to the soft x rays. Direct measurements of the time structure of the ring bunches were limited by the bandwidth of the real time recording system (400 MHz), but inidividual ring pulses were easily recorded with a detector pulse amplitude of 65 mV for the unfiltered beam. The detector response was constant over the energy range examined at 2.7×10-3 A/W.
Index Keywords: INDIUM COMPOUNDS; RADIATION DETECTORS; X-RAYS; INDIUM PHOSPHIDE; PHOTOCONDUCTING MATERIALS

Title: Gap states in silicon nitride
Affiliations: Central Electricity Research Laboratories, Leatherhead, Surrey, United Kingdom; Philips Research Laboratories, Redhill, Surrey, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Robertson, J., Central Electricity Research Laboratories, Leatherhead, Surrey, United Kingdom; Powell, M.J., Philips Research Laboratories, Redhill, Surrey, United Kingdom
Abstract: The energy levels of defect states in amorphous silicon nitride have been calculated and the results are used to identify the nature of trap states responsible for charge trapping during transport and the charge storage leading to memory action. We argue that the Si dangling bond is the memory trap in chemical vapor deposited memory devices and is also the center in plasma-deposited nitride responsible for hopping at low electric fields and for charge-trapping instabilities in amorphous silicon-silicon nitride thin-film transistors.
Index Keywords: TRANSISTORS; SILICON NITRIDE; SILICON COMPOUNDS

Authors: Zax D.B., Bielecki A., Pines A., Sinton S.W.
Title: Differentiation between 27Al nuclei in alums by Fourier transform pure nuclear quadrupole resonance
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Exxon Production Research Company, PO Box 2189, Houston, TX 77001, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zax, D.B., Department of Chemistry, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Bielecki, A., Department of Chemistry, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Pines, A., Department of Chemistry, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Sinton, S.W., Exxon Production Research Company, PO Box 2189, Houston, TX 77001, United States
Abstract: Aluminium is the most abundant metal in the Earth's lithosphere and is present in many commercially important materials. Recent studies on its role in zeolites1 and proposed solar energy storage schemes involving aluminium salts2 have led to renewed interest in analytical methods capable of identifying and characterizing specific crystalline sites. In particular, new techniques are necessary which do not require single crystals. One such technique is Fourier transform nuclear quadrupole resonance (NQR) with pulsed field cycling3,4, and we report here on its application to the determination of specific 27 Al sites in model aluminium compounds, the alums. © 1984 Nature Publishing Group.

Title: A thermophonic investigation of threshold and memory switching phenomena in thick amorphous chalcogenide films
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Department of Physics, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI 48202, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kotz, J., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Department of Physics, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI 48202, United States; Shaw, M.P., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Department of Physics, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI 48202, United States
Abstract: The behavior of amorphous chalcogenide switching and memory devices is examined for the first time in an experiment which measures the acoustic response of a thermophonic cell enclosing an electrically pulsed device. The experiments employ coplanar samples made of memory-type material. The cell response under single square-pulse excitation is measured and the results are analyzed using techniques developed by Aamodt and Murphy. In general, under all bias conditions, analysis of our results indicates that the sample cools immediately after the switching event occurs. Under low ON-state power conditions, a large jump in microphone signal occurs at the switching transition. This is attributed to the current discharge driven by the large external circuit capacitance. There is a gradual reduction in the mirroring of the capacitive discharge as the ON-state power level is increased, suggesting that the discharge energy is used as a heat of transformation for melting formed (crystalline) regions, as well as for heating the conducting path. For a memory event to occur it is necessary that the ON-state power be large enough to promote crystallization of the filament yet be low enough to avoid melting the conducting filament at the end of the pulse. In order to model the microphone signal and the temperature of the sample during switching, the analysis of Aamodt and Murphy is modified to allow for changes in the thermal conductivities of the sample and substrate. The post-switching volume is estimated using scanning electron microscopy, thereby allowing an estimation of the power density. The agreement between the experimental and computed curves is good.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR - Storage Devices; SEMICONDUCTING GERMANIUM COMPOUNDS - Amorphous; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES

Authors: Hodge W.L., Stratton B.C., Moos H.W.
Title: Grazing incidence time-resolving spectrograph for magnetic fusion plasma diagnostics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD 21218
Authors with affiliations: Hodge, W.L., Department of Physics, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD 21218; Stratton, B.C., Department of Physics, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD 21218; Moos, H.W., Department of Physics, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD 21218
Abstract: A time-resolving grazing incidence spectrograph based on an image intensified photodiode array detector has been constructed and has demonstrated its utility as a fusion plasma diagnostic. The total wavelength coverage is 15-360 Å with 0.7 Å resolution (line profile FWHM); portions of this range may be observed during a single plasma discharge with a bandwidth of ∼40 Å when the detector is centered at 40 Å and ∼80 Å with it centered at 200 Å. Integration times from 5.4 to 13.1 ms are available when the entire photodiode array is read out; integration times as short as 1 ms can be obtained for a few lines of interest through the readout of selected photodiodes. The spectrograph has been radiometrically calibrated over the 60- to 360-Å range at the NBS SURF II electron storage ring and is currently in operation on the Princeton Large Torus (PLT) tokamak.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions; PLASMAS

Title: Micromagnetics of domain walls in vertical recording
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Authors with affiliations: Soohoo, R.F., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: A detail micromagnetics calculation for a simplified model of domain walls in vertical recording is presented. From the resulting analytical expression for the wall magnetization distribution, wall energy density and wall width are determined for a single as well as for multiple walls. Whereas our simplified model presupposes a homogeneous medium, columnar structure is frequently observed in vertical recording media. Possible modifications to our results due to columnar formation is discussed. Finally, a comparison between the limiting recording densities of horizontal and vertical recording in the context of head field gradient and medium hysteresis loop squareness is given.
Index Keywords: DOMAIN WALLS; MICROMAGNETICS; VERTICAL RECORDING; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Authors: Kishimoto M., Amemiya M., Hayama F.
Title: Magnetic annealing and relaxation in cobalt-substituted acicular iron oxide particles
Affiliations: Hitachi Maxell Limited, 1 Oyamazaki, Kyoto, 618, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kishimoto, M., Hitachi Maxell Limited, 1 Oyamazaki, Kyoto, 618, Japan; Amemiya, M., Hitachi Maxell Limited, 1 Oyamazaki, Kyoto, 618, Japan; Hayama, F., Hitachi Maxell Limited, 1 Oyamazaki, Kyoto, 618, Japan
Abstract: The magnetic anisotropy induced by annealing in a magnetic field and the activation energy were measured for cobalt-substituted acicular iron oxide particles using a torque meter. The induced magnetic anisotropy linearly increased with the cobalt content in the particles. The induced magnetic anisotropy at 293 K in the particles containing a cobalt of 1.6 wt. % was 1.1×105 erg/cc, and this value nearly agreed with the value reported in iron-cobalt ferrite. The change of coercivity in the particles was attributed to the induced magnetic anisotropy. The activation energy in the particles was 0.8-0.9 eV, and this value was close to the value reported in iron-cobalt ferrite.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC; IRON COMPOUNDS; IRON OXIDE; MAGNETIC ANISOTROPY; MAGNETIC ANNEALING; MAGNETIC MATERIALS

Authors: Canaani O., Ronen R., Garty J., Cahen D., Malkin S., Galun M.
Title: Photoacoustic study of the green alga Trebouxia in the lichen Ramalina duriaei in vivo
Affiliations: Biochemistry Department, Weigmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel; Botany Department, The George S. Wise Faculty of Life Sciences, Tel-Aviv University, Tel-Aviv, 69978, Israel; Structural Chemistry Department, Weigmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Canaani, O., Biochemistry Department, Weigmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel; Ronen, R., Botany Department, The George S. Wise Faculty of Life Sciences, Tel-Aviv University, Tel-Aviv, 69978, Israel; Garty, J., Botany Department, The George S. Wise Faculty of Life Sciences, Tel-Aviv University, Tel-Aviv, 69978, Israel; Cahen, D., Structural Chemistry Department, Weigmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel; Malkin, S., Biochemistry Department, Weigmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel; Galun, M., Botany Department, The George S. Wise Faculty of Life Sciences, Tel-Aviv University, Tel-Aviv, 69978, Israel
Abstract: Photosynthetic parameters of the lichen Ramalina duriael were investigated in vivo, by the photoacoustic method using intensity-modulated exciting light (frequency range 5-300 Hz). The photoacoustic signal in intact lichens was similar in its general characteristics to that obtained from intact leaves of higher plants (Poulet et al., Biochim. Biophys. Acta 724, 433-446, 1983). It included two components interpreted to be due to modulated heat and modulated oxygen evolution. The quantum yield of the oxygen evolution component was maximal in the red spectral region and exhibited the 'red drop' decrease at wavelengths larger than 680 nm, similar to observations in higher plants. In contrast to those however, there was a pronounced decrease in this yield in the region below about 600 nm, indicating that pigments absorbing at shorter wavelengths are inefficient energy transfer agents. Similar results were observed for the quantum yield spectrum of photochemical energy storage. Analysis of oxygen diffusion in the symbiont alga, from the modulation frequency dependence of the ratio of oxygen evolution to photothermal signal component is consistent with an average diffusion path of about 4 μm, compared to a smaller, 1 μm, average diffusion path obtained in green leaves. © 1984 Martinus Nijhoff/Dr W. Junk Publishers.
Author Keywords: lichens; photoacoustic speetrometry

Title: Limiting battery performance parameters for polyacetylene
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Materials Research Laboratory, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chien, J.C.W., Department of Chemistry, Materials Research Laboratory, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States; Schlenoff, J.B., Department of Chemistry, Materials Research Laboratory, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States
Abstract: The discovery that polyacetylene, [CH]x could be reversibly electrochemically oxidized or reduced ('doped')1 has led to its usage as an electrode in light-weight rechargeable storage batteries2,3. Using a 100-m thick electrode comprised of 20-30 nm diameter fibrils 4, performance characteristics slightly superior to those of the lead-acid battery have been achieved. Our cyclic voltammetry study utilizing ultrathin (<0.1 m) films of [CH]x comprised of 2-3 nm microfibrils shows significantly improved electrode properties. A current density of 2.4 MA kg-1, power density of 8 MW kg-1, average potential of 3.5 V, maximum energy density of 250 W h kg-1 and coulombic efficiency >95% have been obtained with a Li/salt/[CH]x system. The potential of polyacetylene electrodes for light-weight rechargeable batteries is, therefore, several orders of magnitude higher than presently recognized. © 1984 Nature Publishing Group.

Authors: Handman J., Harriman A., Porter G.
Title: Photochemical dehydrogenation of ethanol in dilute aqueous solution
Affiliations: Davy Faraday Research Laboratory, Royal Institution, 21 Albemarle Street, London W1X 4BS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Handman, J., Davy Faraday Research Laboratory, Royal Institution, 21 Albemarle Street, London W1X 4BS, United Kingdom; Harriman, A., Davy Faraday Research Laboratory, Royal Institution, 21 Albemarle Street, London W1X 4BS, United Kingdom; Porter, G., Davy Faraday Research Laboratory, Royal Institution, 21 Albemarle Street, London W1X 4BS, United Kingdom
Abstract: The need for alternative sources of energy has stimulated research into the storage of sunlight as chemical potential. Many systems have been investigated but photogeneration of H2 seems to be the most practical. The cyclic photodissociation of water has yet to be realized in homogeneous solution using visible light, although heterogeneous photosystems are known1-3. Efficient photogeneration of H2 in homogeneous conditions can be achieved4-7 at the expense of an added electron donor but such systems have little application in practical devices. Replacement of the sacrificial donor with waste material, for example sulphide8, offers a route for improving these systems and, here we describe efficient H 2 photogeneration from a system using aqueous ethanol, as available from low-grade fermentation, as donor. To couple the photoproduction of H 2 to the oxidation of ethanol we have used NADH/alcohol dehydrogenase as a relay. © 1984 Nature Publishing Group.

Witzeling, W., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Woody, C., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, United States
Abstract: We study the production of identified charged particles in pp collisions at a c.m. energy of 63 GeV in events with an identified high-pT trigger particle. The measurements were performed at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings using the Axial Field Spectrometer. Production ratios are presented as a function of pT in the range 2.5 to 8 GeV/c. © 1984.

Title: A study of e+e- pairs in the mass range 11 to 25 GeV/c2 at the CERN intersecting storage rings

Abstract: A sample of 58e+e- events with an invariant mass greater than 11 GeV/c2 produced in pp collisions at a centre-of-mass energy of 62.3 GeV is discussed. The cross sections are presented as a function of the mass and transverse momentum. The electron pairs produced with a mean transverse momentum of 2.50 ± 0.25 GeV/c. © 1984.

Authors: Griessen R., Driessen A., De Groot D.G.
Title: Search for new metal-hydrogen systems for energy storage
Affiliations: Natuurkundig Laboratorium Vrije Universiteit, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Griessen, R., Natuurkundig Laboratorium Vrije Universiteit, Netherlands; Driessen, A., Natuurkundig Laboratorium Vrije Universiteit, Netherlands; De Groot, D.G., Natuurkundig Laboratorium Vrije Universiteit, Netherlands
Abstract: The heats of formation of the transition metal hydrides A5BHx A2BHx, ABHx, AB2Hx and AB5Hx (A ≡ Sc, Ti, V, Y, Zr, Nb, La, Hf, Ta, Ni, Pd; B ≡ transition metal) are calculated by means of a semiempirical model based on the electronic structure of the host alloy. Out of the 1380 possible compounds A5B, A2B and AB, only 44 are predicted by the model to react with hydrogen with a heat of formation between -12 and -25 kJ. Approximately half of these potential hydrogen storage systems have already been investigated. © 1984.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN - Storage; HEAT OF FORMATION; HYDROGEN STORAGE MATERIALS; TRANSITION METAL HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN INORGANIC COMPOUNDS

Title: Analyses of bit-oriented optical memories using photochromie media
Affiliations: Bell Communications Research, Crawfords Corner Road, Holmdel, NJ, 07733, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tomlinson, W.J., Bell Communications Research, Crawfords Corner Road, Holmdel, NJ, 07733, United States
Abstract: Using a simple model we estimate the achievable characteristics of bit-oriented optical memories using photochromie recording media. For readout by sensing the absorption of the medium, which will degrade the stored information, the required write energy per bit is of the same order as or lower than that for common ablative or pit-forming write-once media, and the required sample concentration appears to be achievable. To be able to erase at the same rate as data are written, the erase source must have a power output as much as an order of magnitude greater than that of the write source, and this may present a serious problem. For readout by sensing the refractive-index change in the medium, to achieve a nondegradative readout, the required erase exposure and sample concentration both appear to be impractically large. © 1984 Optical Society of America.
Index Keywords: OPTICAL DATA PROCESSING; OPTICAL DEVICES; BIT-ORIENTED OPTICAL MEMORIES; PHOTOCHROMIC MEDIA; REFRACTIVE INDEX CHANGE; WRITE ENERGY PER BIT; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Authors: Martin B.A., Horn M.E., Widholm J.M., Rinne R.W.
Title: Synthesis, composition and location of glycerolipids in photoautotrophic soybean cell cultures
Source title: Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA)/Lipids and Lipid Metabolism
Affiliations: Department of Agronomy, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; USDA-ARS, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Martin, B.A., Department of Agronomy, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Horn, M.E., Department of Agronomy, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Widholm, J.M., Department of Agronomy, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Rinne, R.W., USDA-ARS, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Abstract: The location, synthesis and composition of glycerolipids in photoautrophic soybean (Glycine max L. Merr.) cell cultures were investigated to begin to elucidate the function of neutral lipids in photosynthetic tissues. The neutral lipids, diacylglycerol and triacylglycerol, were primarily located in the chloroplast which was also the primary location of diacylglycerol acyltransferase (EC 2.3.1.20), the final enzymatic step in the synthesis of triacylglycerol. The chloroplasts were also the primary location of synthesis of fatty acids from acetate and lysophosphatidic acid by glycerophosphate acyltransferase (EC 2.3.1.15). Neutral lipid made up to 20% of the total glycerolipid in dark-grown heterotrophic cells, 10% in photoautotrophic cells (both 2 weeks after subculture) and less than 1% in leaf cells. The amount of neutral lipid in photoautotrophic cells was maximal 1 week after transfer and declined to less than half that value 4 weeks after transfer. Starch content, however, increased for up to 3 weeks after transfer in parallel with dry weight accumulation. The data suggest that in these cells neutral lipids may serve for temporary storage of fatty acids and glycerol for later membrane synthesis rather than for storage of energy, a function of neutral lipids in seeds. © 1984.
Author Keywords: (Soybean cell culture); Glycerolipid; Lipid metabolism; Lipid storage; Neutral lipid; Photoautotrophism

Title: Sub-Microsecond electro-optical shutter
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: The BDM Corporation, 1801 Randolph Road S.E., Albuquerque, NM, 87106, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goranson, R.W., The BDM Corporation, 1801 Randolph Road S.E., Albuquerque, NM, 87106, United States; Butler, E.W., The BDM Corporation, 1801 Randolph Road S.E., Albuquerque, NM, 87106, United States
Abstract: The Directed Energy Group at BDM Albuquerque, under contract to the Directed Energy Directorate of the U.S. Army, MICOM, Redstone Arsenal, Huntsville, Alabama, has developed a concept to achieve an effective ten million frames-per-second infrared videograph for intensity distribution diagnostics of high power CO2 laser pulses. The concept uses separate pyroelectric surfaces, either vidicons or self-scanning arrays, for each desired frame of data. The pyroelectric surface acts as analog storage of the image until such time as it can be digitized and read into data storage between laser pulses. Each pyro-electric surface is shuttered in sequence by Pockel’s cells, with adjustable shutter “on” times and frame-to-frame timing as short as 100 nanoseconds. This paper constitutes a continuation of the design detail of the shutter and optical system for the IR video camera. A delay in the procurement provided time to rework the shutter design previously reported.1 The revised design reduces the impractically high pulse currents by matching the high voltage pulse generator and line impedance to the Pockel’s cell’s impedance at the desired pulse rise time rather than the reverse, as in the original design. The optical design has been revised to incorporate a kinematic lens mount to facilitate the field replacement of the objective lenses necessitated by the two design applications. Both of these improvements should find application in similar high speed camera design problems. © 1984 SPIE.
Index Keywords: CAMERAS - Shutters; INFRARED DEVICES; LASERS, CARBON DIOXIDE - Measurements; IR VIDEOGRAPHS; LASER PULSES; POCKEL'S CELLS; PYROELECTRIC SURFACES; SUBMICROSECOND SHUTTERS; VIDICONS; TELEVISION EQUIPMENT

Title: PLENARY LECTURES PRESENTED AT THE FOURTH INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON HIGH TEMPERATURE AND ENERGY-RELATED MATERIALS.
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 7 papers. The topics discussed are the following: phase equilibria and thermodynamics; measurements; new materials from high temperature synthesis; materials for nuclear energy; laser diagnostics of materials and chemistry; vaporization processes far from equilibrium at high temperatures; materials challenges in electrochemical energy storage systems; and new techniques and opportunities in high temperature mass spectrometry.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES; LASERS - Applications; MASS SPECTROMETERS; METALLIC COMPOUNDS; NUCLEAR REACTORS; EIREV; GAS-SOLID REACTION; HIGH TEMPERATURE CHEMICAL KINETICS; HIGH TEMPERATURE REACTIONS; KNUDSEN EFFUSION METHODS; URANIA; MATERIALS TESTING

Title: HIGH-PERFORMANCE ENERGY STORAGE: THE HOMOPOLAR GENERATOR.
Affiliations: Fraunhofer-Inst fuer, Naturwissenschaftlich-Technische, Trendanalysen, Euskirchen, West Ger, Fraunhofer-Inst fuer Naturwissenschaftlich-Technische Trendanalysen, Euskirchen, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Knoth, Artur, Fraunhofer-Inst fuer, Naturwissenschaftlich-Technische, Trendanalysen, Euskirchen, West Ger, Fraunhofer-Inst fuer Naturwissenschaftlich-Technische Trendanalysen, Euskirchen, West Ger
Abstract: A review of the latest developments concerning the construction and utilization of a homopolar generator (HPG) as an energy storage system is made. Civilian as well as military applications are discussed. A comparison with alternate systems is made, and the advantages of the HPG are represented.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC GENERATORS; FLYWHEELS; HOMOPOLAR GENERATORS; ROTATING GENERATORS; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: JAPAN TUNNELS FOR ENERGY.
Authors with affiliations: Gould, Robin
Abstract: Construction of the Sabigawa pumped storage scheme in hills 150 km north of Tokyo is now well underway and the building of this 900 MW plant marks a milestone in meeting the demands of the energy hungry industries situated around Japan's capital. The Sabigawa project is the last of seven major pumped storage schemes being built by the Tokyo Electric Power Company (TEMCO) in the last 20 years. When it comes on stream at the end of the decade TEMCO will be able to utilize 5538 MW from pumped storage plants to meet the surge peaks in electric demand during daylight hours. Like Sabigawa many of these underground projects have been built into very bad rock conditions.
Index Keywords: HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Pumped Storage; ROCK DRILLING - Equipment; UNSTABLE ROCK; TUNNELS AND TUNNELING

Title: ESTIMATE OF THE STORAGE EFFICIENCY OF THE PRODUCTS OF THE PULSES OF A COHERENT PACKET OF SIGNALS.
Source title: Radio Engineering and Electronic Physics (English translation of Radiotekhnika i Elektronika)
Authors with affiliations: Latushkin, V.V.
Abstract: The storage of the pulses of a signal reflected from a target in a radar receiver is done coherently or noncoherently. For noncoherent storage it is impossible to measure the radial velocity of the target. A method is known for storing the products of pulses of a coherent packet. The signals of two adjacent periods are superimposed in time by means of a delay line and multiplied. The result of the multiplication is sent to the storage unit and then it is compared with the threshold. It is noted that the result of the multiplication depends on the Doppler frequency of the signal; therefore, the device retains the possibility of measuring the radial velocity of the target. The storage method considered here has lower energy losses than the noncoherent storage method; in addition, it has the capability of measuring the velocity of motion.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL TRANSFORMATIONS - Laplace Transforms; SIGNAL DETECTION; COHERENT SIGNALS; PULSE STORAGE; RADAR RECEIVERS

Title: ELECTRIC EARTH STORAGE SYSTEM HEATS HUGE RAIL MAINTENANCE SHOP.
Affiliations: Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co,, Industrial Marketing Dep, Cleveland,, OH, USA, Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co, Industrial Marketing Dep, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bush, William M., Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co,, Industrial Marketing Dep, Cleveland,, OH, USA, Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co, Industrial Marketing Dep, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: An electric heating earth storage system constructed for the new central rail maintenance facility in Cleveland, Ohio, is described. Design of the earth storage system consists of mat configurations in the service building, 50,000 square feet; and the rail shop, 176,000 square feet. Thirty-four zones were allocated, each consisting of 60 to 100 kwc, totaling 2262 kwc, Most of the floor area, because of loading requirements, was 20 inch concrete. This dimension caused the heating mats to be 2 one-half feet below the floor level. The rail shop, largest of the two buildings, included numerous pits and below-floor equipment. Flexibility of the earth storage system lent itself to providing an excellent heating system in these hard to heat areas. A demand control device programs all heating zones to operate during nonpeak periods. Each zone is thermostatically controlled to provide an average floor temperature of 70 degrees F and a design temperature of 65 degrees F at approximately 4 feet above the floor. Considerable savings in energy costs were achieved.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; RAILROAD ROLLING STOCK - Maintenance; ELECTRIC EARTH STORAGE SYSTEM; ENERGY COST SAVINGS; FLOOR HEATING; RAIL MAINTENANCE SHOPS; HEATING

Title: Effects of increased wood energy consumption on carbon storage in forests of the United States
Affiliations: Holcomb Research Institute, Butler University, Indianapolis, 46208, Indiana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Armentano, T.V., Holcomb Research Institute, Butler University, Indianapolis, 46208, Indiana, United States
Abstract: Large but feasible increases that have been projected for the production of wood energy in the United States can be expected to significantly alter the current carbon storage patterns in US forest vegetation. The 1976 net wood increment left after forest cutting equals about 136 × 106 tons of carbon/year, with about 60% of the increment found in merchantable trees, and the remainder in nonmerchantable components. Achieving 5-10 quads of wood energy beyond 1976 levels by the year 2010 can significantly change current carbon storage patterns with the magnitude of change dependent on the extent of residue harvest to meet energy goals, and the rate of future forest growth. Complete loss of the apparent net wood increment is a possible outcome. Although the future growth and harvest situation cannot be known now, a range of possible scenarios suggests that US forests in the year 2010 will store much less carbon than today, thus significantly changing their role in the global carbon cycle. © 1984 Springer-Verlag New York Inc.
Author Keywords: Carbon storage; US forests; Wood energy consumption
Index Keywords: CARBON - Environmental Impact; ENERGY UTILIZATION - Environmental Impact; FORESTRY; CARBON STORAGE; WOOD ENERGY CONSUMPTION; WOOD

Title: STRUCTURE TO FORM N-SKIN UNDER THE STORAGE NODE.
Authors with affiliations: Pan, P.H.
Abstract: Smaller dynamic random-access memories (DRAMs) require a very thin insulator (or insulators) for the storage node. The total storage capacitance can be increased by the formation of an N-skin under the storage insulator. This article describes a method of adding a thin layer of silicon atop the storage electrode to allow high energy N-skin implants.
Index Keywords: DRAM; N-SKIN IMPLANTS; STORAGE NODE; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL

Title: OPTIMISATION OF RELATIVISTIC ANTIMATTER ROCKETS.
Source title: JBIS. Journal of the British Interplanetary Society
Affiliations: United Technologies Research Cent,, East Hartford, CT, USA, United Technologies Research Cent, East Hartford, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cassenti, B.N., United Technologies Research Cent,, East Hartford, CT, USA, United Technologies Research Cent, East Hartford, CT, USA
Abstract: In antimatter rockets, energy for propulsion is obtained by combining matter with antimatter. Equal quantities of each will be annihilated converting the total mass entirely into energy. The resulting energy can be used directly to propel a vehicle or the energy can be used to heat additional matter and this heated matter used as a propellant. Acquiring and storing antimatter are difficult technical problems that must be overcome in order to make antimatter rockets a reality. These technical problems can be minimized if the amount of antimatter required for a mission is minimized. Previous minimizations have been performed for the case of constant antimatter and propellant flow rates. The extension of these previous analyses to the case of variable antimatter and propellant flow rates and arbitrary efficiencies are presented. The results indicate variable flow rates can allow savings of up to 35 percent in the amount of antimatter required over constant flow rates.
Index Keywords: PROPULSION - Aerospace Applications; SPACE FLIGHT - Interplanetary Flight; ANTIMATTER PRODUCTION; ANTIMATTER STORAGE; FINAL VELOCITIES; RELATIVISTIC ANTIMATTER ROCKETS; ROCKETS AND MISSILES

Title: Solar Thermal Power Towers
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Institute, Golden Colorado, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kreith, F., Solar Energy Research Institute, Golden Colorado, United States; Meyer, R.T., Solar Energy Research Institute, Golden Colorado, United States
Abstract: The solar thermal central receiver technology, known as solar power towers, is rapidly evolving to a state of near-term energy availability for electrical power generation and industrial process heat applications. The systems consist of field arrays of heliostat reflectors, a central receiver boiler, short term thermal storage devices, and either turbine-generators or heat exchangers. Fluid temperatures up to 550 °C are currently achievable, and technology developments are underway to reach 1100 °C. Six solar power towers are now under construction or in test operation in five countries around the world. © 1984 Harwood Academic Publishers GmbH
Index Keywords: BOILERS; INDUSTRIAL HEATING; SOLAR RADIATION - Concentrators; CENTRAL RECEIVER BOILERS; HELIOSTAT REFLECTORS; SOLAR THERMAL CENTRAL RECEIVERS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: Sucrose transport into vacuoles isolated from barley mesophyll protoplasts
Affiliations: Lehrstuhl Botanik I der Universität, Mittlerer Dallenbergweg 64, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kaiser, G., Lehrstuhl Botanik I der Universität, Mittlerer Dallenbergweg 64, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany; Heber, U., Lehrstuhl Botanik I der Universität, Mittlerer Dallenbergweg 64, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany
Abstract: Sucrose transport has been investigated in vacuoles isolated from barley mesophyll protoplasts. Rates of sucrose transfer across the tonoplast were even higher in vitro than in vivo indicating that the sucrose transport system had not suffered damage during isolation of the vacuoles. Sucrose transport is carrier-mediated as shown by substrate saturation of transport and sensitivity to a metabolic inhibitor and to competitive substrates. A number of sugars, in particular maltose and raffinose, decreased uptake of sucrose. Sorbitol was slowly taken up but had no effect on sucrose transport. The SH-reagent p-chloromercuribenzene sulfonate inhibited sucrose uptake completely. The apparent Km of the carrier for sucrose uptake was 21 mM. Transport was neither influenced by ATP and pyrophosphate, with or without Mg2+ present, nor by protonophores and valinomycin (with K+ present). Apparently uptake was not energy dependent. Efflux experiments with preloaded vacuoles indicated that sucrose unloading from the isolated vavuoles is mediated by the same carrier which catalyses uptake. The vacuole of mesophyll cells appears to represent an intermediary storage compartment. Uptake of photosynthetic products into the vacuole during the light apparently minimizes osmotic swelling of the small cytosolic compartment of vacuolated leaf cells when photosynthetic productivity exceeds the capacity of the phloem for translocation of sugars. © 1984 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Hordeum (sucrose transport, vacuole); Protoplast; Sucrose (partitioning and transport); Tonoplast; Vacuole

Title: Key modifications bolster performance of RDF plants
Authors with affiliations: Makansi, J.
Abstract: Unlike the municipal waste mass-burning plants that have been successfully operating in the US, it is only recently that a few of the RDF-fired plants built in the late 1970s are approaching design performance levels on a consistent basis. Though the modifications made to these plants were extensive and expensive, continued success may yet make RDF technology a competitor in US refuse-fired plants. The modifications can be grouped as follows: drastic simplification of the materials-handling equipment and outright elimination of several components; improvements in the fuel-feeding technique at the furance and in the RDF-storage and -transport facilities; protection of boiler tubes from severe erosion and corrosion; safety improvements to reduce the chance of explosions in the materials-handling train; replacement of dry ash-handling systems with a wet process. Modifications at two such plants are described in detail.
Index Keywords: FUELS - Refuse Derived Fuels; Municipal engineering; REFUSE DISPOSAL - Incineration; Refuse incinerators; STEAM POWER PLANTS - Waste Utilization; RDF PLANTS; REFUSE-FIRED POWER PLANTS; Boiler firing; energy resource; incineration; nonhuman; recycling; solid waste management; theoretical study

Title: SUPER ENERGY CONSERVATION BUILDING-OHBAYASHI-GUMI TECHNICAL RESEARCH INSTITUTE.
Affiliations: Ohbayashi-Gumi Ltd, Mechanical & Electrical Dep, Jpn, Ohbayashi-Gumi Ltd, Mechanical & Electrical Dep, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Sakai, Kanji, Ohbayashi-Gumi Ltd, Mechanical & Electrical Dep, Jpn, Ohbayashi-Gumi Ltd, Mechanical & Electrical Dep, Jpn
Abstract: The Ohbayashi-Gumi Technical Research Institute building was built in April 1982 near Tokyo. This building was designed to reduce drastically fossil fuel consumption through many energy-conservation techniques, for example, double-skin, soil thermal storage, solar cells, task/ambient lighting, etc. After completion, its energy use has been measured for twelve months and the result was 87 Mcal/m**2. This value is 1/4 of the conventional office building in Japan. In fact, for fully air conditioned buildings, this building may have the lowest energy use in Japan. The incremental investment will be paid back within 8. 7 years. So this building is also economically feasible.
Index Keywords: RESEARCH LABORATORIES - Energy Conservation; AIR CONDITIONED BUILDINGS; ENERGY-CONSERVATION TECHNIQUES; FOSSIL FUEL CONSUMPTION; SOIL THERMAL STORAGE; BUILDINGS

Title: DYNAMIC MODELLING OF SOLAR THERMAL DEVICES.
Affiliations: Chalmers Univ of Technology, Dep of, Energy Conversion, Goteborg, Swed, Chalmers Univ of Technology, Dep of Energy Conversion, Goteborg, Swed
Authors with affiliations: Honarbakhsh, Ahmad, Chalmers Univ of Technology, Dep of, Energy Conversion, Goteborg, Swed, Chalmers Univ of Technology, Dep of Energy Conversion, Goteborg, Swed
Abstract: Solar thermal devices are subject to time-dependent driving forces. Characterization of the dynamic behavior of those devices and the evaluation of their long-term performance leads to criteria for design purposes. The solar thermal devices studied here are solar collectors, greenhouses, a solar battery and a combination of these, namely the Greenhouse Solar Collector. A dynamic model is developed, comprised of the heat balance equation for the surfaces of the Greenhouse Solar Collector, the ground, the batteries, the plants and the interior air, together with a mass balance over the interior air.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Utilization; GREENHOUSE; HEAT STORAGE; HEAT UTILIZATION; SOLAR COLLECTORS; THERMAL EFFICIENCY; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: NASA REDOX STORAGE SYSTEM DEVELOPMENT PROJECT.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hagedorn, Norman H., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The Redox Storage System Technology Project was jointly supported by the U. S. Department of Energy and NASA. The objectives of the project were to develop the Redox flow battery concept and to prove its technical and economic viability. The iron and chromium redox couples were selected as the reactants. Membranes and electrodes were developed for the original mode of operating at 25 degree C with the reactants separated by an ion-exchange membrane. Analytical capabilities and system-level operating concepts were developed and verified in a 1-kW, 13-kWh preprototype system. A subsequent change was made in operating mode, going to 65 degree C and using mixed reactants. New membranes and a new electrode catalyst were developed, resulting in single cell operation as high as 80 mA/cm**2 with energy efficiencies greater than 80 percent.
Index Keywords: ELECTROCHEMISTRY; ENERGY STORAGE; FLOW BATTERIES; REBALANCE CELLS; REDOX STORAGE SYSTEM; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Authors: Fujii I., Tsuchiya K., Ohtsuki T.
Title: CALCIUM HYDROXIDE AS AN ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Meiji Univ, Dep of Mechanical, Engineering, Tokyo, Jpn, Meiji Univ, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Fujii, I., Meiji Univ, Dep of Mechanical, Engineering, Tokyo, Jpn, Meiji Univ, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo, Jpn; Tsuchiya, K., Meiji Univ, Dep of Mechanical, Engineering, Tokyo, Jpn, Meiji Univ, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo, Jpn; Ohtsuki, T., Meiji Univ, Dep of Mechanical, Engineering, Tokyo, Jpn, Meiji Univ, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: Thermochemical energy storage has been studied using Ca(OH)//2 as an energy storage material. Some basic experiments such as an effect of physical conditions on the dehydration and deterioration of the material and heat storage tests were carried out using a bigger scale prototype system built for heat recovery through the solid-gas reaction: CaO plus H//2O reversible reaction Ca(OH)//2.

Abstract: IHI has been participating in the TRISTAN Project carried out by the National Laboratory for High Energy Physics. The construction of a huge accelerator under the TRISTAN Project has been started, and it has been decided that an aluminum-alloy ultra-high vacuum system is to be employed in full measure for this accelerator for the first time in the world. Title: DIGITAL-STORAGE OSCILLOSCOPE APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Gould Instruments, Gould Instruments
Authors with affiliations: Crook, C.R., Gould Instruments, Gould Instruments
Abstract: Applications discussed in this feature are the simultaneous display of reference trace and updated trace for easy testing of electronic circuits, the automatic plotting of spikes on power supply lines to analyze cause of data corruption in computer circuits, the automatic recording of alarm conditions using variable set point facility, the automatic recording of bursts of pulses or transients into separate stores to overcome store output delays, the automatic copying of the displayed waveform into a computer for analysis such as averaging, Fourier analysis, integration to find the energy represented by the waveform, etc. and the automatic copying of the displayed waveform onto a pen recorder.
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS - Automatic Testing; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Applications; DIGITAL DEVICES; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS - Testing; DIGITAL STORAGE; OSCILLOSCOPES, CATHODE RAY

Title: VESSELS UNDER STRESS.
Authors with affiliations: Swan, Russ
Abstract: Prestressed concrete pressure vessels (PCVs) are usually associated with nuclear power stations, where they have been employed since the late 1950s. Originally developed as an alternative to all-steel vessels, largely because of the difficulties associated with quality assurance and welding on the very thick plates required, PCPVs rapidly became the accepted norm. Their advantages were numerous, not only being more economical than the equivalent steel vessel, but also providing a large measure of radiation protection ('biological shielding') and with a more predictable failure mode, gradual rather than sudden. The applications of PCPVs go beyond the nuclear power industry, however. Energy storage schemes, using compressed gas or hot water storage media, and pressure vessels for coal conversion and hydrocracking processes, are some of the other potential uses for vessels of this nature.
Index Keywords: CONCRETE CONSTRUCTION - Prestressing; PRESSURE VESSELS

Title: TRENDS IN INDUSTRIAL POWER PLANTS.
Affiliations: Power Engineering, Barrington, IL,, USA, Power Engineering, Barrington, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Smith, Douglas J., Power Engineering, Barrington, IL,, USA, Power Engineering, Barrington, IL, USA
Abstract: Evolution of industrial power plants has turned a full circle, with industry again increasing the percentage of electrical power that it generates. What was first called simply on-site generation became a 'total energy system' in the 1970s, and today is called a 'cogeneration plant'. Estimated installed capacity of industrial power plants is about 15,000 MW and the potential is about 44,000 MW by the year 2000. With abundant coal reserves, manufacturers are speeding up the development of circulating fluidized bed boilers to burn this fuel without damage to the environment. Energy storage systems are helping to reduce the energy costs for some industrial operations.
Index Keywords: COGENERATION PLANTS; COMBUSTION - Fluidized Beds; ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Design; ENERGY STORAGE; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS

Authors with affiliations: Kishore, V.V.N., Central Salt & Marine Chemicals, Research Inst, Bhaungar, India, Central Salt & Marine Chemicals Research Inst, Bhaungar, India; Joshi, V., Central Salt & Marine Chemicals, Research Inst, Bhaungar, India, Central Salt & Marine Chemicals Research Inst, Bhaungar, India; Rao, K.S., Central Salt & Marine Chemicals, Research Inst, Bhaungar, India, Central Salt & Marine Chemicals Research Inst, Bhaungar, India
Abstract: This article discusses the use of a salt gradient solar pond (SGPC) for process heat for the specific case of a dairy situated at Jamnagar. The minimum area required to meet the load and the yearly solar fraction is calculated by different methods and a comparison is made of the results obtained. Considering all the thermal losses occurring in the pond, the authors have concluded that the thermal energy delivered by the pond could meet 50% of the annual load.

Title: SIMULTANEOUS ACTIVE AND REACTIVE POWER CONTROL OF SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNET ENERGY STORAGE USING GTO CONVERTER.
Source title: Technology Reports of the Osaka University
Affiliations: Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ise, Toshifumi, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn; Nakano, Toshihide, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn; Kotoo, Yukihiro, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn; Murakami, Yoshishige, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn; Tsuji, Kiichiro, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Jpn
Abstract: By using GTOs (Gate Turn-Off Thyristor) in place of normal thyristors in a conventional six-pulse Greatz bridge converter, not only lagging but also leading phase reactive power can be absorbed. This feature enables superconducting magnet energy storage (SMES) to control reactive power in the wide range between the lagging phase and the leading phase. A GTO converter which mainly consists of six GTOs, was developed and tested. By using two sets of GTO converters, we carried out some experiments of simultaneous active and reactive power control of SMES. The ability of controlling reactive power in the wide range between the lagging phase and the leading phase was confirmed experimentally.
Index Keywords: THYRISTORS - Applications; GATE TURN-OFF THYRISTOR; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNET ENERGY STORAGE; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Abstract: Most events with high neutral transverse energy, ET0, produced in pp colisions at √s = 62.3 GeV, are jet-like. The evidence for this is presented, based on data collected using an electromagnetic calorimeter covering 90% of 2π in azimuth. The spectrum dN/dET0 has been measured over the ET0 range from 10 to 35 GeV. Properties of the observed jets are discussed. © 1984.

Title: Organic compounds as candidate phase change materials in thermal energy storage

Abstract: Organic compounds have been screened as potential phase change materials for thermal energy storage in the temperature range 60-90°C. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was used to assess the melting range, enthalpy of fusion and thermal stability of the compounds. The Cleveland open cup method was used to determine flash points. Of the materials studied, Neofat 18S, a local Slackwax and the Hoechst F wax were considered suitable for further study. © 1984.
