Abstract: The process of thermal activation of an Italian natural zeolite, namely chabazitic tuff, is studied in the view of its possible use for solar energy storage. An evaluation of the amount of heat storable through the dehydration of the zeolite is also given. © 1984.

Authors: Major R.V., Jasko T.M., Cruickshank K.J.
Title: DEVELOPMENT OF AMORPHOUS Fe-B BASED ALLOYS FOR CHOKE AND INDUCTOR APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Telcon Metals Ltd, Crawley, Engl, Telcon Metals Ltd, Crawley, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Major, R.V., Telcon Metals Ltd, Crawley, Engl, Telcon Metals Ltd, Crawley, Engl; Jasko, T.M., Telcon Metals Ltd, Crawley, Engl, Telcon Metals Ltd, Crawley, Engl; Cruickshank, K.J., Telcon Metals Ltd, Crawley, Engl, Telcon Metals Ltd, Crawley, Engl
Abstract: A method is described of obtaining linear permeability characteristics from Fe-B based amorphous alloys, suitable for choke and inductor applications. The properties are developed by heat treatment at temperatures above those conventionally used to develop the optimum low or high frequency magnetic properties in these alloys. Within a narrow heat treatment temperature range it is possible to develop permeabilities of between 200 and 700, linear up to high flux density levels. dc energy storage curves are presented for Fe//7//7//. //5B//1//3 Si//9//. //5 alloy, toroidal tape wound cores, heat treated in this manner. These curves indicate the potential advantages of these cores over powder cores and gapped ferrites in dc choke applications.
Index Keywords: MAGNETIC CORES; MAGNETIC PROPERTIES; MAGNETIZATION; FLUX DENSITY; MAGNETIC PERMEABILITY; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; IRON AND ALLOYS

Authors: Lefranc C., Feliachi M., Coulomb J.L.
Title: ON NUMERICAL MODELLING OF HYSTERESIS IN RECORDING SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Compagnie BULL, Cent de Recherche,, Les Clayes sous Bois, Fr, Compagnie BULL, Cent de Recherche, Les Clayes sous Bois, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Lefranc, C., Compagnie BULL, Cent de Recherche,, Les Clayes sous Bois, Fr, Compagnie BULL, Cent de Recherche, Les Clayes sous Bois, Fr; Feliachi, M., Compagnie BULL, Cent de Recherche,, Les Clayes sous Bois, Fr, Compagnie BULL, Cent de Recherche, Les Clayes sous Bois, Fr; Coulomb, J.L., Compagnie BULL, Cent de Recherche,, Les Clayes sous Bois, Fr, Compagnie BULL, Cent de Recherche, Les Clayes sous Bois, Fr
Abstract: Two-dimensional simulation is presented of the read and write processes in perpendicular magnetic recording, which takes into account the strong anisotropy and hysteresis characteristics of the ferromagnetic materials involved in the recording system. The algorithm, which has been implemented in the electromagnetic analysis package FLUX developed by ENSIEG, is based on finite element method and successive minimizations of the energy and the co-energy of the recording system head/medium. Results in terms of induction lines, magnetization distributions and computed readback signals are presented and analyzed.
Index Keywords: HYSTERESIS; MAGNETIZATION; MAGNETIC HYSTERESIS; MAGNETIC RECORDING; NUMERICAL SIMULATION; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Authors: Goto F., Osaka T., Koiwa I., Okabe Y., Matsubara H., Wada A., Shiota N.
Title: ELECTROLESS PLATED DISKS FOR PERPENDICULAR MAGNETIC RECORDING.
Affiliations: NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab,, Kawasaki, Jpn, NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab, Kawasaki, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Goto, F., NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab,, Kawasaki, Jpn, NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab, Kawasaki, Jpn; Osaka, T., NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab,, Kawasaki, Jpn, NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab, Kawasaki, Jpn; Koiwa, I., NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab,, Kawasaki, Jpn, NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab, Kawasaki, Jpn; Okabe, Y., NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab,, Kawasaki, Jpn, NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab, Kawasaki, Jpn; Matsubara, H., NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab,, Kawasaki, Jpn, NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab, Kawasaki, Jpn; Wada, A., NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab,, Kawasaki, Jpn, NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab, Kawasaki, Jpn; Shiota, N., NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab,, Kawasaki, Jpn, NEC, Microelectronics Research Lab, Kawasaki, Jpn
Abstract: Co-Ni-Mn-Re-P perpendicular recording disks were prepared by the electroless plating method using newly developed plating baths. Typical magnetic properties on the disks were the anisotropy energy, coercivity and saturation magnetization. Recording performance on these disks was evaluated by using Winchester heads under practical head-medium spacing. Higher recording density, D//5//0 equals 68k FRPI (2700 FRPM), was attained by decreasing the medium thickness and head-medium spacing to 0. 2 mu m and 0. 12 mu m, respectively.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC - Disk; ELECTROLESS PLATING; MAGNETIC RECORDING; PERPENDICULAR RECORDING; RECORDING DENSITY; COBALT AND ALLOYS

Authors: Houston James R., Chou Lucia W.
Title: EROSION CONTROL OF SCOUR DURING CONSTRUCTION; REPORT 6, FINITE - A NUMERICAL MODEL FOR COMBINED REFRACTION AND DIFFRACTION OF WAVES.
Source title: Technical Report - US Army Engineer Waterways Experiment Station
Affiliations: US Army Engineer Waterways Hydraulic, Lab, Experiment Station, Vicksburg,, MS, USA, US Army Engineer Waterways Hydraulic Lab, Experiment Station, Vicksburg, MS, USA
Authors with affiliations: Houston, James R., US Army Engineer Waterways Hydraulic, Lab, Experiment Station, Vicksburg,, MS, USA, US Army Engineer Waterways Hydraulic Lab, Experiment Station, Vicksburg, MS, USA; Chou, Lucia W., US Army Engineer Waterways Hydraulic, Lab, Experiment Station, Vicksburg,, MS, USA, US Army Engineer Waterways Hydraulic Lab, Experiment Station, Vicksburg, MS, USA
Abstract: A hybrid finite element numerical model (FINITE) is presented that solves a linear mild-slope equation for short-wave propagation. The efficient formulation of the model permits the solution of large problems with relative small time and memory storage requirements. Although the model solves an equation that is strictly valid only for mild bathymetric variations, the model can provide reasonable answers for problems where there are rapid depth variations (at much lower cost than required by three-dimensional models that are appropriate for problems involving rapid depth variations). The model does not provide a mechanism for energy dissipation, and thus energy loss through wave breaking is simulated by permitting waves to propagate out of the computational region. The program documentation, user guide, and sample problem output, are provided. Refs.
Index Keywords: EROSION - Control; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Element Method; WATER WAVES - Propagation; COASTAL ZONE; DEPTH VARIATIONS; HYDRAULIC STRUCTURES

Authors: Boldyrev V.M., Starostenko V.I., Starostenko N.N.
Title: THERMOCHEMICAL METHOD OF TRANSFER OF ENERGY FROM A NUCLEAR POWER STATION FOR INDUSTRIAL HEAT SUPPLY.
Authors with affiliations: Boldyrev, V.M.; Starostenko, V.I.; Starostenko, N.N.
Abstract: Construction of nuclear power (NP) stations, heat and power stations, nd nuclear heat supply (NHS) stations which is under way at present will not solve the problem of large-scale use of nuclear fuel for industrial heat supply for technological considerations and will require the development of new nuclear power generating and processing plants. Taking into consideration the large number of various industrial users of heat and the contingent necessity of energy transfer over considerable distances it is also advisable to examine the problems of introduction of nonconventional methods of heat transportation from nuclear energy sources based on systems of thermochemical storage to power generating and processing cycles.
Index Keywords: INDUSTRIAL HEATING; CHEMICAL SYSTEM ENERGY CAPACITY; FLOW PARAMETERS; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS

Title: ENERGY-SAVING HOUSE FOR SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA.
Authors with affiliations: Bissett, Debra; Bissett, Ronald
Abstract: The authors describe a three-story energy-saving house of passive solar design, with superinsulation in the walls and roof, movable insulation on the windows, and an air-tight vapor retarder system. Solar heat gain is through the south-facing glazing, with heat storage mass concentrated in the lowest level. Space heating is completely provided, as needed, by a wood furnace equipped with a catalytic converter and water coil. Heat distribution is by natural circulation through a series of operable floor grilles. The wood heater will also preheat incoming well water. Since the proposed site is presently not part of an existing power system, a wind-powered electrical generator is being considered as a power source for necessary electrical appliances, pending a favorable outcome of a local wind analysis.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; WIND POWER - Applications; HOUSES

Authors: de Gennaro M., Colella C., Aiello R., Franco E.
Title: ITALIAN ZEOLITES 2. MINERALOGICAL AND TECHNICAL FEATURES OF CAMPANIAN TUFF.
Affiliations: Univ di Napoli, Naples, Italy, Univ di Napoli, Naples, Italy
Authors with affiliations: de Gennaro, M., Univ di Napoli, Naples, Italy, Univ di Napoli, Naples, Italy; Colella, C., Univ di Napoli, Naples, Italy, Univ di Napoli, Naples, Italy; Aiello, R., Univ di Napoli, Naples, Italy, Univ di Napoli, Naples, Italy; Franco, E., Univ di Napoli, Naples, Italy, Univ di Napoli, Naples, Italy
Abstract: An evaluation of the mineralogical and technical properties of Campanian tuff, a chabazite-containing rock widely occurring in Campanian Region of South Italy, is presented. The possibility of large amounts of rock being available, either in the form of powder or as pelletsize grains with high zeolite content is emphasised. Potential utilisation, especially in drying processes or in solar energy storage, due to its high rehydration kinetics and water vapor adsoption capacity, are indicated.
Index Keywords: BUILDING MATERIALS - Performance; MINERALS - Applications; CHABAZITE; DESICCANTS; NAPOLITANIAN TUFF; REHYDRATION KINETICS; ZEOLITES

Title: WEATHER SENSING - A NEW ERA FOR OFF-PEAK ELECTRIC HEATING.
Source title: Heating and Ventilating Engineer: The Journal of Environmental Services
Affiliations: Pactrol Controls Ltd, Skelmersdale, Engl, Pactrol Controls Ltd, Skelmersdale, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Green, D.A., Pactrol Controls Ltd, Skelmersdale, Engl, Pactrol Controls Ltd, Skelmersdale, Engl
Abstract: The use of off-peak electricity in storage heaters can show considerable cost-savings in energy bills. These savings can be increased considerably - sometimes by up to 50% - if the energy input to the heaters can be controlled according to time of need and outside weather conditions.
Index Keywords: ELECTRICITY - Costs; TEMPERATURE CONTROL; STORAGE HEATERS; TIMESHARING TEMPERATURE CONTROL; WEATHER WATCHER; HEATING

Title: The vacuum structure in QCD and hadron-hadron scattering
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik C: Particles and Fields
Affiliations: Institut für Theoretische Physik der Universität Heidelberg, Heidelberg, D-6900, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Nachtmann, O., Institut für Theoretische Physik der Universität Heidelberg, Heidelberg, D-6900, Germany; Reiter, A., Institut für Theoretische Physik der Universität Heidelberg, Heidelberg, D-6900, Germany
Abstract: Standard ideas on the structure of the vacuum in QCD suggest it to be full of fluctuating color fields. We investigate the possible influence of the chromomagnetic vacuum fields on high energy hadron-hadron reactions. We suggest that high energy quarks traversing these fields will produce soft gluon and photon radiation analogous to synchrotron radiation from electrons and positrons in a storage ring. We argue that this radiation will lead to polarization phenomena for quarks in spin- and colorspace which in turn can explain the K-factor in the Drell-Yan reaction. We point out that jet production offers another way to study these polarization phenomena. We present then a calculation of the number of "synchrotron" photons which should be emitted in p-p collisions at high energies. Thus, we predict a sizable signal of prompt photons of nnergy less than a few hundred MeV with a characteristic frequency distribution. Observation of such photons would give strong support to our naive picture. Finally we point out a number of other phenomena like charmed particle decays where our "synchrotron" effect may be of importance. © 1984 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Some hydrodynamic aspects of compressed-air energy storage in aquifers
Affiliations: Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, 32000, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Braester, C., Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, 32000, Israel; Bear, J., Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, 32000, Israel
Abstract: In a compressed-air energy storage in an aquifer (CAESA) project, compressed air is injected into an anticlinal aquifer to form a compressed-air reservoir at a desired pressure. Once a compressed-air reservoir has been established, air is withdrawn for energy production during periods of peak demand for electric power, and reinjected during off-peak periods. In this way, excess energy produced during off-peak hours is stored for use during periods of peak demand. In order to plan a CAESA project, information is required, among other parameters, on the pressure fluctuations in the production-injection well as a function of the rate of production-injection and other pertinent reservoir parameters. During the preliminary phases of planning, it is important to obtain estimates of this information, quickly and at low cost. A simplified model is proposed here for this purpose. The model is based on the assumption that the air and the water domains are separated by an abrupt interface. Two simplified geometries are investigated: a one-dimensional vertical column with air injection and pumping at the top, and a partially penetrating well in the center of a cylindrical domain. For each case, the mathematical model was established and solved numerically. Several examples are given to demonstrate the application of the proposed model. © 1984.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS; HYDRODYNAMICS; PEAKING POWER; COMPRESSED AIR

Authors: Cole S.K., Baer T., Guyon P.M., Govers T.R.
Title: Symmetric electron transfer reactions of state-selected ions: H2+ + H2 → H2 + H2+(ν= 0-10)
Affiliations: LURE, Laboratoire CNRS, Université Paris-sud, 91405 Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Cole, S.K., LURE, Laboratoire CNRS, Université Paris-sud, 91405 Orsay, France; Baer, T., LURE, Laboratoire CNRS, Université Paris-sud, 91405 Orsay, France; Guyon, P.M., LURE, Laboratoire CNRS, Université Paris-sud, 91405 Orsay, France; Govers, T.R., LURE, Laboratoire CNRS, Université Paris-sud, 91405 Orsay, France
Abstract: Total symmetric electron transfer cross sections for state-selected H2+ ions were measured for vibrational levels of the ion from ν = 0 to 10 at a relative translational energy of 16 eV. The internal energy of the H2+ ions was selected by threshold photoelectron-photoion coincidence using pulsed synchrotron radiation from the ACO storage ring at Orsay. The relative cross sections agree very well with the recent calculations of Lee and DePristo using a semiclassical energy conserving trajectory approach with an accurate diabatic interaction potential between the ion and neutral diatoms. © 1984.

Title: MECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF POLYMERS.
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: Univ of Akron, Inst of Polymer, Science, Akron, OH, USA, Univ of Akron, Inst of Polymer Science, Akron, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hamed, G.R., Univ of Akron, Inst of Polymer, Science, Akron, OH, USA, Univ of Akron, Inst of Polymer Science, Akron, OH, USA
Abstract: If a polymer is deformed, some of the input energy is stored in the polymeric chains and can be recovered (elastic response) while a part of the energy is dissipated into heat via irreversible molecular motions (viscous response). Hence, polymers are termed viscoelastic. The relative portions of energy stored compared to that which is dissipated depends on test rate and temperature. Generally, the largest portion of energy is dissipated under the conditions in which a polymer is undergoing its glass transition temperature. Several methods can be used to characterize the viscoelastic nature of polymers. Stress relaxation (stress relaxation modulus), creep (creep compliance) and dynamic mechanical response (storage and loss modulus) are the most common.
Index Keywords: FRACTURE MECHANICS; PLASTICS - Deformation; STRESSES - Analysis; VISCOELASTICITY; ABSTRACT FORM ONLY; DYNAMIC MECHANICAL RESPONSE; ELASTIC RESPONSE; STRESS RELAXATION; VISCOUS RESPONSE; POLYMERS

Title: Optical klystron experiments for the ACO storage ring Free Electron Laser
Source title: Applied Physics B Photophysics and Laser Chemistry

Authors with affiliations: Deacon, D.A.G., L.U.R.E., L.P. CNRS 008, Université de Paris-Sud, Bâtiment 209-C, Orsay, F-91405, France; Billardon, M., L.U.R.E., L.P. CNRS 008, Université de Paris-Sud, Bâtiment 209-C, Orsay, F-91405, France; Velghe, M., L.U.R.E., L.P. CNRS 008, Université de Paris-Sud, Bâtiment 209-C, Orsay, F-91405, France; Madey, J.M.J., L.U.R.E., L.P. CNRS 008, Université de Paris-Sud, Bâtiment 209-C, Orsay, F-91405, France; Petroff, Y., L.U.R.E., L.P. CNRS 008, Université de Paris-Sud, Bâtiment 209-C, Orsay, F-91405, France
Abstract: To improve the gain in the Orsay storage ring Free Electron Laser (FEL) experiment, the 17 period permanent magnet undulator has been modified to form an optical klystron (OK). We report the measurement of spontaneous emission and the effects on it of energy spread and angular spread. Gain and laser induced bunch lengthening measurements with the OK are also reported and are in very good agreement with the FEL classical theory. The spontaneous emission spectrum which is easy to measure with good signal to noise ratio, turns out to be a very good diagnostic tool for energy spread and angular spread measurements on storage rings. The factor of four increase in the small gain obtained by converting the undulator NOEL into an OK was the critical factor in the recent operation of the ACO storage ring laser above threshold. © 1984 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; FREE ELECTRON LASER; LASERS

Title: SOLID POLYMER ELECTROLYTE COMPLEXES OF ALKALI SALTS WITH POLY(METHACRYLATE)S CARRYING PENDANT GLYME CHAINS.
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: State Univ of New York at Syracuse,, Polymer Research Inst, Syracuse, NY,, USA, State Univ of New York at Syracuse, Polymer Research Inst, Syracuse, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Xia, Du Wei, State Univ of New York at Syracuse,, Polymer Research Inst, Syracuse, NY,, USA, State Univ of New York at Syracuse, Polymer Research Inst, Syracuse, NY, USA; Smid, Johannes, State Univ of New York at Syracuse,, Polymer Research Inst, Syracuse, NY,, USA, State Univ of New York at Syracuse, Polymer Research Inst, Syracuse, NY, USA
Abstract: Considerable interest exists in the development of solvent-free solid polymeric electrolytes because of their potential application in high energy storage devices. Our recent studies on the ion-binding properties of solvent-swollen cross-linked resins of polystyrene and polymethacrylates containing immobilized macrocyclic and linear polyethers induced us to look at the properties of solid state mixtures of salts with poly(methacrylate)s endowed with oligo-oxyethylene (glyme) side chains. In several systems crystalline complexes are formed, in some instances with a salt to CH//2CH//2O ratio as high as unity. Other systems form homogeneous, transparent films with a high salt content. Conductivities as high as 10** minus **3 OMEGA ** minus **1 cm** minus **1 have been obtained.
Index Keywords: ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS - Chemical Reactions; ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Materials; PLASTICS FILMS - Electric Conductivity; POLYESTERS; PENDANT GLYME CHAINS; POLYMER ELECTROLYTE COMPLEX; POLYMETHACRYLATES; POLYELECTROLYTES

Title: ELECTROCATALYSTS FOR Fe/Cr REDOX BATTERIES.
Source title: American Chemical Society, Division of Petroleum Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Giner Inc, Waltham, MA, USA, Giner Inc, Waltham, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jalan, V.M., Giner Inc, Waltham, MA, USA, Giner Inc, Waltham, MA, USA; Swette, L.L., Giner Inc, Waltham, MA, USA, Giner Inc, Waltham, MA, USA
Abstract: This short communication describes some features of the iron/chromium redox energy storage system which has the capability of providing inexpensive reliable bulk energy storage suitable for the efficient capture of energy from intermittent sources such as solar or wind energy, and it has the potential for meeting the requirements of electric utility applications such as load levelling and peak shaving. All of the reactant species in the system are soluble in hydrochloric acid at practical concentrations, a feature which permits scaling of the energy section of the system independently of the power section. Results of a test program are presented which show that using transmission electron microscopy and scanning transmission electron microscopy, uncatalyzed carbon felt fibers can be fluted resembling a bundle of smaller fibers but otherwise smooth and generally free of particles. Catalyzed felts exhibited opaque particles in the range of 10-500 mm scattered over the surfaces. EDAX analysis (energy dispersive analysis by X-ray) showed these particles to be gold. Estimates of the gold surface area also showed direct correlation with reactivity and the observed lead loadings.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Redox; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; ELECTRODES, ELECTROCHEMICAL - Chemistry; MICROSCOPES, ELECTRON; IRON-CHROMIUM REDOX ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM; SOLAR ENERGY; WIND ENERGY; CATALYSTS

Authors: Devyatkov N.D., Naumenko Ye.D., Sretenskiy V.N., Filimonova T.N.
Title: KLYSTRON METHOD OF BUNCHING A HOLLOW ROTATING RELATIVISTIC ELECTRON BEAM.
Source title: Radio Engineering and Electronic Physics (English translation of Radiotekhnika i Elektronika)
Authors with affiliations: Devyatkov, N.D.; Naumenko, Ye.D.; Sretenskiy, V.N.; Filimonova, T.N.
Abstract: The possibility of rearranging a continuous stream of high-energy electrons into a stream of discrete bunches by means of a formation of spiral electron trajectories with storage of the primary energy in rotational motion and the use of klystron-type bunching cavity is shown. The dependence that is found for the translational component of the electron velocity on the energy increment in the gap of the buncher indicates a formal similarity between the bunching of a hollow rotating relativistic electron beam and a rectilinear beam of conditional hyperparticles, the charge of which is equal to the electron charge while the mass is somewhat less than the relativistic mass of the electrons of the hollow beam.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON TUBES, KLYSTRON; RELATIVITY; BEAM BUNCHING; ELECTRON BEAMS

Abstract: The possibility of energy storage in product molecules in an exothermic surface interaction has been checked for nitrogen atom recombination at palladium surfaces by means of the field ionization method. © 1984.

Title: The control of cadmium uptake in the lichen genus peltigera
Affiliations: Department of Botany, University Bristol, BS8 1UG, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Beckett, R.P., Department of Botany, University Bristol, BS8 1UG, United Kingdom; Brown, D.H., Department of Botany, University Bristol, BS8 1UG, United Kingdom
Abstract: Intra- and extracellular Cd uptake in the lichen genus Peltigera were investigated, and intracellular uptake found to display Michaelis-Menten kinetics. Compared with values reported for Zn uptake in free-living algae and fungi, Peltigera had low affinities for Cd and low maximum uptake rates. Intra-, and to a lesser extent extracellular uptake rates were temperature dependent. When lichens were incubated concurrently with Cd and equimolar concentrations of a range of other cations, most were found to reduce both extra- and intracellular Cd uptake, implying that the Cd uptake systems had low specificities. Mg, though not a strong competitor for extracellular Cd uptake, inhibited intracellular Cd uptake to a similar extent to borderline elements, and it is postulated that intracellular Cd uptake occurs by a system which normally transports Mg. Although concurrently-supplied cations reduced Cd-induced inhibitions of photosynthesis, the reductions were not proportional to the effect of the cations on intracellular Cd uptake. This indicated that other cations affected the toxicity of Cd to photosynthesis by some means in addition to reducing Cd uptake. Intracellular Cd uptake was light-stimulated, suggesting that a close relationship existed between metal uptake and metabolism. The rate of intracellular Cd uptake in the dark was probably not directly linked to the supply of respirable reserves, as it was unaffected by prolonged storage in the dark, and was not increased by adding glucose. It is hypothesized that light-stimulated Cd uptake represents active entry into algal cells, but with uptake in the dark it is not clear which symbiont is involved, and whether energy is required. © 1984 Oxford University Press.
Author Keywords: Cadmium uptake; Cation competition; Lichen; Light; Temperature
Index Keywords: cadmium; lichen; nonhuman

Title: Role of carbohydrate in exercise.
Authors with affiliations: Gollnick, P.D.; Matoba, H.
Abstract: Carbohydrate is an important energy source during exercise. During short, heavy exercise it may be the only energy source for the working muscle and may be derived exclusively from the glycogen stores within the muscle fibers themselves. During prolonged, submaximal exercise the magnitude of the contribution that carbohydrate makes to the total fuel consumed depends upon a number of factors, including (1) the intensity of the exercise, (2) the duration of the exercise, (3) the state or type of training that the individual has engaged in, or both, and (4) the diet previously consumed. Due to their limited storage in the body and the relative ease with which these stores can be manipulated by combinations of diet and/or training, a knowledge of the dynamics of carbohydrate metabolism is an important component in the arsenal of knowledge for coaches and athletes.
Index Keywords: glycogen; article; carbohydrate diet; exercise; fat intake; glucose blood level; human; metabolism; muscle; physical education; physical stress; time; Blood Glucose; Dietary Carbohydrates; Dietary Fats; Exertion; Glycogen; Human; Muscles; Physical Education and Training; Physical Endurance; Time Factors

Title: ECONOMICAL PRECISION VOLTAGE REGULATOR.
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Authors with affiliations: Kapustin, G.A.; Perepukhov, M.V.
Abstract: An economical bipolar voltage regulator with a relative output voltage instability is described. The output voltage is variable within plus or minus (8. 5-25) v for a load current of 5-200 mA. The current consumed by the regulator circuit is less than equivalent to 1 mA. The described voltage regulator (VR) is designed to supply measuring units in galvanomagnetic measurements in pulsed magnetic fields of up to 400 kOe. In order to eliminate inductions through the supply circuits from a current pulse in a solenoid (up to 30 kA at up to 5 kv), the VR is supplied by an independent power source (storage battery or capacitor) during the pulse and from the line in the intervals between pulses. It was required that the output voltage U//o//u//t of the VR not vary by more than plus or minus 1 mv for a twofold variation of the voltage of the capacitor supply and that efficiency be high, in order to reduce the dimensions of the independent sources.
Index Keywords: CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES - Voltage; MINIMUM REGULATION CURRENT; PULSED MAGNETIC FIELDS; SOURCE OF ENERGY LOSS; VOLTAGE REGULATORS

Title: SOAKING UP THE SUN.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) has begun investigating the effectiveness of salt gradient solar ponds, which combine the collection and storage of the sun's thermal energy into a single operation. The TVA pond measures approximatedly half a hectare in surface area with four sloping sides tapering to a depth of three meters. It is filled with 12 million liters of water ad 2,000 tons of salt. An impermeable liner material prevents leakage of the briny solution into the surrounding ground. This fabric, produced from high tenacity industrial fibers of 'Dacron' polyester, is coated with a compound containing 'Elvaloy' resin modifier.
Index Keywords: POLYESTERS - Applications; TEXTILES - Applications; IMPERMEABLE LINERS; SALT GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: USERS' UNDERSTANDING OF A HEATING SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Univ of Hull, Ergonomics Research, Group, Hull, Engl, Univ of Hull, Ergonomics Research Group, Hull, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Crawshaw, C.M., Univ of Hull, Ergonomics Research, Group, Hull, Engl, Univ of Hull, Ergonomics Research Group, Hull, Engl; Dale, H.C.A., Univ of Hull, Ergonomics Research, Group, Hull, Engl, Univ of Hull, Ergonomics Research Group, Hull, Engl
Abstract: A study of 24 occupants of an apartment building provided with off-peak electric storage heating is reported. Reasonable living temperatures were obtained and at least qualified satisfaction with the system was general. However, there was poor understanding of how the system worked, especially the controls, some of which were either rarely used or not used appropriately; even the room thermostat was misused by most occupants. Reasons for this 'inefficiency' in controls are suggested, and the implications for design of domestic heating systems are discussed.
Index Keywords: APARTMENT HOUSES - Energy Storage; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; THERMOSTATS; 'ELECTRICAIRE'; HEATING

Title: Exercise and energy metabolism.
Authors with affiliations: Maddaiah, V.T.
Abstract: Most of the energy required for muscle contraction is generated by the splitting of ATP. Catabolism of carbohydrates to pyruvate and lactate by glycolysis (anaerobic) produces ATP needed during exercise of high intensity and short duration but the energy release is incomplete. The first step in the release of the remaining energy is the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA which is also formed from the oxidation of fatty acids particularly during sustained exercise. Acetyl-CoA is next oxidized in the tricarboxylic acid cycle producing the reduced forms of pyridine and flavin nucleotides. The hydrogens of the reduced nucleotides are transported in the form of electrons through the electron transport (respiratory) chain to molecular O2 to form H2O. The resulting free energy change is used to phosphorylate ADP to ATP. Enzymes of fatty acid oxidation, tricarboxylic acid cycle and respiration are located inside mitochondria. Energy status of cells can be described by the relative concentrations of adenine nucleotides (ATP, ADP and AMP) since the nucleotides act as allosteric modifiers of several key enzymes of energy metabolism. Energy is expended to synthesize and store fuel nutrients in utilizable forms (glycogen, triglycerides and proteins) and to maintain the storage forms in a dynamic steady state. The energy cost of such postprandial metabolic processes is defined as the "thermic" effect of food. Storage of dietary carbohydrates as adipose tissue triglycerides expends more energy than that of dietary fats. Overfeeding of certain individuals is known to burn more energy over and above that expected from the "thermic" effect and the process is referred to as "luxus consumption."(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate; creatine phosphate; enzyme; fatty acid; article; cell; citric acid cycle; energy metabolism; exercise; glycolysis; human; metabolism; mitochondrion; obesity; oxidation reduction reaction; oxidative phosphorylation; Adenosine Triphosphate; Cells; Citric Acid Cycle; Energy Metabolism; Enzymes; Exertion; Fatty Acids; Glycolysis; Human; Mitochondria; Obesity; Oxidation-Reduction; Oxidative Phosphorylation; Phosphocreatine

Title: Strains and stresses in the rock around and unlined hot water cavern
Affiliations: Swedish Rock Engineering Research Foundation, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Rehbinder, G., Swedish Rock Engineering Research Foundation, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: Hot water stored in an unlined rock cavern is an efficient energy storage. A research program has been carried out with a test plant at the city of Avesta, Sweden. The plant consists of a rock cavern, the volume of which is 15000 m3, which serves as an energy buffer in the district heating system of the city. The water is heated from a garbage incinerator located close to the cavern. During the first test period the temperature of the stored water has varied between 40°C and 95°C. The heating of the rock causes strains and stresses in the rock. The measurements show that the state in the rock does mainly respond to the average temperature and not to the fluctuations. The maximum thermal stress is 9 MPa occurring at the wall of the cavern. The heave of the ground is less than 5 mm. The development of stress and strain will continue after the first test period since thermal equilibrium was not reached during this period. © 1984 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: ROCK - Stresses; ROCK MECHANICS - Testing; STRAIN - Analysis; UNLINED HOT WATER CAVERN; TUNNELS AND TUNNELING

Abstract: 1. Investigations and calculations showed that the installation of equalizing racks in the outlet sections of draft tubes increases the operating efficiency of hydraulic machines and is expedient both in energy and economic respects. 2. To determine the actual positive effect, an equalizing rack should be installed at one of the operating HES or PSS and the necessary on-site observations and measurements carried out. © 1985 Plenum Publishing Corporation.

Authors: Govers T.R., Guyon P.M., Baer T., Cole K., Fröhlich H., Lavollée M.
Title: State-selected ion-molecule reactions: N2+(X, v″), N2+(A, v′) + Ar → N2 + Ar+
Affiliations: L.U.R.E., Université Paris-Sud, Batiment 209c, 91405 Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Govers, T.R., L.U.R.E., Université Paris-Sud, Batiment 209c, 91405 Orsay, France; Guyon, P.M., L.U.R.E., Université Paris-Sud, Batiment 209c, 91405 Orsay, France; Baer, T., L.U.R.E., Université Paris-Sud, Batiment 209c, 91405 Orsay, France; Cole, K., L.U.R.E., Université Paris-Sud, Batiment 209c, 91405 Orsay, France; Fröhlich, H., L.U.R.E., Université Paris-Sud, Batiment 209c, 91405 Orsay, France; Lavollée, M., L.U.R.E., Université Paris-Sud, Batiment 209c, 91405 Orsay, France
Abstract: The total, absolute cross sections for charge transfer between N2+(X, A, v) and Ar have been measured at 8, 14 and 20 eV center of mass translational energy. The internal energy of the N2+ ions was selected by threshold photoelectron-photoion coincidence using pulsed synchrotron radiation from the ACO storage ring. The vibrational levels investigated were v″ = 0-4 for the X state, and v′ = 0-6 for the A state. The data for the A state were corrected for the fraction of ions which fluoresced to the X state prior to reaction with Ar. The N2+(X, v″ = 0) state was found to be much less reactive (by a factor ≥ 10) than the other X-state levels, at all three translational energies. The levels N2+(A, v′ ≥ 3) were found to react with cross-sections which depend strongly on the relative translational energy. The data are interpreted in terms of the interaction between vibronic curves as discussed by Bauer, Fisher and Gilmore. This model accounts well for the low reactivity of the N2+(X, 0) level. It is proposed that the variation in the cross section of the N2+(A, v′ ≥ 3) + Ar reactions is a result of competition with a radiationless transition which converts N2+(A, v′) ions into N2+(X, v″) ions. © 1984.

Authors: Sakamoto R., Kamimoto M., Takahashi Y., Abe Y., Kanari K., Ozawa T.
Title: Investigation of latent heat-thermal energy storage materials. III. Thermoanalytical evaluation of pentaerythritol
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sakamoto, R., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Kamimoto, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Takahashi, Y., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Abe, Y., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Kanari, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Ozawa, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetry (TG) are used to evaluate pentaerythritol for latent heat-thermal energy storage materials. Pentaerythritol is a promising material from the viewpoints of latent heat and material cost. Moreover, it is a unique material because of the large heat of crystalline transition which is the property used. The transition behavior was observed by DSC, and the compatibility with some heat transfer fluids, which will be used in direct contact with pentaerythritol as a slurry, was also examined by keeping them in energy-stored state and then observing the heat of transition by DSC. Pentaerythritol is useful in the temperature range 150-200°C, and heat transfer fluids of hydrocarbon are suitable. © 1984.

Authors: Wahl F., Duscher R., Göbel K., Maichle J.K.
Title: Foundations of a Theory Concerning Hydrogen Centres in Metals
Source title: Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung - Section A Journal of Physical Sciences
Affiliations: Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wahl, F., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, Germany; Duscher, R., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, Germany; Göbel, K., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, Germany; Maichle, J.K., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, Germany
Abstract: The present work is an attempt to treat hydrogen storage in metals with the aid of field theoretical methods. Starting with the many-body Schrödinger equation, an adiabatic decomposition yields an electronic system, a protonic system and a host lattice system. We define a storage energy consisting of a lattice contribution and an electronic part. The latter one will be evaluated by the New Tamm-Dancoff (NTD) procedure. This formalism is a method to compute differences of eigenvalues in quantum mechanical problems. As an example we derive a one-particle equation describing a single hydrogen atom in a metal crystal. © 1984, Walter de Gruyter. All rights reserved.

Authors: Biscari C., Buon J., Montague B.W.
Title: Depolarizing effects of quantum fluctuations and the action of nonlinear wigglers on equilibrium polarization level
Affiliations: Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare dell'Università, Napoli, Italy; Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Orsay, France; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Biscari, C., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare dell'Università, Napoli, Italy; Buon, J., Laboratoire de l'Accélérateur Linéaire, Orsay, France; Montague, B.W., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: In high-energy storage rings the spin tune spread, proportional to the energy spread, becomes comparable to the distance between depolarizing resonances. In this work the effect of quantum fluctuations on the equilibrium polarization level is studied, by taking into account the energy spread. An enhancement depolarizing factor is obtained as result and the appearance of satellite synchrotron resonances. The use of a nonlinear wiggler (dipole-quadrupole and dipole-octupole) is proposed as a method for reducing the depolarizing effects. © 1984 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: 41.70; Particles in electromagnetic fields: classical aspects (including synchrotron radiation)

Title: Rutherford backscattering for measuring corrosion layers on glasses for long-term storage of radioactive waste
Affiliations: Commission of the European Communities, Joint Research Centre, Karlsruhe Establishment, European Institute for Transuranium Elements, Postfach 2266, Karlsruhe, D-7500, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Matzke, Hj., Commission of the European Communities, Joint Research Centre, Karlsruhe Establishment, European Institute for Transuranium Elements, Postfach 2266, Karlsruhe, D-7500, Germany
Abstract: The method considered safest for isolation of nuclear waste is vitrification (solidification in a glass or glassceramic matrix) with long-term storage in stable geological repositories. Borosilicate glasses are candidates for this purpose on a world-wide scale. Though it is very unlikely that water will ever have access to these repositories, the leaching (corrosion in aqueous solutions) of glasses is studied. Rutherford backscattering of beams of charged particles (e.g. He-ions of 2-3 MeV energy) is shown to be a versatile technique to study surface layers and to obtain information on their thickness and composition. The method is non-destructive and can be applied to layers with thicknesses in the range of about 0.1 to 2 μm. Results for nuclear waste glasses leached in H2O or in quinary salt solution (Q-brine) with and without presence of material from the metal container are presented. Presence of steel is shown to greatly enhance leaching rates by preventing glass components to become saturated in the leachant. © 1984 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Solar irradiance changes caused by g-modes and large scale convection
Affiliations: Laboratory for Planetary Atmospheres, Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, 20771, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wolff, C.L., Laboratory for Planetary Atmospheres, Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, 20771, MD, United States
Abstract: Solar irradiance measurements from the ACRIM experiment show a clear response to the rotation periods of g-mode oscillations (l = 1, 2, and 3) and their first harmonics. Peaks in the ACRIM spectrum at 16.6, 18.3, 20.7, 36.5, and ≃- 71 days all lie within about 1% of periods arising from g-mode rotation. This means that the g-modes are a fundamental cause of irradiance fluctuations. On time scales of months and less they modulate the irradiance by means of transient flows of global scale which they stimulate in the Sun's convective envelope. Dimensional arguments indicate that the flows carry up heat at an average rate ∼ 10-3L⊙ which is not in conflict with observed changes in the irradiance. Five additional tests for g-modes and large-scale convection are given. An instability is described which undermines diffusion models of sunspot energy storage. © 1984 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Title: Optimization of hydro energy storage plant problems by variational methods
Affiliations: Institut für Mathematik, Johannes Kepler Universtiät, Altenbergerstr. 69, Linz, A-4040, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Gfrerer, H., Institut für Mathematik, Johannes Kepler Universtiät, Altenbergerstr. 69, Linz, A-4040, Austria
Abstract: We consider the problem of controlling a hydro energy storage plant within a fixed period of time. Our objective is to maximize the energy production - weighted with the time dependent tariff rate - subject to the given technical restrictions and the influx. The resulting control problem is transformed by means of the maximum principle for the calculus of variations into an equivalent nonlinear optimization problem. © 1984 Physica-Verlag.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Variational Techniques; OPTIMIZATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Authors: Bauer W., Gfrerer H., Wacker Hj.
Title: Optimization strategies for hydro energy storage plants
Affiliations: Institut für Mathematik, Johannes Kepler Universität, Altenbergerstraße 69, Linz, A-4040, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Bauer, W., Institut für Mathematik, Johannes Kepler Universität, Altenbergerstraße 69, Linz, A-4040, Austria; Gfrerer, H., Institut für Mathematik, Johannes Kepler Universität, Altenbergerstraße 69, Linz, A-4040, Austria; Wacker, Hj., Institut für Mathematik, Johannes Kepler Universität, Altenbergerstraße 69, Linz, A-4040, Austria
Abstract: This paper is concerned with the optimization of base load production of hydro energy storage plants within a given time interval at a varying tariff rate. For three real world storage plants in Austria, each of them presenting some characteristic difficulty we discuss both mathematical models and numerical techniques. Beside classical techniques as Dynamic Programming and Simulation two newly developed nonlinear optimization methods were used. The first combines the Homotopy method with the active index set strategy, the second technique is based on decomposition and is strongly directed to the special structure of the problems. © 1984 Physica-Verlag.
Index Keywords: OPTIMIZATION; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: PERFORMANCE OF A 3-kw (250-A) ELECTROLYZER.
Source title: Research and Development Report - Canadian Electrical Association
Affiliations: Hydro-Quebec, Research Inst,, Varennes, Que, Can, Hydro-Quebec, Research Inst, Varennes, Que, Can
Authors with affiliations: Anon, Hydro-Quebec, Research Inst,, Varennes, Que, Can, Hydro-Quebec, Research Inst, Varennes, Que, Can
Abstract: The behavior of a 3 kw (250 A) electrolyzer has been established under a constant current close to 250 and variable input. The variable input consisted in a daily linear variation of current with time from 0 to 250 A and in a random variation of current generated by a rectifier coupled to a signal following the wind speed. The following parameters have been recorded or evaluated: the voltage drop for each cell, the total voltage for the five cells, the dc input current to the electrolyzer, the temperature of the cells, the quantity of hydrogen generated and the hydrogen content in oxygen. A wind turbine with a rating of several kilowatts could be coupled to an electrolyzer of the type studied after certain modifications to the hardware and in the operation conditions.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HYDROGEN FUELS - Manufacture; WIND TURBINES; ELECTROLYZER EFFICIENCY; WATER

Title: SOLAR PRODUCTION OF INDUSTRIAL PROCESS STEAM AT THE HOME CLEANING AND LAUNDRY CO.
Source title: U.S. Department of Energy Conservation and Solar Applications (Report) CS
Affiliations: Jacobs Engineering Group Inc,, Pasadena, CA, USA, Jacobs Engineering Group Inc, Pasadena, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Anon, Jacobs Engineering Group Inc,, Pasadena, CA, USA, Jacobs Engineering Group Inc, Pasadena, CA, USA
Abstract: This report presents the results of the operation and performance evaluation period at the Home Laundry Solar Industrial Process Heat Project at Pasadena, California. The installation comprises 6,496 ft**2 (603. 5 m**2) of linear parabolic trough concentrating collectors supplying solar thermal energy for use in laundry and dry cleaning processes. The solar plant was designed and built by Jacobs Engineering Group, Inc. as part of the U. S. Department of Energy Solar Industrial Process Heat Program. Solar thermal energy is supplied to a standard tube and shell generator to produce 100-110 psig (0. 69-0. 75 MPa) steam at a design flow rate of 935 lb/hr (424,1 kg/hr) for use in a commercial laundry. Production of domestic hot water at 160 degree F is an optional operations mode. The system is sized to provide 20 percent of the laundry's annual steam demand. The Data Monitoring and Control system monitors and controls the collection and delivery of solar thermal energy, and protects against equipment damage due to anamolous conditions such as high pressures or low flow.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING; HOT WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS; LAUNDRIES - Boilers; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; STEAM GENERATORS; DOMESTIC HOT WATER TANK; DRY CLEANING; HIGH TEMPERATURE STORAGE TANK; INDUSTRIAL PROCESS STEAM; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: SOLID PROGRESS WITH SOLID ELECTROLYTE BATTERIES.
Authors with affiliations: McNamee, Mike
Abstract: The sodium sulfur system commenced relatively recently in the late 60's and has been under continuous development since that time. This couple, now known as the 'Beta Battery', utilizes a solid ionically conducting electrolyte, most frequently a beta -Alumina. The beta -Alumina is a ceramic material requiring highly specialized mechanical and electrical properties and it is the reliability of this component i. e. , its ability to withstand service without fracturing, that has been a major development objective. Not all the development problems have been directly associated with the beta -Alumina; solutions have had to be found for the containment of the electrodes under adverse corrosion conditions at temperatures of 350 degree C. Interactions between various components have also impeded progress in the past and required the development of unique solutions. 95% of cells now survive 500 charge discharge cycles and the mean time to failure of cell populations has reached 3000 cycles. New designs have improved the cell volumetric energy density from 300 to 450 WHR/1.
Index Keywords: ALUMINA - Applications; ELECTRODES - High Temperature Effects; ELECTROLYTES - Physical Properties; BETA ALUMINA; BETA BATTERIES; ELECTRODE CONTAINMENT; SODIUM-SULFUR STORAGE BATTERIES; SOLID ELECTROLYTES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Abstract: Experimental studies carried out on a system containing a flat plate collector and a rock bed storage unit connected in series, called an 'augmented integrated rock system', are reported. This system finds applications in the domestic, agricultural, and industrial sectors. Experimental results for varying mass flow rate, effect of number of glazings, depth (thickness) of the rockbed, and use of night cover over the rock bed unit are discussed. The system was tested for 24 hours over a number of days.

Title: Performance of a new plane-grating grazing-incidence UHV monochromator
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Tanashi, Tokyo, 188, Japan; Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Roppongi, Tokyo, 106, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Suga, S., Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Tanashi, Tokyo, 188, Japan; Taniguchi, M., Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Tanashi, Tokyo, 188, Japan; Shin, S., Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Tanashi, Tokyo, 188, Japan; Sakamoto, H., Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Tanashi, Tokyo, 188, Japan; Yamamoto, M., Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Tanashi, Tokyo, 188, Japan; Seki, M., Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Tanashi, Tokyo, 188, Japan; Murata, Y., Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Roppongi, Tokyo, 106, Japan; Daimon, H., Institute for Solid State Physics, University of Tokyo, Roppongi, Tokyo, 106, Japan
Abstract: A UHV monochromator with an ion-beam etched plane laminar grating (1200 grooves/mm) is designed, constructed and installed at the third beam line of SOR-RING (a 0.38 GeV electron storage ring). By using four interchangeable pre-reflecting plane mirrors (incidence angles set to 88, 75, 70 and 35°, coated with gold or aluminum) and two interchangeable spherical focusing mirrors (88 and 83°), one can cover the photon energy region from 8 to 400 eV with low content of the higher order light and the stray light. The performance of this monochromator is checked by reflectance, photoemission and photoelectron diffraction experiments. © 1984.

Title: Thermal problems on high flux beam lines
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Avery, R.T., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: Wiggler and undulator magnets can provide very intense photon flux densities to beam line components. This paper addresses some thermal/materials consequences due to such impingement. The LBL/Exxon/SSRL hybrid-wiggler beam line VI [1] now nearing operation will be able to provide up to ∼ 7 kW of total photon power at planned SPEAR operating conditions. The first masks are located at 6.5 m from the source and may receive a peak power density (transverse to the beam) exceeding 20 kW/cm2. Significantly, this heat transfer rate exceeds that radiated from the sun's surface (7 kW/cm2) and is comparable to that if welding torches. Clearly, cooling and configuration are of critical importance. Configurations for the first mask, the movable mask and the pivot mask on this beam line are presented together with considerations of thermal stress fatigue and of heat transfer by conduction to water-cooling circuits. Some preliminary information on the heating of crystals and mirrors is also presented. For the future, many additional intense wiggler/undulator beam lines are contemplated at several storage rings. The design of these beamlines would be enhanced by faster and more accurate computational techniques. LBL is developing a computer code which will be capable of giving photon power densities onto impinged surfaces for a wide range of source and beam line parameters. These include electron beam energy, current, emittance and orbit deviations; wiggler/undulator length, period and magnetic field; photon energy and angular distribution; reflection/absorption at intermediate impinged surfaces; defining apertures and focusing by mirrors. Three-dimensional computer programs for temperature, stress and strain have been available for some years, but "user friendly" versions are being sought. Other items to pursue are also suggested. © 1984.
Index Keywords: STRESSES - Thermal; Thermal effects; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Castellano M., Cavallo N., Cevenini F., Masullo M.R., Patteri P., Rinzivillo R., Solimeno S., Cutolo A.
Title: Analytical and experimental analysis of the undulator radiation at finite distance as a function of the e-beam parameters
Affiliations: Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Napoli, Istituto di Fisica Sperimentale dell'Università, Napoli, Italy; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Napoli, Dipartimento di Elettronica dell'Università, Napoli, Italy

Abstract: The radiation emitted by the linear undulator installed on a straight section of the ADONE storage ring is studied both experimentally and theoretically. In particular, expressions are provided for the field at finite distance, based on the complex Fresnel integral. In addition, several expressions are derived for the average intensity pattern as a function of the electron beam divergence and energy spread. These formulae are used for analysing the spectral and angular patterns of the radiation measured from a distance of 20 m from the undulator origin. The excellent quality of the undulator and the negligible influence on the pattern of the electron beam divergence are confirmed by the satisfactory agreement of the measured radiation field with the computer-generated one. © 1984 Società Italiana di Fisica.

Title: Kinetics of Phase Transitions in the System Sodium Sulfate-Water

Inc., Richmond, VA., United States; Plgford, R.L., Institute of Energy Conversion and Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, Delaware 19716, United States, Department of Chemical Engineering, United States
Abstract: The rates of growth and solution of single crystals of sodium sulfate decahydrate and anhydrous sodium sulfate were measured under conditions of low driving force and low solution velocity past the crystal. The rates of growth and solution of sodium sulfate decahydrate were found to be controlled by the rates of heat and mass transport between the crystal surface and the bulk solution. The rate of growth of anhydrous sodium sulfate was controlled by the rate of incorporation of ions into the crystal lattice at the crystal surface. This information can be used to predict the rates of phase transitions in a system containing sodium sulfate and water, where the crystal populations, nucleation rates, and the fluid mechanics at the crystal surfaces are known. © 1984, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Muravitskii M.A., Gulyuk A.M., Lozovenko A.E.
Title: CHARGING CONTROL FOR ENERGY-STORAGE CAPACITORS.
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Authors with affiliations: Muravitskii, M.A.; Gulyuk, A.M.; Lozovenko, A.E.
Abstract: An arrangement is described for charging energy-storage capacitors with a control in the primary circuit of the power transformer which can eliminate the influence of magnetic biasing in the core and which also reduces the level of the interference that occurs during the operation of the thyristor commutator. A battery of capacitors having a capacity of 600 mu f is charged up to 2 kv in 5 sec. The voltage is adjustable over a range from 0. 8 to 2 kv. The voltage instability is less than 1% when the voltage varies by plus or minus 10%.

Authors: Müller M.F., Ris H., Ferry J.D.
Title: Electron microscopy of fine fibrin clots and fine and coarse fibrin films. Observations of fibers in cross-section and in deformed states
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Department of Zoology University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Department of Chemistry University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Müller, M.F., Department of Chemistry University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Ris, H., Department of Zoology University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Ferry, J.D., Department of Chemistry University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: Fine fibrin clots and coarse and fine fibrin films (both ligated and unligated), formed by shrinkage of clots in one dimension, were examined by electron microscopy. Specimens of clots were prepared by critical point drying and by embedding and sectioning; specimens of films were prepared by embedding and sectioning only. In the fine clots, network junctions appeared to be formed by fiber segments in which two or more protofibrils were gently twisted around each other for distances of the order of 200 nm and then diverged to give trifunctional branch points. This topology appeared to be preserved in the fine films. It is proposed that the strength of the junctions is primarily provided by the twisting topology, though reinforced by non-covalent bonding involving the B sites uncovered by thrombin. In coarse films, bundles of protofibrils, lying primarily in the film plane, had diameters of 40 to 200 nm and were gently twisted around each other to form thicker cables. Uniaxial stretching, up to 100%, of either fine or coarse film before fixing caused suprisingly extensive orientation of the protofibrils or bundles. However, random orientation was recovered if a stretched ligated film was allowed to retract to its original dimensions before fixing. In a stretched coarse film sectioned perpendicular to the stretch direction, fiber bundles could be seen in cross-section; these were roughly circular with scalloped edges. The changes with stretching and recovery are discussed in relation to possible mechanisms of deformation and elastic energy storage. © 1984.
Index Keywords: fibrin; animal cell; animal experiment; blood and hemopoietic system; cattle; electron microscopy; nonhuman; priority journal; ultrastructure; Animal; Blood Coagulation; Cattle; Clot Retraction; Fibrin; Microscopy, Electron; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Title: APPLICATION OF KINETIC MODELS AND ARRHENIUS METHODS TO PRODUCT STABILITY EVALUATION.
Affiliations: Cobe Lab Inc, Denver, CO, USA, Cobe Lab Inc, Denver, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Porterfield, R.Ira, Cobe Lab Inc, Denver, CO, USA, Cobe Lab Inc, Denver, CO, USA; Capone, James J., Cobe Lab Inc, Denver, CO, USA, Cobe Lab Inc, Denver, CO, USA
Abstract: Kinetic models and Arrhenius prediction methods, which presuppose a knowledge of the order and the energy of activation of the degradation reaction, have been used for many years to monitor the stability of pharmaceutical compounds. Very few studies, however, have investigated and stability characteristics of analytes in biological matrices such as human plasma or sera. Thus, the authors performed a detailed investigation of the stability of D-alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) using Kennon probability models coupled with data collected on 18 lots of human serum-based clinical chemistry controls. The order of SGPT's degradation pattern at both normal and elevated storage temperatures was estimated, as was SGPT's energy of activation.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Reaction Kinetics; ARRHENIUS METHODS; SHELF STABILITY; DRUG PRODUCTS

Title: MOLTEN SALTS. CRITICAL DATA EVALUATIONS.
Affiliations: Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst,, Cogswell Lab, Troy, NY, USA, Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Cogswell Lab, Troy, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Janz, George J., Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst,, Cogswell Lab, Troy, NY, USA, Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Cogswell Lab, Troy, NY, USA
Abstract: Critical data evaluations reported include the properties: density, surface tension, conductance, viscosity, diffusion, enthalpy of fusion, heat capacity, thermal conductivity, vapor pressure, and cryoscopic constant. Information and results on containment and corrosion, and data on safety and hazards are also examined. Database automation for access/interrogation by remote terminal is in progress. Calibration-quality reference data sets are a further concern and a 'round-robin' approach for upgrading data sets to this confidence level has been undertaken. Aspects of these tasks are discussed, and the data status for selected systems in advanced battery and energy storage concepts is briefly summarized.

Title: The role of zooxanthellae in the nutritional energy requirements of Pocillopora eydouxi
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, The University, Glasgow, G12 8QQ, United Kingdom; the Marine Laboratory, University of Guam, Guam, 96913, United States
Authors with affiliations: Davies, P.S., Department of Zoology, The University, Glasgow, G12 8QQ, United Kingdom, the Marine Laboratory, University of Guam, Guam, 96913, United States
Abstract: Previous studies have attempted to quantify the nutritional importance of zooxanthellae to the respiratory requirements of their host, from measurements of the 24 h photosynthesis to respiration ratio. This preliminary study explores an alternative approach by trying to account for the energy fixed in photosynthesis in terms of expenditure, storage and loss. The energy budget so derived for Pocillopora eydouxi suggests that about 51% of the photosynthetically fixed energy is used in respiration, 0.9% in growth and 48% is unaccounted for and presumably lost from the colony. By partitioning the energy budget, it is found that 24% of the respiration and 11% of the energy retained in growth is attributable to the zooxanthellae. It is postulated that nutritionally, a coral is analogous to an aphid in being supplied with a high carbon diet and in being obliged to excrete the excess, probably in the form of mucus. © 1984 Springer-Verlag.

Abstract: An experiment has been performed at the storage ring VEPP-4 using the MD-1 detector. The resonance depolarization method has been employed for the absolute calibration of the beam energy. This has allowed the accuracy of the mass measurement to be improved by a factor of ten. The following mass values of Υ{hooked}, Υ{hooked}′ and Υ{hooked}″ -mesons have been obtained: M(Υ{hooked})=9460.6±0.4 MeV, M(Υ{hooked}′)=10023.8±0.5 MeV, M(Υ{hooked}″)=10355.5±0.5 MeV. © 1984.

Abstract: Three soft x-ray monochromators at the Berlin electron storage ring BESSY are described: a plane grating monochromator (SX-700) for the photon energy range 9 eV to about 2000 eV at high resolution, a high energy toroidal grating monochromator which delivers high photon flux up to ~ 1000 eV at medium resolution and a double crystal monochromator for the range 800 eV to about 4000 eV. The first experimental results obtained with these instruments are presented: resonant photoemission from europium intermetallic compounds, SEXAFS spectra of oxygen on copper and Cls photoelectron spectra from gaseous CO including satellite structure up to 20 eV excitation energy. © 1984 SPIE.

Title: Possibility of enlarging x-ray exposure area with x-ray mirror or by electron beam vertical motion
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Fraunhofer-Institut für Festkörpertechnologie (IFT), Abteilung für Mikrostrukturtechnik (AMT), Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany; Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für, Synchrotronstrahlung m.b.H. (BESSY), Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Betz, H., Fraunhofer-Institut für Festkörpertechnologie (IFT), Abteilung für Mikrostrukturtechnik (AMT), Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany, Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für, Synchrotronstrahlung m.b.H. (BESSY), Lentzeallee 100, Berlin, D-1000, Germany
Abstract: High collimation of synchrotron radiation perpendicular to the orbital plane of the electrons in a storage ring results in only a small exposed stripe on the wafer. Typically, the height ranges between 0.5 and 1 cm. Two methods of enlarging the exposure field, dealt with in this paper, are the application of plane scanning X-ray mirrors and the stimulation of electron beam oscillations in the ring. Due to the considerable decrease in reflectivity with decreasing wavelength and increasing mirror angle, the usable reflection angles are limited to the grazing-incidence region below 2° in the case of X-ray lithography. The pure SiO2-mirror (Zerodur) used in the experiments has reflectivities above 80% at up to 1.5°. For the wavelengths in question (-1 nm). The theoretical values of the absorbed energy in the resist, depending on the glacing angle, have been compared with experimental results. From this dependence, the velocity profile of the mirror movement for attaining a homogeneous exposure can be derived. The preliminary experiments concerning surface degradation due to cracked hydrocarbons indicate that this factor is not as severe as previously expected in the case of the soft X- rays used in lithography. The alternative method of enlarging the exposed area, by stimulating electron oscillations in the storage ring, has also been investigated. The initial results show a practically- homogeneous exposure area 3 cm in height. A simple improvement in the control electronics for the additional steering magnets, which is being made at the moment, will at least double this area. Then, the exposable step-and-repeat field will amount to 6 x 6 cm2 with this specific method, which does not require any special arrangements in the beam line. © 1984 SPIE.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON BEAMS; INTEGRATED CIRCUIT MANUFACTURE; LITHOGRAPHY; ELECTRON BEAM WOBBLING; SCANNING X-RAY MIRRORS; STIMULATION OF ELECTRON OSCILLATIONS; STORAGE RING; X-RAY LITHOGRAPHY; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Authors: Ito F., Fujitsuka N., Hanaichi T.
Title: Effects of dantrolene and methylxanthines on the sensory nerve terminal of the frog muscle spindle
Affiliations: Department of Physiology, Nagoya University School of Medicine, Nagoya, 466, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ito, F., Department of Physiology, Nagoya University School of Medicine, Nagoya, 466, Japan; Fujitsuka, N., Department of Physiology, Nagoya University School of Medicine, Nagoya, 466, Japan; Hanaichi, T., Department of Physiology, Nagoya University School of Medicine, Nagoya, 466, Japan
Abstract: The application of 1.5-4 μM dantrolene decreased the threshold and the current sensitivity of the rhythmic hyperpolarizations that occur during depolarization of the sensory nerve terminal in the frog muscle spindle. The higher concentration provoked spontaneous rhythmic changes even without depolarization. Methylxanthines (5 mM caffeine, theophylline or pentylene-tetrazole) increased the threshold and the sensitivity. Electron microscopic observations of the dantrolene-treated spindles revealed numerous electron-dense deposits associated with the cytoplasmic membrane of the sensory terminals and with mitochondrial membranes. The deposits were found to contain K+ and Ca2+ by energy dispersive X-ray microanalysis. Electron-dense deposits containing Ca2+ were usually observed in the inner capsular space and in the mitochondria of the sensory terminals perfused by normal or high Ca2+ Ringer solutions. They were reduced in number following incubation with methylxanthines. The amplitudes of afferent spikes and the spindle potential were increased by methylxanthines in much the same way as by K+ channel blockers, suggesting that GK of the terminal membrane may be reduced by methylxanthines. We suggest that methylxanthines may modulate the terminal responses both as a K+ channel blocker and by enhancing the release of Ca2+ from a storage site, perhaps in the inner capsular space, whereas dantrolene has the opposite effect. © 1984.
Author Keywords: caffeine; dantrolene; frog muscle spindle; GC dependent oscillation

Authors: Yacout A.M., Gardner R.P., Verghese K.
Title: Cubic spline techniques for fitting X-ray cross sections
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Center for Engineering Applications of Radioisotopes, North Carolina State University, Box 7909, Raleigh, NC 27695-7909, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yacout, A.M., Center for Engineering Applications of Radioisotopes, North Carolina State University, Box 7909, Raleigh, NC 27695-7909, United States; Gardner, R.P., Center for Engineering Applications of Radioisotopes, North Carolina State University, Box 7909, Raleigh, NC 27695-7909, United States; Verghese, K., Center for Engineering Applications of Radioisotopes, North Carolina State University, Box 7909, Raleigh, NC 27695-7909, United States
Abstract: Cubic spline least squares fitting algorithms are developed for continous functions and functions with jump discontinuities. The cubic spline coefficients for incoherent and coherent scattering cross sections for elements from sodium through cobalt are reported for energies from 1 to 150 keV, and when two interior knots (three regions) are used they yield accuracies better than those obtined by a single cubic polynomial. Specialized discontinuous cubic spline functions are used to fit X-ray photoelectric cross sections to allow accurate fitting across the absorption edge discontinuities for a wide range of energies with a very simple function. Cubic spline coefficients for photoelectric cross sections of all elements in the atomic number range from 11 to 27 and in the energy range from 1 to 150 keV are reported. The cubic spline representation provides a computationally faster method of using X-ray cross sections than polynomial interpolation from discrete data sets and requires much less computer storage. © 1984.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Curve Fitting; X-rays

Authors: Layssac J., Pire B., Ralston J.P.
Title: Spin asymmetry in γe↑→e+2 jets: A laboratory for final state interactions
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik C Particles and Fields
Affiliations: Département de Physique Mathématique, USTL, Montpellier Cedex, F-34060, France; CERN, Geneva 23, CH-1211, Switzerland; Argonne National Laboratory, HEP Division, Argonne, 60439, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Layssac, J., Département de Physique Mathématique, USTL, Montpellier Cedex, F-34060, France; Pire, B., CERN, Geneva 23, CH-1211, Switzerland; Ralston, J.P., Argonne National Laboratory, HEP Division, Argonne, 60439, IL, United States
Abstract: We isolate final state interactions not parametrized by fragmentation functions and yet present in QCD O(αs) corrections to two-jet production in photon-longitudinally polarized electron scattering. Our calculation focuses on dynamical imaginary (absorptive) corrections that are absent in any tree diagrams. We explicitly demonstrate cancellation of imaginary infinities in the sum over graphs. The resulting asymmetry is predicted to be small. Such a quantity should be soon measured in experiments exploiting the naturally large electron polarization occurring in standard high energy storage rings. © 1984 Springer-Verlag.

Title: COMPUTER-GENERATED DEFECT REPORT SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Medtronic Inc, Energy Technology, Div, Minneapolis, MN, USA, Medtronic Inc, Energy Technology Div, Minneapolis, MN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kendall, John, Medtronic Inc, Energy Technology, Div, Minneapolis, MN, USA, Medtronic Inc, Energy Technology Div, Minneapolis, MN, USA
Abstract: Quality and reliability are of utmost importance in the manufacture of implantable life-support devices and systems. For this reason, quality-assurance engineering plays a major role in the medical device industry. At Energy Technology (a division of Medtronic), which produces power sources, hermetic seals, and polymer parts for implantable devices, use is made of an existing manufacturing data collection and computer storage system to identify and prevent the defects that result in product rejects. Since it is well known in quality engineering that a few vital defects account for most product rejects, the objective has been to identify these few with the least possible effort and then use available resources to prevent their recurrence.

Abstract: A free piston internal combustion engine is described as having several essential advantages, including the absence of side thrust force between piston and cylinder; the direct transmission of the power from gas to power transmission medium without a bearing which has to support large forces due to the gas pressure and the piston inertia; and the superior controllability of output torque and speed. In this paper, the kinematic behavior of the free piston of above mentioned hydraulic free piston engine is theoretically analyzed and the fundamental characteristics of the engine of this type are revealed.

Title: SOLAR PONDS: ALTERNATE ENERGY SYSTEMS.

Authors with affiliations: Newell, Ty A., Univ of Illinois at, Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, USA, Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, USA
Abstract: Salt-gradient solar ponds are becoming increasingly recognized as economically feasible systems for supplying thermal energy. Although many basic phenomena require research for improved understanding, both natural and man-made demonstrations of this system have proved its practical viability. The integral collection and storage of solar energy and the relatively passive control of solar ponds are key factors in its cost feasibility. In addition to its technological simplicity, the availability of basic materials (land, water, and salt) gives solar ponds a worldwide range of applications.

Abstract: The e+e--storage ring DORIS II provides polarized beams with polarizations up to 80% in the energy range of the Υ{hooked}′ meson. The method of resonance depolarization allows the average beam energy to be determined to a precision of ±0.1 MeV. An energy scan of the hadronic cross section over the resonance range with the detectors ARGUS and Crystal Ball determines the Υ{hooked}′ mass to be (10023.1 ± 0.4) MeV. © 1984.

Title: Multipurpose reservoir operation. 1. Monthly model for a single reservoir
Affiliations: Department of Land, Air and Water Resources, Department of Civil Engineering, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mariño, M.A., Department of Land, Air and Water Resources, Department of Civil Engineering, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Mohammadi, B., Department of Land, Air and Water Resources, Department of Civil Engineering, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: The Becker and Yeh monthly operation model, which maximizes the energy output of a reservoir system, has been extended to allow for maximization of both water and energy from the system. The model is a combination of parametric linear programming (used for month-by-month optimization) and dynamic programming (used for optimization over the 1-yr. operation period). The resulting operating policy is updated as new monthly inflow forecasts become available, thus incorporating the stochasticity of inflows. An iterative procedure is used to reduce the computation time and computer storage requirements. This efficiency allows the use of minicomputers which are less expensive than mainframe computers. The use of the model is illustrated for the Shasta reservoir (California Central Valley Project). © 1984.
Index Keywords: HYDROLOGY; MATHEMATICAL PROGRAMMING; STATISTICAL METHODS; OPERATING POLICY; RESERVOIRS

Authors: Kuczynski J.P., Milosavljevic B.H., Lappin A.G., Thomas J.K.
Title: Ion-pair complexes of methyl viologen and anionic solutes
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kuczynski, J.P., Department of Chemistry, University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States; Milosavljevic, B.H., Department of Chemistry, University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States; Lappin, A.G., Department of Chemistry, University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States; Thomas, J.K., Department of Chemistry, University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, IN 46556, United States
Abstract: Methyl viologen forms ion-pair complexes with anionic solutes such as EDTA, hexametaphosphate, acetate, citrate and sulfide ions. The luminescence properties of all complexes are similar, exhibiting an emission maximum centered about 520 nm and an excitation peak at 405 nm. The lifetime of the luminescence is on the order of 5 ns. For all complexes a new absorption band appears as a shoulder extending out to 500 nm. For the EDTA complex there is a strong pH dependence of both the intensity of the absorption and the stoichiometry of the complex suggesting that at pH values substantially greater than pKa3 of EDTA (10.2) a 2:1 complex (2MV2+:⋯ EDTA4-) is formed. At pH values significantly less than pKa3 of EDTA a 1 : 1 complex is formed (MV2+⋯HEDTA3-). Photoexcitation of the complexes leads to the formation of reduced methyl viologen. The data draw attention to complications in previous model systems for the storage of solar energy. © 1984.
