Authors: Carpentier R., Larue B., Leblanc R.M.
Title: Photoacoustic spectroscopy of Anacystis nidulans. III. Detection of photosynthetic activities
Affiliations: Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Carpentier, R., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Larue, B., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Leblanc, R.M., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, Trois-Rivières, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada
Abstract: Photosynthetic activities of Anacystis nidulans can be detected by photoacoustic spectroscopy. Algae treated by a photosynthetic inhibitor are used to provide the signal from the photochemically inactive sample. The results of these measurements correspond well with the activities which can be monitored by conventional biochemical assays. Acoustic data from A. nidulans are used to obtain the action spectrum for photochemical energy storage. It is concluded that phycocyanin harvests light for both photoreactions but that chlorophyll a molecules convey most of their excitation energy to photoreaction I. As judged from the relationship between the modulation frequency and the acoustic signal intensity, at least 60% of the photons absorbed at 630 nm perform photochemical work and about half of the useful energy is stored as stable products. Although it cannot be separated from the purely thermal effect, the contribution of modulated oxygen evolution to the acoustic signal of algae is estimated to be relatively small. Due to structural peculiarities, the opposite situation predominates in low frequency measurements performed with leaves from Impatiens petersiana. © 1984.
Index Keywords: chlorophyll; phycocyanin; article; Cyanobacterium; energy transfer; metabolism; methodology; oxidation reduction reaction; photochemistry; photosynthesis; spectroscopy; Chlorophyll; Cyanobacteria; Energy Transfer; Oxidation-Reduction; Photochemistry; Photosynthesis; Phycocyanin; Spectrum Analysis; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't

Authors: Askar'yan G.A., Ivanov V.A., Kossyi I.A., Nikuradze P.O., Sergeichev K.F.
Title: PLASMA-BURST CONVERSION OF MICROWAVE ENERGY INTO ELECTRICAL ENERGY WITH CAPACITANCE STORAGE; RESONANT PUMPING OF CIRCUIT OSCILLATIONS BY A PULSE TRAIN.
Source title: Soviet Technical Physics Letters (English Translation of Pis'ma v Zhurnal Tekhnicheskoi Fiziki)
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst, of General Physics, Moscow, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst of General Physics, Moscow, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Askar'yan, G.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst, of General Physics, Moscow, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst of General Physics, Moscow, USSR; Ivanov, V.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst, of General Physics, Moscow, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst of General Physics, Moscow, USSR; Kossyi, I.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst, of General Physics, Moscow, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst of General Physics, Moscow, USSR; Nikuradze, P.O., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst, of General Physics, Moscow, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst of General Physics, Moscow, USSR; Sergeichev, K.F., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst, of General Physics, Moscow, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Inst of General Physics, Moscow, USSR
Abstract: In this letter we report a study of the conversion efficiency when a capacitive energy storage is used. We used three microwave sources: a decimeter-range source with a single-pulse power p approximately equals mw (A), a centimeter-range source with a single-pulse power p approximately equals 100 kw (B), and an intermediate-range source with a repetition frequency up to 150 Hz and a pulsed power p approximately equals 300 kw (C). We measured the charging of the capacitor in one or several pulses; we also measured the rate of increase of the potential and the conversion efficiency at various numbers of pulses. We also studied the discharge of the capacitor into various types of loads. In experiments with microwave source C, we also studied a resonant pumping of the circuit by periodic microwave pulses with a repetition frequency near the resonant frequency.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; MICROWAVE GENERATION; PLASMAS - Production; BURST-ARC DISCHARGE; MICROWAVE-BURST CHARGING; OPTIMUM LOAD RESISTANCES; PLASMA BURST CONVERSION; RESONANT PUMPING; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION

Title: Growth and spawning of Urechis caupo (Echiura) in Bodega Harbor, California
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, University of California, Davis, 95616, California, United States; Bodega Marine Laboratory, Bodega Bay, 94923, California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Suer, A.L., Department of Zoology, University of California, Davis, 95616, California, United States, Bodega Marine Laboratory, Bodega Bay, 94923, California, United States
Abstract: Growth and spawning of the large, infaunal echiuran worm Urechis caupo Fisher and MacGinitie were studied at Bodega Harbor on the coast of central California, USA, from 1978 through 1981. In situ growth rates of marked worms were negatively related to initial size. Short-term, summer growth rates (volmo-1) of small worms (<80 ml) were greater than longer-term growth rates measured over several seasons (asesonal). Size-frequency distributions of worms sampled from two sites also suggested a seasonal growth pattern with relatively fast spring-summer growth and slower winter growth. However, larger worms sometimes lost volume during in situ growth experiments, and the loss was most pronounced during short-term, summer growth periods. It is suggested that energy used in burrow construction may have contributed to volume loss during short-term growth experiments. In contrast, longer-term, aseasonal growth rates were nearly always positive, and indicated that reproductive size (about 56 ml) could be reached within about 1.5 yr of recruitment, and a large size (about 158 ml) could be reached within about 6 yr. A seasonal pattern of spawning was observed during three consecutive years, as indicated by ripeness indices (storage organ dry weight ÷ body wall dry weight). At least two spawning episodes occurred annually: ripe gametes that accumulated in the storage organs during the summer and fall were spawned during the winter; gametes that accumulated during late winter and early spring were spawned during the spring or early summer. Worms were spawned-out by mid-summer. © 1984 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Nycthemeral variation in brain monoamines of Syrian hamsters: relation to activity and energy homeostasis
Affiliations: Department of Psychology, Center for Neurobiological Sciences, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rowland, N., Department of Psychology, Center for Neurobiological Sciences, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Abstract: No significant time-of-day variations were found in whole brain content of various monoamines and metabolites of sedentary Syrian hamsters. In a second experiment, norepinephrine and serotonin levels in diencephalon were higher in the morning than the evening of both sedentary and voluntarily exercising hamsters. In telencephalon, levels of most transmitters were elevated in the evening, with the most dramatic rises in the metabolites 3,4-dihydroxyphenylacetic acid and 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid. Again, in most instances, there was no difference between sedentary and exercise conditions. © 1984.
Author Keywords: brain neurotransmitters; fuel storage and mobilization; hamster; monoamine metabolites; nycthemeral changes; voluntary exercise

Title: Ten million frame per second IR videography
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Systems Design and Analysis, The BDM Corporation, 1801 Randolph Street, Albuquerque, NM, 87106, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goranson, R.W., Systems Design and Analysis, The BDM Corporation, 1801 Randolph Street, Albuquerque, NM, 87106, United States
Abstract: The Directed Energy Group at BDM Albuauercrue, in cooperation with and for the Directed Energy Directorate of the U.S. Army, MICOM, Redstone Arsenal, Huntsville, Alabama, has deve-loped a concept to achieve an effective ten million frames-per-second infrared videography for intensity distribution diagnostics of high power CO2laser pulses. The concept uses separate pyroelectric surfaces, either vidicons or self-scanning arrays, for each desired frame of data. The pyroelectric surface acts as analog storage of the image until such time as it can be digitized and read into data storage between laser pulses. Each pyroelectric surface is shuttered in sequence by Pockels cells, with adjust-able shutter “on” times and frame-to-frame timing as short as 100 nanoseconds. © 1984 SPIE.

Title: ASSESSMENT OF COMMERCIALLY AVAILABLE AND EXPERIMENTAL HYDROGEN ELECTRODES.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Charleston, Jo Ann, NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: NASA Lewis Research Center is currently involved in advanced cell component development for nickel-hydrogen cells and batteries. Long life, high energy density, improved performance and reliability are required for energy storage systems in future space missions. Commercially available as well as experimental hydrogen electrodes were assessed and compared to the state-of-the-art hydrogen electrode that is currently being used in the nickel-hydrogen batteries. These electrodes were evaluated by scanning electron microscopy and standard electrochemical polarization measurements. Production variables such as Teflon content and platinum catalyst loading were considered in order to assess various hydrogen electrodes with regard to the different electrode manufacturing processes.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Space Applications; Energy storage; HYDROGEN - Applications; NICKEL-HYDROGEN CELLS; TEFLON; Electrodes

Authors: Manzo Michelle A., Hoberecht Mark A.
Title: 37. 5-kw POINT DESIGN COMPARISON OF THE NICKEL-CADMIUM BATTERY, BIPOLAR NICKEL-HYDROGEN BATTERY, AND REGENERATIVE HYDROGEN-OXYGEN FUEL CELL ENERGY STORAGE SUBSYSTEMS FOR LOW EARTH ORBIT.
Authors with affiliations: Manzo, Michelle A.; Hoberecht, Mark A.
Abstract: Nickel-cadmium batteries, bipolar nickel-hydrogen batteries, and regenerative fuel cell storage subsystems were evaluated for use as the storage subsystem in a 37. 5 kw power system for space station. Design requirements were set in order to establish a common baseline for comparison purposes. The storage subsystems were compared on the basis of effective energy density, round trip electrical efficiency, total subsystem weight and volume, and life.
Index Keywords: FUEL CELLS - Space Applications; Electric batteries

Authors: Kawakita K., Nawata Y., Miyamoto H.
Title: Complex solar cooling system using wind energy for a college building.
Authors with affiliations: Kawakita, K.; Nawata, Y.; Miyamoto, H.
Abstract: Discusses experimental results obtained with a hybrid solar and wind power system for cooling a building. The cooling system comprises flat plate solar collectors, storage tank, two absorption chillers and an auxiliary boiler. The wind power system has 4 m diameter wind turbine induction generator, accelerator and torquemeter, with inverter. Presents performance characteristics of the absorption chiller, and solar collector, and analyses wind power system characteristics. The solar collector is less efficient at higher wind speeds. Periodical efficiency is about 19%. Simulation studies confirm that use of an auxiliary boiler wipes out any energy savings contributed by wind power.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning

Title: Solar electric systems.
Authors with affiliations: Warfield, G.
Abstract: The main part of the book is a series of noted lectures on solar electricity covering topics such as solar radiation principles, wind power solar cells, photovoltaics and solar thermal systems. The second part provides an overview of solar energy programmes and policies in the Arab World, with contributions from Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Egypt, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Syria, Sudan, Tunisia and The Yemen, Arab Republic. Topics include wind energy for water pumping, solar energy storage, sea water desalination and photovoltaic shallow water pumping. (C.J.U.)
Index Keywords: book

Authors: Kapellen D.R., Jamzadeh F., Frank A.A., Wang S.
Title: Analysis of energy-storage concepts for refuse collection trucks
Affiliations: International Harvester, General Motors Corp., United States; Detroit Diesel Allison, General Motors Corp., United States; Univ. of Wisconsin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kapellen, D.R., International Harvester, General Motors Corp., United States; Jamzadeh, F., Detroit Diesel Allison, General Motors Corp., United States; Frank, A.A., Univ. of Wisconsin, United States; Wang, S., Univ. of Wisconsin, United States
Abstract: Four hybrid powertrain designs are compared for a refuse collection truck driven over approach, loading and return segments of a representative route. Appropriate matching of component characteristics, drivetrain design and control strategy is shown to reduce fuel consumption by 39% to 56% compared to a conventional vehicle. Concurrently, brake usage is reduced 54% to 85% and the number of engine revolutions is reduced 66% to 84%. The four hybrid powertrains consist of Integrated and Add-On designs using flywheel or accumulator energy storage to recover braking energy and optimize engine efficiency. The average engine efficiency for each design is comparable and the vehicle fuel economy depends on the ability of each design and control strategy to minimize parasitic losses and use of the service brakes. Copyright © 1984 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Brakes; Energy storage; Engines; Fuel economy; Fuels; Hybrid powertrains; Trucks; Braking energy; Component characteristics; Design and control; Engine efficiency; Parasitic loss; Powertrain design; Service brakes; Vehicle fuel economy; Refuse collection

Title: An attempt to characterize future microcars
Authors with affiliations: Quilici, J.-F.
Abstract: Microcars can be defined as: enclosed and wheel supported vehicles, stable at standstill and (i) lighter than japanese K-class, kerb weight under 400kg and (ii) 2-seaters compatible with suburban traffic. After notice of significant past and present designs, the environment, function and anatomy of microcars are examined and compared to light japanese cars and leaning 3-wheelers. Considerations about dynamic data: starting, braking and transverse accelerations; tire and air resistances; safety, allow gross evaluation of dimensions, of positioning track and drive (FWD, 3-wheeler), of power and transmission choice (CVT, energy storage), of brake location and suspension and/or steering specific design.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Magnetic levitation vehicles; Air resistance; Dynamic data; Past and present; Automobiles

Authors: Bradley J.E., Wu C.L., Derr J.H.
Title: AC electric dynamometer system for end-of-line engine hot test
Affiliations: Research Staff, Ford Motor Company, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bradley, J.E., Research Staff, Ford Motor Company, United States; Wu, C.L., Research Staff, Ford Motor Company, United States; Derr, J.H., Research Staff, Ford Motor Company, United States
Abstract: An AC electric motor drive system has been evaluated as a means of engine loading for production engine hot testing. It has been demonstrated that an 80% reduction in test cycle stabilization time is possible when compared with the water brake dynamometer that is commonly used in production engine testing. Hot testing is normally a bottleneck in engine assembly, and the number of test stands is a direct function of the length of the test cycle. The steady state cycle that is used for engine testing may be reduced by quickly stabilizing the speed/load settings. The cycle may be further reduced by shortening the duration of the steady state sampling condition when the speed/load setting is held more accurately (fewer samples are required).[1,2] The AC drive demonstrated a set point stabilization time of 4 seconds or less and speed control accuracy of 0.25%. The drive system evaluated is an AC adjustable speed drive with adjustable frequency static conversion. The drive will absorb power from the engine and deliver it to the AC power line through automatic regeneration as well as motor the engine as required. The transition from motoring to absorption is automatically controlled. Speed is regulated with the AC motor and torque is regulated with the engine via the throttle. Advantages of the AC drive; in addition to fast stablizaton time, include: energy savings due to regeneration, elimination of the need for a seperate starting system, ability to measure frictional torque, more accurate timing setting and prevention of green engine stall-out during rapid speed/load changes. Data in this paper include speed and torque control results with an eight-cylinder 5.0L and four-cylinder 1.6L and 2.3L engines in both steady state and transient operations. Comparisons are made with a water brake test system. Copyright © 1984 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: AC motors; Brakes; Digital storage; Dynamometers; Electric drives; Electric lines; Energy conservation; Engines; Speed; Stabilization; Adjustable frequency; Adjustable speed drives; Automatic regeneration; Electric motor drives; Sampling conditions; Set-point stabilization; Stabilization time; Steady state and transients; Variable speed drives

Title: Regenerative braking in diesel-powered Urban Buses
Affiliations: Polytechnic Institute of New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Slutsky, S., Polytechnic Institute of New York, United States; Levi, E., Polytechnic Institute of New York, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the results of a study on a pneumatic energy storage system for on-vehicle applications. These are: 1.The 4-stroke diesel engine can be adapted to perform the additional functions of compressor and expander. With the exception of the storage tank, the regenerative braking is accomplished without further increase in weight and cost of the vehicle. 2.The number of miles traveled per gallon of fuel consumed in High Prformance Urban Route Cycle by a heavy urban bus or by a light school bus are increased by a factor of about three. Similar savings of fuel can be expected for a taxi. 3.The reduction in emissions is expected to equal or exceed the reduction in fuel consumption. © 1984 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Buses; Diesel engines; Fuels; Taxicabs; Trucks; Pneumatic energy; School bus; Storage tank; Urban bus; Vehicle applications; Regenerative braking

Title: Geomagnetic services: Real-time alerts, data, and disturbance predictions
Affiliations: NOAA/Space Environment Lab., United States
Authors with affiliations: Joselyn, J.A., NOAA/Space Environment Lab., United States; Carran, K.L., NOAA/Space Environment Lab., United States
Abstract: The Space Environment Services Center (SESC), jointly operated by NOAA and the U.S. Air Force, offers data, alerts, and forecasts on solar activity and the effects of that activity on spacecraft and a variety of terrestrial systems. In particular, the geomagnetic field responds to variations in the solar wind and severe disturbances (geomagnetic storms) can result. Auroras are a familiar result of geomagnetic activity, but the same solar-terrestrial interaction which drives the auroras induces currents in power lines, pipelines, and cables and can compromise geomagnetic survey expeditions and high-frequency radio communications and radars. Severe effects on spacecraft include electrical charging and increased satellite drag. Even homing pigeons and other migratory creatures that rely on the geomagnetic field as part of their intrinsic navigation systems can become disoriented and permanently lost during storms. Recently, the SESC inaugurated a new data dissemination system. Users may now continuously access our real-time data base by receiving a broadcast via the Westar IV communications satellite. The earth station consists of a small, 2-ft diameter dish antenna coupled to an equally portable controller which has a versatile RS232C interface. The earth station can be purchased for approximately $3000 or can be leased. © SPE All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Navigation systems; Parabolic antennas; Radio communication; Satellite ground stations; Solar energy; Storms; Communications satellite; Disturbance prediction; Electrical charging; Geomagnetic activities; Geomagnetic surveys; High frequency radios; Solar terrestrial interactions; Terrestrial systems; Geomagnetism

Title: Coal-water-methanol slurries: viscometric properties and the effects of coal type.
Authors with affiliations: Ekmann, A.C.; Ekmann, J.
Abstract: A plot of viscosity measurement for coal/water/methanol mixtures vs. percent methanol in the liquid indicates that the visccosities of both coal/water and coal/alcohol slurries are increased by the addition of the second liquid. The viscometric properties of these coal/water/methanol slurries are important in the utilization of both coal/water and coal/alcohol slurries. The addition of methanol to a coal/water mixture may eliminate the need for combustion air preheat and will inhibit freezing during storage. Alternatively the cost of a coal/methanol fuel will be reduce if low grade methanol (which contains water) is used. However, significant increases in fuel viscosity could cause handling probelsm. Initial viscosity measurements were made on water methanol slurries in support of a combustion test programme at the Pittsburgh Energy Technology Center involving coal/water/methanol fuels containing 60 wt% Pittsburgh seam coal. Slurries of ground glass were evaluated for comparison; here too, a viscosity maximum was observed, although the peak occurred at a methanol concentration somewhat lower than it occurs in the pure liquid mixtures. Also for comparison, slurries of Pittsburgh coal in water/ethylene glycol mixtures were evaluated viscometrically, and the relationship between viscosity and percent ethylene gylcol was compared to the relationship for the pure liquids. In both slurries and liquid mixtures, viscosities increased steadily as percent ethylene glycol was increased, with the maximum occurring when the liquid contained no water. Common predictive correlations for suspension viscosity were examined and appeared to be inadequate. The magnitudes and locations of these viscosity maxima for the coal slurries relative to the various liquid mixtures are related to the physical and the chemical properties of the coals, although the relationships are not readily quantifiable. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Coal-water-methanol slurries: viscometric properties and the effects of coal type.
Authors with affiliations: Ekmann, A.C.; Ekmann, J.
Abstract: A plot of viscosity measurement for coal/water/methanol mixtures vs. percent methanol in the liquid indicates that the visccosities of both coal/water and coal/alcohol slurries are increased by the addition of the second liquid. The viscometric properties of these coal/water/methanol slurries are important in the utilization of both coal/water and coal/alcohol slurries. The addition of methanol to a coal/water mixture may eliminate the need for combustion air preheat and will inhibit freezing during storage. Alternatively the cost of a coal/methanol fuel will be reduce if low grade methanol (which contains water) is used. However, significant increases in fuel viscosity could cause handling probelsm. Initial viscosity measurements were made on water methanol slurries in support of a combustion test programme at the Pittsburgh Energy Technology Center involving coal/water/methanol fuels containing 60 wt% Pittsburgh seam coal. (from authors' abstract)

Title: 5 major energy storage and hydroelectric projects.
Abstract: The details of five major energy storage and hydroelectric projects, undertaken by the Harza Engineering Company, Illinois, U.S.A. are presented. They are: the Guri Hydroelectric Project, Venezuela; Rea Shah Kabir Project, Iran; Seneca Reservoir, Pennsylvania, U.S.A.; Susitna Hydroelectric Project, Alaska. Details of dam construction, reservoir features, dimensions and costs are presented for the first two projects. (A.J.)

Title: The feasibility of operating a system of flood control dams for dynamic benefits.
Authors with affiliations: Hunt, R.T.
Abstract: The assessment of the feasibility of using a system of flood control dams in a large river basin for hydropower storage reservoirs is described. The practicality of developing hydroelectric power facilities at ten lock and dam sites was investigated. The study also examines the optimization of energy output at these plants by releasing stored water from the flood control (storage) reservoirs during peak electrical consumption periods to augment normal river flow. A preliminary economic screening analysis was also performed. The results of the feasibility study show that the use of such flood control dams could not be justified for hydropower facilities. (from author's abstract)

Title: Operational flexibility of various designs of pumped storage plants.
Authors with affiliations: Grein, H.L.; Jaquet, M.
Abstract: The dynamic benefits of pumped storage consist of the ability to operate at variable energy output in the generating mode, to consume surplus power in the pumping mode and to change quickly from one mode of operation to the other. Various designs of machinery and plant conceptions such as single stage regulated and multistage regulated and unregulated reversible pump turbines, as well as tandem units with different auxiliary machines, were developed and put into operation. The most common plant design operations are described and changeover times from one mode of operation to various others are presented along with the estimated shortest possible amount of time for each plant conception. The consequences of dynamic duties are low and high cycle stresses in many parts of the machinery and may cause fatigue if they have not been designed to operate at a sufficiently high number of cycles. (A)

Title: AE characteristics during hydrostatic tests of oil storage tanks repaired.
Authors with affiliations: Sasaki, H.; Inagaki, M.
Abstract: To evaluate the ability of acoustic emission techniques for diagnosis of structural integrity of oil storage tanks, 5 hydrostatic tests were monitored with a multi channel AE measuring system. The tanks are in practical use in petroleum and electric power corporations. They are made of mild steel, and their capacities are from 1000 kl to 25,000 kl. The hydrostatic tests were performed after repairing bottom parts. AE data was recorded with a multi channel data recorder and the analysis of this data was performed in the laboratory. AE parameters analyzed are event rate, peak amplitude distribution, signal source location, average energy per event. Using those parameters, the following AE characteristics during hydrostatic tests were investigated: (1) Time variation of AE activities. (2) AE source location. (A)
Index Keywords: Condition monitoring; storage vessel

Title: Direct and remote coupling of wind turbines to heat pumps and other mechanical devices. Final report.
Authors with affiliations: Rogers, W.E.
Abstract: This research set out to find alternative uses for wind power other than dumping the excess energy into the local grid. The alternatives investigated were space conditioning, and the generation of compressed air to power tools and other equipment which can be located at distant points from the wind turbine. Various methods of storage of the energy were considered since often the availability to power does not match the need for it. However, as time has permitted, the limitation of purchased wind hardware has been augmented by the company's own designs and the initial research has been conducted. Contrary to initial speculation, the economics of using wind energy economically without the use of the local grid is unattractive today due to the high costs of storage. (from author's abstract)

Title: 25 KW Autonomous wind-diesel system with transistor convertors and accumulator storage. A progress report.
Authors with affiliations: Holmblad, L.; Linders, J.
Abstract: This paper describes an autonomous wind/diesel system with energy storage under development at The Department of Electrical Machines and Power Electronics, Chalmers University of Technology. This system is the base for a wind/diesel study in collaboration with Risoe National Laboratories, Denmark. The components of the system are described: a windmill with an asynchronous generator, a power regulating unit, an accumulator, two convertors, a diesel engine with a synchronous generator and a computer control system. The control strategy is described: the frequency and the voltage control, the accumulator control, the diesel start/stop strategy and the wind power optimation. (A)
Index Keywords: power; Wind

Title: Ontario Ministry of Energy wind power program.
Authors with affiliations: Stewart, B.S.
Abstract: Describes the wind power programme in Ontario, Canada. The research and development focusses on hybrid (wind/diesel) or stand alone systems for remote communities. Notes success of the Sudbury 100 kW wind/diesel project and outlines future developments. Battery storage is being studied for wind power (stand alone) systems. Notes a study in a cold, northern site. (C.J.U.)

Title: Problems and recommendations for wind energy development in Hawaii.
Authors with affiliations: Neill, D.R.; Richards, H.M.
Abstract: Discusses wind power potential and prospective development in Hawaii. New facilities include the Kahua wind farm with 198, 17 kW Jacobs turbines for 3.4 MW peak output. Describes plans of other sites. The principal technical issues are the reliability of wind power and utility interface problems. Reports briefly the August 1984 HNEI Wind Energy Technical Workshop. Considers the institutional and environmental issues, financial and investment aspects. Notes the Wind Energy Battery Storage project and research on nonutility applications of wind power. (C.J.U.)

Title: European Communities oil and gas technological development projects. Second status report.
Abstract: Details of EEC development projects are listed for the topics of geophysics and prospecting; drilling, production systems; secondary and enhanced recovery; environmental influence on offshore; auxiliary ships and submersibles; pipeline laying; transport natural gas technology; energy source; storage, and miscellaneous categories. Details of the Community Energy Research and Development Strategy, implementation and overall results each year since 1975 are summarized. Each individual project listed contains information concerning contractors, aim of the project, a brief description and whether it is still in progress or not. Results and applications are summarized where available. (A.J.)

Title: Impact of pumped storage operation on economic resource commitment.
Authors with affiliations: Adam, P.J.; Neill, G.V.
Abstract: The full benefits of a pumped storage facility can only be evaluated within the context of full system operations over the expected pattern of hourly load requirements. The operating benefits are found during both on peak and off peak times. On peak beneftis are straightforward and represent the fuel savings due to displacement of high fuel cost by base unit energy which was generated and stored during off peak periods. Off peak benefits are due to three factors: the improvement in operating efficiency of baseload units; the improvement in system heat rate because of the increase in off peak load; and a reduced level of unit commitment to meet spinning and operating reserve levels. (A)

Authors: Allen R.D., Doherty T.J., Kannberg L.D.
Title: Underground pumped hydroelectric storage.
Authors with affiliations: Allen, R.D.; Doherty, T.J.; Kannberg, L.D.
Abstract: Underground pumped hydroelectric energy storage was conceived as a modification of surface pumped storage to eliminate dependence upon fortuitous topography, provide higher hydraulic heads, and reduce environmental concerns. A UPHS plant offers substantial savings in investment cost over coal fired cycling plants and savings in system production costs over gas turbines. Potential location near local centres lowers transmission costs and line losses. Environmental impacts is less than that for coal fired cycling plant. The inherent benefits include those of all pumped storage (i.e. rapid load response, emergency capacity, improvement in efficiency as pumps improve, and capacity for voltage regulation). A UPHS plant would be powered by either a coal fired or nuclear baseload plant. The economic capacity of a UPHS plant would be in the range of 10000 to 3000 MW. This storage level is compatible with the load levelling requirements of a greater metropolitan area with population of 1 million or more. The technical feasibility of UPHS depends upon excavation of a subterranean powerhouse cavern and reservoir caverns within a competent, impervious rock formation, and upon selection of reliable and efficient turbomachinery, pump turbines and motor generators, all remotely operable. (A)

Title: Electric power generation: Tidal and wave power. 1970-February, 1984 (Citations from the Engineering Index Data Base)
Abstract: This bibliography contains citations concerning the use of tidal and wave energy for the generation of electric power. The engineering and economic aspects are emphasized. Theoretical analysis of the power plant potential of selected sites around the world is presented. The combination of tidal power with pumped storage is also included. This bibliography is only available from N.T.I.S. (A)

Title: Reservoir system management for hydropower.
Authors with affiliations: Dotson, H.W.
Abstract: Describes use of the HEC-5 computer program (simulation of Flood Control and Conservation Systems) in modelling the Cumberland River System for evaluation of reservoir operating criteria. Nine existing hydroelectric power station projects are involved, though only four have significant storage for power generation. A 27 year historical period was chosen for simulation. Describes reservoir definition and lists levels and corresponding general operating criteria used. Five system simulations were made, with different methods of hydroelectric power simulation. The simulation resulting in the best estimate of full existing system utilization used the SEPA power rule curve for individual site energy requirements and the determined dependable system energy for system requirements. (C.J.U.)
Index Keywords: multi-purpose; reservoir

Title: First experimental results for an absorption heat pump coupled to an energy roof.
Issue: (eds.), Bristol, U.K. Bristol Univ., 1984, Session 2, Paper 2.11, p.2.11-12.11-7. (ISBN 0-86292-138-
Authors with affiliations: Lazzarin, R.M.; Schibuola, L.
Abstract: An experiment was carried out at Musile di Piave near Venice supported by the Commission of the European Communities Contract EEA-4-047-I(S) in order to study the performance of an ammonia water absorption heat pump coupled either to a vertical tube earth seasonal storage or to an energy roof. During summer the energy roof recharges the storage. The plant which is described, is monitored so that it is possible to evaluate both absorption h.p. and energy roof performances under different meteorological conditions. The experimental results can be used to give project sizing suggestions and in adjusting the estimates in full simulation of systems under different conditions. (from paper)
Index Keywords: Heat transfer

Authors: Mahrt L., Pan H., Paumier J., Troen I.
Title: A boundary layer parameterization for a general model.
Authors with affiliations: Mahrt, L.; Pan, H.; Paumier, J.; Troen, I.
Abstract: A two-layer model of soil hydrology is developed from the basic soil moisture transport equations. The thin upper layer responds to short term evaporation. A thick lower layer includes the root zone and longer term water storage. The model is tested against a high resolution soil hydrology model. Simple transpiration and canopy interception models are also included in the surface water budget. A surface energy balance is employed. Fluxes from the surface to the atmosphere are formulated with a stability-dependent bulk aerodynamic relationship and a stability dependent Penman relationship. The latter is evaluated with the Wangara data set. The model of the atmospheric boundary layer uses a stability-dependent, height dependent eddy diffusivity which provides for countergradient convective transport. Boundary layer growth is modelled with a bulk Richardson number which is generalized to include purely convective boundary layer growth. The model development emphasizes self-consistency and reduction of the number of velocity scales compared to previous models of this type.-from STAR, 22(24), 1984
Index Keywords: atmospheric boundary layer; moisture transport; soil hydrology

Title: Natural phenomena hazards modeling project: extreme wind- tornado hazard models for Department of Energy sites.
Authors with affiliations: Coats, D.W.
Abstract: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) has developed wind hazard models for the Office of Nuclear Safety (ONS), Department of Energy (DOE). The work is part of a three phase effort aimed at establishing uniform building design criteria for seismic and wind hazards at DOE sites throughout the US. In Phase 1, LNL gathered information on the sites and their critical facilities, including nuclear reactors, fuel reprocessing plants, high level waste storage and treatment facilities, and special nuclear material facilities. In Phase 2, development of seismic and wind hazard models, was initiated. These hazard models express the annual probability that the site will experience an earthquake or wind speed greater than some specified magnitude. This report summarizes the final wind/tornado hazard models recommended for each site and the methodology used to develop these models.-from STAR, 22(20), 1984
Index Keywords: building design; nuclear reactors; seismic hazard; United States; wind hazard models

Title: Windmills for rural water supplies.
Authors with affiliations: Ewens, M.
Abstract: Describes the requirements for a durable low maintenance wind powered water pump for rural Botswana. The Rural Industries Innovation Centre (RIIC) collaborated with the Intermediate Technology Development Group (IT Power) in development of a suitable rotation windmill. Examines operational aspects such as the uneven distribution, need for storage, and pump maintenance. Lists the advantages rotary (centrifugal and positive displacement) offer over reciprocating pumps, and discusses the reasons why Mono pumps were selected. By changing the pumps connection to the rotor during operations more energy is available for pumping water, and thus the low pump efficiency is tolerable. Describes the RIIC design scheme. (C.J.U.)

Authors: Atwood R., Green J., Lipman N.H., Infield D., Magraw J., Forbes R., Percival M., Warner G.
Title: The isolated wind system project at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory.
Authors with affiliations: Atwood, R.; Green, J.; Lipman, N.H.; Infield, D.; Magraw, J.; Forbes, R.; Percival, M.; Warner, G.
Abstract: Discusses a multi-disciplinary project on integration of a wind turbine supplying an isolated electricity network fed from diesel sets. Theoretical work involves development of logistic models, study of stability problems and optimum control policies. Phase 1 of the experimental work examines component pairs of the system, Phase 2 studies operation of an integrated wind/diesel system (diesel continuously running) and Phase 3 studies a system which permits diesel starts and stops, with the fast response dump load and probably a storage medium. Lists the monitoring equipment attached to the 9 m diameter (6 kw MISTRAL turbine. and outlines measurement of electrical machine parameters. Fuel consumption wear (in different operating modes) and transient response of the diesel sets will be studied. Presents results from the computer logistic modelling, which indicate that short term energy storage is necessary. (C.J.U.)

Title: Recent developments of wind energy utilization in The Netherlands.
Authors with affiliations: Beurskens, H.J.M.; Piepers, G.G.
Abstract: Describes wind power research and development activities in The Netherlands, under the National Development Programme NOW-2. Large scale applications studied includes the 10 MW demonstration wind farm, connection to the grid and storage, and design of a large 1.3 MW wind turbine. A test station exists at Petten for small wind turbines. Commercial development to presently hampered by economic and local government restraints. Outlines some test station results and examines briefly commercial applications and economic properties for wind power development.

Authors: Schainker R., Nakhamkin M., Stange J.R., Giannuzzi L.F.
Title: Turbomachinery engineering and optimizaton for 25 MW and 50 MW compressed air energy storage systems.
Authors with affiliations: Schainker, R.; Nakhamkin, M.; Stange, J.R.; Giannuzzi, L.F.
Abstract: Results of engineering and optimization of 25 MW and 50 MW turbomachinery trains for compressed air energy storage (CAES) power plant application are presented. Submitted by equipment suppliers, proposals are based on an analysis of the commercially available equipment. Performance data and budget prices indicate that the CAES power plant is one of the most cost effective sources of providing peaking power and load management. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Reception of LNG at Gaz de France's methane terminals (unloading, analysis, metering).
Authors with affiliations: Danan, J.; Flesch, E.
Abstract: Describes procedures at the LNG Reception Terminals of Montoir-de-Bretagne in France. There are two wharfs capable of handling 125,000 m SUP 3 tankers, and each wharf has a set of five articulated arms. Storage is in 120,000 m SUP 3 membrane tanks (Technigaz) with self supporting tank and safety features. Describes recovery, gasification, cryogenic pipelines and discharge operations. Details the method used for collecting and analysing gas samples. The energy value of an LPG shipment is based on the level of LNG in the methane carrier tanks, average temperature and chromatographical analysis. Discusses flow meter turbines and ultrasound flow meters. (C.J.U.)

Title: The sodiumsulphide/water system as a chemical heat pump used for long term energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Dyrnum, O.S.
Abstract: Test results show that charging the system last for 200 hours at a charging temperature at 80 DEGREE C and a condenser temperature at 15 DEGREE C. Discharging the system was carried out at rates of 25 and 70 W and lasted for 140 and 50 hours respectively, both at a discharging temperature of 50 DEGREE C. After 3 cycles the energy turn over raised to 90% of the theoretically value due to maturing and stabilizing of the absorbent material. The system is working well within its limitations, and has a quick response to changes in discharging rates but much of the stored energy is required to heat the system from storage temperature to working temperature and much energy is lost to the surroundings through the surface of the storage tank. (from author's abstract)
Index Keywords: Heat transfer

Title: High performance heat pipes for a latent heat thermal energy storage application.
Authors with affiliations: Abhat, A.
Abstract: The present paper describes the results from experimental investigations with a copper/water and an aluminium/ammonia heat pipe for a proposed latent heat storage system. Both heat pipes, outer diameter 40 mm length, 3070 mm were tested within the temperature range 10-70 DEGREE C in three operation modes that simulated the charging, discharging and simultaneous charging and discharging of the latent heat store. The steady state heat transport capability of the heat pipes as a function of the driving temperature potential for heat flow, as well as the influence of other relevant parameters on heat pipe performance, is discussed. Some comparisons with previous data from a 20 mm o.d., 3070 mm long copper/water heat pipe developed for the same application are provided. (A)

Authors: Kutsuna H., Akagawa K., Mizuno S., Matsui N.
Title: Thermosyphon heat pipes for long-term underground storage system of solar energy.
Authors with affiliations: Kutsuna, H.; Akagawa, K.; Mizuno, S.; Matsui, N.
Abstract: Thermosyphon heat pipes have been applied to extract heat from warm ground for a long term underground storage system of solar energy. Both laboratory and field tests were carried out. It was found that the room temperature of a greenhouse was about 6 DEGREE C when average ground temperature was about 25 DEGREE C. This field test result quantitatively agreed with the laboratory test. This system provides desirable cultivation conditions for tomatoes in winter.

Title: Equivalent stiffness and damping coefficients for squeeze film dampers.
Authors with affiliations: Hahn, E.J.
Abstract: Analyses of multi degree of freedom rotor bearing system incorporating non linear elements, such as squeeze film dampers, generally necessitate time consuming transient solution. Consequently, it is often too expensive to carry out parametric design studies on such systems. This article presents a general technique for linearizing the non-linear element forces using equivalent stiffness and damping coefficients based on energy dissipation and energy storage release concepts. The approach is illustrated and tested for both centrally preloaded squeeze film dampers and for squeeze film dampers without centralizing springs under a combination of unidirectional and unbalance loading. The results predicted by using such equivalent stiffness and damping coefficients agree quite well with those obtained from the full transient solution, even where the undirectional load exceeds the dynamic load and the damper is operating at high eccentricity. An interative procedure is proposed which, with the aid of such stiffness and damping coefficients, should significantly reduce the computation time presently needed to carry out parametric design studies on general multi degree of freedom systems incorporating non-linear elements such as squeeze film dampers. (A)

Title: Thermal diffusivity in a stratified storage tank.
Authors with affiliations: Palacio, A.; Rodriguez, A.
Abstract: A numerical and experimental study of a thermal energy storage tank is presented whereby the transient response to a step increase in temperature is predicted with reasonable accuracy. With the introduction of an 'apparent diffusivity' which significantly simplifies the mathematical model of the storage tank, it is possible to achieve simulations of solar energy thermal systems without excessive use of computer time. The energy equation is reduced to a one dimensional model with the thermal diffusivity factor accounting for all temperature dependent fluid properties. A numerical solution was implemented and correlated with data obtained from an experimental apparatus, to determine an expression for the apparent diffusivity. It was found that the apparent diffusivity is a function of the temperature gradient and the mass flow rate. The discrepancy between the temperature profile predictions and experimental data was less than ten percent in the most unfavourable case, and the average was about two percent. (A)

Title: Heat pumps - domestic and industrial applications.
Abstract: The study of energy conservation within the First and Second Energy R&D programmes of the European Community covers a wide range of topics, including heat pumps, heat recovery using heat exchangers, combustion, improvements in transport, and energy storage. This information brochure presents data on projects involving the development and application of heat pumps for space and water heating in dwellings and industrial process uses. (A)

Title: Vortex-flow drop structures.
Issue: (ed.), Lexington, U.S.A., OES Publications, 1984, Session III, p.115-120. (UKY BU135)
Authors with affiliations: Jain, S.C.; Kennedy, J.F.
Abstract: The design and hydraulic performance of the vortex flow drop structures recommended for the Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage District (MMSD) Inline Storage System are presented. The drop structures comprise a tangential inlet, a circular drop shaft connected to a larger diameter deaeration chamber, and an air vent pipe connected to the top of the dropshaft. The drop structure configuration is very simple, consisting of only plane surfaces, circular sections, and their intersections. A significant amount of energy is dissipated in the dropshaft. The flow is highly stable, and the boundary pressures are nearly atmospheric everywhere. The inception of cavitation is unlikely in these drop structures. (A)

Title: Low temperature geothermal energy in Canada.
Authors with affiliations: Cousins, R.J.; Larkin, B.
Abstract: This paper reviews technical factors and economic potential for low temperature geothermal heating using deep sedimentary resources. It shows the high cost of hydrothermal fluid production and the economic imperative of selecting processes having large heat loads, preferably high load factors and sensible energy capture from the fluid. Peak load lopping, and short term and seasonal thermal storage techniques are shown to improve the geothermal supply load factor and the unit cost of energy. Four large scale space heating applications offer particular economic potential, namely residential and commercial office complexes, greenhouses and mine ventilation air heating. (A)

Title: Small scale wind/diesel systems for electricity generation in isolated communities.
Authors with affiliations: Infield, D.G.
Abstract: Lists some problems forcing integrated wind power/diesel generator systems and examines three of these. Variability of wind turbine outputs leads to a high number of stop/start cycles for the diesel generator, and low load conditions for the diesel generator means increased wear and maintenance. Hence wind energy may be sufficiently used. Considers possible energy storage options and develops a methodology to assess these. The simple pay-back period is calculated. Results indicate that hydraulic storage is best for low values of characteristic time, while thermal storage is best for longterm storage. Notes possibilities for load control as an alternative. Discusses computer simulation of twin diesel back up as an alternative to short term energy storage. Various control strategies are investigated and results appear promising. (C.J.U.)

Title: Research in the U.K.: Energy Group, University of Reading.
Abstract: A description of the activities of the Energy Group, in the Department of Engineering at the University of Reading is given. Its location and facilities in terms of workshops, and computers, and relationship with other departments are explained. The projects undertaken, and in progress, include: wind energy; solar energy; wave energy and hydro conversion and pumps. The wind energy research covers large scale and small scale system studies and original wind turbine design for U.K. and overseas. One project in progress is examining the integration, on a large scale of electricity generated by wind power into a large national grid. Problems of battery storage to cope with fluctuating wind energy supply are also being investigated. (A.J.)

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF A MODULAR SOLAR DOMESTIC HOT WATER SYSTEM FOR DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE BARRACKS.
Source title: Technical Report - United States Army Corps of Engineers, Construction Engineering Research Labora
Authors with affiliations: Joncich, D.M.; Kirts, R.E.
Abstract: This paper describes the development of a modular concept for solar domestic water heating on Department of Defense (DOD) barracks buildings. In this approach, the solar energy system consists of only two major components: a collector module and a heat-exchanger-pump-storage tank (HPS) module. HPS module contains the system pump, heat exhanger, thermal storage vessel, expansion tank, controls, Btu meter, and other minor components. A prototype modular system was placed into operation in March 1983 on an 80-person barracks at the Naval Construction Battalion Center in Port Hueneme, CA. This system, consisting of approximately 900 sq ft of collectors and a 1200-gal tank, is operating properly with a thermal performance near its design goal. Although the system is not economically feasible in current market conditions, its cost effectiveness will improve as fuel prices rise.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Military Purposes; HOT WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS - Modular Construction; BARRACKS; COLLECTOR MODULE; DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE; HEAT EXCHANGER-PUMP-STORAGE TANK MODULE; MODULAR SOLAR DOMESTIC HOT WATER SYSTEM; Water heaters

Authors: Hoberecht Mark A., Miller Thomas B., Rieker Lorra L., Gonzalez-Sanabria Olga D.
Title: DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS FOR A 10-kW INTEGRATED HYDROGEN-OXYGEN REGENERATIVE FUEL CELL SYSTEM.
Authors with affiliations: Hoberecht, Mark A.; Miller, Thomas B.; Rieker, Lorra L.; Gonzalez-Sanabria, Olga D.
Abstract: Integration of an alkaline fuel cell subsystem with an alkaline electrolysis subsystem to form a regenerative fuel cell (RFC) system for low-earth-orbit (LEO) applications characterized by relatively high overall round-trip electrical efficiency, long life, and high reliability is possible with present state-of-the-art technology. A hypothetical 10-kW system is being computer modeled and studied based on data from ongoing contractual efforts in both the alkaline fuel cell and alkaline water electrolysis areas. The alkaline electrolysis technology uses a static water vapor feed technique and scaled-up cell hardware being developed under an NASA-LeRC program. This paper addresses the computer-aided study of the performance, operating, and design parameters of the hypothetical system.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Fuel cells

Authors: Kihlblom Ulf, Hyden Hans, Kellner Jonny, Matsson Lars Olof
Title: STORAGE OF COLD HOUSE AIR-CONDITIONING.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Kihlblom, Ulf; Hyden, Hans; Kellner, Jonny; Matsson, Lars Olof
Abstract: This report deals with seasonal storage of cold in drillhole storages in the bedrock (Sunstore storages) for air-conditioning of houses in hot climates. Energy costs for climate control systems in hot climates can be lowered 30-35% using seasonal storage of cold in the ground in comparison with the conventional air-conditioning systems used today. The cold can be collected in two ways: Cooling radiators facing the clear sky collect cold which can be stored on a seasonal and daily basis; A mechanical cooler of limited size working with a high cooling factor during periods of low electric power demand and stored in a drillhole storage. The two systems can operate separately or they can be used together in a hybrid system. The results of the study show that in systems of some 100 apartments and more, a climate control system based on seasonal storage of cold has a potential significant economic interest for users as well as suppliers of electric energy. Refs.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Thermal Insulation; COLD STORAGE - Control; CLIMATE CONTROL COSTS; DRILLHOLE ENERGY STORAGE; Air conditioning

Title: PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER SYSTEM FOR THE HOLMAN GUEST HOUSE, FORT HUACHUCA, AZ.
Source title: Technical Report - United States Army Corps of Engineers, Construction Engineering Research Labora
Authors with affiliations: Joncich, D.M.
Abstract: This report documents the specification, design, installation, and acceptance of a 5-kilowatt-Peak, grid-connected, photovoltaic power system for the Holman Guest House at Fort Huachuca, Arizona. This system, designed and installed at a cost of 112,000, was funded by the Department of Energy's Federal Photovoltaic Utilization Program. The system operates in parallel with the local utility grid without battery storage. The photovoltaic (PV) array, consisting of 196 roof-mounted panels, generates direct current at about 210 v. The array output is converted to alternating current by a three-phase, line-commutated inverter developed specifically for the application. The inverter output, estimated at about 11,000 kwh per year, meets a portion of the Guest House's electrical demands. Tests performed at the time of the system's acceptance have demonstrated its ability to deliver the rated power output. The U. S. Army Construction Engineering Research Laboratory is now conduting a 1-year evaluation to determine the system's long-term performance and to learn more about the feasibility of applying grid-connected PV systems to fixed military facilities.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Military Purposes; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Solar Energy; MILITARY ENGINEERING - United States; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS - Applications; POWER GENERATION - Solar Energy; ARIZONA; PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER SYSTEMS; Solar cells

Title: ROAD LOAD SIMULATOR TESTS OF THE GOULD PHASE I FUNCTIONAL MODEL SILICON CONTROLLED RECTIFIER ac MOTOR CONTROLLER FOR ELECTRIC VEHICLES.
Authors with affiliations: Gourash, Francis
Abstract: This report presents the test results for a functional mdoel ac motor controller for electric vehicles and a three-phase induction motor which were dynamically tested on a road load simulator. Results show that the controller has the capability to accelerate a 1576-kg (3456-lb) simulated vehicle to a cruise speed of 88. 5 km/hr (55 mph). Combined motor controller efficiency is 72 percent and the power inverter efficiency alone is 89 percent for the cruise region of the D cycle. Steady state test results for motoring, regeneration, and thermal data obtained by operating the simulator as a conventional dynamometer are in agreement with the contractor's previously reported data. The regeneration test results indicate that a reduction in energy requirements for urban driving cycles is attainable with regenerative braking.
Index Keywords: STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Title: An energy approach to linearizing squeeze film damper forces.
Authors with affiliations: Hahn, E.J.
Abstract: Analyses of multi-degree of freedom rotor bearing systems incorporating non-linear elements, such as squeeze film dampers, generally necessitate time-consuming transient solution. Consequently, it is often too expensive to carry out parametric design studies on such systems. This report presents a general technique for linearizing the non-linear element forces using equivalent stiffness and damping coefficients based on energy dissipation and energy storage-release concepts. The approach is illustrated and tested for both centrally preloaded squeeze film dampers and for squeeze film dampers without centralizing springs under a combination of unidirectional and unbalance loading. The results predicted by using such equivalent stiffness and damping coefficients agree quite well with those obtained from the full transient solution, even where the unidirectional load exceeds the dynamic load and the damper is operating at high eccentricity. An iterative procedure is proposed which, with the aid of such stiffness and damping coefficients, should significantly reduce the computation time presently needed to carry out parametric design studies on general multi-degree of freedom systems incorporating non-linear elements such as squeeze film dampers. (A)

Title: SAFETY PRECAUTIONS ON LPG INSTALLATIONS.
Source title: Heating and Ventilating Engineer: The Journal of Environmental Services
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: In many parts of the UK LPG is the only economic means of providing energy. As is the case of all fuels based on the refining of crude oil, LPG has proved to be remarkably safe in use, despite the potential hazards that are associated with its delivery and storage. This admirable safety record has not been achieved by accident. It is the result of dedicated (and expensive! ) research carried out by major oil companies, of which the Shell organization has been one of the leaders, in safety. This paper is an extract from 'LPG Installations' published by Shell U. K. Oil.
Index Keywords: Petroleum gas, Liquefied

Title: SPACE POWER TECHNOLOGY INTO THE 21ST CENTURY.
Authors with affiliations: Faymon, Karl A.; Fordyce, J.Stuart
Abstract: This paper discusses the space power systems of the early 21st century. The focus is on those capabilities which are anticipated to evolve from today's state-of-the-art and the technology development programs presently in place or planned for the remainder of the century. The power system technologies considered include solar thermal, nuclear, radioisotope, photovoltaic, thermionic, thermoelectric, and dynamic conversion systems such as the Brayton and Stirling cycles. Energy storage technologies considered include nickel hydrogen biopolar batteries, advanced high energy rechargeable batteries, regenerative fuel cells, and advanced primary batteries. The present state-of-the-art of these space power and energy technologies is discussed along with their projections, trends and goals. A speculative future mission model is postulated which includes manned orbiting space stations, manned lunar bases, unmanned earth orbital and interplanetary spacecraft, manned interplanetary missions, military applications, and earth to space and space to space transportation systems. The various space power/energy system technologies anticipated to be operational by the early 21st century are matched to these missions.
Index Keywords: DIRECT ENERGY CONVERSION - Space Applications; ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Power Supply; FUEL CELLS - Space Applications; SATELLITES - Power Supply; Spacecraft

Title: USE OF ROCK ANCHORS TO HEIGHTEN A CONCRETE DAM.
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Increasing storage capacity of a reservoir by raising the height of its retaining dam can be an effective way of meeting increased requirements for water or energy. But it is a process which must be carefully engineered. Sebakwe dam is the largest dam in the midlands of Zimbabwe, serving both the urban and industrial requirements of the towns of Kwe Kwe and Redcliff and local agricultural needs. It had been established that the optimal method of increasing the supply of water to this area would be by raising the height of the dam by an effective 6 m. The method of raising the dam and assuring its stability combines the use of post-tensioned cables anchored in the foundation with the placing of a large volume of weighting concrete within the voids between the buttress webs.
Index Keywords: CONCRETE CONSTRUCTION - Anchorages; INLAND WATERWAYS - Water Level; RETAINING DAM RAISING; Dams, Concrete

Title: Wind electric conversion and utilization.
Issue: (ed.), Washington, U.S.A., Hemisphere Publishing Corp., 1984, Chapter 1, Section 2, p.15-36. (ISBN 0
Authors with affiliations: Ramakumar, R.
Abstract: Reviews wind energy conversion. Examines wind characteristics, and the components of a wind power system. Lists parameters involved, and discusses in particular constant versus variable speed operation. A variety of wind power systems are available. Discusses generation schemes design. Operational and experimental schemes, both large and small, are outlined and wind energy storage and reconversion discussed. Connection to the electricity grid and capacity credit determination require examination of some control and technical problems. Economics and possibilities for cost reduction, are considered. (C.J.U.)
Index Keywords: book; chapter

Authors: Mitani Y., Tsuji K., Murakami Y.
Title: A Method for Evaluating the Stabilizing Effect of Superconducting Magnet Energy Storage in Power System
