Authors: Beachley N.H., Anscomb C., Burrows C.R.
Title: Evaluation of split-path extended range continuously-variable transmissions for automotive applications
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, USAU.S.A.; Department of Dynamics and Control, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow G1 1XJ, UKU.K.
Authors with affiliations: Beachley, N.H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, USAU.S.A.; Anscomb, C., Department of Dynamics and Control, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow G1 1XJ, UKU.K.; Burrows, C.R., Department of Dynamics and Control, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow G1 1XJ, UKU.K.
Abstract: One potentially important application of continuously-variable transmissions (CVT's) is the improvement in fuel economy of internal combustion engine vehicles. However, many otherwise attractive CVT designs have a ratio coverage less than ideal for such applications. Split-path configurations can be used to extend the ratio coverage, providing even a geared neutral and reverse capability with some combinations of parameters. The increased coverage is in general achieved, however, only at the expense of lower overall CVT efficiency and a larger required variable unit capacity. All possible single-regime designs which use a single differential to extend the ratio coverage of the basic variable unit are considered, as well as two 2- regime designs. Data for the CVT efficiency characteristics are developed for both otherwise conventional vehicles and those utilizing an energy-storage flywheel, with steady speeds and three driving cycles used for the evaluation. It is found that the efficiency penalty for extending the ratio coverage can be quite severe for some combinations of system parameters and operating conditions, so that a complete analysis of this aspect is important when considering the concept for any specific application. © 1984.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOBILE TRANSMISSIONS

Authors: Guo Y.-L., Yao M.-Y., Pang S.-M.
Title: High Efficiency Up-Conversion and Real-Time Storage by Two-Fold Degenerate Four-Wave Mixing in BDN Dye
Affiliations: Department of Radio Electronics, Tsinghua University, Peking, China
Authors with affiliations: Guo, Y.-L., Department of Radio Electronics, Tsinghua University, Peking, China; Yao, M.-Y., Department of Radio Electronics, Tsinghua University, Peking, China; Pang, S.-M., Department of Radio Electronics, Tsinghua University, Peking, China
Abstract: Infrared to visible frequency up-conversion with efficiency as large as 377 percent and real-time storage of nanosecond pulses for a few tenths of a millisecond have been simultaneously achieved in a BDN organic dye solution in toluene. Two remarkable effects influencing the four-wave mixing (FWM) efficiency are found: (1) transient energy transfer between writing beams, and (2) the time matching between reading beam and the molecular relaxation time of medium. The full frequency-domain absorption characteristic and full time-domain storage characteristic of BDN have been studied in detail. The experimental results are identical to preliminary theoretical analysis. © 1984 IEEE
Index Keywords: DYES AND DYEING; UP-CONVERSION; INFRARED RADIATION

Title: Unit commitment in a thermal generation system with multiple pumped-storage power stations
Source title: International Journal of Electrical Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering and Electronics, UMIST, PO Box 88, Manchester, M60 1QD, United Kingdom; Faculty of Engineering, University of Malaya, Lembah Pantai, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Lidgate, D., Department of Electrical Engineering and Electronics, UMIST, PO Box 88, Manchester, M60 1QD, United Kingdom; Khalid, B.M.N., Faculty of Engineering, University of Malaya, Lembah Pantai, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Malaysia
Abstract: A model is presented of the unit-commitment problem which takes into account generator maximum and minimum outputs, maximum loading and unloading rates, minimum shutdown times, and both on- and offline costs. This is formulated as a mixed-integer problem and solved by using a branch and bound method. The linear-programming problems that arise during the search procedure in the branch and bound algorithm are converted into capacitated transshipment problems which can be solved efficiently by a graphically-based solution procedure. Multiple pumped-storage power stations are then scheduled by a search procedure based on the principle that pumping can only take place if the resulting hydrogeneration reduces total production costs. This is applied iteratively to an initial thermal unit schedule until no further cost improvement occurs. Finally, the computational requirements of this method, both with and without pumped-storage stations, are shown to be less than those of other existing techniques and to be applicable to systems of realistic size. © 1984.
Author Keywords: pumped-storage power stations; thermal-electric power stations; unit commitment
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Computer Aided Analysis; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Pumped Storage; MATHEMATICAL PROGRAMMING, LINEAR; UNIT COMMITMENT; THERMOELECTRIC ENERGY CONVERSION

Authors: Goetzberger A., Schmid J., Wittwer V.
Title: Transparent Insulation System for Passive Solar Energy Utilization in Buildings
Affiliations: Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Freiburg, West-Germany, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Goetzberger, A., Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Freiburg, West-Germany, Germany; Schmid, J., Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Freiburg, West-Germany, Germany; Wittwer, V., Fraunhofer-Institut für Solare Energiesysteme, Freiburg, West-Germany, Germany
Abstract: A new concept for the passive use of solar energy, transparent insulation, is described together with the first experimental results. Transparent insulation material has the property of being transparent or translucent to solar radiation while at the same time acting as heat insulation, Elements made of this material can be attached to the walls of buildings and thus permit the utilization of solar energy for heating. Relations are given for the dependence of heat flux and conversion efficiency of radiation into useful heat on the thermal resistance of the components. Calculations using meteorological data show that with materials parameters achievable with present technology not only south but also west/east and possibly even north orientations can lead to significant contributions to heating. In order to avoid overheating in summer, control of radiation must be provided. Experiments with unoptimized materials on two buildings during 1982/83 showed promising results: for a south facade during a sunny period in January, a mean flux of 9 W/m2into the house was observed. For the entire heating season the extrapolated value is 16 W/m2. On a western orientation a net loss was observed, but the mean effective heat transfer coefficient of the element was lowered from 1.8 W/m2K without radiation to 0.25 W/m2K with radiation. The beneficial effect of masonry walls with regard to heat storage and damping of temperature fluctuation was also demonstrated. The elements proposed here therefore appear particularly attractive for retrofitting. © 1984, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; THERMAL INSULATION - Applications; TRANSPARENT INSULATION SYSTEMS; BUILDINGS

Title: A mathematical model for the Iron/Chromium redox battery
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, North carolina State University, Raleigh North Carolina 27695, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fedkiw, P.S., Department of Chemical Engineering, North carolina State University, Raleigh North Carolina 27695, United States; Watts, R.W., Department of Chemical Engineering, North carolina State University, Raleigh North Carolina 27695, United States
Abstract: A mathematical model has been developed to describe the isothermal operation of a single anode-separator-cathode unit cell in a redox-flow battery and has been applied to the NASA iron/chromium system. The model, based on porous electrode theory, incorporates redox kinetics, mass transfer, and ohmic effects as well as the parasitic hydrogen reaction which occurs in the chromium electrode. A numerical parameter study was carried out to predict cell performance to aid in the rational design, scale-up, and operation of the flow battery. The calculations demonstrate: (i) an optimum electrode thickness and electrolyte flow rate exist; (ii) the amount of hydrogen evolved and, hence, cycle faradaic efficiency, can be affected by cell geometry, flow rate, and charging procedure; (iii) countercurrent flow results in enhanced cell performance over cocurrent flow; and (iv) elevated temperature operation enhances cell performance. © 1984, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: battery; energy storage
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN; IRON CHROMIUM ALLOYS; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Authors: Tiwari G.N., Husain M.S., Garg H.P.
Title: Analysis of a flat plate solar collector/storage water heater with evaporation
Authors with affiliations: Tiwari, G.N.; Husain, M.S.; Garg, H.P.
Abstract: We analyse the performance of a flat-plate collector with a constant rate of evaporation of flowing water between a glass cover and an absorbing plate. The effects of fluid-flow velocity, depth of fluid and length of the absorbing surface are discussed. We have allowed for periodic variation of the solar intensity and ambient air temperature during a typical day in New Delhi. © 1984.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; WATER HEATERS

Title: NATURAL ENERGY AUTONOMOUS HOUSE WITH UNDERGROUND WATER RESERVOIR.
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, Takeo
Abstract: A natural energy autonomous system with an underground water reservoir utilizing solar thermal energy, natural coolness, and sky radiation cooling is presented featuring two modes of operation: long-term thermal energy storage mode from September to early December, in which solar energy is collected and stored in the underground reservoir and long-term cool storage mode from April to late June, in which the water temperature of the underground reservoir is cooled by using a sky radiation cooling device.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Japan; Solar energy

Title: Influence of protein intake, energy intake and stage of gestation on growth, reproductive performance, nitrogen balance and carcass composition in gestating gilts.
Authors with affiliations: Willis, G.M.; Maxwell, C.V.
Abstract: Thirty-six crossbred gilts were fed three levels of protein (146, 255 and 364 g/d) and two levels of energy (6,200 and 7,440 kcal of digestible energy/d) throughout gestation in a 3 x 2 factorial arrangement of treatments. Five-day N balance studies were conducted in early (0 to 30 d), mid- (30 to 60 d) and late (60 to 90 d) gestation. At slaughter (90 d of gestation), reproductive tracts were weighed and evaluated for reproductive performance and samples of the reproductive tract, liver and semimembranosus muscle (SM) were analyzed for crude protein. The right half of the carcass was subjected to a physical separation of fat, lean and bone. Neither dietary protein nor energy level significantly affected weight gain or reproductive performance. Nitrogen retention increased as dietary protein level increased and stage of gestation progressed (linear effect, P less than .01), but efficiency of N utilization and dry matter digestibility decreased with increasing protein intakes (quadratic effect, P less than .05 and linear effect, P less than .01, respectively). Nitrogen retention (P less than .01), efficiency of N retention (P less than .05) and dry matter digestibility (P less than .01) were higher in gilts fed high (H) energy compared with gilts receiving moderate (M) energy diets. Increasing dietary protein increased total carcass separable lean tissue (quadratic effect, P less than .01), liver weight (linear effect P less than .01) SM weight (quadratic effect, P less than .05) and SM percentage M (linear effect P less than .10). Similarly, total carcass N and carcass lean N increased as protein level increased (quadratic effect, P less than .10, P less than .05, respectively). In contrast to the increase in muscle N, N in uterine tissue and fluids was not affected by dietary protein level. The results of this experiment suggest that 146 g of crude protein/d during gestation is just as effective as higher levels of crude protein for litter size or storage of N in reproductive tissue, but 255 to 364 g of protein/d are required to maximize muscle N.
Index Keywords: nitrogen; animal; article; body composition; body weight; breeding; caloric intake; digestion; female; litter size; metabolism; physiology; pregnancy; protein intake; reproduction; swine; Animals; Body Composition; Body Weight; Dietary Proteins; Digestion; Energy Intake; Female; Litter Size; Nitrogen; Pregnancy; Pregnancy, Animal; Reproduction; Swine

Title: PERFORMANCE OF MAN-POWERED AIRCRAFT.
Authors with affiliations: Lilley, G.M.
Abstract: This paper reviews the aerodynamic performance of many of the previous man-powered aircraft designs and sets out the general equations and design parameters which need to be used in the design of new man-powered aircraft. The paper also discusses briefly the performance of man-powered aircraft with energy storage for assisted take-off and as a contribution for cruising flight.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Applications; Aircraft

Title: Refrigeration systems based on long-term storage of ice
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Energetica, Politecnico di Torino, Corso Duca degli Abruzzi 24, 10129 Torino, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Masoero, M., Dipartimento di Energetica, Politecnico di Torino, Corso Duca degli Abruzzi 24, 10129 Torino, Italy
Abstract: A new refrigeration system with annual storage of ice, called the Ice Pond, has been developed and tested at Princeton University. The first commercial ice pond is now under construction to serve a 30 000 m3 office building in the Princeton area. This technique leads to substantial reductions in energy consumption with respect to conventional cooling and helps reduce summer peak electricity demand. In this article, the physics and engineering of ice production, preservation, and utilization are discussed. Experimental results of the Princeton research are reviewed. Finally, a method of economic analysis of the system is presented. © 1984.
Author Keywords: ice; ice storage; refrigeration
Index Keywords: ICE - Storage; SNOW AND SNOWFALL - Manufacture; ICE POND; REFRIGERATION SYSTEMS; SNOW MACHINE; REFRIGERATION

Title: Experimental Investigation of Solar Cooling and Heating Systems (1st Report, Operation Results and Simulation of Solar Cooling System)
Source title: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series B
Authors with affiliations: Nawata, Y.
Abstract: A solar cooling and heating system is in operation at the Co-Operative Research Center in the Yatsushiro National College of Technology. The system uses flat plate collectors, a thermal storage tank, two absorption chillers and an auxiliary boiler. To evaluate system performance, data were collected from the 53 measured points of system. This report shows two year's results of operation of the solar cooling system. Further, performance of the solar cooling system has been simulated by using an introduced model. Simulation results using weather data collected on site were compared with experimental results to examine the model for its validity. Using the verified model, a simulation study was undertaken with the intent of extending the experimental analysis. © 1984, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Solar Buildings; Solar Collector; Solar Cooling; Solar Energy; System Simulation; Thermal Engineering Equipment

Title: LONG DISTANCE PNEUMATIC TRANSPORTATION.
Authors with affiliations: Soo, S.L.
Abstract: Future development and potential applications of pneumatic pipelines for transport and gathering of coal over distances around 10 km are discussed considering the design limitations. These applications call for critical design and energy efficiency. Gathering and transshipment by pneumatic pipelines reduce storage needs and tie-ups at delivery and receiving points of railroad and ports.
Index Keywords: Coal transportation; Pneumatics; Pipelines

Title: Implantable power-sources: A review
Source title: Journal of Medical Engineering and Technology
Affiliations: Wilson Greatbatch Prosthetics Ltd, 10871 Main Street, Clarence, NY 14031, United States
Authors with affiliations: Greatbatch, W., Wilson Greatbatch Prosthetics Ltd, 10871 Main Street, Clarence, NY 14031, United States
Abstract: It has now been 25 years since the first pacemakers were implanted. It is indeed fascinating to see the breadth and the vision of the early investigators on both sides of the ocean, most of them friends of the author, in the almost desperate search for a power source that would enable the pacemaker to last as long as the expected lifetime of the average patient. Every conceivable method of power generation, power storage, and energy conservation was studied. The result was an orderly transition from zinc-mercury batteries, to lithium-iodine batteries, to the newest lithium oxyhalide systems of the coming decade, all of which coincided with tentative sidesteps into rechargeable batteries and nuclear batteries. This paper traces this 25 years of progress and salutes the many investigators who have brought the implantable pacemaker and its power source to their present state of acceptance by the medical profession. © 1984 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.
Author Keywords: Implantable; Pacemakers; Power sources

Title: ENERGY SAVING THROUGH THE USE OF FAN AND REFRIGERATION CYCLING IN APPLE COLD STORAGE.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Authors with affiliations: Yost, G.E.
Abstract: The rising cost of electrical power has created interest in saving power in apple cold storage. The engineering and economic aspects of cycling the fans off and on without causing the apple core temperature to rise above 1 degree C were studied. Tests were conducted to investigate alternate cycling schemes and their effect on apple quality, fruit temperature and energy savings. This study indicated that fruit temperature and fruit quality can be maintained when fans and refrigeration are cycled in apple cold storage rooms during the temperature maintenance period.
Index Keywords: FANS - Energy Conservation; REFRIGERATION - Energy Conservation; APPLE COLD STORAGE; FAN CYCLING; REFRIGERATION CYCLING; Agricultural products; Malus x domestica

Authors: Arinze E.A., Schoenau G.J., Besant R.W.
Title: DYNAMIC THERMAL PERFORMANCE SIMULATION MODEL OF AN ENERGY CONSERVING GREENHOUSE WITH THERMAL STORAGE.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Authors with affiliations: Arinze, E.A.; Schoenau, G.J.; Besant, R.W.
Abstract: In this study a dynamic mathematical model for predicting temperatures and moisture levels in a solar-assisted energy conserving circular (hoop) type greenhouse was developed. Active and passive forms of thermal storage were investigated. The greenhouse thermal model was programmed on a digital computer and comparisons of the greenhouse measured variables with model predictions showed a high degree of correlation.

Authors: Harris K., Hill R.J., Rand D.A.J.
Title: Quantitative Phase Analysis of Crystalline and Amorphous Components of Positive Plates in Lead-Acid Batteries Operated Under Simulated Electric-Vehicle Service
Affiliations: Institute of Energy and Earth Resources, CSIRO Division of Mineral Chemistry, Port Melbourne Victoria 3207, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harris, K., Institute of Energy and Earth Resources, CSIRO Division of Mineral Chemistry, Port Melbourne Victoria 3207, United States; Hill, R.J., Institute of Energy and Earth Resources, CSIRO Division of Mineral Chemistry, Port Melbourne Victoria 3207, United States; Rand, D.A.J., Institute of Energy and Earth Resources, CSIRO Division of Mineral Chemistry, Port Melbourne Victoria 3207, United States
Abstract: The crystalline and amorphous component phases of positive plates taken from lead-acid batteries in simulated electric-vehicle service were examined by quantitative XRD analysis. They were compared with independent determinations from electrical measurements and wet chemical analysis. Changes in temperature, discharge current, the ratio of a-PbO2:β-PbO2, and the amount of amorphous material are correlated with the capacity and cycle life of the batteries. © 1984, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. Title: Photointercalation and Optical Information Storage Using Cu6-xPS5I
Affiliations: Hahn-Meitner-Institut für Kernforschung Berlin GmbH, Bereich Strahlenchemie, D-1000 Berlin 39, Germany; Albert-Ludwigs-Universität, Kristallographisches Institut, D-7800 Freiburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Betz, G., Hahn-Meitner-Institut für Kernforschung Berlin GmbH, Bereich Strahlenchemie, D-1000 Berlin 39, Germany, Albert-Ludwigs-Universität, Kristallographisches Institut, D-7800 Freiburg, Germany; Tributsch, H., Hahn-Meitner-Institut für Kernforschung Berlin GmbH, Bereich Strahlenchemie, D-1000 Berlin 39, Germany
Abstract: The agyrodite Cu6-xPS5I is simultaneously a copper ion conductor and a p-type electronic semiconductor. With an energy gap of ΔEg= 2.05 eV, the compound intercalates copper upon illumination as demonstrated in photoelectrochemical experiments. The intercalation of copper is accompanied by a color change which is believed to be due to an annihilation of I2- color centers. In experiments in which Cu was partially replaced by Ag, photointercalation was verified by means of x-ray fluorescence measurements. It is shown how such a photointercalation reaction could be used to store optical information. © 1984, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: Generation of a 75-MW 5-kHz Pulse Train From an Inductive Energy Store
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Honig, E.M., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Abstract: The first demonstration of fully controlled high-power high-repetition-rate burst-mode operation of an inductive energy storage and transfer system with nondestructive switches was achieved with fast-recovery vacuum switches and a new repetitive transfer circuit. The system delivered a 5-kHz pulse train with a peak power of 75 MW (at 8.6 kA) to a 1-Ω load. © 1984 IEEE
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions; INDUCTIVE ENERGY STORAGE; PULSED POWER; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: LIVING AND LEARNING WITH ENERGY CONSCIOUS DESIGN.
Authors with affiliations: Palmer, Sandra
Abstract: A unique, energy-efficient building joins the faculty of a small college in Maryland. While combining advanced energy-conserving building techniques, materials and equipment, the building would have to fulfill a unique combination of residential living/learning, academic and social functions. All windows are double glazed. The single corridor that connects the first floor apartments and the central teaching/social spaces along the south side doubles as solar heat-gathering area. In the ceiling of this sunspace is a return air grill which draws warmed air back into the heating system in winter if the internal temperature up there exceeds 70 degree F.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION - Design; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; PASSIVE SOLAR STORAGE; College buildings

Title: The freezing-in of non-equilibrium values of the limiting compliances as a mechanism of physical ageing
Affiliations: Department of Engineering Science, Oxford University, Parks Road, Oxford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Chai, C.K., Department of Engineering Science, Oxford University, Parks Road, Oxford, United Kingdom; McCrum, N.G., Department of Engineering Science, Oxford University, Parks Road, Oxford, United Kingdom
Abstract: The theory of a new method for measuring the temperature dependence of the limiting compliances, JR and JU, is described. The method is based on the observation of secondary creep; this is a small effect generated in a stressed specimen by a T-jump. In the experiment, the specimen is maintained isothermally under a constant stress until the primary creep rate is negligible. A T-jump of several degrees, positive or negative, is then imposed and this generates the secondary creep. If JR and JU are independent of temperature there is no secondary creep. The secondary creep has the same time dependence as primary creep. A comparison of the magnitudes of secondary and primary creep — at equivalent reduced times — leads by means of the theory of thermoviscoelasticity to the determination of α and β, the temperature coefficients of (JR-JU) and JU. For isotactic polypropylene in the α-region at 40°C both coefficients are positive: α = 0.7 × 10−2 and β = 0.1 × 10−2°C−1. It is clear from the positive sign for the coefficient of (JR-JU) that the α-relaxation is of the type in which stress increases the entropy. The magnitudes of the coefficients support the conclusion that the use of un-normalized time-temperature superposition to determine activation energy in polypropylene will be highly erroneous. The magnitude of the coefficient of (JR-JU) is sufficiently large to account partially for physical ageing in crystalline polymers. Quenching from T down to T0 will freeze in a non-equilibrium value of (JR-JU), considerably in excess of the equilibrium value at T0. Storage at T0 permits the equilibrium value to be slowly attained, so that with increasing ageing time the polymer becomes stiffer and exhibits lower creep rates. © 1984, All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: ageing; Creep; limiting compliances; polypropylene
Index Keywords: MATERIALS TESTING - Creep; Polymers; Polypropylene

Title: HOW TO INCREASE TROMBE WALL EFFICIENCY.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Designers and builders are showing increased interest in the use of concrete masonry, a traditional material that offers high thermal efficiency and excellent comfort control, in passive solar applications. Trombe walls are widely used in both residential and commercial designs. The addition of a selective absorber to a concrete block Trombe wall enhances the heat collection and storage capacity of the wall substantially.
Index Keywords: CONCRETE PRODUCTS - Blocks; Energy conservation; HOUSES - Walls; Masonry materials; Optical coatings; Buildings

Title: HIGH TEMPERATURE THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE FOR POWER GENERATION.
Authors with affiliations: Durrant, O.W.; Braun, M.J.
Abstract: Energy conservation is a significant factor in efficient energy management. Where there is desynchronization between cyclic energy production and use, an energy storage system can significantly buffer the difference between production and demand. An investigation is presented on the use of high-temperature thermal storage to bridge the gap between cyclic energy generation and consumption. The accent falls specifically on the description of a new concept for moving, storing, and retrieving energy - the Moving Bed Thermal Energy Storage System - and its application to fossil- and solar-powered boilers for power generation.
Index Keywords: Thermoelectric energy conversion; Power generation

Title: UV CURING COMPOUNDS FOR COATING, BONDING, POTTING, AND ENCAPSULATION.
Authors with affiliations: Brenner, Walter
Abstract: Commercial organic coatings, adhesive/sealants, pottings, and encapsulants generally contain solvents and various diluents, or they are composed of two components which must be weighed and mixed prior to use. After such compounds are applied, heat is generally used to drive off the solvents and other volatiles or to speed the cure (hardening) - especially for two-component systems. UV curing compounds, on the other hand, are one-component materials which remain stable - even after prolonged storage - until activated by UV light. They also do not require any weighing or mixing prior to application. In UV curing compositions, radiant energy from a UV light source is absorbed and converted to chemical energy so quickly that cure is practically instantaneous. The formulations are 100 percent reactive with no volatile losses upon curing and therefore are essentially non-polluting. Characteristics of UV-cure compounds and their applications are discussed.
Index Keywords: UV CURING COMPOUNDS; Printed circuits

Title: CURTAIN WALL SOLAR COLLECTOR AND STORE.
Affiliations: Ispra Cent, Italy, Ispra Cent, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Colombo, R., Ispra Cent, Italy, Ispra Cent, Italy; Pellegrini, G., Ispra Cent, Italy, Ispra Cent, Italy
Abstract: Introducing a feature of the controlled storage and release of energy, especially captured solar energy, this article describes the design for a curtain wall which will provide seasonal heating and cooling in a passive solar building. It is being tested at the EEC Commission's Joint Research Centre at Ispra, Northern Italy. The principles and techniques employed in this phase-change concept produce a module which can collect, store and release solar heat at around 20 degree C with forced air circulation. It is dimensioned to meet the daily energy demand for air conditioning during the summer and most of the heating demand in the winter.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Solar Energy Systems; BUILDINGS - Walls; HEATING - Solar; CURTAIN WALL; PASSIVE SOLAR BUILDING; TROMBE WALL; Solar radiation

Title: NEW ICE AGE.
Source title: Australian refrigeration, Air conditioning and heating
Authors with affiliations: Rule, John
Abstract: As energy costs continue to escalate, designers of cooling systems are continually seeking new technologies to reduce operating costs. Often, old technologies in new applications can provide significant cost-saving opportunities too. Such is the case with the concept of thermal storage. Full or partial ice storage systems can reduce peak electric power demand, and reduce equipment capacity requirements.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Electric Power; Ice

Authors: Baev S.G., Bessmel'tsev V.P., Lomovskii O.I., Lushnikov A.Ya.
Title: OPTICAL RECORDING OF DATA IN THERMALLY SENSITIVE COPPER SALT FILMS.
Authors with affiliations: Baev, S.G.; Bessmel'tsev, V.P.; Lomovskii, O.I.; Lushnikov, A.Ya.
Abstract: A study was made of the use of the thermal effect of optical radiation in recording (storing) data in thermally sensitive films of copper salts. The energy characteristics were determined and an estimate of the data recording rate was obtained. Feasibility of recording images obtained from a computer was demonstrated experimentally.
Index Keywords: COPPER COMPOUNDS - Thin Films; Data storage, Optical

Title: TOY DESIGN IN HONG KONG.
Authors with affiliations: Leung, T.P.; Ip, P.W.
Abstract: Hong Kong's toy industry is outlined that has made tremendous progress during the last two decades. The paper is intended to give a systematic analysis of the various aspects of engineering design. General aspects of toy design, together with brief points about manufacturing are discussed. Details of energy sources, energy storage and transmission mechanisms are also considered.
Index Keywords: Toy manufacture

Title: Eurelios, the 1-MW(el) helioelectric power plant of the european community program
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Authors with affiliations: Borgese, D.; Dinelli, G.; Faure, J.J.; Gretz, J.; Schober, G.

Title: Smart coal-pile management can cut heating-value losses
Authors with affiliations: Ripp, J.
Abstract: Measurements of all components of the water balance of three large coal piles included precipitation (rain or snow); storm-water runoff; evaporation from the pile surface; leachate flow (in-filtrated water which eventually seeps from the coal-pile base); infiltration rate and coal-moisture changes. The results showed that only a small amount of water is lost to evaporation after the surface of the pile becomes dry and crusty. Inhibiting the amount of water percolating through a coal-storage pile can minimize the Btus wasted in driving off moisture preparatory to combustion. This may be accomplished by the construction of a pile that enhances surface runoff and better drainage.
Index Keywords: Energy conservation; Coal storage; coal; environmental sanitation; mining; nonhuman; prevention; theoretical study

Title: MODEL FOR HEAT TRANSFER BETWEEN HUMAN BODY, CORE AND SKIN.
Source title: Journal of the Institution of Engineers. India. Interdisciplinary and General Engineering
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, N.K.; Tandon, P.N.
Abstract: Incorporating the effects of locally variable blood perfusion and metabolic heat generation in one-dimensional steady state heat transfer through the tissue in the peripheral region, temperature profiles and other characters have been obtained for different environmental conditions and under the assumption of negligible thickness of the skin. Thus, dividing the region into an isothermal core and a pheripheral region, the analysis of heat transfer from the core to the skin has been made. It has also been observed that the changes in atmospheric temperature modifies these profiles in such a way that the tissue serves as a source of thermal energy storage and maintains thermal equilibrium at all variable conditions.
Index Keywords: BLOOD PERFUSION RATES; HEAT TRANSFER; METABOLISM; Biomedical engineering

Title: STUDIES ON SALT HYDRATES FOR LATENT HEAT STORAGE: V. PREHEATING EFFECT ON CRYSTALLIZATION OF SODIUM ACETATE TRIHYDRATE FROM AQUEOUS SOLUTION WITH A SMALL AMOUNT OF SODIUM PYROPHOSPHATE DECAHYDRATE.
Source title: Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan
Authors with affiliations: Wada, Takahiro; Matsunaga, Koji; Matsuo, Yoshihiro
Abstract: Influences of preheating temperature and time were studied on the crystallization of CH//3CO//2Na multiplied by (times) 3H//2O from three kinds of CH//3CO//2Na aqueous solutions, whose concentrations were 58. 0, 60. 3, and 62. 8 wt% and which contained a small amount of crystal nucleation catalyst, Na//4P//2O//7 multiplied by (times) 10H//2O In 60. 3 wt% aqueous solution (CH//3CO//2Na multiplied by (times) 3H//2O), the nucleation catalyst begins to get deactivated by preheating at about 81 degree C, higher by 23 degree C than the melting point of CH//3CO//2Na multiplied by (times) 3H//2O. The temperature at which the catalyst begins to get deactivated is raised with increasing CH//3CO//2Na concentration of the solution; thus, in 62. 8 wt% CH//3CO//2Na aqueous solution, the catalyst begins to get deactivated at 85 degree C.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; SODIUM COMPOUNDS - Crystallization; Salts

Title: A 1-MWe central receiver type solar thermal electric power pilot plant
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: SUNSHINE Project Promotion Headquarters, Agency of Industrial Science and Technology, Ministry of International Trade and Industry, Japan; Solar Energy Department, New Energy Development Organization, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hirono, T., SUNSHINE Project Promotion Headquarters, Agency of Industrial Science and Technology, Ministry of International Trade and Industry, Japan; Horigome, T., Solar Energy Department, New Energy Development Organization, Japan
Abstract: We experienced a few problems in a year. The utilization factor of thermal energy was low at the beginning of the operation, because the heat loss from the accumulators and pipes was large. As the result of improvement in the thermal insulation of the accumulators, reducing the leakage of steam from valves and decreasing the number of operating accumulators from 5 to 2, ihe utilization factor was increased from 0.35 to 0.79. Optical system efficiency is dependent on the season. The main problem is considered to be condensed moisture on the mirror surfaces of the heliostats at night. For future projects, it is essential for solar power plants to prevent the small losses of heat that are gathered from a wide area. It is also necessary to match the solar collector system and thermal storage system. The confirmation of the reliability of the heat receiver is important. Heat absorbing tubes in the receiver experience violent temperature cycles every day and night and in the shadow from clouds even in sunny days. Thermal insulation materials and valve and pipe joints which have both good thermal insulation and small heat capacity must be developed in parallel with the development of main components. © 1984 ASME.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: Thermal performance of a heat storage module using calcium chloride hexahydrate
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Foster Wheeler Development Corporation, Livingston, NJ, 07039, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dietz, D., Foster Wheeler Development Corporation, Livingston, NJ, 07039, United States
Abstract: The thermal performance of an air-heated/cooled, phase-change, heat stoage module was tested and evaluated. The module (rated at 38.7 kWh) consist of 130 vertically oriented tubes filled with 729 kg (1607 lb) of calcium chloride hexahydrate and enclosed in a rectangular box. Heat transfer rates measured during charging and discharging decreased with time as a result of decreasing effective heat transfer area and increasing thermal resistance of the phase-change material. These two dominant effects are included in a proposed mathematical model that predicted the experimental data. © 1984 ASME.
Index Keywords: CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; HEAT STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: APPLICATION OF A TOTAL ENERGY SYSTEM AT THE POLARIS MINING PROJECT.
Authors with affiliations: Nielsen, A.
Abstract: The Polaris mining operation is located on Little Cornwallis Island in the Canadian Arctic, an area with a limited shipping season and a hostile climate. The operation consists of the underground works, barge-mounted concentrator facilities, concentrate storage and shipping facilities, a personnel accommodation complex and an airstrip. The power plant has been designed as a Total Energy System with maximum energy efficiency and heat recovery.
Index Keywords: MINES AND MINING

Title: The effects of aluminium substitution in TiFe on its hydrogen absorption properties
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 150 Chongryang, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lim, S.H., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 150 Chongryang, Seoul, South Korea; Jai-Young, L., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 150 Chongryang, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: The influence of the partial substitution of iron by aluminium in TiFe on the hydrogen absorption properties was systematically investigated. The pressure-composition isotherms were determined to establish differences in the thermodynamic properties. When aluminium was added to the TiFe compound, the hydrogen storage capacity decreased markedly and the γ phase was not formed. The plateau pressure was sloping and was higher for TiFe0.98Al0.02 and TiFe0.96Al0.04 and lower for TiFe0.94Al0.06 and TiFe0.90Al0.10 than for pure TiFe. These results are explained by the difference between the number of valence electrons present in aluminium and iron. The ΔHo, ΔSo and ΔGo values were obtained from plots of In P versus 1 T using the van't Hoff relation. The hysteresis energy loss decreased with increasing aluminium content. © 1984.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN - Absorption; HYDROGEN STORAGE; TITANIUM IRON ALLOYS

Title: The effects of the addition of aluminium on the kinetic properties of the intermetallic compound TiFe
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 150 Chongryang, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lim, S.H., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 150 Chongryang, Seoul, South Korea; Jai-Young, L., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 150 Chongryang, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: The kinetic properties of TiFe0.94Al0.06 were investigated and compared with those of TiFe. The dependence of the hydrogen absorption rate on the driving force and the reacted fraction F showed that the chemisorption of hydrogen molecules on the sample surface is rate controlling up to F ≈ 0.15 with an apparent activation energy of about 1.7 kcal (mol H2)-1. At a later stage of the reaction the rate-controlling step changes from chemisorption to hydrogen diffusion through the hydride phase. © 1984.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN - Absorption; TITANIUM IRON ALUMINUM ALLOYS; HYDROGEN STORAGE; INTERMETALLICS

Authors: Alexandrovitz A., Yair A., Epstein E.
Title: Analysis of a Static VAR Compensator with Optimal Energy Storage Element
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Alexandrovitz, A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel; Yair, A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel; Epstein, E., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Abstract: This paper analyzes a single-phase static VAR compensator, based on the current source-forced commutated inverter. Emphasis is given to the subject of energy storage in the circuit. Analytic results, as well as small-scale laboratory system results, give an estimation of the system's size and design procedure. © 1984, IEEE.
Index Keywords: CONTROL EQUIPMENT, ELECTRIC

Authors: Wolf D., Sembira A.N., Kudish A.I.
Title: Dynamic simulation and parametric sensitivity studies on a central solar domestic hot water system
Affiliations: Solar Energy Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Beer Sheva, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Wolf, D., Solar Energy Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Beer Sheva, Israel; Sembira, A.N., Solar Energy Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Beer Sheva, Israel; Kudish, A.I., Solar Energy Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Beer Sheva, Israel
Abstract: A computer simulation program for a central solar domestic heat water (DHW) system has been developed and validated by comparing it with the actual performance data obtained from a real-life system. A computer simulation language, CSMP, was used for the simultaneous solution of the differential equations describing the system. The program was developed from basic principles and defined parameters. It was utilized to study the dynamic behavior of the system and to perform parametric studies to determine the effects of various system parameters on its performance. Parametric sensitivity studies were carried out to determine the response of the central solar DHW system performance to the following parameters: flow rate of heat-exchange fluid in the solar collector loop, consumption rate in the consumer loop, start-up time (i.e., activation of the collector loop circulation pump), and storage tank capacity. The concept of consumption management is analyzed and discussed in order to emphasize the fact that solar loop productivity, both qualitative and quantitative, is not independent of load. As a corollary, we show that it is possible, when the situation allows, to maximize solar loop productivity by controlling the consumer loop consumption schedule. © 1984.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES - Problem Orientation; COMPUTER SIMULATION - Applications; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Sensitivity Analysis; TANKS - Energy Storage; CONTINUOUS SYSTEM MODELING PROGRAM; DOMESTIC HOT WATER; WATER HEATERS

Title: STUDIES ON SALT HYDRATES FOR LATENT HEAT STORAGE: VI. PREHEATING EFFECT ON CRYSTALLIZATION OF SODIUM ACETATE TRIHYDRATE FROM AQUEOUS SOLUTION WITH A SMALL AMOUNT OF DISODIUM HYDROGENPHOSPHATE.
Source title: Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan
Authors with affiliations: Wada, Takahiro; Matsuo, Yoshihiro
Abstract: With particular reference to the use of Na//2HPO//4 as nucleation catalyst for crystallization of CH//3CO//2Na multiplied by (times) 3H//2O, influences of preheating temperature and time were studied on the crystallization of CH//3CO//2Na multiplied by (times) 3H//2O from three kinds of CH//3CO//2Na aqueous solutions, whose concentrations were 58. 0, 60. 3, and 62. 8 wt%. In 60. 3 wt% aqueous solution (CH//3CO//2Na multiplied by (times) 3H//2O), the nucleation catalyst begins to get deactivated by preheating at 81 degree C. The temperature at which the catalyst begins to get deactivated is slightly raised with increasing CH//3CO//2Na concentration of the solution. The results obtained are compared with those previously reported on the use of Na//4P//2O//7 multiplied by (times) 10H//2O as nucleation catalyst, and are discussed on the basis of the crystalline adsorption model.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; SODIUM COMPOUNDS - Crystallization; Salts

Title: Spectral analysis of the effective temperature in passive solar buildings
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, 80523, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kirkpatrick, A.T., Mechanical Engineering Department, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, 80523, United States; Winn, C.B., Mechanical Engineering Department, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, 80523, United States
Abstract: The effective temperature, a linear combination of a building’s enclosure temperature, mean radiant temperature, and the ambient temperature, is a measure of the thermal comfort inside a building. Results from an analytical study of the relationship between the effective temperature, glazing areas, and thermal energy storage in passive solar buildings are presented in this paper. Spectral analysis is used to find the effective temperature response of a mixed-direct and indirect-gain passive solar building to Typical Meteorological Year (TMY) weather data. The response is given by the complex product of the building transfer functions and the weather inputs. Results are presented for the sensitivities of the maximum, minimum, and average daily effective temperature to changes in the direct and indirect gain glazing area and thermal energy storage. © 1984 ASME.
Index Keywords: METEOROLOGY; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; BUILDINGS

Title: CHEMICAL HEAT PUMPS DRIVE TO UPGRADE WASTE HEAT.
Authors with affiliations: Clark, Charles E.
Abstract: Recently, several companies have been investigating chemical heat pumps as a cost-effective means of capturing low-grade waste heat and reusing the heat at increased temperatures. Application areas include industrial processing, air or gas moisture-removal, and energy storage. These chemical heat pumps operate without mechanical compressors or turbines, as in conventional units. In this system, the waste heat is used to drive an exothermic chemical reaction, most often between water and a soluble chemical such as lithium bromide or sulfuric acid. Higher-quality heat is then recovered from the reaction products, which are at higher temperatures - because of the exothermic reaction - than the waste heat introduced to the system. Some design details are given along with cost considerations.
Index Keywords: Chemical plants; Economics; Waste heat utilization; Heat pump systems

Title: Energy Transfer in Inertial Confinement
Affiliations: 83310—La Garde Freinet, France
Authors with affiliations: Linhart, J.G., 83310—La Garde Freinet, France
Abstract: One of the main problems in IC fusion is the efficient transfer of energy from a low energy-density source to the fusion target. Some general concepts of optimum energy-staging are described. The applicability of these concepts is illustrated by a few examples. Particular emphasis is put on the use of several liners in series, which permits both the amplification of the liner-velocity and a spatially symmetric collapse. © 1984, Cambridge University Press. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions; ENERGY TRANSFER; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Dodd D.S., Brancatisano T., Engel L.A.
Title: Chest wall mechanics during exercise in patients with severe chronic air-flow obstruction
Affiliations: Department of Medicine, Westmead Centre, Westmead, NSW 2145, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Dodd, D.S., Department of Medicine, Westmead Centre, Westmead, NSW 2145, Australia; Brancatisano, T., Department of Medicine, Westmead Centre, Westmead, NSW 2145, Australia; Engel, L.A., Department of Medicine, Westmead Centre, Westmead, NSW 2145, Australia
Abstract: We studied the dynamic mechanical properties of the chest wall in 7 patients with severe chronic air-flow obstruction (CAO). Measurements were made during quiet breathing at rest and during exercise on a bicycle ergometer at work rates equivalent to 50 and 100% of their maximal work rate (Ẇmax). The peak inspiratory pleural pressure relative to the chest wall relaxation curve (Pmus) increased from 13.5 ± 1.5 cm H2O at rest to 16.5 ± 2.3 the coincident transdiaphragmatic pressure increased from 9.7 ± 2.1 cm H2O at rest to 16.5 ± 2.3 cm H2O at Ẇmax. Consequently, the coincident gastric pressure relative to its value during relaxation (Pab) was negative at rest (-4.5 ± 1.7 cm H2O) and became even more negative (-6.3 ± 2.3 cm H2O) at Ẇmax. Yet the increase in ventilation with increasing exercise was associated with an increase in the passive outward displacement of the abdomen (ΔVab) relative to the total volume change (♀ab + ΔVrc), such that the ratio ΔVab/(ΔVab + ΔVrc) increased from 0.37 ± 0.08 at rest to 0.52 ± 0.05 at Ẇmax. There was no respiratory paradox. From the analysis of volume-pressure tracings of the chest wall compartments we inferred that expiratory intercostal and abdominal muscles contracted forcefully during expiration on exercise, resulting in a marked increase in pleural pressure and a change in thoraco-abdominal configuration. This represented the storage of elastic and gravitational energy, which was released during inspiration, contributing to inspiratory pleural pressures and the enhanced inspiratory flow. Although recruitment of abdominals as accessory muscles of inspiration facilitated the increase in ventilation while protecting the diaphragm, the other inspiratory muscles generated a high proportion of their maximal pressure, possibly limiting ventilation during exercise.
Index Keywords: bicycle ergometry; chronic obstructive lung disease; computer analysis; diagnosis; exercise; human; human experiment; inspiration; plethysmography; respiratory system; thorax wall; Abdominal Muscles; Aged; Biomechanics; Exertion; Human; Lung Diseases, Obstructive; Lung Volume Measurements; Middle Age; Movement; Pleura; Pressure; Respiration; Ribs; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Thorax

Authors: Otto G., Wolff H., Häcker R.
Title: Adenine nucleotides and glycolysis during liver preservation by simple hypothermic storage
Affiliations: Surgical Department, Charité Hospital, Berlin, Germany; Department of Biochemistry, Research Institute of Physical Culture and Sports, Leipzig, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Otto, G., Surgical Department, Charité Hospital, Berlin, Germany, Department of Biochemistry, Research Institute of Physical Culture and Sports, Leipzig, Germany; Wolff, H., Surgical Department, Charité Hospital, Berlin, Germany, Department of Biochemistry, Research Institute of Physical Culture and Sports, Leipzig, Germany; Häcker, R., Surgical Department, Charité Hospital, Berlin, Germany, Department of Biochemistry, Research Institute of Physical Culture and Sports, Leipzig, Germany
Abstract: Adenine nucleotides and glycolytic metabolites were examined during hypothermic storage of porcine livers by different preservation methods. The parameters ATP, ADP, AMP, G6P, F6P, FDP, GAP, 2PG, PEP, Pyr and Lact were investigated. The results indicate a dependence of adenine nucleotides but no dependence of glycolytic metabolites on preservation method. Storage by plasma protein fraction or Collins C2 solution causes a better result in TAN concentration after 6 h than albumin and Ringer storage or Ringer trickle perfusion. Conditioning the organ for a better outcome of preservation aimed at increasing the glycolytic rate is of questionable value. © 1984 S. Karger AG, Basel.

Title: The infant's ability to self-regulate caloric intake: A case study
Source title: Journal of the American Dietetic Association
Affiliations: Department of Anthropology, Rice University, Houston, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Adair, L.S., Department of Anthropology, Rice University, Houston, TX, United States
Abstract: A case study which illustrates the infant's ability to regulate caloric intake through adjustments in formula intake is presented. A daily record of infant formula and supplemental food intake of a normal, bottle-fed male infant was kept from 1 week to 9 months after birth. The infant's physical growth was assessed at regular intervals. Measurements included weight, recumbent length, head circumference, and skinfold thicknesses. Feeding was ad libitum, and caregivers were highly responsive to the infant's satiety behaviors. Under these conditions, the infant adjusted his caloric intake as supplemental foods were added to his diet by progressively decreasing the volume of formula consumed. His growth was well canalized and tracked very close to the 50th centile of NCHS weight and length standards. The regularity of his growth attests to the adequacy of his intake for meeting energy needs without excess energy storage. This suggests that to avoid overfeeding the bottle-fed infant, caregivers should attempt to facilitate the infant's self-regulation of intake.
Index Keywords: autoregulation; body height; caloric intake; child; diagnosis; food intake; human; human experiment; infant; skinfold; subcutaneous tissue; weight; Case Report; Energy Intake; Energy Metabolism; Feeding Behavior; Human; Infant; Infant Nutrition; Infant, Newborn; Male

Title: Meal to meal energy balance in rats
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Neurophysiologie Sensorielle, Comportementale Collège de France, 11, Place Marcelin-Berthelot, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France
Authors with affiliations: Le Magnen, J., Laboratoire de Neurophysiologie Sensorielle, Comportementale Collège de France, 11, Place Marcelin-Berthelot, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France; Devos, M., Laboratoire de Neurophysiologie Sensorielle, Comportementale Collège de France, 11, Place Marcelin-Berthelot, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France
Abstract: Meal to meal energy balance was examined in thirty-eight simultaneous recordings of feeding pattern and O2 consumption in six rats. The mean difference between energy intake in a meal and energy expenditure until the onset of the next meal was found positive at night and negative during day time. At night the excess of meal intake over meal to meal expenditures was decreasing from the beginning to the end of the night and was strongly correlated to meal sizes. During day time meal to meal deficit was decreasing from the beginning to the end of the period but was not correlated to meal sizes. These meal location and size effects on the meal to meal energy balance were not determined by an effect of these factors on metabolic rate. No indication was provided that meal to meal energy balance was influenced by a "meal induced thermogenesis." Rather an evolution from the beginning to the end of the night of the correlation between meal size and durations of meal to meal intervals was found to be parallel to the evolution of positive meal to meal energy balance throughout the night. From these data it is concluded that at night a dual utilization of meal caloric intake (current energy metabolism plus fat storage) and a dual source of fuel during the day (food plus mobilized fats) determine time and mechanism of meal onset. © 1984.
Author Keywords: Dark/light cycle; Feeding behavior; Meal onset; Meal to meal balance
Index Keywords: animal experiment; central nervous system; energy transfer; food intake; light dark cycle; meal; nonhuman; rat; Animal; Eating; Energy Intake; Energy Metabolism; Male; Oxygen Consumption; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Time Factors

Title: Evaluation of kidney viability during hypothermic perfusion or cold storage
Affiliations: Surgical Metabolic Research Laboratory, Departments of Urology and Surgery, Sahlgrenska Sjukhuset, Sweden; Department of Surgery, Östra Sjukhuset, Göteborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Nauclér, J., Surgical Metabolic Research Laboratory, Departments of Urology and Surgery, Sahlgrenska Sjukhuset, Sweden, Department of Surgery, Östra Sjukhuset, Göteborg, Sweden; Bylund-Fellenius, A.C., Surgical Metabolic Research Laboratory, Departments of Urology and Surgery, Sahlgrenska Sjukhuset, Sweden, Department of Surgery, Östra Sjukhuset, Göteborg, Sweden; Jonsson, O., Surgical Metabolic Research Laboratory, Departments of Urology and Surgery, Sahlgrenska Sjukhuset, Sweden, Department of Surgery, Östra Sjukhuset, Göteborg, Sweden; Kleist, H., Surgical Metabolic Research Laboratory, Departments of Urology and Surgery, Sahlgrenska Sjukhuset, Sweden, Department of Surgery, Östra Sjukhuset, Göteborg, Sweden; Lundstam, S., Surgical Metabolic Research Laboratory, Departments of Urology and Surgery, Sahlgrenska Sjukhuset, Sweden, Department of Surgery, Östra Sjukhuset, Göteborg, Sweden; Pettersson, S., Surgical Metabolic Research Laboratory, Departments of Urology and Surgery, Sahlgrenska Sjukhuset, Sweden, Department of Surgery, Östra Sjukhuset, Göteborg, Sweden; Scherstén, T., Surgical Metabolic Research Laboratory, Departments of Urology and Surgery, Sahlgrenska Sjukhuset, Sweden, Department of Surgery, Östra Sjukhuset, Göteborg, Sweden
Abstract: The effect of up to 6 days of hypothermic perfusion and up to 72 h of cold storage on tissue viability were studied from measurements of sodium potassium pump activity and adenosine nucleotide content. For the hypothermic perfusion two different albumin-based perfusates were used, one with, the other without addition of caprylic acid and amino acids. No difference could be found in the parameters studied between perfusion with these two perfusates. For both perfusates total adenine nucleotide content (TAN) decreased by approximately 60% during perfusion while energy charge potential (ECP) and the ATP/ADP ratio remained constant. During cold storage a decrease of both TAN and ECP and the ratio ATP/ADP was seen, the main decrease occurring within the 1st h. The transmembrane potassium influx as deduced from potassium content in incubated cortical slices during steady state conditions decreasedduring 6d ays of hypothermic storage to 24.5 ± 2.4 μmol/kg which was a significantly higher level than after 24 h of cold storage. Thus, addition of extra substrate to the perfusate does not seem to improve kidney cortex viability during hypothermic perfusion. Parenchymal viability is belter preserved with continuous hypothermic perfusion, compared to simple cold storage in a solution of the same ionic composition as that used for perfusion. © 1984 S. Karger AG, Basel.
Author Keywords: Adenine nucleotides; Cold storage; Dog kidney; Hypothermic perfusion; Kidney viability

Title: Assessing the impact of peak-load electricity pricing and the solar tax credits on the adoption of solar energy.
Authors with affiliations: Procter, R.J.; Tyner, W.E.
Abstract: Examines the impacts of some new energy legislation on the development of residential solar energy. Indicates that, with storage of off-peak electric energy, the heating cost was so low that even highly subsidized solar energy could not compete.-from Authors

Title: Isabelle shielding criteria and design
Affiliations: Safety and Environmental Protection Division, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Building 535A, Upton, NY, 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gollon, P.J., Safety and Environmental Protection Division, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Building 535A, Upton, NY, 11973, United States; Casey, W.R., Safety and Environmental Protection Division, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Building 535A, Upton, NY, 11973, United States
Abstract: ISABELLE is a high-intensity 400-GeV proton-storage ring under construction at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL). The radiation-protection problems encountered in its design are in many ways similar to those at high-energy fixed-target facilities: Both the laboratory personnel nearby and the, public several kilometers away must be appropriately protected from high-energy neutron and muon radiation. These radiations will result from the routine operation of the accelerators, as well as from unplanned and possibly large losses of the stored beam. The radiation exposures resulting from the loss of beam already in the accelerator could be more severe than those resulting from a full year's normal operation. The design goals (mrem/yr) which have been adopted for different populations, exposure scenarios and radiation sources are outlined. We also describe the methods (hardware, shielding, access control) which will be used to achieve these goals. . © 1984 Health Physics Society Pergamon Press Ltd.
Index Keywords: radioisotope; human; methodology; prevention; proton accelerator; radiation protection; radiation shield; Facility Design and Construction; New York; Particle Accelerators; Protons; Radiation Dosage; Radiation Protection; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.

Authors with affiliations: Golay, A., Division of Endocrinology and Clinical Biochemistry, Department of Medicine, CHUV, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Diabetic Unit, La Source, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Institute of Physiology, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Felber, J.P., Division of Endocrinology and Clinical Biochemistry, Department of Medicine, CHUV, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Diabetic Unit, La Source, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Institute of Physiology, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Meyer, H.U., Division of Endocrinology and Clinical Biochemistry, Department of Medicine, CHUV, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Diabetic Unit, La Source, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Institute of Physiology, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Curchod, B., Division of Endocrinology and Clinical Biochemistry, Department of Medicine, CHUV, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Diabetic Unit, La Source, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Institute of Physiology, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Maeder, E., Division of Endocrinology and Clinical Biochemistry, Department of Medicine, CHUV, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Diabetic Unit, La Source, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Institute of Physiology, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Jéquier, E., Division of Endocrinology and Clinical Biochemistry, Department of Medicine, CHUV, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Diabetic Unit, La Source, Lausanne, Switzerland, the Institute of Physiology, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: Knowing the relationship between obesity and diabetes, the purpose of our work was to study the alterations in lipid metabolism as measured by continuous indirect calorimetry in the course of a 100-g oral glucose-tolerance test in groups of obese patients without and with diabetes, respectively. Seventy-nine obese patients participated in the study. They were divided into four groups according to the degree of carbohydrate intolerance: group A, normal glucose tolerance; group B, impaired glucose tolerance; group C, diabetes with hyperinsulinemic response to the load; group D, diabetes with impaired insulin response. All four groups of patients presented an increase in lipid oxidation, both in the fasting state and during the three-hour glucose tolerance test, when compared to the control group. The lipid oxidation rate was roughly parallel to plasma free fatty acid (FFA) levels. The contribution of lipids to energy expenditure was higher in obese as compared to control subjects. These observations suggest that the larger part taken by lipids in the energy metabolism of both nondiabetic and diabetic obese humans is a consequence of their increased fat stores and that the resulting decrease in carbohydrate metabolism may lead, as a late consequence, to alterations in glucose tolerance. The latter may result in delayed glucose storage and oxidation in the obese patient. © 1984.
Index Keywords: fatty acid; clinical article; diabetes mellitus; endocrine system; etiology; glucose tolerance test; human; lipid metabolism; obesity; therapy; Adult; Age Factors; Calorimetry; Diabetes Mellitus; Energy Metabolism; Female; Glucose Tolerance Test; Humans; Lipid Metabolism; Male; Middle Aged; Obesity; Oxidation-Reduction

Title: A multidetector alpha spectroscopy analysis system
Affiliations: Inhalation Toxicology Research Institute, Lovelace Biomedical and Environmental Research Institute, P.O. Box 5890, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States
Authors with affiliations: Guilmette, R.A., Inhalation Toxicology Research Institute, Lovelace Biomedical and Environmental Research Institute, P.O. Box 5890, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States; Archibeque, F.A., Inhalation Toxicology Research Institute, Lovelace Biomedical and Environmental Research Institute, P.O. Box 5890, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States
Abstract: This document describes the attributes of an alpha spectroscopy counting and analysis system called Low Level Pulse Height Analysis (LLPHA). It was developed for multi-sample alpha spectroscopy analysis. The LLPHA system is controlled by a MIK-11/2 microcomputer with 28K of memory and uses a double-density, dual floppy disk for data storage. Detectors are interfaced to the computer via CAMAC (Computer Automated Measurement and Control) equipment. The system simultaneously supports 32 active and independent surface-barrier alpha-particle detectors. It operates with the total collection rate of up to 300 counts/sec from all active detectors, using 128 channels per spectrum and a dynamic energy range of 1.4 MeV. The system is not limited, however, to these conditions. In addition to spectral acquisition, the system provides analysis functions which include peak identification, curve-smoothing, integration, linear and logarithmic scale graphics, and corrections for base-line shift, dead-time, and background counts. These functions can be implemented while other spectra are being collected. The LLPHA system represents a highly cost-effective means of acquiring alpha spectrometric data from a large number of samples simultaneously and with rapid data analysis capability. © 1984 Health Physics Society Pergamon Press Ltd.
Index Keywords: radioisotope; alpha radiation; alpha radiation emitter; methodology; nonhuman; spectroscopy; Alpha Particles; Microcomputers; Spectrum Analysis; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.

Title: Ultrastructural pathology of intrapulmonary arteries in 3‐methylindole‐induced pneumotoxicity in cattle: II. Glycogen accumulation in the smooth muscle cells and intimal changes
Affiliations: Anatomical Laboratories, Department of Biomedical Sciences, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario, N1G 2W1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Atwal, R.O.S., Anatomical Laboratories, Department of Biomedical Sciences, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario, N1G 2W1, Canada; Persofsky, M.S., Anatomical Laboratories, Department of Biomedical Sciences, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario, N1G 2W1, Canada
Abstract: 3‐Methylindole (3MI) was orally administered as a single dose of 0·1–0·2 g/kg which then produced acute pulmonary oedema in cattle 72 h post‐treatment. Electron microscopic examination of intrapulmonary arteries ranging between 35–120 μm in the control animals, revealed microsequestration of rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) and the storage of proteinaceous material in the dilated cisternae of RER of the endothelial cells. Lung tissue samples collected after 72 h of 3MI administration, showed denudation and hyperplasia of the endothelial cells. Massive storage of glycogen particles and the lamellar bodies in association with glycogen, were observed in the smooth muscle cells of the media. The importance of glycogen accumulation in vascular smooth muscle cells of the pulmonary arteries is discussed in terms of energy utilization and vascular energetics to meet the metabolic requirement of haemodynamic stress arising from alveolar hypoxia and possible vasoconstriction. Furthermore, the suggestion is made, that the alterations may signify the early changes of pulmonary hypertension induced by the toxic effect of 3MI in cattle. Copyright © 1984 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: 3‐Methylindole; pulmonary hypertension; pulmonary oedema; ultrastructure

Title: A parametric study of open loop solar heating systems-I
Affiliations: Solar Energy Unit, University College, Cardiff, WalesUK, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kenna, J.P., Solar Energy Unit, University College, Cardiff, WalesUK, United Kingdom
Abstract: The performance of open loop solar heating systems is studied using a single non-dimensional equation. For any location the long term solar fraction depends primarily on three non-dimensional groups M, K and R. M is the ratio of energy available on the collector aperture to energy demand and is hence a collector sizing parameter. K is the ratio of a reference rate of collector heat loss to a reference rate of energy available and is a collector performance parameter. R is the number of days storage available. A correlation relating the solar fraction, E, to M, K and R is given and the range of validity of this correlation is examined. For open loop systems with short term storage, the correlation can be used as a design method for a large range of demand temperatures, demand patterns, collector types and orientations. Comparisons are made between the solar fraction calculated by an hour by hour computer model and that predicted by the design method. Agreement is good. Further comparisons are made between measured and predicted performance figures for a large 20 m2 domestic hot water system. It is concluded that the correlation can be used as a reliable design method and will allow simple selection of optimum system designs. © 1984.
Index Keywords: SOLAR RADIATION - Mathematical Models; OPEN LOOP SOLAR HEATING SYSTEMS; HEATING

Authors: Feilchenfeld H., Fuchs J., Sarig S.
Title: A calorimetric investigation of the stability of stagnant calcium chloride hexahydrate melt
Affiliations: The Casali Institute of Applied Chemistry, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel

Abstract: An improved method for measuring the enthalpy of melting of salt hydrates in large nonstirred samples is presented. Results for calcium chloride hexahydrate are around 200 J/g. The decline of this value with consecutive cycles of cooling and heating is due to stratification followed by degradation to the tetrahydrate. The application to heat storage is discussed. A procedure for an accelerated stability test is proposed. © 1984.

Title: Experimental simulation of solar drying of garlic using an adsorbent energy storage bed
Affiliations: Instituto de Agroquímica y Tecnología de Alimentos, Jaime Roig, 11. Valencia-10, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Piñaga, F., Instituto de Agroquímica y Tecnología de Alimentos, Jaime Roig, 11. Abstract: Solar drying of garlic with energy storage in silica gel is experimentally simulated in a closed system in which the air is continuously circulated between food and adsorbent. Kinetics of the drying process are studied and equilibrium data are predicted by a mathematical model developed from the experimental results. By comparing the end points of drying with equilibrium values the length of the drying process can be established. From sorption data, a garlic surface area of 63-188 m2 g-1 and a heat of adsorption in the first layer of 2548-2691 kJ kg-1 have been calculated. A value of 746 kJ kg-1 has been deduced for the activation energy for water removal. © 1984.

Title: ANALYSIS OF TRANSIENT HEAT TRANSFER IN LATENT HEAT STORAGE EQUIPMENT FOR SOLAR ENERGY.
Source title: Denshi Gijutsu Sogo Kenkyusho Iho/Bulletin of the Electrotechnical Laboratory
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, Tadayoshi; Tani, Tatsuo
Abstract: The feasibility of heat storage equipment using the latent heat capacity of materials for storing intermittent incident heat energy, such as solar energy, and delivering the stored heat at constant temperature is studied. It is difficult to solve analytically this type of heat transfer between a fluid and a material in the latent heat storage equipment, because the boundary condition between the fluid and the material is determined by the heat exchange between them while the temperature of the storage material remains constant. Accordingly, by a numerical solution method the heat transfer phenomena between the fluid and the material in a heat storage device of a shell-tube type using a latent heat material are analyzed and its thermal characteristics are clarified. As a main result it is shown that the Biot Number is an important factor in order to deliver the heat at constant temperature.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Heat Storage; SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; BIOT NUMBER; INTERMITTENT INCIDENT HEAT ENERGY; LATENT HEAT CAPACITY; TRANSIENT HEAT TRANSFER; Heat transfer

Title: Conservation and fixation of solar energy in Pinus patula plantations of Darjeeling Himalaya
Affiliations: Centre of Advanced Study in Botany, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, 221005, India
Authors with affiliations: Singh, B., Centre of Advanced Study in Botany, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, 221005, India
Abstract: Evaluation of six experimental plantations of Pinus patula in Darjeeling, ranging from 8-34 years in age, showed the maximum storage of energy of 7·2 TJ ha-1 in the aerial biomass of a 34-year-old stand, with 84% in the long straight bole followed by branch, needle and cone components in decreasing order. The net annual energy fixation for the plantations varied from 33·1-58·2 GJ ha-1. 16·50% of this value was lost as litter fall with an increasing trend in older stands. Production efficiency of these plantations is 0.13-2.29% of the visible spectrum of light which depicts their high potential for energy yields in the Darjeeling environment. The forest floor also accumulated a significant proportion of the energy capital in a thick raw humus and surface litter. The magnitude increases with the maturity of stands which indicates the very slow dissipation from the forest floor. © 1984.
Author Keywords: biomass; calorific value; energy conservation; energy fixation; Himalaya; litter; Pinus patula; production efficiency; stand

Abstract: In developing countries and remote areas where an electric supply is not available, a thermo-electric refrigerator is often needed for food and medical drugs storage. Such a refrigerator, which requires a direct current supply is suitable for matching with a photo-voltaic collector (PV). A normal automobile 12-volt lead-acid battery may be used as the storage system. Abstract: A comparative techno-economic evaluation of the methods of hydrogen storage in an automobile as to the overall energy consumption is presented. The effect is demonstrated of the storage vessel mass and the primary energy expenditures on the specific energy consumption of the automobile at its given fuel distance endurance. It is shown that, at present, the most expedient systems for automobiles of all types are metal hydride systems. Some aspects of thermal exchange and mass transfer in metal hydride are discussed, which allows an evaluation of the dynamic performance of storage vessels. Test results of prototype automobiles confirm that the use of metal hydride storage vessels is promising, especially if the engine operates on mixed fuel (gasoline and hydrogen). © 1984.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOTIVE FUELS; HYDROGEN

Abstract: A simulation study on the possibility of the utilization of cyclohexane as a vector for hydrogen storage in transport vehicles equipped with hydrogen engine has been carried out. The results of this study for the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst indicate that a dehydrogenation multi-tube reactor for cyclohexane is feasible. Nevertheless, a good heat transfer, which is a limiting factor of the process, has to be assured. To heat this reactor, part of the hydrogen combustion energy normally wasted by the engine cooling system can be used. A system of heat pipes was proposed to transfer the waste heat from the wall of engine cylinders to the wall of the dehydrogenation reactor. © 1984.

Title: PRESSURIZED 40-kV, 300-KA THREE-ELECTRODE DISCHARGER.
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Authors with affiliations: Zemskov, A.I.; Mokeev, A.N.; Prut, V.V.
Abstract: A controllable pressurized three-electrode discharger is described which is designed for current switching of a capacitor storage device with a working voltage of 40 kv, an energy capacity of 20 kJ, and a current amplitude in the first half-cycle of 320 kA. The discharger has an inductance of 25 nH and an operating life of about 10**4 actuations. With an electric-strength margin of 1. 8, the actuation delay is minus 15 nsec and the actuation-time spread is plus or minus 3 nsec.

Abstract: A commercial scale experiment (472 tonnes total) was performed to compare the storability of Winter Green cabbages in an Atmolysair System Controlled Atmosphere (ASCA) room with those stored in a conventional cold room. In the ASCA room, the cabbages were stored for 32 weeks at a temperature of 1.3°C and in an atmosphere consisting of 5-6% carbon dioxide, 2-3% oxygen, 92% nitrogen and traces of other gases; whereas in the control regular atmosphere (RA) room, the period of storage was the same but the temperature was 0.3°C. The average trimming losses were less than 10% for the ASCA room and greater than 30% for the RA room. The cabbages stored in the ASCA room showed better retention of their green colour, flavour and texture than those stored in the RA room. The energy consumption in the ASCA room was about 30% less than that in the RA room. © 1984.
Author Keywords: cabbage; cold rooms; controlled atmosphere; storage
